site_title: US Senate edges towards vote on Trump’s divisive spending bill
summary: US Senate is nearing a vote on Donald Trump's spending bill, which would add over $3 trillion to the country's debt and strip health care from millions of the poorest Americans. The bill, dubbed the "One Big Beautiful Bill," aims to extend Trump's expiring tax cuts and boost border security. However, Republicans are divided over the package, with some opposing the Medicaid cuts that would threaten rural hospitals and lead to 8.6 million Americans losing health care. The bill faces opposition from Democrats and is unpopular across multiple demographic groups, raising concerns about its passage.

site_title: Orchid Country Club, Science Park sites among plots rezoned for housing
summary: Singapore's Draft Master Plan 2025 (DMP2025) rezones several sites for housing, including Orchid Country Club, Warren Golf & Country Club, and Marina Bay Golf Course. The plan aims to meet demand and optimize land use, with a focus on regional hubs and industrial estates. More than 10,000 private and public homes could be built at Orchid Country Club, while the Marina Bay Golf Course site could yield an iconic public housing precinct. Rezoning underutilized business parks to residential use is also expected to enhance demand and reduce risk.

site_title: Star Entertainment’s Hong Kong backers threaten to soon exit Brisbane casino deal
summary: Star Entertainment's Hong Kong backers, Chow Tai Fook Enterprises and Far East Consortium, have threatened to withdraw from the Brisbane casino deal, which could be terminated in five business days. This comes after Star Entertainment's shareholders approved a $300 million rescue package to keep the casino group operational. The Hong Kong firms own 25% of the Brisbane development and are demanding repayment of $10 million or forfeiting their remaining stake in the Gold Coast casino. The deal's termination would be a major setback for Star Entertainment, which has invested heavily in the project.

site_title: G7 agrees to exempt US multinationals from global minimum tax
summary: The G7 nations have agreed to exempt US multinational companies from a global minimum tax, a deal reached in part due to changes in the US international tax system included in President Trump's domestic policy bill. The "side-by-side" system will tax US companies only at home, on both domestic and foreign profits, providing greater stability and certainty in the international tax system. The agreement, negotiated under the OECD, includes a 15% global minimum tax rate, which the US companies will not be subject to.

site_title: Bangkok building collapse tied to construction and design flaws, Thailand’s PM says
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra has attributed the collapse of a partially built 30-storey building in Bangkok to design and construction flaws. An investigation found that the elevator and stairwell walls were improperly designed and built, failing to absorb shear force. The building, intended to house Thailand's State Audit Office, collapsed during a 7.7-magnitude earthquake in Myanmar, killing at least 89 people. Police have filed charges against a prominent construction tycoon and others for negligence, with a fact-finding committee to submit its report for further action.

site_title: Renewable energy source important factor in location of IBM data centres
summary: IBM, a leading tech giant, is seeking locations for data centers that can source 90% of their electricity from renewable sources by 2030. The company's chief sustainability officer, Christina Shim, notes that South-east Asian markets with renewable energy sources may have an advantage in attracting IBM's data center investments. However, data center management efficiency and overall sustainability efforts are also crucial factors in the decision-making process. IBM aims to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and is exploring opportunities to integrate sustainability and artificial intelligence in its business operations.

site_title: Asian banks fuel more than US$2 billion loan boom in Middle East
summary: Asian banks have fueled a loan boom in the Middle East, with over $2 billion in deals launched in recent weeks. The growth is driven by Middle East borrowers, primarily from Gulf States, seeking to diversify funding beyond domestic markets and regional economies' expensive diversification plans. Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Kuwait, and the UAE are among countries with agendas requiring heavy investment to shift away from traditional energy sources, leading to fiscal deficits and borrowing needs. Asian banks are taking advantage of the demand to tap into Middle Eastern borrowing, offering higher returns and better credit ratings.

site_title: UOB unveils world’s tallest, brightest and longest projection canvas
summary: UOB unveiled a nightly light show on its 280m-tall facade, claiming three Guinness World Records titles: world's tallest, brightest, and longest projection canvas. The six-minute show, called "Unity," runs nightly until National Day on Aug 9, featuring UOB's past and future, as well as SG60-themed visuals. The light show was created by multimedia integrator Hexogon Solution and celebrates the bank's spirit of innovation and change.

summary: Japan's factory output rose 0.5% in May, slower than expected, amid a US tariffs threat. Manufacturers surveyed by the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry expect a 0.3% rise in June and a 0.7% fall in July. Tokyo is seeking to exempt its automakers from 25% US tariffs, which could impact the country's manufacturing sector and economy, now in its fourth year of a lacklustre recovery.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market showed stability with modest drops in freight levels this week. The LPG market experienced a slight decline, with rates dropping by $6.25 to $80.583 per metric ton. The Capesize market saw a significant decline, with sentiment weakening amid low activity and the prolonged absence of major C5 miners. The Panamax market remained positive, with wide-ranging views on market value. The Asian basin saw decent volume, while the US Gulf market showed signs of weakening support. The MR market saw significant gains, with USG MRs stealing the show, and the US Atlantic Triangulation Basket TCE rising by $6,743.

site_title: StashAway’s Singapore operations turn Ebitda positive in FY2024
summary: StashAway's Singapore operations turned earnings before tax, interest, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) positive in FY2024, driven by a 36% revenue growth to S$14.8 million, with the main market being the key driver. Existing customers contributed to the growth, with marketing expenses only increasing slightly. The company's tech-first approach and discipline in managing costs enabled the Ebitda positive result, with S$1.4 million in profit in 2024. StashAway aims to remain nimble and is open to inorganic growth, including acquisitions, to reach profitability.

site_title: Best performing S-Reits post double-digit total returns in H1
summary: The Singapore Reit sector delivered stable performance in the first half of 2025, with the iEdge S-Reit index gaining 0.6% to 1,010.73. Over half of the 30 constituents on the index delivered positive total returns, with top performers delivering double-digit gains. The top five outperformers were Frasers Hospitality Trust, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, First Reit, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, and Parkway Life Reit. The sector trades at compelling valuations and has seen increased investor interest, with retail investors net buyers and institutional investors net sellers.

site_title: Americans cash out on gold coins as Asian investors bulk up
summary: US retail investors are cashing out on gold coins amid a glut in the market, with some dealers offering discounts to spur sales. In contrast, Asian investors, particularly in China and South-east Asia, continue to buy gold bars and coins, driven by concerns over local currency depreciation and geopolitical tensions. This divergence in investor sentiment suggests US residents are more optimistic about the US economy, while Asian investors view gold as a strategic asset for diversification.

images.alt_text: Robert Brigandi, Vice President of Brigandi Coin Co., holds American Eagle Gold Bullion Coins at Brigandi Coin Co. in New York on Monday December 27, 2004. The coins, shown here in 1 oz., 1/2 oz., 1/4 oz., and 1/10 oz. sizes, are some of the world's leading gold bullion investment coins.  A fund created last month to invest in gold bullion has attracted $1.29 billion from investors, making it the most successful start for an exchange-traded fund since the securities were created in 1993.  BLOOMBERG
Set up as a public-private partnership, Lao Bullion Bank currently operates out of a five-storey building in the capital, Vientiane.

site_title: Tech firms warn 'Scattered Spider' hacks are targeting aviation sector
summary: Tech firms Google and Palo Alto Networks have warned of the "Scattered Spider" hacking group's interest in the aviation sector. The group, blamed for disruptive hacks in the US and Europe, has targeted companies such as Hawaiian Airlines and WestJet, although specific details remain unknown. The hacking group, comprising youngsters operating in Western countries, has previously disrupted casinos, gaming companies, and the US insurance industry. The companies' statements come as the group's activities raise concerns about potential threats to the aviation sector.

images.alt_text: code, programming, hacking
Binance uses artificial-intelligence bots to spot offers of potential bribes in different languages.

site_title: Nvidia insiders sell over US$1 billion in stock amid market surge
summary: Nvidia insiders sold over $1 billion in company stock in the past year, with a notable increase in recent trading activity amid surging investor interest in artificial intelligence. The company's stock price reached an all-time high, making Nvidia the world's most valuable company. CEO Jensen Huang started selling shares for the first time since September, and the stock has rebounded over 60% from its closing low on April 4. This surge reflects optimism about the emerging technology, with analysts predicting a "Golden Wave" of AI growth.

images.alt_text: Google’s addition of OpenAI to its customer list shows how the tech giant has capitalised on its in-house AI technology.
All three major US stock indices post weekly gains.

site_title: Nikkei 225 expected to trend higher if trade deals are inked
summary: The Nikkei 225 Index is expected to trend higher if trade deals are inked, driven by a structural bull case for Japan equities. The index is trading at a 30% discount to the S&P 500 and below its five-year average multiple, making relative valuation attractive. A 90-day pause in US tariffs and lowered Chinese tariffs have supported Japanese equities, while higher Japanese Government Bond yields pose a threat. However, a narrower-than-expected Q1 real GDP contraction and the Bank of Japan's decision to leave policy rates unchanged suggest near-term support for equities.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board showing the Nikkei 225 index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 9, 2025. Japan's main Nikkei index of shares fell in early trade on April 9 after Wall Street stocks turned lower on worries about US tariffs and a trade war with China. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Why gold is glimmering again in an uncertain world
summary: Gold is experiencing a resurgence as investors seek safe-haven assets amid economic uncertainty. The World Gold Council, StashAway, and State Street Global Advisors discuss gold's comeback, its role in diversifying portfolios, and how to time investments. Central banks are also stockpiling gold, and the price has increased but timing is not as crucial as allocation. The episode offers a calm and clear-headed look at gold's role in modern portfolios, emphasizing its stabilizing effect rather than its potential as a quick-hit investment.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
What asset classes are or aren’t appropriate for long-term investing?
(From left) Hassan Ahmed, Deborah Tan-Pink and Howie Lim.

site_title: Hit the gas – stocks’ dashboard is working again
summary: The yield curve, a key economic indicator, has silently steepened, signaling economic growth and bullish conditions. Despite being inverted for over a year, the curve has flipped positive, inspiring banks to lend and boosting profits. This has led to a surge in stocks, particularly value stocks in Europe and Asia, while growth stocks in the US lag. As investors tune out the beeping of the yield curve, its growing bullish power remains unpriced, expected to drive lasting European leadership and boost developed Asia.

images.alt_text: Real estate investment trusts, particularly those focused on Singapore, stand to gain from lowered interest rates and borrowing costs.

site_title: Singapore’s snares its largest Reit IPO in a decade while HK looks to another bumper year driven by China companies
summary: Singapore's stock exchange, SGX, has seen a surge in listings, with the largest Reit IPO in a decade, while Hong Kong's Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKEX) is expected to have another bumper year with 40 IPOs projected in the first half of 2025. HKEX's new CEO Bonnie Chan aims to boost its global profile by attracting secondary listings from South-east Asia and China companies seeking to raise funds outside the mainland. Singapore's stable political environment and transparent legal system make it an attractive option for companies, with SGX offering a faster time to market and access to capital in both US and Singapore dollars.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
The STI is up 4.7 per cent since the beginning of the year, and 16.9 per cent above its Apr 9 low
Hong Kong Stock Exchange, under new CEO Bonnie Chan, aims to boost its global profile by attracting secondary listings from Southeast Asia.
NTT is spinning off its assets into a data centre Reit that will potentially be listed on SGX.
HKEX has been striving to attract IPO hopefuls from elsewhere as part of its ambition to become a global capital raising platform.

People pass an electronic sign showing the price of the Hang Seng Index at Exchange Square in Hong Kong on April 10, 2025. Asian stocks rocketed on April 10 as investors breathed a huge sigh of relief after Donald Trump announced a pause on crippling tariffs on US partners, with Chinese markets even brushing off his decision to ramp up duties on Beijing to 125 percent. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)

site_title: Standard Chartered brings families, community together for National Family Festival
summary: Standard Chartered, a global bank, brought together over 500 employees and their families for the National Family Festival 2025, a month-long event aimed at promoting family bonding and community engagement. The festival featured various activities, including sports, workshops, and marketplace booths. Employees volunteered in various roles, including running financial literacy workshops and guiding visitors, with many participating with their own families. The event marked Standard Chartered's Global Employee Volunteering Month, which encourages employees to use their volunteering leave for causes they care about.

images.alt_text: Guided by StanChart and Prudential volunteers, the children were given a limited budget to shop for groceries.
A StanChart volunteer guiding a senior in using during the fraud awareness event in January.

site_title: Wall Street’s booming June is big bet against economy doomsayers
summary: Wall Street experienced a strong June, with the S&P 500 surging 3.4% and closing at a record high. Despite concerns over a global trade war, cooling inflation, and a potential recession, investor optimism has driven a buying frenzy in various assets, including tech funds, junk bonds, and commodities. Experts warn of complacency, citing risks such as trade negotiations, macroeconomic slowdowns, and rising interest rates. However, many bulls remain bullish, with some predicting the best monthly performance in 13 months.

images.alt_text: All three major US stock indices post weekly gains.

site_title: Citigroup sees bigger IPOs as private deals bulk up valuations
summary: A wave of big initial public offerings (IPOs) is building as emerging growth companies stay private for longer, bulk up their valuations, and attract institutional investors eager to invest in late-stage companies. Private placements have surged to $60 billion, up from $50 billion last year, with companies like SpaceX and OpenAI using private sales to provide liquidity to investors. Citigroup's head of growth equity, Cully Davis, believes that companies will eventually see the benefit of going public, citing a flurry of zero-coupon convertible bonds being sold by publicly traded tech companies as a positive sign.

images.alt_text: ASIC’s new measures come just days after Virgin Australia launched a closely watched A$685 million IPO that attracted strong investor demand.

site_title: Billionaire Michael Dell reaps US$1.2 billion from stock sale
summary: Michael Dell, the 60-year-old CEO of Dell Technologies, sold US$1.2 billion worth of shares, reducing his stake by about 3%, according to a recent filing. The sale follows a similar pattern to his September sale, which generated over US$2.3 billion. Despite this, Dell still owns nearly US$39 billion in Dell Technologies stock, a third of his total fortune. The company's stock has risen over 9% since May, driven by a surge in AI server business revenue.

site_title: CATL breaks ground on US$6 billion Indonesia battery venture
summary: CATL, the world's top electric-vehicle battery maker, broke ground on a $6 billion battery material ecosystem in Indonesia, with an estimated 15 GW battery capacity. The joint venture with Indonesia Battery Corp and Aneka Tambang will produce batteries for 250,000 to 300,000 cars and battery storage for solar panels. The project aims to support Indonesia's goal of moving up the global metals supply chain and achieving energy self-sufficiency. The venture is part of President Prabowo Subianto's plan to accelerate the development of smelters, battery factories, and electric vehicle factories in the country.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A screen shows the logo of the Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL) during the listing ceremony at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, May 20, 2025. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

Smoke billows from an explosion in southwest Tehran on June 16, 2025. Iran's state broadcaster was briefly knocked off the air by an Israeli strike and explosions rang out across Tehran on June 16, after a barrage of Iranian missiles killed 11 people in Israel on the fourth day of an escalating air war. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP)

site_title: Big banks pass Fed’s stress test, setting stage for payouts
summary: US banks, including Wells Fargo, Bank of America, and JPMorgan Chase, have passed the Federal Reserve's annual stress test, setting the stage for increased buybacks and dividends for shareholders. The test, which simulated a severe recession, showed that banks would withstand more than $550 billion in losses. The results indicate that large banks are well-positioned to weather a severe recession, with the Fed estimating a decline in common equity tier 1 capital ratio of 1.8 percentage points. This could lead to lower capital requirements, allowing banks to boost dividends and share buybacks.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending, which accounts for more than two-thirds of economic activity, dropped 0.1 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.2 per cent gain in April.

site_title: Brad Pitt’s ‘F1’ cruises to top of North American box office
summary: Brad Pitt's "F1: The Movie" topped the North American box office with $55.6 million in ticket sales, beating out "How to Train Your Dragon" and Disney/Pixar's "Elio." The racing film, starring Pitt as a washed-up Formula One driver, received positive reviews from critics and audiences, according to analyst David Gross. Other films in the top 10 included "M3GAN 2.0," "28 Years Later," and "Lilo & Stitch."

images.alt_text: In 2018, Lalo Schifrin received an honorary Oscar for lifetime achievement, presented by Clint Eastwood.

site_title: Australia cuts commodity export outlook despite gold price gain
summary: Australia has cut its forecast earnings from commodity exports, with total earnings expected to fall about 7% to A$385 billion in the 12 months to June. Despite a rise in gold prices, iron ore and natural gas earnings will decline due to lower grades and prices. Gold earnings are expected to jump 22% to US$56 billion, while copper, lithium, and uranium are forecast to see increased earnings. The decline in commodity earnings is attributed to rising trade barriers, weaker global economic growth, and declining prices.

images.alt_text: Iron ore stockpiles at a mine in the Pilbara region of Western Australia. Photographer: Carla Gottgens/Bloomberg
Australia last year exported 702,000 metric tons of lamb, mutton and goat meat worth US$3.6 billion, almost 200,000 tons more than in 2019, previously the biggest export year.

site_title: Trump’s court win opens a path to clear hurdles to his agenda
summary: The US Supreme Court's ruling on curbing judges' power to block government actions on a nationwide basis has raised questions about the future of dozens of orders halting President Donald Trump's policies. The conservative majority's ruling may lead to the invalidation of nationwide preliminary orders in cases involving Trump's policies, including limits on automatic birthright citizenship and foreign students' legal status. The Justice Department could quickly ask federal judges to revisit the scope of these orders, while Trump vowed to target policies that have been "wrongly enjoined on a nationwide basis."

images.alt_text: Trump has unleashed a pressure campaign on the central bank to cut rates.

site_title: Trump says he’ll pick a Fed chair who wants to cut rates
summary: US President Donald Trump said he will choose a Federal Reserve chair who wants to cut interest rates, a move that could undermine the central bank's independence. Trump criticized current Fed Chair Jerome Powell, calling him "a stubborn mule and a stupid person" for not supporting rate cuts. Trump has three or four people in mind to succeed Powell, but Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent downplayed speculation of a quick move. The president's comments risk clouding the Fed's independence, which could impact the central bank's ability to make independent decisions.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has repeatedly expressed frustration with Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s cautious approach to lowering interest rates, citing benign inflation data.

site_title: China’s rare earths are flowing again, but not freely
summary: China has begun issuing licenses for rare earth magnet exports, speeding up the flow of the critical materials to the automotive supply chain. The rate of issuance has accelerated to 60% from 25%, with European suppliers receiving enough licenses to avoid widespread disruptions. However, US-based companies and those with third-country connections continue to face uncertainty, with some experiencing delays of up to 45 days. The agreement aims to resolve the rare earth issue, but the opaque export licensing system remains a concern, and some production lines may still be affected.

images.alt_text: China has grown to dominate production of rare earths; Above: pipes from a rare earth smelting plant spewing polluted water into a vast tailings dam near Xinguang Village in China.
US President Donald Trump earlier said the United States had signed a deal with China on Wednesday, without providing additional details.

site_title: Gold-rich Laos hits mother lode with S-E Asia’s first bullion bank amid inflation, currency blues
summary: Laos has launched the first dedicated gold bank in South-east Asia, Lao Bullion Bank, amid high inflation and currency blues. The bank offers traditional deposit, withdrawal, and transfer services, as well as unique offerings like gold vending machines and certificates that can be used as collateral. The bank aims to bring gold back into the formal financial system, with a goal of scaling up refinery services to account for 70% of its assets in one year. With over 1,000 tonnes of gold underground and $10 billion in private holdings, Laos sees gold as a safe-haven asset to boost its economy.

Set up as a public-private partnership, Lao Bullion Bank currently operates out of a five-storey building in the capital, Vientiane.

site_title: Bruce Springsteen digs into the vault to rewrite his 'lost' '90s
summary: Bruce Springsteen is releasing "Tracks II: The Lost Albums," a collection of 83 unreleased songs spanning 1983-2018, including material from the 1990s. Contrary to fan perception, Springsteen was actively working during this period, influenced by his family and personal life. The box set includes seven albums, revisiting tracks from the 1990s, including the "Streets of Philadelphia Sessions" and a country-rooted romp, "Somewhere North of Nashville." Critics have praised the release as a "revelation" to fans, offering a new perspective on Springsteen's creative process.

images.alt_text: Singer Bruce Springsteen performs with the E Street Band during his concert in Cape Town, in this Jan 26, 2014 file photo.
Brian Wilson of The Beach Boys performs onstage at the 54th Annual GRAMMY Awards in Los Angeles, California, Feb 12, 2012. Brian Wilson has died, his family announced on June 11, 2025. He was 82.

site_title: Sweet endings at Coda
summary: Singapore's Coda speakeasy has removed visible alcohol brands from its bar to encourage customers to judge drinks on their own merit. The minimalist space, designed by owner Michel Lu, features a custom-built bar counter and a dim, box-like room lined with mirrors. Coda's cocktail menu, themed after different moods, showcases Asian spirits and flavors, with signature drinks like the Fling and Smoke. Lu aims to create a "sweet spot" where customers can round off their day with a delightful experience.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Chia’s favourite on the new menu is Kid Me Not, inspired by a specific “mama shop” near his house as well as shared memories of such local convenience stores in public housing estates.

site_title: Flood-hit China expands social security net as extreme rain takes toll
summary: China expands its social security net as extreme rainfall takes a toll on the country, particularly in provinces such as Hubei and Guizhou. The central government will now bear 70% of compensation funds for flood diversions, while local governments will cover the remaining 30%. Livestock losses are also included in the compensation scheme. The move comes after record rainfall in June, with daily rainfall in some areas breaking records, and flooding in Guizhou, where a city was hit by extreme flooding that could only happen once in 50 years.

images.alt_text: A man walks through the rain at Milsons Point in Sydney, Australia, May 22, 2025. The weather system is now moving south with heavy rains in Sydney on Friday.

site_title: Hong Kong’s sixfold jump in share sales drives boom year in Asia
summary: Hong Kong is experiencing a record-breaking year for share sales, with proceeds reaching about US$33 billion in the first half, a sixfold jump from last year. Chinese companies are flocking to Hong Kong for additional listings, with the US$5.2 billion offering by battery giant CATL being the largest. Despite geopolitical concerns, investors remain optimistic, and experts predict a busy second half of the year. Hong Kong's share sales are poised to double to a four-year high, driven by companies seeking to shield themselves from tariff effects and geopolitics.

images.alt_text: People pass an electronic sign showing the price of the Hang Seng Index at Exchange Square in Hong Kong on April 10, 2025. Asian stocks rocketed on April 10 as investors breathed a huge sigh of relief after Donald Trump announced a pause on crippling tariffs on US partners, with Chinese markets even brushing off his decision to ramp up duties on Beijing to 125 percent. (Photo by Peter PARKS / AFP)

site_title: Frasers Hospitality’s Tokyo debut part of growth strategy to expand to business gateway cities
summary: Frasers Hospitality has successfully launched its debut property in Tokyo, Yotel Tokyo Ginza, which has exceeded expectations with an average occupancy rate of 70% since its opening in December. The delayed completion was a blessing in disguise, as the weaker yen has fueled Japan's tourism boom. According to Jason Leong, head of investment and asset management, the hotel's performance is a testament to Frasers Hospitality's growth strategy to expand into business gateway cities. The company's focus on longer-stay assets and curated experiences is also paying off, as it continues to expand its portfolio across 20 countries.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

site_title: Wealthy Silicon Valley investors in line for US$17 billion windfall in US senate Republican tax Bill
summary: US Senate Republicans' proposed tax and spending bill could expand Qualified Small Business Stock (QSBS) tax breaks, benefiting wealthy Silicon Valley investors. The provision, which allows for tax-free income on capital gains from venture capital investments, could be relaxed to allow investments at later stages, cash out earlier and still receive a partial benefit, and skip taxes on up to 50% more of windfalls. The changes could boost the provision's cost by $17.2 billion over the decade, with critics arguing it's unnecessary and overly expensive.

site_title: Meta seeks US$29 billion from private capital firms for AI data centres, FT reports
summary: Meta Platforms is seeking US$29 billion from private capital firms to build AI data centers in the US, raising US$3 billion in equity and US$26 billion in debt. The company is in discussions with private credit investors, including Apollo Global Management and KKR. This comes as Meta has doubled down on its AI commitment, with a US$14.8 billion investment in startup Scale AI and plans to spend up to US$65 billion this year on AI infrastructure. The fundraising aims to strengthen Meta's position in the AI technology landscape against competitors OpenAI and Google.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump has prioritised winning the AI race against China and declared on his first day in office a national energy emergency.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq hit record closing highs amid trade negotiations, rate cut bets
summary: US stocks hit record highs amid trade negotiations and rate cut bets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closing at all-time highs. Despite President Trump's termination of trade negotiations with Canada, investor risk appetite remained strong, fueled by economic data and expectations for rate cuts from the US Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1% to its lowest record high since December.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on June 2, 2025, in New York City. Oil prices surged Monday over renewed concerns about Russia's war in Ukraine and relief over OPEC+ production, while stock markets mostly slumped as US-China trade tensions resurfaced. The dollar was under pressure while Wall Street opened mixed, with the Dow and the broad-based S&P 500 in the red while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong-listed China Medical System seeks secondary listing on SGX
summary: China Medical System, a Hong Kong-listed specialty pharma, is seeking a secondary listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in July. The company aims to deepen its presence in South-east Asia and tap into a new investor base in Singapore. CMS has a proven track record in China's pharmaceutical industry and expects growth momentum to accelerate with the replenishment of its innovative drug pipeline. The secondary listing will not involve the issuance of new shares, and the company's shares will continue to be primarily listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
There is interest from Chinese companies to make secondary listings on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), said Jason Saw, head of investment banking at CGS International.

site_title: OpenAI turns to Google's AI chips to power its products: source
summary: OpenAI has begun renting Google's artificial intelligence (AI) chips, specifically tensor processing units (TPUs), to power its products, including ChatGPT. This marks a shift away from relying on Nvidia's GPUs and a move to lower inference costs. The collaboration shows Google's expansion of its in-house AI technology, which has helped win customers including Apple and startups. The deal is a surprise collaboration between two prominent AI competitors, and OpenAI's use of non-Nvidia chips could boost TPUs as a cheaper alternative to GPUs.

The winners in this new landscape will be those who combine AI’s computational power with human insight, intuition, and relationship skills.

site_title: US consumer spending falls unexpectedly in May
summary: US consumer spending unexpectedly fell 0.1% in May after a 0.2% gain in April, as households pulled forward goods purchases ahead of tariffs. This drop, combined with slower service spending, restrained consumer spending growth to 0.5% in the last quarter, the slowest rate since 2020. Despite moderate inflation, the Federal Reserve is unlikely to cut interest rates in July, citing the need to gauge the impact of tariffs on prices.

images.alt_text: Transportation equipment orders soared 48.3 per cent, driven by a 230.8 per cent surge in commercial aircraft orders, which are extremely volatile.

site_title: MAS fines 5 payment firms S$960,000 for anti-money laundering lapses
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has fined five major payment institutions a total of S$960,000 for breaches of anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism requirements. The firms, licensed for cross-border money transfer services, failed to conduct adequate customer due diligence measures and did not provide information on wire transfer originators and beneficiaries. The regulator has established plans to publish a paper providing further guidance to the industry, and the payment institutions have committed to remediation.

site_title: GuocoLand’s Dora Chng on flex designs and biodiversity to lure new condo buyers
summary: GuocoLand's residential director, Dora Chng, highlights the importance of flexible condo designs to cater to evolving customer needs, particularly among the younger generation. The company's next condo launch, Springleaf Residence, incorporates biodiversity-sensitive design and development approaches, featuring unobstructed views of a 30-hectare forest. Chng notes that the development strikes a balance between living with nature and providing modern amenities, such as a forest corridor and dining rooms that can accommodate up to 50 people.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

The “cluster effect” is particularly pronounced in the Lentor Hills estate cluster, which has seen six launches to date and one more to come in 2026. Despite initial concerns about a potential supply glut in an untested area, each successive launch in the Lentor Hills cluster saw healthy take-up rates and higher home prices.

site_title: Sygnum is sole new unicorn from South-east Asia in H1 2025: report
summary: Sygnum, a Singapore-based digital asset group, is the sole new unicorn from South-east Asia in the first half of 2025, according to a report by Tracxn. The region saw US$2 billion in tech funding, a 7% increase from the previous year, with Singapore firms taking the bulk of the money. Late-stage funding deals rose 149% to US$1.4 billion, while seed-stage investments declined 68% to US$87 million. The report highlights the resilience of the region's tech landscape, driven by strong activity in acquisitions, IPOs, and enterprise infrastructure investments.

site_title: OCBC trims 360 Account interest rates for the second time in 2025
summary: OCBC has cut the maximum interest rate of its 360 Account to 5.45% per annum for the first S$100,000, from 6.3%, effective August 1. This is the second rate cut for the account in 2025, following a previous reduction to 6.3% in May. The move is in line with lower interest rate expectations, with analysts predicting at least two more rate cuts for the rest of 2025.

site_title: Mid-year insights: Opportunities amid globalisation’s discontents
summary: Global markets are shifting towards a more globalized approach, with South Korea's market outperforming the US market year-to-date, driven by aerospace and defense gains. The UK's defense spending plans and the rise in global military expenditure are expected to boost job growth and industrial centers. The eurozone, particularly Germany, is seen as an attractive destination for investors, with proposed infrastructure spending and resilient corporate earnings. Mexico and Brazil are also expected to benefit, with Mexico's consumer staples and communication services sectors showing resilience, and Brazil's strategic positioning as a key commodity exporter.

images.alt_text: Many US companies operate on a global scale with dominant positions in the US and international markets. For instance, Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet hold more than 60 per cent of the global cloud market share.
The European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.28 per cent lower at 535.03 on Monday, after touching its lowest level in over a month earlier in the session.

site_title: Oil steadies after report of planned Opec+ August output hike
summary: Oil prices edged up slightly on Friday after a report that Opec+ planned to hike production in August, but still tumbled 12% for the week. Brent crude futures rose to $67.77 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $65.52 a barrel. The planned August increase, similar to a July hike, followed a 12% decline in the week due to the Israel-Iran ceasefire. Analysts attribute the price drop to geopolitical risk premiums being shrugged off as the market returns to fundamentals-driven analysis.

images.alt_text: A gas flare at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 27)
summary: NTT, Japan's largest telco, is spinning off its data centers into a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (Reit), marking the largest S-Reit listing in a decade. Meanwhile, Singapore's job market saw a rise in job vacancies and unemployment in Q1, with the ratio remaining unchanged. The country's port, ranked the world's top for the 12th consecutive year, and FedEx partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas.

site_title: Warren Buffett donates record US$6 billion Berkshire shares
summary: Warren Buffett, 94, donated US$6 billion of Berkshire Hathaway stock to the Gates Foundation and four family charities, boosting his overall giving to over US$60 billion. The donation includes 9.43 million shares to the Gates Foundation, and shares to his children's charities, with Buffett maintaining he won't sell any Berkshire shares. He now owns 13.8% of the company's stock and ranks fifth in the world's richest people list, with a net worth of US$152 billion.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Warren Buffett, CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, speaks to the press as he arrives at the 2019 annual shareholders meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, May 4, 2019. Buffett said May 3, 2025, he would retire from leading his Berkshire Hathaway business group by the end of the year and that he would recommend Greg Abel to take over. "The time has arrived where Greg should become the chief executive officer of the company at year end," Buffett told an annual shareholder meeting. (Photo by Johannes EISELE / AFP)

A cardboard cutout depicting Berkshire Hathaway CEO Warren Buffet during a shareholders shopping day ahead of the Berkshire Hathaway annual shareholders meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, US, on Friday, May 2, 2025. CEO Warren Buffett might offer thoughts on the direction of earnings at the May 3 annual meeting. Photographer: Dan Brouillette/Bloomberg

site_title: CCCS okays Tamarind Health’s proposed acquisition of TalkMed
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has cleared Tamarind Health's proposed acquisition of TalkMed Group, stating that the deal will not substantially lessen competition within the Singapore market. Patients can choose alternative providers of medical oncology services, limiting the impact, and insurers and regulatory frameworks are expected to constrain any increase in market power. Tamarind Health, controlled by Templewater, will privatise TalkMed through a scheme of arrangement at S$0.456 per share, with 65 Equity Partners subscribing for shares in the deal.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
CCCS 裁定串标违规案
From left: Adrienne Teh, managing director; Francis Woo, chief corporate officer and managing director (Singapore); chief executive Tan Chong Lee; and investment principal Timothy Wee.

From left: Dr Ang Peng Tiam, CEO of TalkMED Group; Tan Kwang Cheak, CEO of SCS; President Tharman, Patron of SCS; Lee Meng Tat, chairman of SCS walk the lap with all participants at Relay For Life 2025.
In 2024, 17 companies listed on the SGX were the subject of privatisation offers.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq touch record highs after tame inflation data
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opened at record highs on June 27, 2025, after a benign inflation report raised hopes for a dovish policy outlook from the US Federal Reserve. The S&P 500 rose 9.7 points, or 0.16%, to 6,150.7, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 49.4 points, or 0.24%, to 20,217.264. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also rose, with a 118.8-point gain, or 0.27%, to 43,505.6. The strong market performance follows a period of concerns over inflation and monetary policy.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Trump plans executive orders to power AI growth in race with China: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump is planning executive orders to boost the growth of artificial intelligence by easing grid connections for power projects and opening federal land for data centers. The moves aim to support the US expansion of AI, which requires a rapid increase in power supplies straining utilities and grids. The administration also plans to release an AI action plan and schedule public events to draw attention to the efforts. The goal is to win the AI race against China and secure an economic and military edge.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Donald Trump holds a signed executive order on AI, in the Oval Office of the White House, in Washington, U.S., January 23, 2025.   REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque/File Photo
SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son speaks during the company's annual general meeting in Tokyo, Japan, June 27, 2025.
“All of us have to get our head around this idea that AI can do things that before we were doing,” Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff said.
More than two-thirds of European businesses said they struggle to understand their responsibilities under the EU AI Act, according to a survey by Amazon Web Services.
Siemens' selling point is that it knows industry because it makes things, including robots and gas turbines.

Signage for artificial intelligence at the China Unicom Hong Kong Ltd. booth at the MWC Shanghai tech show in Shanghai, China, on Thursday, June 19, 2025. The show runs through June 20. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore's renewables usage hits record high as imports, solar output rise
summary: Singapore has reached a record high of 2.58% in its power generation mix, driven by a 0.4% growth in total electricity generation and a rise in renewable imports and domestic solar power. Renewable imports rose a third straight month, with 122.7 million kilowatt-hours of clean power imported in the first five months of 2025, displacing some fossil fuel-fired generation. The country aims to meet 6 GW of its power demand from clean electricity imports by 2035.

images.alt_text: Solar energy is the most promising source of renewable energy in Singapore. Renewable energy is one of the points of cooperation brought up during PM Wong's visit to Manila in June 2025.

site_title: Outperformed by AI: Time to replace your analyst?
summary: A recent study by the CFA Society Singapore found that artificial intelligence (AI) models outperformed human analysts in producing comprehensive Swot (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats) analyses for three companies. The AI models, which were trained on advanced prompting techniques, consistently produced more detailed and specific analyses than human analysts. However, human analysts are still essential for interpretation, strategy, and understanding management thinking. The study recommends a hybrid approach, using AI for heavy lifting and human judgment for interpretation and strategy. The findings highlight the need for investment professionals to master prompt engineering and choose the right models to extract value from AI tools.

site_title: Cambodia’s Hun Sen urges change in Thai leadership over border dispute
summary: Cambodian former Prime Minister Hun Sen urged a leadership change in Thailand, citing concerns over the border dispute between the two countries. He made the comments during a televised address, suggesting that a new Thai prime minister could resolve issues with neighboring countries, particularly Cambodia. The move adds to tensions between the two countries, which have been heightened by a leaked call between Hun Sen and Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a press conference following the 6th BIMSTEC Summit, in Bangkok, Thailand, April 4, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

site_title: Japan private-sector rice imports soar in May
summary: Japan's private-sector rice imports surged to 10,600 metric tons in May, defying high levies, amid supply shortages. This represents a significant jump from the 3,004 tons imported in the previous financial year. Rice prices in Japan have doubled since last year due to extreme heatwaves and stockpiling. The government has released stockpiled rice to retailers, and Japanese consumers are increasingly turning to US brands for cheaper prices.

images.alt_text: Renewed rise in food prices, particularly a 90 per cent spike in the price of rice, is pushing up not just headline but underlying inflation, which is typically influenced mostly by improvements in the economy and a tight job market, Kazuo Ueda said.

site_title: Reits and tech lead net institutional inflows; Frencken chair and DHLT CEO raise their stakes
summary: Institutions remained net sellers of Singapore stocks over the last five trading sessions, with a net outflow of S$248 million, bringing the year-to-date outflow to S$2.16 billion. The sectors with the highest net institutional inflow were Reits and technology, while financial services and telecommunications saw the most outflow. 19 primary-listed companies made buybacks totaling S$72.9 million, with UOB, DBS, and OCBC leading the consideration tally. Directors or CEOs filed 11 acquisitions and three disposals, while substantial shareholders filed 24 acquisitions and 13 disposals.

images.alt_text: Generic image of SGX
Over the four trading sessions from Jun 13 to 18, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with net institutional outflow of S$42 million.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise as US-China trade tensions ease; auto stocks jump
summary: European stocks rose 1.1% on Friday, snapping a two-week losing streak and posting their first weekly gain in three, as investors took more risks on hopes for a truce in the US-China trade spat. The Stoxx 600 index, energy sector losses aside, reached an over one-week high, driven by gains in auto stocks and the luxury sector. A deal to fast-track rare earth shipments to the US and US Treasury Secretary's efforts to remove retaliatory taxes also contributed to the market's optimism.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed up 0.09 per cent at 537.48 points on Thursday.

site_title: New World gets 100% lender approval for US$11 billion refinancing
summary: Hong Kong's New World Development has secured written commitments from all banks for a $11.1 billion loan refinancing, bringing it closer to finalizing a critical lifeline just days before a deadline. The deal, which would be one of the largest of its kind ever in Hong Kong, marks the end of months-long negotiations and provides short-term relief. The refinancing agreement pushes back HK$63.4 billion of borrowings, extending maturities for three years, and grants New World some reprieve from default.

images.alt_text: Markets are closely watching New World’s debt issues, wondering if they might signal a sector crisis similar to the one that hit mainland China in 2021.

site_title: Elon Musk says first Tesla drove itself from factory to customer
summary: Elon Musk announced Tesla's first autonomous delivery, where a Tesla Model Y SUV drove itself from the factory to a customer's home, reaching a max speed of 72 miles per hour. The delivery, made "across town" and including highways, was completed without anyone in the car and no remote operators. This marks Tesla's push into autonomous driving and highlights Musk's bet on AI and robotics as the future of his electric car company.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico/Bloomberg
Xiaomi received 289,000 orders for the YU7 - only its second vehicle and one that undercuts Tesla’s Model Y in price by nearly 4 per cent - in its first hour on sale, according to CEO Lei Jun.

site_title: BlackRock, Mubadala unwind partnership for Asia private credit: sources
summary: BlackRock and Mubadala Investment have mutually agreed to unwind their Asian private credit partnership, focusing on investments in China and Indonesia, due to challenges in sourcing deals. The partnership, launched in 2023, aimed to deploy capital but struggled to originate deals, particularly in China with a mid-teens return profile. Mubadala's head of private credit in Indonesia also left, further hindering deal origination. The partnership's limited deployment of capital and difficulties in sourcing deals led to the decision to unwind the partnership.

images.alt_text: Mainland investors are increasingly drawn to overseas opportunities due to deflationary risks and low bank deposit rates at home.
Dennis Quah, head of Singapore wealth at BlackRock, says the strategy aims to give an investor "non-market-driven returns".
Private credit holdings can make up 15% to 30% of some family offices’ portfolios.
Middle East sovereign wealth funds made up five of the top 10 most active global dealmakers for the second year in a row, according to the report.
The ranking places Abu Dhabi ahead of Oslo, Beijing, and Singapore.
Global cumulative data-centre demand is expected to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 11 per cent by 2032, Mubadala said.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends at 6-month high, tracking Wall Street rally
summary: Japan's Nikkei index reached a six-month high, closing at 40,150.79, a 1.43% jump, driven by a Wall Street rally. Technology stocks, including Tokyo Electron and SoftBank Group, led the gains, while defence-related stocks rose on expected increased spending. The broader Topix index also rose 1.28% to 2,840.54, its sharpest weekly gain since September 2024. Investors attributed the rally to easing Middle East tensions and expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei rallied more than one per cent to break 40,000 for the first time since January, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney and Singapore stocks were also up on Friday.

site_title: Unilever to pay US$1.5 billion for men's grooming brand Dr Squatch
summary: Unilever is acquiring men's grooming brand Dr Squatch for US$1.5 billion. The deal will complement Unilever's men's personal care offerings, including Axe and Dove Men+Care deodorants, and scale Dr Squatch internationally. Dr Squatch, launched in 2013, sells deodorant, hair care products, and other personal care items. Unilever declined to disclose financial details, citing a lack of transparency. The acquisition is expected to expand Unilever's presence in the global men's grooming market.

images.alt_text: Ben & Jerry’s also says Unilever tasked one of its executives with persuading the company’s founders to take its side in the dispute.

site_title: HSBC private banking arm names new Apac head of wealth planning
summary: HSBC Global Private Banking has appointed Ann Ling, a seasoned financial services professional, as the new regional head of wealth planning and advisory for Asia-Pacific, effective July 1. Ling brings over two decades of experience to the role, previously holding senior wealth planning positions at JP Morgan, UBS, and Morgan Stanley. Her appointment aims to strengthen HSBC's bespoke solutions for customers seeking intergenerational wealth transfer and preservation goals, according to Lok Yim, Asia-Pacific regional head of private banking.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: HDB US$1.5 billion India IPO sold out as wealthy investors pile in
summary: HDB Financial Services' US$1.5 billion initial public offering (IPO) sold out, with 242.8 million shares bid for, exceeding the 130.4 million shares offered. Wealthy investors, including individual investors and qualified institutions, drove the demand, while retail investors saw a slightly short allocation. The sale comes amid a rebound in the benchmark NSE Nifty 50 Index, which may serve as a barometer for demand in large Indian issuances.

images.alt_text: The Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai.  Indian stocks are now positioned for more gains after the central bank on Friday delivered a bigger-than-expected interest rate cut and injected further liquidity into the banking system.

site_title: Betting on local assets could pay off for Singapore investors: Deutsche Bank Private Bank CIO
summary: Singapore investors may consider allocating more funds to local assets due to the country's economic positioning and limited exposure to US tariffs. Deutsche Bank's Christian Nolting notes that Singapore's real estate and stock markets offer promising prospects, with a "very safe" asset status and a 5% dividend yield. Despite expected US dollar weakness, US assets remain attractive due to the country's stronger productivity growth and larger market size. Nolting expects the greenback to weaken further but not collapse over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: SGS bonds have enjoyed a rally as traders fled from US assets, RHB analysts said.

site_title: Impossible Foods aims to put plant-based burgers on European menus this year
summary: Impossible Foods aims to launch its plant-based burgers in European markets this year, marking a major breakthrough for the company after a six-year quest. Despite EU food safety regulators approving its ingredients last year, the company is still awaiting final regulatory approvals for its genetically-modified ingredient. CEO Peter McGuinness expects the approvals to come in the next few months, citing a growing demand for plant-based products in Europe and the UK, where consumers prioritize sustainability.

images.alt_text: Over the four trading sessions from Jun 13 to 18, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with net institutional outflow of S$42 million.
Shopee owns more than 50 per cent of all the market share across countries in South-east Asia, excluding Indonesia.

site_title: Mystery US$33 billion Chinese medicine fortune collapses in days
summary: Regencell Bioscience Holdings, a traditional Chinese medicine company, saw its stock price surge 82,000% and its CEO's net worth increase to $33 billion after being founded in 2014. However, the company's rapid rise was short-lived, with its net worth plummeting to $10.1 billion in just one week. Regencell has no sales, posted net losses of $4.4 million and $6.1 million, and has a vacant chief medical officer position. Experts warn that the company's wild price swings may be indicative of pump-and-dump schemes, prompting regulators to investigate.

images.alt_text: Regencell Bioscience sells herbal medicine treatments for ADHD and autism spectrum disorder.
Its traditional Chinese medicine formula, which forms the basis of its product candidates, “contains only natural ingredients without any synthetic components”.

site_title: Japan’s May jobless rate unchanged at 2.5%
summary: Japan's jobless rate remained unchanged at 2.5% in May, according to government data. The jobs-to-applicants ratio fell to 1.24 from 1.26 in April. Economists had forecast a slight decrease. This maintains the country's labor market stability, with no significant changes in the employment landscape.

images.alt_text: Morning commuters make their way to work in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, May 29, 2012. Japan's jobless rate unexpectedly rose and retail sales fell for a second month, underscoring concern that an economic recovery will lose momentum in the face of gains in the yen and Europe's debt crisis. Photographer: Tomohiro Ohsumi/Bloomberg

site_title: AEM, UMS, Frencken lead semiconductor stock surge; robust weekly gains ride on domestic, global tailwinds
summary: Semiconductor stocks in Singapore surged on Friday, with AEM, UMS, and Frencken leading the gains. The sector's upbeat outlook, driven by booming AI demand and a recovery from 2024's cyclical downturn, is expected to offset potential tariff-related headwinds. The opening of a new $123 million manufacturing facility in Singapore and pushback against US President Trump's tariff threats also contributed to the gains. AEM rose 26.8% for the week, while UMS and Frencken gained 12.4% and 12.2% respectively.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
A stacker sorts silicon wafers. semiconductor Photographer: Kyle Green/Bloomberg
Excluding the volatile biomedical manufacturing cluster, output grew 4.9 per cent year on year in May, moderating from the revised 7.8 per cent growth posted in April.
Tariffs threaten to snarl supply lines and jack up costs for consumers.

site_title: Roger Federer’s long-term deals make him a tennis billionaire
summary: Tennis superstar Roger Federer has become a billionaire, with a net worth of approximately US$1.3 billion, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index. His wealth comes from a combination of prize money from his 24-year career, bumper sponsorship deals, and an investment in the Swiss sneaker brand On. Federer's longest deals include a 10-year contract with Uniqlo worth US$300 million and a stake in On Holding, which is now worth close to US$17 billion. His success in avoiding overexposure through endorsement roles and maintaining a scandal-free image has contributed to his marketability and wealth.

images.alt_text: Spain's Rafael Nadal is set to end his two decades as a professional with 92 titles and prize money alone of US$135 million, his status long since secured as one of the greatest tennis players of all time.
Nadal tally of 14 victories at a single Grand Slam appears unlikely to be beaten, with Margaret Court’s 11 Australian Open titles second on the all-time list.

site_title: Asia: Stocks climb, dollar holds on trade hopes and rate bets
summary: Asian stocks rose on Friday, with the Nikkei breaking 40,000 for the first time since January, driven by fresh trade hopes and bets of US interest rate cuts. The dollar held around three-year lows amid expectations of two rate cuts this year. Easing concerns over Middle East tensions and progress in US-China trade talks also contributed to the upbeat mood. The US Federal Reserve hinted at a softer approach, with President Trump mentioning potential candidates to succeed Jerome Powell.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board showing the Nikkei share average in Tokyo, Japan, June 23, 2025. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
The Stoxx 600 index closed up 0.09 per cent at 537.48 points on Thursday.
The broad-based S&P 500 gained 0.8 per cent to 6,141.02 on Thursday, about three points shy of an all-time record.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, June 27, 2025
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 stock index reached a 6-month high, tracking the Wall Street rally. In Singapore, job vacancies and unemployment rose in Q1, but the impact of US tariffs remains unclear. Info-Tech Systems launched its initial public offering (IPO) at SGD 0.87 apiece, marking SGX's first mainboard listing in two years. Japan's NTT is set to file a billion-dollar real estate investment trust (Reit) listing with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), expected to be the largest SGX IPO in four years.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board showing the Nikkei 225 index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in Tokyo on April 9, 2025. Japan's main Nikkei index of shares fell in early trade on April 9 after Wall Street stocks turned lower on worries about US tariffs and a trade war with China. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Manpower Minister Tan See Leng says that the slight rise in the unemployment rate suggests that employers are remaining cautious in hiring amid heightened global uncertainty.

Info-Tech Systems CEO and co-founder Babu Dilip and chairman and co-founder Peter Lee on June 27, 2025. Info-Tech Systems IPO launch press briefing. This will be the first company listing on SGX mainboard in 2025.

site_title: Singapore stocks track overnight Wall Street gains on Friday; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to 3,966.2, tracking overnight Wall Street gains. Hongkong Land was the top gainer, while Sembcorp Industries was the biggest decliner. The broader market saw 309 gainers and 202 losers, with 1.8 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changing hands. Regional markets were mixed, with the Nikkei 225 and IDX Composite up, while the Hang Seng Index and Kospi fell. The STI's gain was attributed to weaker-than-expected economic data and a potential new US Federal Reserve chair.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
NTT is spinning off its assets into a data centre Reit that will potentially be listed on SGX.

Info-Tech Systems CEO and co-founder Babu Dilip and chairman and co-founder Peter Lee on June 27, 2025. Info-Tech Systems IPO launch press briefing. This will be the first company listing on SGX mainboard in 2025.
A stacker sorts silicon wafers. semiconductor Photographer: Kyle Green/Bloomberg
Despite an upward revision to its H1 profit guidance, AEM maintains the view that the business environment faces uncertainty.

site_title: Another private members’ club expands: Mandala Club puts in S$2 million to grow its space by almost 50%
summary: Mandala Club, a private members' club in Singapore, is expanding its space by almost 50% with a S$2 million investment. The new 9,000-square-foot, four-storey property will feature a ballroom, an all-day dining restaurant, and other facilities, set to open in the fourth quarter of this year. The expansion follows the growth of the club's membership and programming ambitions, driven by a partnership with the Icon1C Group, a luxury hospitality collective.

images.alt_text: Grand Mansion is a former diplomatic landmark that has served as the residence of some of China’s prominent magnates and hosted several high profile events.
1880 was suddenly closed this week, following the abrupt closure of its Hong Kong branch last month.
The Singapore private members' club is closed from Jun 17.

site_title: Singapore’s job vacancies, unemployment up in Q1, with US tariff impact yet to be seen: MOM
summary: Singapore's job vacancies and unemployment rose in Q1 2025, with a slight increase in unemployment rate to 2% overall, 2.9% for residents, and 3.1% for citizens. Despite this, job vacancies per unemployed persons remained steady at 1.64, indicating a tight labor market. The impact of US President Trump's tariffs is yet to be seen, expected to show up in Q2 or Q3. Employers remain cautious in hiring amid heightened global uncertainty, but the government reassures that there are still good job opportunities available, especially in growth sectors.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Employers planning to hire cited company expansion as the primary driver of staffing increases.
Generic image of Singapore financial district

site_title: China’s 344 billion yuan chip fund switches tack to fight US curbs: sources
summary: China's Big Fund III, a $48 billion chip investment fund, is shifting its focus to local companies and projects in areas like lithography and semiconductor design software, aiming to overcome US curbs on China's technological advances. The fund, which has secured only a portion of its original capital, will prioritize investments in key bottlenecks and plans to spur industry consolidation. Its new approach aims to promote China's semiconductor industry, essential for cutting-edge AI development, and could potentially become the country's largest-ever semiconductor fund.

images.alt_text: The new restrictions are likely to cut off Huawei and SMIC’s access to Taiwan’s plant construction technologies, materials and equipment essential to build AI chips.
The chances of the United States withdrawing the authorisations are unclear.
Huawei invests 180 billion yuan (S$32.3 billion) in research annually and sees promise in compound chips - or chips made from multiple elements - CEO Ren Zhengfei said in an interview.

Electronic design automation software makers, which include Cadence, Synopsys and Siemens EDA, were told via letters from the Commerce Department to stop supplying their tech to Chinese groups, FT said.

site_title: Thailand central bank vows to step in if baht moves are unhinged
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, has vowed to intervene if the baht's recent surge, up 5% this year, becomes "unhinged" and loses connection to its fundamentals. Deputy Governor Piti Disyatat stated that the bank closely monitors the currency's volatility and will reduce it if driven by non-fundamental reasons. The bank does not target a specific level or direction for the baht and its gain is in line with regional peers, according to Disyatat. The comments come amid trade talks with the US to lower tariffs on Thai goods.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand cuts its growth forecast for 2025 to 2 per cent.

site_title: Masayoshi Son hints at succession plan while chasing AI ambition
summary: Masayoshi Son, SoftBank's billionaire founder, hinted at a succession plan, stating he plans to hold the reins for another 10 years. However, he has several internal candidates in mind, including SoftBank's telecom head Junichi Miyakawa, who oversees AI infrastructure in Japan. Son expressed confidence in Miyakawa's abilities, saying he has "almost never felt the need to interfere" in his work. Son's focus remains on achieving his ambitious AI goals, including becoming the world's top platform for artificial super-intelligence, with a potential partnership with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing.

images.alt_text: Masayoshi Son, chairman and chief executive officer of SoftBank Group Corp., gestures as he speaks during the company's annual general meeting in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, June 27, 2025. Son said he plans to hand over the reins of SoftBank Group to someone within the technology and telecom group, addressing what may be the single biggest concern among investors and business partners. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg
Son has built his career on taking long-shot gambles. It hasn’t always worked out. But such a mentality has propelled his rise from Japanese slum to the single-largest foreign investor in the US.
FILE PHOTO: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son speaks at the SoftBank World 2023 corporate conference, in Tokyo, Japan, October 4, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Tang/File Photo
The Japanese technology giant is offering 21.5 million shares for US$224 to US$228 each, the terms show.

site_title: Far East Organization opens Amber House condo for sale with prices from about S$2,900 psf
summary: Far East Organization is opening its Amber House condo project in District 15 for sale, with prices starting from S$1.92 million for two-bedroom units. The 105-unit freehold development spans 3,801.4 sq m, with prices ranging from S$2,900 psf to S$5.13 million for four-bedroom units. The project, previously delayed, aims to reflect the "evolving meaning of home" with carefully designed layouts and lifestyle amenities.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
CapitaLand Development will be launching its first residential project in Singapore Science Park - the 343-unit LyndenWoods condo.

rydmp25 - An artist’s impression of the mixed-use hub planned for the new Paterson neighbourhood on top of Orchard MRT station.  

Credit: URA

site_title: Japan’s NTT files for billion-dollar listing; set to be SGX’s biggest Reit IPO in a decade
summary: Japan's NTT is spinning off its data centers into a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust (S-Reit), NTT DC Reit, valued at approximately US$1.6 billion. The portfolio comprises six data centers across the US, Austria, and Singapore, with an initial offer price of US$1 per unit. The Reit is sponsored by NTT Ltd and has received backing from Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC, among other cornerstone investors. The listing is expected to be the largest S-Reit listing in a decade, with NTT DC Reit aiming to distribute up to 90% of its distributable income.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan

Info-Tech Systems CEO and co-founder Babu Dilip and chairman and co-founder Peter Lee on June 27, 2025. Info-Tech Systems IPO launch press briefing. This will be the first company listing on SGX mainboard in 2025.
The listing, if it proceeds, would be the biggest in Singapore since the US$977 million IPO of Digital Core Reit in 2021.

site_title: Seoul asks Temu, AliExpress to pull children’s products over safety concerns
summary: The Seoul city government has asked online retailers Temu and AliExpress to suspend sales of certain children's products due to safety concerns. An inspection of 35 products found 11 failed to meet safety standards or contained hazardous substances, including phthalate-based plasticisers and lead, exceeding local limits by up to 443.5 times. The government cited prolonged exposure to these substances as a risk to children's growth and health, and urged consumers to review product information before making purchases.

site_title: Vietnam dangles incentives for members of its two-city International Financial Centre
summary: Vietnam's parliament approved incentives for its International Financial Centre (IFC), aiming to develop it into one of the world's top 20 IFCs by 2045. The IFC, spanning two cities, Ho Chi Minh City and Da Nang, will offer preferential corporate income tax rates, tax holidays, and exemptions for foreign experts. Members will also be allowed to conduct transactions in foreign currencies and establish trading platforms. The government plans to develop detailed guidelines and allocate budgets for infrastructure development to support the IFC's growth.

site_title: Nike profits sink but company says it is turning a corner
summary: Nike reported a 86% decline in quarterly profits to $211 million, down from $1.8 billion a year ago. Revenues fell 12% to $11.1 billion, primarily due to oversupply and weak consumer demand. The company aims to reduce its China imports to 9% and implement "surgical" US price increases to mitigate tariff costs. Despite the challenges, CEO Elliott Hill expressed confidence in the company's ability to mitigate the impact of tariffs over time.

images.alt_text: Skims has seen growing demand for its premium bras, loungewear and shapewear.

site_title: Taiwan to impose anti-dumping duties on Chinese beer, steel for four months
summary: Taiwan's finance ministry announced the imposition of anti-dumping duties on Chinese-made beer and hot-rolled steel for four months, starting July 3. Duties on Chinese beer will be as high as 64.14% and on steel will be as high as 20.15%. The move aims to protect Taiwan's industry from substantial damage caused by the imported products.

site_title: At Hyrox, a stern test of strength, endurance and determination
summary: The 2025 Hyrox season is set to kick off with over 550,000 athletes participating in 90 races worldwide. The event, dubbed the "world series of fitness racing," features a mix of strength, endurance, and determination exercises, including burpees, sled pulls, and rowing. AIA Singapore is partnering with Hyrox for the first time, providing complimentary personal accident coverage to participants and sponsors. The event will take place at the National Stadium in Singapore, with a mixed relay championship and a corporate relay category. General counsel Penny Koo from AIA Singapore will be competing in the corporate relay.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Since 2021, Google searches for cardio workouts have declined on average by 3% year over year each month, while interest in strength-focused routines has grown 6%.

site_title: China’s industrial profits slip back into sharp decline in May
summary: China's industrial profits declined 9.1% in May from a year earlier, snapping a two-month growth streak. The decline was attributed to insufficient demand, declining industrial product prices, and short-term fluctuations. Industrial profits fell 1.1% in the first five months of 2025, compared to a 1.4% increase in the January-April period. The US trade truce and high tariffs on autos have contributed to the decline, prompting calls to end price wars. State-owned firms saw a 7.4% decline, while private and foreign firms saw increases of 0.3% and 3.4%, respectively.

site_title: Gold heads for second weekly loss, investors eye US inflation data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.4% to $3,314.27 per ounce, poised for a second consecutive weekly loss, as the dollar strengthened and markets awaited US inflation data for potential signals on Federal Reserve rate policy. Silver remained steady, while platinum and palladium saw gains. All three metals are on track for weekly gains.

site_title: Swiss-American eye care firm Alcon launches expanded Tuas manufacturing facility
summary: Alcon, a Swiss-American eye care firm, has launched an expanded manufacturing and logistics facility in Tuas, Singapore, marking the company's total investment in the country at over $600 million since 2005. The new facility features advanced automation, smart manufacturing systems, and industry 4.0 capabilities, supporting global demand for its contact lenses. Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling highlighted the partnership between Alcon and Singapore as an example of deep collaboration driving industrial growth and creating meaningful careers for Singaporeans, with the expansion expected to create new "high-value" jobs and support Singapore's ambition to grow its medtech workforce.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AEM, Aztech Global
summary: AEM raised its H1 revenue guidance to S$185-195 million, up from an earlier range of S$155-170 million, despite uncertainty in the business environment. The company maintained its view on the tariff situation. Meanwhile, Aztech Global's wholly owned subsidiary Huuve entered into a sale and purchase agreement to divest factory buildings and land in Malaysia for RM28.8 million (S$8.7 million). Both companies will report their earnings on August 13 and 14, respectively.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: IHH Healthcare unveils S$5 million programme to fund healthcare research and pilot projects
summary: IHH Healthcare launches a S$5 million programme to fund clinical research and pilot projects across its network, focusing on oncology and chronic diseases. 55 submissions were received, with 15 shortlisted projects selected for funding, including a study on Type 2 diabetes patients, a project on kidney failure, and an artificial intelligence-powered health application. The programme aims to empower IHH clinicians and employees to address critical health issues, with funds expected to be disbursed over five years.

Pantai Hospital KL is a hospital under IHH Healthcare

Despite the impact of medical inflation and the Ramadan fasting period on Malaysia, contributions from Island Hospital in Penang resulted in the segment’s revenue gaining 17 per cent year on year to RM1.1 billion.

site_title: UK made fewer vehicles for the fifth straight month in May as tariffs bite
summary: UK vehicle production declined 32.8% in May, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline, due to factory disruptions and US tariffs. Exports to the EU and US dropped 22.5% and 55.4% respectively. US President Donald Trump's 25% tariffs on imported automobiles and parts have disrupted global supply chains, adding costs for manufacturers. Despite this, a trade deal with India and a reaffirmed trade deal with the US offer some optimism for the industry, with up to 100,000 UK-made cars allowed to enter the US at a 10% tariff.
