site_title: Why Singapore’s fresh grads are struggling to get hired
summary: Singapore's fresh graduates are struggling to get hired, with only 79.5% of the 2024 cohort finding full-time permanent jobs, a 4.6-percentage-point drop from 2023 levels. The unemployment rate for graduates from private universities has jumped 8.4 percentage points year on year to 25.2%. Experts attribute this to a mismatch between university training and industry needs, shifting employer preferences, and AI disruption. The job market is also characterized by a trend towards non-traditional employment, with gig work, contract roles, and short-term work becoming more prevalent. While some observers see this as a cyclical fluctuation, others warn of a prolonged trend of higher unemployment among graduates.

site_title: ‘Mission: Impossible’ composer Lalo Schifrin dies aged 93
summary: Lalo Schifrin, the renowned composer of the 'Mission: Impossible' theme, has died at the age of 93. Born in Argentina, Schifrin blended classical, jazz, and modern sounds in his diverse film and television scores. He received an honorary Oscar in 2018 and worked on notable films like 'The Cincinnati Kid', 'Bullitt', and 'Dirty Harry'. Schifrin's legacy includes over 100 film scores and two Grammy music awards, cementing his place as a respected international orchestra conductor and jazz pianist.

Anna Wintour will continue to hold senior roles at Conde Nast and remain Vogue’s global editorial director.

site_title: China confirms trade deal framework reached with United States
summary: China and the US have reached a trade deal framework, with the US lifting "restrictive measures" and China reviewing and approving export-controlled items. The deal aims to address US concerns over China's rare earth metals, essential for electric vehicles, hard drives, and national defense equipment. China will also ease some non-tariff countermeasures, but US officials have accused Beijing of violating the pact and slow-walking export license approvals. The agreement comes after talks in Geneva and London, and could lead to a delay in steep tariffs set to expire on July 9.

images.alt_text: The delays are holding an array of American industries hostage to the rocky US-China relationship, as some firms wait for magnets and others face restrictions son elling to China.

May’s export volume of rare earth products fell by 61 per cent from a year earlier to 2,117 tons, the lowest level since February 2020.

site_title: Info-Tech Systems launches IPO at S$0.87 apiece, marks SGX’s first mainboard listing in two years
summary: Info-Tech Systems, a Singapore-based software services firm, has launched its initial public offering (IPO) at S$0.87 apiece, marking the Singapore Exchange's (SGX) first mainboard listing in two years. The company expects to raise S$23.4 million, primarily for research and development, sales, and marketing activities. Info-Tech Systems, which offers HR and accounting software, aims to grow its market share in Southeast Asia and globally. The IPO, managed by OCBC, will see 258 million shares listed, with an estimated market capitalization of S$224.5 million.

site_title: Europe: Stocks muted as investors gauge US interest rate outlook
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed up 0.09% at 537.48 points on Thursday, despite muted investor sentiment amid uncertainty over US interest rate outlook. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's comments hinted at potential rate cuts if not for tariffs, while US President Trump criticized Powell and hinted at a potential shake-up. The EU must decide on a deal with the US by July 9, a tariff pause deadline, with markets focused on the outcome.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 gained 0.8 per cent to 6,141.02 on Thursday, about three points shy of an all-time record.

site_title: Bumper orders for Xiaomi’s new SUV heighten threat to Tesla
summary: Xiaomi's new SUV, the YU7, received 289,000 orders in its first hour of sale, exceeding market expectations and undercutting Tesla's Model Y in price by nearly 4%. The strong initial orders sent Xiaomi's shares to a record high and raised speculation that Tesla may need to cut prices to compete. Analysts predict Tesla's Model Y will lose market share, further eroding the US automaker's ground in the electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: The Xiaomi YU7 SUV car is a hallmark of Xiaomi’s US$10 billion EV strategy as larger vehicles gain popularity across China.
Automakers issuing pledges on Wednesday included BYD, Chery and Geely. State-owned Guangzhou Automobile Group and FAW Group made their pledges on Tuesday evening.

Xiaomi founder and CEO Lei Jun introduced the Chinese smartphone maker's new electric SUV YU7 at a launch event in Beijing on May 22.

site_title: US: Stocks rise, S&P 500 ends just shy of record
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.8% to 6,141.02, just shy of an all-time record. The Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.9% and the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 1.0%. The gains were attributed to unexpected flexibility from President Trump's signals on extending a July tariff deadline and strong economic indicators. The market also benefited from solid earnings from chip company Micron and positive labour market data. Markets now look ahead to key US inflation data on Friday, which will guide future Federal Reserve decisions.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. site_title: Wall Street forecasts windfall for big US banks from Fed plan to ease leverage rule
summary: The US Federal Reserve unveiled a proposal to relax leverage rules for large global banks, which could free up as much as $6 trillion in balance sheet capacity and billions in capital. The plan aims to boost participation in US Treasury markets and is the first in a possible series of deregulatory moves. The proposal reformulates the "enhanced supplementary leverage ratio" to tie capital requirements to a bank's global role, with potential benefits including increased liquidity in financial markets and the US treasury market.

images.alt_text: Fed chair Jerome Powell has supported revisions to SLR standards to help bolster banks’ roles as intermediaries in the Treasury market.

Banks, which have spent years modernising their IT systems to speed up processes and shave costs in the wake of the financial crisis, have been flocking into the new generation of AI tools that could further improve productivity.

site_title: Recurring US jobless claims jump to highest since Nov 2021
summary: US jobless claims jumped to 1.97 million in the week ended June 14, the highest since November 2021, signaling a slowdown in hiring. Continuing claims, a proxy for those receiving benefits, increased, while initial claims decreased to 236,000. The US central bank left interest rates steady, citing solid labor conditions. This rise in jobless claims contrasts with a Conference Board survey that found the lowest measure of job availabilities since March 2021.

site_title: Data is changing shareholder capitalism
summary: US corporations' shift from prioritizing shareholder returns to considering other values is underway, with some CEOs, like Palantir's Alex Karp, expressing willingness to take a stance on progressive issues. A 2020 pledge by 181 top CEOs to prioritize all stakeholders over shareholders has largely been abandoned due to backlash and burnings of companies or executives taking political stances. This trend reflects the rapidly changing economy and growing recognition that companies must adapt to new expectations and values.

site_title: Decision on naming next Fed chair not ‘imminent’: White House
summary: The White House stated that no decision is imminent on naming a successor to Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, contrary to a Wall Street Journal report suggesting an announcement by September or October. President Donald Trump has expressed frustration with Powell's cautious approach to lowering interest rates, and has considered selecting and unveiling a replacement. The choice of successor could impact the Fed's interest rate path, raising concerns about the independence of the central bank. Trump's potential choices include former Fed governor Kevin Warsh and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.

images.alt_text: The US Fed unveiled a proposal on Wednesday that would overhaul how much capital large global banks must hold against relatively low-risk assets, as part of a bid to boost participation in US Treasury markets.

site_title: Iran says no plan for new US nuclear talks, plays down impact of strikes
summary: Iran has denied plans to resume nuclear talks with the US, after a 12-day war with Israel, and accused Washington of exaggerating the impact of US strikes. Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei hailed Iran's "victory" over Israel and vowed never to yield to US pressure. Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi said no agreement has been made to start new negotiations, and the country is suspending cooperation with the UN nuclear watchdog. The US had claimed the strikes had "obliterated" key facilities, but a leaked assessment suggests the damage may be less severe, delaying progress by only a few months.

site_title: Rolls-Royce Black Badge Spectre review: The dark side of luxury
summary: The Rolls-Royce Black Badge Spectre is a high-performance, fully electric luxury car that offers a more dynamic driving experience without compromising refinement. With a twin-motor setup delivering 585 horsepower and 900 Newton-metres, it accelerates from 0-100 km/h in 4.5 seconds. The "Infinity" button unlocks an additional 74 horsepower, while a "Spirited Mode" allows for launch control. The car features a recalibrated chassis, air suspension, and weighty steering, ensuring a connected drive. Personalization options are available through Rolls-Royce's Private Office programme, allowing clients to create a unique car.

site_title: Oil inches up on US demand strength; fading Middle East supply risks offset gains
summary: Oil prices rose on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling 5 cents higher to US$67.73 a barrel, as US demand strengthened during the summer driving season. Crude inventories in the US fell by 5.8 million barrels, exceeding expectations. Middle East supply risks, which had been a concern, eased, offsetting some gains. A weaker dollar also contributed to the increase, making oil less expensive for holders of other currencies.

site_title: Malaysia set to be ‘biggest beneficiary’ from surge in data centre investment in Apac: Barclays
summary: Malaysia and India are poised to benefit significantly from a surge in foreign direct investment in data centers in Asia-Pacific, driven by increased demand for data storage and cloud computing. The estimated annual FDI in data centers is expected to reach US$62 billion by 2030, with Malaysia projected to receive US$12 billion. India is expected to have the largest data center capacity in the region by the end of the decade, but its sector's size relative to its economy is smaller compared to others in the region.

images.alt_text: Tenaga Nasional expects Malaysia to add 6-8 gigawatts of gas-fired power by building new plants and extending the life of existing ones as it looks to cut dependence on coal.

site_title: Hong Kong’s equity capital markets bounce back in first half, as Shein IPO looms
summary: Hong Kong's equity capital markets experienced a significant rebound in the first half of 2025, driven by global investors seeking opportunities in China. The Hang Seng Index rose 21.2% year-to-date, making it one of the best-performing major markets globally. The revival was fueled by big-ticket capital raisings, A-to-H share deals, and the potential listing of fast fashion giant Shein in Hong Kong before the end of the year. This could help re-establish Hong Kong as a global fundraising center, amidst US trade policy volatility.

images.alt_text: HKEX has been striving to attract IPO hopefuls from elsewhere as part of its ambition to become a global capital raising platform.

site_title: S-E Asia’s e-commerce platform gross merchandise value growth rate eases: report
summary: South-east Asia's e-commerce platform gross merchandise value (GMV) grew 12% year-on-year in 2024, slowing from a 15.2% increase in 2023. Despite the deceleration, most countries achieved double-digit percentage increases, with Thailand and Malaysia leading the expansion. Indonesia remained the largest market, contributing 44% of the region's platform GMV. E-commerce giants Shopee and Lazada increased their regional market shares, while TikTok Shop moderated its growth due to a strategic adjustment. The region's e-commerce sector is operating at a significant scale, with parcel volumes comparable to the US.

site_title: US goods trade deficit widens in May as exports fall
summary: The US goods trade deficit widened 11.1% to $96.6 billion in May, driven by a $9.7 billion decline in exports to $179.2 billion. Goods imports remained unchanged at $275.8 billion. This increase may contribute positively to the GDP in the second quarter, but economists caution against interpreting it as a sign of economic strength due to softening data on retail sales, housing, and labor markets.

site_title: US reshoring spurs opportunities for Singapore in semiconductor, med-tech, other high tech sectors: RHB
summary: US President Donald Trump's reshoring efforts present opportunities for Singapore to deepen its role as a high-value manufacturing hub and global supply chain diversification partner. Singapore's manufacturing is focused on high-tech sectors such as semiconductors, med-tech, and pharmaceuticals, accounting for 20.6% of the country's GDP. Despite challenges, RHB Research believes Singapore can "thrive" in the long term by capturing advanced, niche production segments that require precision engineering and regulatory compliance.

site_title: Core inflation in Tokyo slows but stays above BOJ target
summary: Core inflation in Tokyo slowed to 3.1% in June, staying above the Bank of Japan's 2% target. This maintains market expectations for further interest rate hikes. The Tokyo consumer price index, excluding volatile fresh food costs, rose from a 3.6% increase in May. Central bank governor Kazuo Ueda has stated the BOJ will continue to raise borrowing costs to maintain inflation stability. Some BOJ board members have suggested decisive interest rate hikes if upward inflation risks intensify.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open near record peak as Micron results boost chip stocks
summary: US stock markets opened near a record high on Thursday, driven by strong earnings from Micron, a memory-chip maker. The S&P 500 rose 19.9 points, or 0.33%, to 6,112.09, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 88.6 points, or 0.44%, to 20,062.19. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also gained 101.6 points, or 0.24%, to 43,084.07. The robust earnings from Micron fueled optimism around artificial intelligence, boosting chip stocks.

site_title: US economy contracts more than estimated in first quarter
summary: The US economy contracted at an annual rate of 0.5% in the first quarter, more than the initially estimated 0.2% decline. The contraction was driven by downward revisions to consumer spending and exports. This was partly offset by a decrease in imports. The revision was attributed to US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs, which have led to businesses stockpiling goods ahead of the tariffs. The data adds to uncertainty in the economy, particularly with a July deadline approaching for higher tariff levels to kick in.

Jerome Powell’s second day of testimony on Capitol Hill this week comes after Fed officials left interest rates steady on Jun 18.

site_title: Salesforce CEO says 30% of internal work is being handled by AI
summary: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff stated that 30% of internal work at the company is being handled by AI, citing job functions such as software engineering and customer service. This is part of a broader trend, with tech leaders like Microsoft and Alphabet also touting AI's potential to replace human workers. Benioff believes AI can do tasks previously done by humans, allowing for a shift to higher-value work. The company's AI product has reached 93% accuracy, including for large customers like Walt Disney.

site_title: India's monsoon set to cover entire country over a week early
summary: India's monsoon season is expected to cover the entire country within the next three to four days, approximately a week ahead of schedule, according to senior weather officials. The monsoon, crucial for the country's nearly $4 trillion economy, delivers 70% of the rainfall needed to water farms and replenish aquifers. This early onset is expected to accelerate planting of summer-sown crops, particularly rice, corn, and sugarcane, in central and northern states.

images.alt_text: In India alone, rice stocks, including unmilled rice paddy, in government warehouses totalled 63.09 million tonnes on Apr 1, nearly five times a government target of 13.6 million tonnes.

site_title: Why India’s oil sector revamp may not be enough to attract foreign players
summary: India's oil sector has undergone a revamp with the Oilfields (Regulation and Development) Amendment Act, 2025, aimed at attracting foreign players. However, analysts say the changes may not be enough due to restrictive legacy procedures and poor economic incentives. The sector is dominated by national players, making it tough for international drillers to break in. Despite the government's efforts to improve transparency and legal clarity, investment risks remain, particularly due to lengthy permitting processes and a shortage of judicial officers. Foreign participation is expected to remain low, with international players forming less than 10% of India's total oil and gas production.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei

site_title: Anna Wintour steps down as US Vogue editor after nearly 40 years
summary: Anna Wintour, editor-in-chief of US Vogue for nearly 40 years, stepped down on Thursday after 37 years. Despite her departure from day-to-day editing, she will continue to hold senior roles at Conde Nast and remain global editorial director. Wintour, 75, will oversee global leadership and work with editors worldwide. Her departure follows the magazine's struggle to adapt to the digital era and the announcement of a new head of editorial content. Wintour, a fashion icon and influential figure, will continue to hold influential positions at Conde Nast.

images.alt_text: Firebird by Suetomi features a showstopping wood-burning grill.
Meh'r by Inderpal's cosy interiors.

site_title: Indian confusion at Meh’r by Inderpal
summary: Indian cuisine at Meh'r by Inderpal is a mixed bag, with some promising dishes and others that fall short. The restaurant's Masterchef-winning chef aims to redefine Asian comfort food, but execution is key. Standout dishes include lamb biryani, with its heavily spiced rice and tender lamb, and satay merah jambu, featuring grilled spiced mushrooms in peanut-free satay sauce. However, other dishes, such as bak bak wings and thosai matti, are overcomplicated and lack balance. Meh'r by Inderpal shows flashes of potential, but needs refinement to perfect its offerings. Rating: 5.5/10.

Firebird by Suetomi features a showstopping wood-burning grill.

site_title: The high cost of Trump’s brain drain
summary: US President Donald Trump's crackdown on elite universities, including Harvard, risks undermining US innovation and competitiveness by discouraging international students from enrolling. A decline in international-student enrollment could weaken the global pipeline of future scientists, diminishing research quality worldwide. Since 2000, US-based researchers have won nearly two-thirds of Nobel Prizes in chemistry, physics, and medicine, with many immigrants completing graduate studies at US universities. The Trump administration's move to strip Harvard of its ability to enroll international students has been blocked by a federal court, but the uncertainty remains unsettling for current and prospective students.

images.alt_text: US District Judge Allison Burroughs issued an injunction barring Donald Trump’s administration from carrying out its latest bid to curtail Harvard’s ability to host international students amid an escalating fight pitting the Republican president against the prestigious Ivy League school.
Student visa applicants will be asked to adjust the privacy settings on all their social media profiles to “public”, a senior US State Department official said.
No institution, though, has come under a bigger assault than Harvard, the country’s most pre-eminent university.

site_title: US durable goods orders soar in May
summary: US durable goods orders surged 16.4% in May, exceeding forecasts, after a revised 6.6% decline in April. Transportation equipment orders, driven by a 230.8% surge in commercial aircraft orders, led the rebound. Non-defence capital goods orders rebounded 1.7% after a 1.4% decline in April. Despite a strong first quarter, economic uncertainty from import tariffs and a softening economy suggest a wait-and-see approach from the Federal Reserve, which left interest rates unchanged.

images.alt_text: Exports of goods dropped US$9.7 billion to US$179.2 billion. Goods imports were little changed at US$275.8 billion.
This week a measure of job availabilities from a Conference Board survey that’s closely watched by economists fell to the lowest since March 2021.
The revision on Thursday mainly reflected “downward revisions to consumer spending and exports,” says the Commerce Department.

site_title: Indonesia signs wiretapping pacts with telco operators; analysts flag privacy concerns
summary: Indonesia has signed agreements with four telco operators to install wiretapping devices, allowing prosecutors to access telecommunication recordings and exchange data for law enforcement purposes. The 2021 law giving wiretapping authority to the Attorney General Office could enable surveillance on suspicion without formal charges or named suspects. Analysts flag concerns over privacy and mass surveillance, citing lack of clear limitations on wiretapping powers and potential for state agencies to do surveillance, threatening civil liberties.

images.alt_text: (From left to right) Hisham Hamdan of Khazanah Nasional Berhad, Pandu Sjahrir, Chief Investment Officer of Danantara, and Abdulla Al-Kuwari of QIA Advisory during the panel session at the Asia Economic Summit in Jakarta on Thursday (June 26).

This illustration photograph taken in Brussels on May 7, 2025 shows the logo of the Chinese social media application Tik Tok on a smartphone in front of a screen displaying an image of a skinny woman, as the "skinnytok" trend promoting thinness worries experts. (Photo by Nicolas TUCAT / AFP)
Indonesia’s sixth president, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono, at the Asia Economic Summit 2025 in Jakarta, Thursday (June 26).
Bank Indonesia is in an interest-rate cutting cycle and investors are redirecting funds from a set of rupiah-denominated tools into sovereign bonds.

site_title: Luxury sector pins hopes on Middle East despite clouds from conflict
summary: The luxury sector is pinning hopes on the Middle East, which has bucked a recent global slowdown in luxury sales. Luxury sales in Gulf countries rose 6% to $12.8 billion last year, outpacing a global 2% drop, driven by strong demand for high-end fashion, jewelry, and beauty products. Despite risks from conflict, the region's travel market has shown long-term resilience, with brands like Prada, Hermes, and Dior experiencing double-digit growth. Maintaining visitor numbers will be crucial to sustaining luxury sales in the Middle East.

images.alt_text: Traditional destinations such as Singapore, Australia, Canada, and New Zealand appear to be losing their appeal, with their lowest net inflows on record provisionally expected in 2025, said a report by Henley & Partners.
The Iran-Israel confrontation, which involved the US, poses one of the most stringent tests yet to UAE’s neutral and open-for-business stance.
Yacht makers are now honing in on the relatively untapped market after China’s push for common prosperity, and high taxes have posed challenges.

A luxury yacht off the French coast. According to McKinsey, the aspirational set, defined as those with between US$100,000 and US$1 million in net worth, spent US$84 billion on high-end vacations in 2023, a figure expected to grow to US$107 billion by 2028.
The gift is the latest example of how Trump’s private and official business have mixed together during his second White House term.
The M9’s most basic battery EV version starts from 509,800 yuan.
Versace, set to become part of Prada after a US$1.4 billion acquisition, cut prices for an average of just 3 per cent of its products on Tmall in the first quarter.

site_title: Britain vows to toughen its trade defences under new strategy
summary: Britain has announced a new trade strategy to toughen its trade defences amid a turbulent global outlook. The government plans to overhaul its trade remedies system to make it more accessible, assertive, and agile, and will adjust the Trade Remedies Authority's policy guidance and framework to tackle imports from countries with unfair market distortions. The strategy also aims to promote environmental goals, labour rights, and human rights, but critics warn that these ambitions may be severely tested in negotiations with countries like the Gulf Cooperation Council.

images.alt_text: epa11468182 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London, Britain, 09 July 2024. The British Retail Consortium has released data showing a 0.2 percent fall in retail sales for June compared to this time last year. Poor weather and the cost of living crisis have kept shoppers off the high street.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: ‘Long overdue’: Experts welcome advisory against private-sector use of NRIC numbers for authentication
summary: Singapore's government has released an advisory urging the private sector to stop using National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers for authentication, citing it as a weak security practice due to NRIC numbers being static identifiers. The government will develop sector-specific guidance for regulated sectors such as finance, healthcare, and telecommunications. Industry players welcome the move, with some having already moved away from using NRIC numbers for authentication, and experts recommend adopting stronger authentication methods like complex passwords or multi-factor authentication to bolster digital safety.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Therese Soh

“It is unsafe for organisations to use NRIC numbers in this manner because a person’s NRIC number may be known to others, permitting anyone who knows his NRIC number to impersonate him and easily access his personal data or records,” the Cyber Security Agency and Personal Data Protection Commission  said.

site_title: India, US trade talks face roadblocks ahead of tariff deadline
summary: Trade talks between India and the US have hit a roadblock due to disagreements on import duties for auto components, steel, and farm goods. India is pushing for a rollback of proposed 26% reciprocal tariff set to take effect on July 9, while US negotiators want deeper import tariff cuts on farm goods. An Indian delegation is expected to travel to Washington before the deadline, with discussions now focusing on a broader agreement.

site_title: Best places to blow off steam for men
summary: In Singapore, a city known for its fast-paced lifestyle, men can unwind and bond with friends at various unique venues. Axe Factor offers axe-throwing, while HomeTeamNS features action-packed facilities like paintball, obstacle courses, and airsoft-style missions. Red Dynasty Paintball Park and Sandbox VR provide immersive experiences through paintball and virtual reality, respectively. For a more creative outlet, Splat Paint House and The Fragment Room offer art studios and a rage room, respectively. Additionally, VOS Men provides an all-male vocal group for men to express themselves through music. These venues offer essential "maintenance" for high-strung individuals to reconnect with themselves and their mates.

images.alt_text: VOS Men is an all-male choir founded in 2022.

site_title: Who needs Accenture in the age of AI?
summary: Accenture CEO Julie Sweet believes clients will require more help with artificial intelligence (AI) than with earlier tech innovations, and the company is well-positioned to provide it. The consulting firm has generated a 370% total return since 2015, outperforming major indices and rival advisory firms. However, its market value has declined by $60 billion since its all-time high in February, following a disappointing quarterly earnings report.

images.alt_text: Julie Sweet, chief executive officer of Accenture Plc, speaks during the Business Roundtable CEO Workforce Forum in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, June 17, 2025. The event will explore how large employers are creating new pathways for workers, including efforts to expand opportunity in skilled trades and manufacturing roles. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

President Tharman Shanmugaratnam (left) and Mark Tham, country managing director of Accenture Singapore, at the company's 50th anniversary dinner, where it also announces that it will donate S$500,000 to the President's Challenge.
The company employs about 801,000 people, meaning the promotions in June will include about 6 per cent of its total workforce.

site_title: Amazon Web Services and Digital Industry Singapore launch programme to spur AI transformation
summary: Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Digital Industry Singapore have launched the AI Springboard programme to accelerate AI transformation among 300 Singapore-based enterprises, providing up to S$600,000 in cloud and training credits. The programme aims to help businesses become more competitive and create better jobs. Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling said AWS' initiatives will enable Singapore businesses to harness AI to enhance their products and services.

images.alt_text: Young Zhan Heng

Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling said that Singapore strongly believes in the transformative impact of AI, and supports the widespread use and adoption of AI across sectors
Dr. Janil Puthucheary, Senior Minister of State, Ministry of Digital Development and Information & Ministry of Health, delivering a speech at the launch of AWS Asia Pacific Hub on Feb 12, 2025.

site_title: Who controls Singapore’s national story? A play quietly asks
summary: A new play, National Memory Project, by Teater Ekamatra, explores the concept of memory and its role in shaping policy in Singapore. Set in a near future, the play follows a civil servant, Judy, who is tasked with obtaining a memory from a convict, Ahmad, to feed into a national AI system. Through their unlikely philosophical duel, the play delves into issues of control, technology, and the limits of memory. The production, featuring two actors speaking in multiple languages, raises questions about whose memories are being celebrated and whose are being erased, highlighting the complexity of national memory.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Chua Mia Tee's rarely-seen 1991 untitled painting of Lee Kuan Yew on the campaign trail was commissioned by former president Ong Teng Cheong.
Foo Kwee Horng's painting 'Majulah' (2016) is a spectral meditation on nationhood and memory.
Sophia Foo Chiao Lin's vivid and heartfelt painting 'Connection' is a previous winner of the 13-19 Art Prize.

site_title: Redefining brotherhood: The new language of male bonding in Singapore
summary: In Singapore, men are redefining brotherhood through unconventional outlets such as axe throwing, all-male choirs, and virtual reality experiences. The "always on" culture and pressure to succeed have led to increased stress and emotional numbness, prompting men to seek alternative ways to express themselves and connect with others. Non-traditional activities like singing, paintball, and VR experiences offer a safe space for men to release tension, build camaraderie, and redefine traditional notions of masculinity. As men explore these new avenues, they are embracing vulnerability, creativity, and emotional expression, leading to a new era of strength and wholeness.

images.alt_text: Aesthetic procedures are popular, but they're not without risks.

site_title: Asian markets in full swing as investors shake off trade jitters
summary: Asian markets have rebounded strongly from the April market turmoil, with the MSCI's Asia equities index jumping 25% to a four-year high. The region's currency gauge has also surged, with a slump in the US dollar creating space for interest-rate cuts. Companies are rushing to raise money, with blockbuster share sales raising over $90 billion. The rebound is attributed to a weakening US dollar and Trump's more flexible trade policies. Asian sovereign bonds have enjoyed a surge in inflows, with South Korea receiving over $39 billion so far in 2025.

Equity markets were mostly down, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Jakarta and Wellington in the red but Tokyo and Taipei in positive territory.
Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney and Singapore leading the gains across Asia.

site_title: Top Glove Q3 profit slides 31% to RM34.7 million despite higher revenue
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a 31% decline in net profit to RM34.7 million in Q3, despite a 30% increase in revenue to RM830.3 million. The decline was attributed to lower average selling prices and increased competition. Despite this, the company maintains a promising long-term outlook due to sustained global demand for gloves.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

A worker at a production line in Top Glove factory in Malaysia. The US raised tariffs on Chinese-made medical goves from 7.5 per cent to 50 per cent. But Malaysian glove makers were unable to raise prices in the US to the extent of the tariff increase because of competition.

site_title: Compassion International launches in Singapore; aims to tackle child poverty in Asia
summary: Compassion International, a US charity, has launched in Singapore with the goal of tackling child poverty in Asia. The charity aims to reach 420,000 more children across Asia by 2028, with Singapore serving as a regional hub to connect with more beneficiaries. Compassion currently supports over 2.3 million children in 29 countries, with a focus on child development, education, and access to critical needs. Singapore's strong economy, global outlook, and generous culture make it an ideal base for regional giving, and the charity plans to build awareness and engage individuals, churches, and businesses in the country.

images.alt_text: Dr Alicia Altorfer-Ong, executive director of Ray of Hope, says the charity serves “emerging and unmet needs” in the community.

site_title: South Korea to announce measures to cool house prices: report
summary: South Korea plans to announce measures to stabilize spiraling house prices in the greater Seoul area, including tightening lending and tax regulations, amid 21 consecutive weeks of price increases, the biggest in nearly seven years. The housing market's overheating has been a concern for the central bank, and President Lee Jae-myung's administration vows to improve affordability and expand housing supplies for middle- and low-income families. The measures aim to curb speculation and speculative sentiment, which have fueled demand and driven up prices.

images.alt_text: Governor Rhee Chang-yong has repeatedly cautioned that cutting rates too quickly could spur a rebound in household debt.
Consumer confidence in South Korea has now risen for a third straight month after plunging in December to the lowest level since the pandemic.

site_title: China tech firms ramp up M&A deals with the blessing of Beijing
summary: China's technology giants, Alibaba and Tencent, are making significant acquisitions as the government shifts its stance on regulation, allowing companies to invest in key areas such as artificial intelligence and robotics. Tencent has agreed to buy podcasting startup Ximalaya and a stake in SM Entertainment, while Alibaba has sold stakes in hypermarket chain Sun Art Retail Group and formed a joint venture with E-Mart's e-commerce platform. The government's support for the private sector has boosted investor confidence, leading to more deals and a normalization of regulation.

images.alt_text: In just a few months, JD, China’s largest online retailer by revenue, amassed 25 million daily takeout orders across 350 cities, capturing more than half the volume of Alibaba Group Holding’s Ele.me, the runner-up to market leader Meituan.
The move comes as Alibaba faces intensifying competition at home and pivots aggressively to AI.
Damai partners with brands such as Pokemon, Sanrio, and Chiikawa, and sub-licenses them to merchants.

The exam is also one of the most strictly controlled in China, to prevent cheating and ensure fairness.
The Hang Seng Tech Index, home to several of the "Terrific Ten" stocks such as Tencent, has surged almost 22 per cent this year.

site_title: Nato leaders’ price for supporting Ukraine is their self-respect
summary: NATO leaders are prioritizing supporting Ukraine's fight against Russia, with the US playing a crucial role in providing weapons supplies. In a summit in The Hague, European leaders stroked President Donald Trump's ego, seeking to maintain US support. Trump's behavior has raised concerns about the effectiveness of NATO's efforts, with some questioning the organization's ability to enforce its decisions. Despite this, the summit resulted in increased defense spending targets, with Germany committing $62.4 billion to its military in 2025. The US must intensify economic sanctions and increase weapons deliveries to Ukraine to sustain its struggle.

The 32-nation alliance heeded a call by Trump for other countries to step up their spending on defence to reduce Nato’s reliance on the US.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bonds fully allocated; 10-year average return drops to 2.49%
summary: The July tranche of Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) received S$353.7 million in applications, short of the S$400 million on offer, resulting in a 10-year average return of 2.49%, a drop from the previous tranche's 2.56%. This marks the second consecutive tranche with lower demand, following the June issuance. The decline in interest rates is attributed to the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep interest rates steady.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
The latest tranche offered a first-year interest rate of 2.2%, a drop from the 2.49% offered by the May issuance.

site_title: World Bank, IAEA to cooperate on nuclear power development, safety
summary: The World Bank and International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) agreed to cooperate on nuclear power development and safety, particularly in extending the lifespan of existing reactors and financing small modular reactors in developing countries. The partnership aims to build knowledge in nuclear safety, security, and energy planning, and to accelerate the adoption of low-carbon power sources. The World Bank President Ajay Banga and IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi signed a memorandum of understanding in Paris, marking a significant step towards the safe development and financing of nuclear power for developing countries.

images.alt_text: Only 8 per cent of South-east Asia’s investable listed companies have reported climate transition plans.
Contrary to popular belief, nuclear power has a good safety profile, noted DBS
TEPCO's crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in the town of Okuma, Fukushima prefecture, Japan, August 24, 2023.
The effort is a bid to meet a coming surge in electricity demand and help the US reclaim its edge in nuclear energy.

site_title: Indonesia working on new e-commerce tax rule in bid to target 'shadow economy'
summary: Indonesia is working on a new e-commerce tax rule requiring platforms to collect and pass on 0.5% of sales income from small and medium-sized sellers to tackle the "shadow economy". The rule could be introduced as early as next month and affects major e-commerce operators like TikTok Shop, Tokopedia, and Lazada. The regulation aims to improve supervision of the "shadow economy" and vendors who do not pay taxes, with potential penalties for late reporting.

images.alt_text: As ByteDance remakes Tokopedia in TikTok Shop’s image, merchants and employees worry it will be a hollowed-out version of its former self.

site_title: Philippines cuts 2025 GDP growth goal, trims inflation view
summary: The Philippine government has cut its economic growth target for 2025 to 5.5%-6.5% from the previous goal of 6%-8%. The downward revision is due to mounting challenges, including the impact of the Trump administration's trade war, oil price shocks from the Israel-Iran tensions, and a slower-than-expected economic expansion last quarter. The government has also narrowed its inflation assumption to 2%-3%. This revised outlook supports further monetary policy easing, particularly amid global uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 26)
summary: The Singaporean government has urged private sector organisations to stop using full or partial National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers for authentication, citing safety concerns due to the risk of impersonation and data breaches. The warning comes as foreigners scramble to seal property deals in Johor before a July 1 levy hike, while Singapore's factory output growth slows to 3.9% in May, beating estimates.

site_title: Frasers, Sekisui, CSC Land consortium tops nine bids for Dunearn Road site with S$1,410 psf ppr bid
summary: A consortium of Frasers Property, Sekisui House, and CSC Land has secured the top bid of S$491.5 million for a 99-year leasehold private housing site in Dunearn Road, Singapore, with a price of S$1,410 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The site can yield about 380 private homes and is part of the new Bukit Timah Turf City estate. The bid was 3.7% above the second-highest bid and reflects consensus on the site's attractiveness. The government has planned for 15,000 to 20,000 public and private housing units for the estate.

site_title: Spacs are back. What could go wrong this time?
summary: US special purpose acquisition companies (Spacs) have seen a surge in new listings this year, with $11 billion raised so far, despite lessons learned from the 2020-2022 boom and bust. While retail investor speculation has decreased, some concerns remain, such as misaligned incentives for insiders and the increasing focus on crypto companies. The regulatory environment has improved, with the SEC's new rules enhancing investor protections. However, the sector still faces challenges, including a grim track record of companies declining in value post-IPO and high redemption rates.

site_title: Trump says US and Iran will talk next week, Middle East war over for now
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that the US will meet with Iran next week, despite casting doubt on the need for a diplomatic agreement on the country's nuclear program. Trump disputed intelligence assessments that US strikes on key sites had set back Iran's program by only a few months, claiming the strikes had "obliterated" them. The comments come as a ceasefire between Israel and Iran ends 12 days of conflict, and Iran has signaled its readiness to resume talks. Trump warned that the conflict could start again, but also played down the prospect of sanctions relief for Iran.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump, seeking credit for ordering military action and then quickly announcing a ceasefire between Israel and Iran, has lashed out angrily at media accounts of a classified report that doubted the extent of damage to Iranian nuclear sites.

US President Donald Trump with US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth, US Vice President JD Vance and US Secretary of State Marco Rubio as he delivers an address to the nation at the White House following US strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, June 26, 2025
summary: Asian stocks experienced a mixed day, with some markets rebounding after a decline. The US dollar declined following a comment from Trump about potentially naming a new US Fed chair early. Japan reached a record of $232 billion in M&A deals, driving an Asia deals rebound. China also made headlines with the opening of its first offshore gold vault and contracts in Hong Kong.

Hong Kong is a well-established banking centre that’s seeking to keep pace with the expansion of other financial hubs in the region.

site_title: 💬 Why we keep using corporate jargon (even though we hate it)
summary: Corporate jargon originated from military lingo after World War II, with sports terms also being adopted into business language. The use of jargon signals belonging to an in-group and serves as a linguistic shortcut for communication within a specific field. While jargon can be useful, its overuse can be exclusionary and used to mask uncomfortable truths. Effective communication prioritizes clarity over buzzwords, and learning industry-specific terms is essential but not necessary to sound smart.

site_title: Indonesia’s sovereign wealth fund looks to invest abroad, with sights set on energy assets
summary: Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund, Danantara, is exploring global investment opportunities, particularly in the energy sector in the US. Its CIO, Pandu Sjahrir, emphasized the need for strategic benefits, such as technology transfer and capacity-building, in any overseas investment. Danantara aims to allocate up to 20% of its capital to overseas investments, following its recent support for Pertamina's acquisition of a stake in a Philippine renewable energy company. The fund also plans to hire international talent to accelerate capacity-building and improve operational efficiency.

site_title: Indonesia’s ex-president Yudhoyono urges Asean to beef up investment game amid global shifts
summary: Indonesia's former president Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono urges ASEAN nations to enhance investment appeal by improving trust, human capital, and regional narrative, as global shifts reshape the investment landscape. The region faces opportunities and risks as industries shift out of China due to US-China trade tensions. Yudhoyono emphasizes the need for diplomatic balance, maintaining relationships with China and the West, and investing in education and skills training to remain competitive. ASEAN nations must project a united front to attract long-term investment and shift the global perception of the region.

Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh said Vietnam’s government was in frequent communication with the Trump administration on tariffs.

site_title: Singapore’s millionaire inflow to halve in 2025: report
summary: Singapore is expected to see its lowest net inflow of millionaires on record in 2025, with a projected 1,600 millionaires moving there, down from 3,500 in 2024. In contrast, Thailand is emerging as a safe haven, with a projected 450 millionaire inflow, and China's millionaire outflow is slowing, with a net outflow of 7,800 expected. Meanwhile, the UK is expected to have the largest net outflow of millionaires, with 16,500 projected to leave, driven by tax reforms.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

“Most of our clients are Asian, so if their own currency is growing, that gives them more purchasing power for wealth management products,” Tan Su Shan, chief executive of Singapore’s biggest bank DBS Group.
Observers say it is still too early to tell if Forest City could truly become a wealth hub; more clarity needs to be given for its tax incentives and legal frameworks first.
The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.
Dubai – and the rest of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) – has become a strong magnet for private wealth and talent in recent years.

site_title: The world’s biggest users of cocaine are in Australia, New Zealand
summary: Australia and New Zealand are the world's biggest users of cocaine, per-capita consumption is most prevalent in these countries, according to the UNODC report. 3% of those aged 15-64 in Australia and New Zealand used cocaine in 2023, nearly double the proportion in the Americas and triple that in Europe. The report also highlights the rise of cocaine production, seizures, and use, making it the world's fastest-growing illegal drug market, with an estimated 316 million people using illicit drugs in 2023.
