site_title: China opens first offshore gold vault and contracts in Hong Kong
summary: China's Shanghai Gold Exchange (SGE) has expanded its presence to Hong Kong with the launch of two new gold contracts and a bullion vault. The move aims to broaden the exchange's international reach, strengthen China's influence in commodity markets, and boost Hong Kong's status as a financial hub. Trading will be conducted in yuan and settled by cash or physical delivery, with fees waived at the vault until the end of the year. The SGE seeks to promote the yuan's use in international trade and reduce China's reliance on the US dollar.

images.alt_text: SHFE, set up in 1999 and run by China’s government, offers trading in contracts from copper and steel to gold, crude oil and petrochemicals.

site_title: Government urges private sector to stop using full, partial NRIC numbers for authentication
summary: The Personal Data Protection Commission (PDPC) and Cyber Security Agency (CSA) in Singapore have advised private organizations to stop using full or partial National Registration Identity Card (NRIC) numbers for authentication, citing safety concerns for citizens from impersonation and data access. The Ministry of Digital Development and Information (MDDI) urged companies to transition away from this practice, recommending alternative methods such as strong passwords, security tokens, or fingerprint identification. This move aims to better protect citizens from potential data breaches and unauthorized access to their personal information.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Digital token service providers that only serve overseas customers will not be licensed by MAS.

site_title: Dining Out with BT: Singapore’s best restaurants for 2025
summary: The article "Singapore's best restaurants for 2025" highlights the top-rated eateries in Singapore, with a score of 7 and above, as awarded by Lifestyle editor Jaime Ee. The selected restaurants include Pizzeria Vincenzo Capuano, Pizza Studio Tamaki, Dill, Mansion 7, Keijo, Belimbing, Pulsii French Bistro, Imperial Treasure Huaiyang Cuisine, Sugarra, Spicy Moment, Yongfu Singapore, and Latido. These establishments offer a diverse range of cuisines, from Italian and Japanese to Scandinavian and Chinese, and are praised for their unique flavors, refined techniques, and welcoming atmospheres.

images.alt_text: Willow's Spring menu snacks.

site_title: AEM raises H1 FY2025 revenue guidance to up to S$195 million on pull-in of customer orders
summary: AEM, a semiconductor test solutions provider, raised its revenue guidance for the first half of FY2025 to between S$185 million and S$195 million, up from S$155 million to S$170 million. The revision comes from an unexpected pull-in of orders from a customer under a non-cancellable, long-dated purchase order programme. Despite the revision, AEM's business environment remains uncertain due to the current tariff situation. The company will provide guidance for the second half of the year when it reports its earnings on August 13.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
AEM, one of the biggest semiconductor companies in Singapore, has been housing its operations at its 52 Serangoon North workspace (Photo taken before the Covid-19 pandemic). Photo: AEM
AEM managed to reduce financial liabilities by 23.1 per cent to S$72.5 million and halve its debt-to-equity ratio to 0.1 time over the quarter, due to repayment of debt.

site_title: Bumble to lay off 30% of global workforce as dating apps struggle
summary: Bumble is laying off 30% of its workforce, affecting 240 roles, as the company struggles to retain Gen Z users in the online dating industry. Despite the layoffs, Bumble raised its second-quarter revenue forecast and plans to save $40 million annually. The move reflects new CEO Whitney Wolfe Herd's strategy of prioritizing user experience over revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Match Group Asia has two apps in its portfolio, Pairs and Azar, which are performing well, said chief executive officer Malgosia Green.

site_title: US hits back at accounts Iran moved uranium
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration pushed back against media accounts that questioned the extent of damage to Iranian nuclear sites after the US bombing. The administration denied reports that Iran may have moved enriched uranium before the strikes, with White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt stating the US had no indication of this. The US military said 14 bunker-buster bombs were dropped on three Iranian nuclear sites, but an initial classified assessment suggested the strike may not have destroyed key components, setting back Iran's nuclear program by only months.

images.alt_text: Excavators are used to clear the rubble outside the Evin prison complex in Tehran that was hit days ago by an Israeli strike, on June 25, 2025. The Israeli defence minister announced strikes on the prison and other domestic security agencies in Tehran on June 23. (Photo by Mostafa Roudaki / mizanonline / AFP)

US President Donald Trump with US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth, US Vice President JD Vance and US Secretary of State Marco Rubio as he delivers an address to the nation at the White House following US strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities.
China, the world’s biggest importer, gets about 14% of its crude from Iran.
Secretary of State Marco Rubio told Politico: “The bottom line is, they are much further away from a nuclear weapon today than they were before the president took this bold action.”

site_title: Asia: Stocks down with eyes on Mideast, dollar hit by Trump Fed comment
summary: Asia's stocks fell on Thursday amid uncertainty over the US-Iran ceasefire and US President Donald Trump's comments on Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell. The dollar dropped after Trump suggested he would replace Powell, fueling rate cut bets. Oil prices edged up for a second day, but gains were capped by OPEC's potential output increase. Despite this, equity markets remained subdued, with most countries not yet reaching deals with the US to avoid tariffs ahead of a July 9 deadline.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index lost steam after Tuesday’s best intraday jump in over a month, dipping 0.74 per cent to 536.98 on Wednesday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 0.3 per cent at 42,982.43 on Wednesday.

site_title: Malaysian agency to forfeit RM177 million linked to ex-PM probe: report
summary: The Malaysian Anti-Corruption Commission (MACC) plans to seek the forfeiture of RM177 million in assets and cash seized in its probe into former prime minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob. The probe focused on allegations of graft and money laundering related to funds used for publicity and promotion while Ismail was in office. Ismail, 65, is among a group of former prime ministers to be ensnared in the MACC's dragnet as Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim seeks to clamp down on corruption.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices little changed in May
summary: Hong Kong's home prices remained largely unchanged in May, edging up 0.03% from the previous month, following a revised 0.5% rise in April. This marks the fourth consecutive month of decline, with prices dropping 0.9% so far this year, the lowest level since 2016. The decline is attributed to higher mortgage rates, a weak economic outlook, and poor demand. Authorities have been trying to prop up the sector, but housing demand remains soft, with many professionals having left the territory. Realtors forecast home prices in 2025 could rise or fall by 5%.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong will maintain its currency’s peg to the US dollar as it is a key success factor, Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu says.
Hong Kong is a well-established banking centre that’s seeking to keep pace with the expansion of other financial hubs in the region.

site_title: Labubu’s biggest threat is not Wakuku, or Lafufu
summary: Labubu, a plush toy with pointy ears and serrated teeth, has become a global sensation, with sales exceeding $43 billion and a market cap worth more than Sanrio and Mattel combined. Its popularity has led to concerns about copycats, but Wakuku and Lafufu, counterfeit versions, are not significant threats. Instead, the biggest challenge for Labubu is its fragile resale market, where resellers have been reaping high profits, leading to a crash in prices. Pop Mart's efforts to manage the resale market are crucial to maintaining Labubu's luxury status and brand exclusivity.

images.alt_text: Data shows that at a global level, the company’s gross merchandise value increased by over 900 per cent year on year in North America, said CGS International analyst Charlotte Zhou.
Chinese consumers are also now far less enamoured with foreign goods simply because they are foreign.

Labubu dolls displayed at a Pop Mart store in Beijing, China, June 17, 2025. Even with the slump this week, Pop Mart has still gained about 170 per cent this year, making it the best performer in the MSCI China Index.

Labubu dolls at a Pop Mart store in Beijing. Labubu is a Nordic-inspired character and collectible plush toy designed by Hong Kong designer Kasing Lung. The dolls went viral after being displayed by celebrities like Rihanna and Dua Lipa.
People look at Labubu dolls at the flagship store of Pop Mart in Shanghai, China June 13, 2025. REUTERS/Go Nakamura
Pop Mart shares rose as much as 3.5 per cent on Friday, putting them on track for a fresh record close.
A human-sized Labubu figurine is displayed before an auction in Beijing, China Jun 6. The figurine was later sold for 1.08 million yuan.

site_title: Shell says it has no intention of making an offer for BP
summary: Shell has denied making a takeover offer for BP, quelling speculation that the two UK oil majors would combine. The statement, made in response to a report by the Wall Street Journal, means Shell is bound by the UK Takeover Code and cannot submit an offer for BP for six months. BP's shares jumped 10% after the report, but the company's poor performance, including a net zero strategy, has led to pressure from activist shareholder Elliott Investment Management.

images.alt_text: Shell CEO Wael Sawan said the rise in oil and gas prices in recent days has been “moderate” as investors wait to see whether physical infrastructure might be damaged.

“This decision stands as a resounding vote of confidence from a world-class investor in our sound economic policies, clarity in our leadership, and promise in our future,”  Malaysia’s Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said.
Shell is evaluating a potential acquisition of BP, but is taking a cautious wait-and-see strategy.
BP has been battling prolonged underperformance stemming in large part from a net-zero strategy embraced by its former chief executive officer Bernard Looney.

site_title: Bishan to get over 2 million sq ft of  office space, new integrated development
summary: Minister for National Development Chee Hong Tat announced plans to develop Bishan as a business node, adding over 2 million square feet of new office space. The integrated development will include community amenities like a polyclinic, hawker centre, and revamped bus interchange. Works are set to begin within this term of government, with a completion period spanning several years. The development aims to grow decentralised office spots across the island, following the unveiling of the Draft Master Plan 2025.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

rydmp25 - An artist’s impression of the pedestrian mall linking future developments and community facilities within Bishan Sub-Regional Centre. 

Credit: URA

rydmp25 - An artist’s impression of the mixed-use hub planned for the new Paterson neighbourhood on top of Orchard MRT station.  

Credit: URA
Active participation by private property developers and more migration will help in Singapore's urban transformation.

site_title: Japan hits M&A record of US$232 billion, driving Asia deals rebound
summary: Japan drove Asia's mergers and acquisitions (M&A) rebound in 2025 with a record US$232 billion in deals in the first half, more than tripling in value from the same period last year. Despite global economic uncertainty, Japanese firms continue to seek growth opportunities abroad, with a strong pipeline of potential deals involving private equity firms. Key transactions include Toyota and Nippon Telegraph taking private subsidiaries for US$34.6 billion and US$16.5 billion, respectively. Bankers expect the trend to sustain, fueled by low interest rates and government calls for better corporate governance.

images.alt_text: Japan's au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose to 50.4 from May’s final 49.4, ending 11 months of readings below the 50.0 threshold that indicate contraction.

In a quarterly outlook report released on May 1, the BOJ cut its price forecasts and said underlying inflation will stagnate for some time as uncertainty on US trade policy weighs on the export-reliant economy.
Tokyo is scrambling to find ways to get Washington to exempt its automakers from 25 per cent automobile industry-specific tariffs.

site_title: Vietnam PM expects US trade deal before July tariff deadline
summary: Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh expects a trade deal with the US before July's tariff deadline, citing frequent communication with the Trump administration on tariffs. Vietnam seeks to avoid a 46% tariff rate, which was initially imposed due to its substantial trade surplus with the US. The country has held several rounds of negotiations and is willing to reduce non-tariff barriers and expand imports of US goods. Vietnam's trade surplus with the US climbed to $12.2 billion in May, with exports to the US surging 42% from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh looks on during a meeting with Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (not pictured) ahead of the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Putrajaya on May 25, 2025. (Photo by HASNOOR HUSSAIN / POOL / AFP)

Rendering of the Alpha City project at No. 87 Cong Quynh Street in Ho Chi Minh City's District 1. This prime location is one of the key projects Van Thinh Phat Group plans to co-develop with partner investors as part of its 12-year plan to remedy the consequences of Truong My Lan's fraud case.
The deal was originally part of Sembcorp’s plans to acquire a 245 MW renewables portfolio in Vietnam
The court ruled in April that Truong My Lan must compensate Saigon Commercial Bank a total of 674 trillion dong – an amount Lan appealed against but still committed to repay “at all costs”.

site_title: SBF proposes 1-2 year extension of compliance deadline for SGX listcos’ climate-related disclosures
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has proposed extending the compliance deadline for small- and mid-sized companies listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to make climate-related disclosures by one to two years. This recommendation aims to give smaller companies more time to strengthen internal capabilities and incorporate best practices in sustainability reporting. The proposal is in response to concerns from smaller listed companies, which make up 84% of SGX listings, about meeting the original deadline of January 1, 2025.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
From left: CEO of WBCSD  Peter Bakker, chairman of NEA and founding president of Singapore Green Building Council Lee Chuan Seng and CEO of SBF Kok Ping Soon.

site_title: Indonesia’s yield curve may steepen as Bank Indonesia unwinds intervention
summary: Indonesia's sovereign yield curve is set to steepen as Bank Indonesia reduces its use of short-term rupiah securities, prompting a shift in demand towards government bonds. The central bank's interest-rate cutting cycle and investors redirecting funds from SRBI securities into sovereign bonds is expected to lower government borrowing costs and support the economy. The amount of outstanding SRBI notes has declined 17% since November, with the latest auction seeing record-low prices for 6- and 9-month notes, making shorter-dated bond yields more attractive.

images.alt_text: Traffic outside the Bank Indonesia headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia. Photographer: Rosa Panggabean/Bloomberg
BI will continue to pay close attention to global and domestic dynamics and maintain exchange rate stability.
BI has cut interest rates three times since September and downgraded its economic growth outlook twice this year.

site_title: Mars US$36 billion Kellanova deal waved ahead by US regulator
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has given regulatory approval to Mars' $36 billion takeover of snack maker Kellanova, stating the deal "does not meet the standard for an anticompetitive merger". The European Union has opened a probe into the deal, which will assess the impact on product prices for consumers. Mars will acquire several popular snack brands, including Pringles chips, and expects to close the deal by the end of 2025.

images.alt_text: Buying Kellanova will bring brands including Pringles potato crisps and Cheez-It cheese crackers to Mars.
Depending on its final size, Mars' bonds offering could feature among the top 10 largest M&A financing deals in the investment-grade bond market since 2013, according to Informa Global Markets data.

site_title: SGS bond demand to stay high as safe havens sought amid tariff risks, Middle East tensions: RHB
summary: Demand for Singapore Government Securities (SGS) bonds is expected to remain high amid investor caution due to tariff uncertainty and Middle East tensions. Analysts from RHB predict a continued rally for SGS bonds, driven by traders' flight from US assets, with the 10-year yield trending lower at 2.28%. The analysts attribute Singapore's safe-haven status to its resilient economy, sound fiscal position, and stable macroeconomic fundamentals, which will continue to attract risk-averse capital inflows.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The latest tranche offered a first-year interest rate of 2.2%, a drop from the 2.49% offered by the May issuance.

site_title: North Korea opens landmark coastal Wonsan tourist zone
summary: North Korea has completed the construction of a massive 20,000-capacity tourist zone in Wonsan, a coastal city on its east coast. The zone, which was driven by leader Kim Jong Un, will open to domestic guests on July 1. The project is part of Kim's efforts to promote tourism and rebuild Wonsan into a billion-dollar destination. The tourist zone was attended by Kim and Russian officials, marking a potential boost to tourism in the reclusive country, which has been slowly lifting restrictions since 2023.

images.alt_text: Kim visited lines for pressing metals and assembly on Friday, checked the progress of shell production in the first half of 2025, and suggested new tasks for improvement, KCNA said.

site_title: Singapore’s factory output growth slows to 3.9% in May, but beats estimates
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 3.9% in May, beating estimates, but at a slower pace than the previous month. The growth was driven by front-loading ahead of US President Donald Trump's tariffs, but economists warn that the boost may be cooling down. The electronics sector, including infocomms and consumer electronics, saw significant increases, while some sectors like computer peripherals and data storage declined. The biomedical manufacturing cluster also recorded a 6.1% year-on-year increase. Despite this, economists caution that the slowdown in trade and industrial production may continue in the second half of 2025, driven by uncertainty in US tariff negotiations.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Front-loading drives Singapore’s factory output growth, which slows to 5.9% in April but far exceeds estimates

site_title: US Federal Reserve releases plan to relax key bank capital rule
summary: The US Federal Reserve announced plans to relax a key bank capital rule, reducing the enhanced supplementary leverage ratio (eSLR) for the largest banks from 5% to 3.5-4.5%. The move aims to build resilience in US Treasury markets and reduce the likelihood of market dysfunction. The proposal, which was first reported last week, has been met with mixed reactions, with some industry leaders and regulators expressing support, while others, including Senator Elizabeth Warren, have raised concerns about the potential impact on financial stability. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation will also follow with its own meeting on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Jerome Powell’s second day of testimony on Capitol Hill this week comes after Fed officials left interest rates steady on Jun 18.
“I know within three or four people who I’m going to pick,” US President Donald Trump told reporters when asked if he is interviewing candidates to replace Powell.

WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 18: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting on June 18, 2025 in Washington, DC. Despite President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25% to 4.5%.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Thursday amid mixed regional trading; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.3% to 3,938.46, with 294 gainers outnumbering 185 losers, following mixed regional trading. DFI Retail Group was the top gainer, rising 2.6% to US$2.75. Market sentiment has rebounded amid tariff de-escalation, with expectations of fewer interest rate cuts and upward revisions to regional GDP growth. However, a key downside risk is the short time frame before reciprocal tariff suspensions expire.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

Generic photograph of Singapore Airlines (SIA) plane and SATS vehicle at Changi Airport.
Caption: 新航 ，旅客，机场，旅客量，入境旅客，旅游，樟宜机场， SQ, SIA, ICA, Tourist, Immigration
Generic image of the Singapore skyline

site_title: SingPost halves sacked CEO Vincent Phang’s pay to S$616,400 as it pursues automation, leadership reset
summary: SingPost's former CEO Vincent Phang received a payout of S$616,400 for the financial year ended March 31, down from S$1.2 million the previous year. Phang was dismissed in December for handling a whistleblower report negligently. The company has announced a leadership reset and is pursuing automation and eCommerce logistics to support future growth. A new group CEO has yet to be appointed, and the board has proposed a one-off ex-gratia payment to outgoing chairman Simon Israel, which he declined.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin

Vincent Phang, CEO of homegrown ST Logistics and Toll Group's Singapore executive vice-president for global logistics, says that in Singapore, where resources are limited, the idea of shared resources and shared capacities is appealing.
SingPost’s operating profit in H2 for its Singapore postal and logistics segment falls 55.5% year on year to S$7.4 million, from S$16.6 million.
SingPost website showed it has 42 post offices remaining, after shuttering about a dozen in recent years amid secular decline of the sector. T
Teo Swee Lian will also be appointed as an additional member of the finance and investment committee, compensation committee and nominations and corporate governance committee.
From left: Group CEO Vincent Phang, group CFO Vincent Yik, and CEO of the company’s international business unit Li Yu.
SingPost’s fired CEO Vincent Phang resigns from board

site_title: Civmec set to acquire ship manufacturer Luerssen Australia for A$20 million
summary: Civmec, a construction and engineering services provider, is set to acquire Luerssen Australia for A$20 million in cash. The acquisition aims to consolidate Australia's sovereign shipbuilding capability under a single unit, enhancing national resilience and supporting long-term defence industry growth. Luerssen Australia, a subsidiary of a German shipyard, specializes in designing, manufacturing, and servicing yachts, naval, and coastguard vessels. The deal has a target completion date of July 1, and Civmec will retain a pre-agreed level of working capital within Luerssen Australia.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Civmec’s newly completed assembly and sustainment facility at Henderson in Western Australia.
Civmec has secured a new contract for a shiploader project that will utilise its Henderson facility in Australia.

site_title: Partial offer for Cordlife lapses with Thai-listed Medeze obtaining less than 1% stake
summary: A partial offer for a 10% stake in Cordlife Group by Medeze Treasury, a subsidiary of Thai-listed Medeze Group, has lapsed after securing less than 1% of the required shares. The offer aimed to provide services to Cordlife customers, but was deemed unfair and unreasonable by an independent financial adviser. As a result, Medeze Treasury now owns 2.4 million shares, representing 0.95% of the company's shares. The offer's failure marks a setback for Medeze Group's entry into the Singapore market.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Cordlife staff inspecting

site_title: Tokyo’s rising rents show inflation cycle deepening for Bank of Japan
summary: Tokyo's apartment rents rose 1.3% in April and May, the largest gains since 1994, indicating Japan's inflation cycle is deepening. This increase backs the case for further interest rate hikes by the Bank of Japan, which features the property market as a key topic in its semi-annual financial system report. Rising mortgage costs, stagnant rent for decades, and higher maintenance costs are driving the trend, with foreign investors accelerating the shift. The BOJ's 2% inflation target has been exceeded for over three years, and rent accounts for 20% of Japan's overall inflation basket.

images.alt_text: Japan's au Jibun Bank flash Japan manufacturing purchasing managers’ index (PMI) rose to 50.4 from May’s final 49.4, ending 11 months of readings below the 50.0 threshold that indicate contraction.

In a quarterly outlook report released on May 1, the BOJ cut its price forecasts and said underlying inflation will stagnate for some time as uncertainty on US trade policy weighs on the export-reliant economy.
Tokyo is scrambling to find ways to get Washington to exempt its automakers from 25 per cent automobile industry-specific tariffs.
Japan is struggling to reach a deal with Washington in tariff negotiations, clouding the outlook for its economy, which is heavily reliant on automobile shipments to the US.

site_title: Trump sees ‘progress’ on Gaza, raising hopes for ceasefire
summary: US President Donald Trump said progress is being made to end the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza, citing a ceasefire agreed on between Israel and Iran's backer. Trump's special envoy Steve Witkoff told him "Gaza is very close" to a resolution. A new ceasefire push has begun, with Qatar announcing a new effort and Hamas saying talks have intensified. However, Hamas has not received new proposals to end the war, and Israeli forces continue to search for hostages. The war has resulted in over 56,000 civilian deaths and widespread famine-like conditions in Gaza.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron with Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Micron forecasts revenue above estimates on AI-driven memory chip demand
summary: Micron Technology forecasts fourth-quarter revenue above Wall Street estimates, driven by strong demand for its memory chips used in artificial intelligence (AI) hardware. The company expects revenue of $10.7 billion, with an adjusted gross margin of 42% plus or minus 1%. This follows a 50% increase in third-quarter sales of high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips, which are used in AI applications. The forecast suggests robust demand for AI-related products, fueled by investments from cloud companies like Google.

images.alt_text: Micron is seeing strong demand for components used in data centre machines that develop and run AI software. Its traditional markets have been weaker. B
Micron president and chief executive officer Sanjay Mehrotra said that he was “extremely impressed” by how fast the government worked to bring the project to reality.

site_title: Gold inches higher as dollar softens, focus shifts to US economic data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $3,334.80 per ounce, supported by a softer US dollar and anticipation of US economic data. Investors await GDP data and Personal Consumption Expenditures data for hints on the Federal Reserve's interest rate direction. The US dollar declined 0.2% against rivals, making gold less expensive for overseas buyers. Investors anticipate 64 basis points of Fed rate cuts by the end of the year, citing significant inflation risk.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index hovered near a one-week low, making greenback-priced gold more attractive to overseas buyers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, Sembcorp, Keppel, Cordlife, CapitaLand India Trust, Civmec, ASL Marine
summary: Singapore Airlines' CEO Goh Choon Phong received a S$7 million remuneration package, 13.5% lower than FY2024. The airline also announced a 7.45-month profit-sharing bonus for eligible employees. Sembcorp Industries' Sembcorp Solar Vietnam faces a delay in acquiring a 49-megawatt hydropower asset in Vietnam due to pending government approvals. Keppel partnered Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank for sustainable infrastructure investments and financing opportunities. Cordlife's partial offer for a 10% stake in its private cord-blood bank lapsed after securing less than 10% of shares needed. Civmec acquired Luerssen Australia for A$20 million, while ASL Marine reported a fire at a Batam shipyard that killed four workers and injured five.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
Across the broader market, advancers outnumbered decliners 333 to 170, after 1.5 billion securities worth S$1.5 billion were traded.

site_title: Chinatown Business Association seeks S$77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over use of outdoor area
summary: The Chinatown Business Association (CBA) is seeking S$77,724.18 in backdated rent from Nanyang Old Coffee for using an outdoor refreshment area. CBA is also demanding the removal of encroaching items and payment of S$5,500 in legal costs. The outdoor area, located at the junction of South Bridge Road and Smith Street, has been used by the cafe since 2024.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
The tender for the Smith Street rejuvenation project will be based on price, quality and capex, says SLA.

site_title: US: Nvidia at new record as stocks end mixed
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.3% and the S&P 500 flat, amid lingering concerns over Iran. However, Nvidia surged to a fresh record, gaining 4.3% to a market valuation of $3.76 trillion, as CEO Jensen Huang presented the company's latest technologies. Investors are reevaluating US intelligence on Iran, and markets are approaching new all-time highs, with some analysts predicting a potential break-through.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Foxconn nears deal to supply electric buses to Mitsubishi Fuso: report
summary: Foxconn is nearing a deal to supply electric buses to Mitsubishi Fuso Truck and Bus, with plans to create a new company to oversee the buses. The Taiwanese chipmaker intends to roll out the Model T and Model U buses in Japan in 2027. Mitsubishi Fuso will sell the buses under its own brand, with the companies aiming to develop a new business model.

site_title: Tech giants’ net zero goals verging on fantasy: researchers
summary: Tech giants' climate goals are fading as their energy consumption doubles in the past three to four years, mainly due to the rapid expansion of artificial intelligence. Researchers have deemed the climate strategies of Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon as "poor," while Apple's and Microsoft's as "moderate." The sector's operational emissions are nearly 300 million tonnes of CO2 in 2023, and if the downstream use of products and services is considered, it would rank fifth in greenhouse gas emissions. The report suggests that the sector's growth is unlikely to be constrained without regulatory action, and recommends ways for tech companies to curb their carbon footprint, including using renewable electricity and increasing the lifespan of devices.

images.alt_text: Netflix has scaled back the number of movies it plans to make, though it still churns out more than almost anyone in Hollywood, while Apple is ramping up.
Apple has met multiple times in recent months with Perplexity, and its AI team has been actively evaluating the technology.
Siemens' selling point is that it knows industry because it makes things, including robots and gas turbines.
The Oakley versions can make and take phone calls, play music, take pictures and video and use Meta’s AI to answer questions about the surrounding environment.
More than two-thirds of European businesses said they struggle to understand their responsibilities under the EU AI Act, according to a survey by Amazon Web Services.

site_title: Johor’s billion-ringgit property market braces for higher foreign-buyer tax
summary: Johor's billion-ringgit property market is bracing for a 3% levy hike on foreign property purchases, effective July 1, with a minimum of RM30,000 (S$9,060). Industry players are concerned about the short notice, particularly among Singaporean investors. Despite the hike, interest in Johor remains resilient, with developers and real estate professionals citing the progress of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) and the RTS Link as major game-changers. The levy will not apply to sale-and-purchase agreements signed before the deadline, and some buyers are adopting a wait-and-see stance.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Effective July 1, Johor will raise the levy on foreign property purchases to 3 per cent or a minimum of RM30,000 (S$9,060)

site_title: US dollar slips as Trump considers naming next US Fed chair early
summary: The US dollar slid to its lowest level in three years amid growing expectations that the next US Federal Reserve chairman will ease monetary policy earlier than anticipated. US President Donald Trump is reportedly considering naming a new chair by September or October, increasing pressure on current chair Jerome Powell to lower interest rates. This has led to a boost in bets on Fed rate cuts and a decline in the dollar's value, with some traders viewing it as a signal that early interest-rate cuts are becoming more likely.

images.alt_text: The latest measures aim to not just facilitate trade but also open China’s financial markets and embed the yuan more deeply in investment flows.

The US dollar index, which earlier over the weekend crept up towards the key 100 threshold after US President Donald Trump posted about air strikes on Iran, sank further after a ceasefire was announced Tuesday morning Asian time.
The greenback has risen about 0.9 per cent since the conflict started, but it’s a relatively small move given the US currency’s traditional role as a haven in times of turmoil.

site_title: Bank of Korea overhauls repo framework amid changing liquidity conditions
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) is overhauling its open market operation framework to manage liquidity, stabilize short-term rates, and respond to financial stress. Starting July 10, the central bank will conduct both buying and selling of repurchase agreements on fixed days, shifting away from a model focused on liquidity absorption through sales. The overhaul aims to increase operational flexibility, manage short-term funding mismatches, and address volatility in the market due to Korea's shrinking current account surplus and growing outbound investment.

images.alt_text: Governor Rhee Chang-yong has repeatedly cautioned that cutting rates too quickly could spur a rebound in household debt.
The BOK governor says that Korea’s market-based measures are harder to interpret due to limited market depth.
Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong said that all six members of the board are open to a rate cut over the next three months.

site_title: US Federal Reserve’s Powell says tariff-driven inflation remains a big question
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that the impact of tariffs on consumer prices remains uncertain, with questions about who will bear the costs. Powell expressed caution against lowering interest rates, citing a strong economy and uncertainty over inflation. Despite pressure from President Donald Trump to lower rates, Powell repeated his message that officials should not rush to make decisions. Two Fed governors have suggested lowering rates as early as July if inflation remains contained, but Powell remains hesitant.

images.alt_text: “I know within three or four people who I’m going to pick,” US President Donald Trump told reporters when asked if he is interviewing candidates to replace Powell.

WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 18: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting on June 18, 2025 in Washington, DC. Despite President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25% to 4.5%.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

The comments by Federal Reserve vice-chair for supervision Michelle Bowman (pictured) came days after Fed governor Christopher Waller also said the bank could lower rates as soon as next month - amid differences among officials on how they should respond to levies.
Last week, the Fed held interest rates steady at 4.25 to 4.5 per cent and signalled uncertainty remains elevated about the effects of Trump’s tariffs on the economy.

site_title: Europe: Shares sag as investors weigh Iran-Israel ceasefire
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.74% to 536.98 on Wednesday, weighed down by concerns over the fragility of the Israel-Iran ceasefire. Despite a boost in defence stocks, major regional bourses closed lower, with Spain, Germany, France, and Britain all shedding 0.6-0.8%. Investors remain cautious ahead of the US tariff pause deadline on July 8, with the EU scrambling to secure trade deals. Analysts expect consolidation and potential bearishness in European stocks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 0.3 per cent at 42,982.43 on Wednesday.

site_title: Tech lobby group urges EU leaders to pause AI Act
summary: A tech lobbying group, CCIA Europe, has urged the European Union to pause the implementation of the AI Act, citing concerns that a rushed roll-out could jeopardize the continent's AI aspirations. The group argues that critical provisions are still missing, and that a pause is needed to ensure the act is implemented correctly. This comes after a survey found that over two-thirds of European businesses struggle to understand their responsibilities under the act, and as some leaders, including Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson, have called for a pause.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A copy of "The European Union Artificial Intelligence (AI) Act" on display during the AI & Big Data Expo 2025 at the Olympia, in London, Britain, February 5, 2025. REUTERS/Isabel Infantes/File Photo
Siemens' selling point is that it knows industry because it makes things, including robots and gas turbines.

The emergence of DeepSeek triggered a rally in China’s tech stocks, fuelling optimism over Chinese competitiveness despite tensions over trade with the Trump administration and economic challenges at home.
A stunning 77 per cent of teens and 20-somethings use online platforms and social media to answer their money questions, according to a 2025 Credit Karma survey.

site_title: HSBC sees ‘huge opportunities’ for Singapore businesses in India’s fast-changing economy
summary: HSBC sees significant business opportunities for Singapore companies in India's rapidly evolving economy, particularly in technology, healthcare, renewables, and data centers. The bank's CEOs highlight key areas of growth, including India's expanding consumer market, dynamic capital markets, and trade complexities. Singapore has been a leading source of foreign direct investment in India, with cumulative investments totaling nearly US$175 billion. HSBC's advisory role will help clients navigate these complexities, including foreign exchange controls and trade regulations.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

The Bombay Stock Exchange in Mumbai.  Indian stocks are now positioned for more gains after the central bank on Friday delivered a bigger-than-expected interest rate cut and injected further liquidity into the banking system.

site_title: CapitaLand India Trust prices S$100 million perpetual securities at 4.4%
summary: CapitaLand India Trust priced S$100 million in subordinated perpetual securities at 4.4% fixed rate under its S$1.5 billion debt issuance programme. The securities will be issued on July 2 and listed on the Singapore Exchange on July 3. Net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings, repay loans, and finance business activities. DBS, UOB, JP Morgan Securities Asia, and Deutsche Bank are joint lead managers for the issuance.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Navi Mumbai data centre.
The impact of US tariffs on the Indian economy could be beneficial in the medium term, the manager of CLINT said.

site_title: The Integrated Shield Plan is broken
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield insurance scheme is broken, according to a letter to the editor, citing examples of insurers raising premiums and introducing co-payments, despite claims being lower than expected. Insurers should take responsibility for their mistakes and apply new rules to new policies, rather than passing the burden to policyholders. Many existing policyholders, like the author, have been locked into contracts and cannot switch insurers due to age, leaving them financially strained. The government must take the lead in studying reforms to protect policyholders.

images.alt_text: Mount Elizabeth Hospital.
A more mindful approach to healthcare consumption has also been cited as a way to ensure long-term sustainability and affordability for all policyholders.

site_title: Xiaomi launches YU7, undercutting Tesla’s Model Y on price
summary: Xiaomi has launched its new electric SUV, the YU7, priced at 253,500 yuan (S$45,102), undercutting Tesla's Model Y by almost 4%. The YU7's base model costs 10,000 yuan less than the Model Y in China. The company aims to challenge Tesla's dominance in the world's largest auto market and has partnered with several manufacturers to build an ecosystem connecting humans, homes, and cars. The YU7 has a driving range of up to 835 km per charge and is Xiaomi's second car since entering the auto sector last year.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi founder and CEO Lei Jun introduced the Chinese smartphone maker's new electric SUV YU7 at a launch event in Beijing on May 22.
Xiaomi’s founder Lei Jun gives viewers a sneak peek at its Xring O1 chip.
Xiaomi has invested 13.5 billion yuan to self-develop its advanced mobile chip XringO1, founder Lei Jun said.

site_title: Microsoft and OpenAI dueling over artificial general intelligence: report
summary: Microsoft and OpenAI are at odds over a contractual provision related to artificial general intelligence (AGI). Under current terms, when OpenAI achieves AGI, Microsoft's access to the technology would be void. Microsoft wants OpenAI to remove this clause, but OpenAI has refused. The two companies have a long-term partnership, with Microsoft investing $1 billion in OpenAI in 2019, but negotiations over OpenAI's transition to a public-benefit corporation have stalled.

site_title: Storm clouds gather as European leaders meet
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen faces a challenging agenda at this week's European Council meeting, with geopolitical challenges crowding out her competitiveness agenda. The EU is frustrated by its lack of influence in the Middle East, and rising tensions with Russia and the US. Von der Leyen hopes to deliver on her reform agenda, including a competitiveness report and a Clean Industrial Deal, but the EU is concerned that her second term may get blown off course due to growing risks from international and domestic challenges, including anti-EU sentiment and the assertive Russia.

images.alt_text: European Commission President Ursula Von der Leyen reacts during a NATO summit in The Hague on June 24, 2025. (Photo by NICOLAS TUCAT / AFP)

site_title: Trump says he is considering three or four candidates for next Fed chair
summary: US President Donald Trump stated he knows three to four potential candidates for the next Federal Reserve chair, including Kevin Warsh, Kevin Hassett, Christopher Waller, and Scott Bessent. Trump has previously criticized Fed Chair Jerome Powell, saying he is "terrible" and considering replacing him. The potential candidates are reportedly contenders for the position, which is set to become available in May 2026. Trump's intentions are seen as an attempt to influence monetary policy, despite Fed chairs typically being insulated from presidential dismissal.

images.alt_text: WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 18: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting on June 18, 2025 in Washington, DC. Despite President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25% to 4.5%.   Win McNamee/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by WIN MCNAMEE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Jerome Powell’s (right) term ends in May 2026, and Donald Trump is expected to nominate a successor in the coming months.
Fed still in wait-and-see mode, as impact of tariff war is not yet fully felt

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington, D.C., June 18, 2025. Despite US President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut, Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent.
Trump has repeatedly called on the Fed and Powell (above) to lower rates.
US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent’s comments came after a Bloomberg News report this month that he was being considered for the job at the central bank.
“ADP number out. ‘Too Late’ Powell must now lower the rate. He is unbelievable. Europe has lowered nine times,” US President Donald Trump said in a Truth Social post.

site_title: Circle K owner misses estimates on lower fuel prices, demand
summary: Circle K owner Alimentation Couche-Tard missed earnings estimates for its fiscal fourth quarter due to lower fuel demand, resulting in a 7.5% decline in revenue to US$16.3 billion. The company maintained its market share in the US fuel business, but saw a 0.4% decline in same-store merchandise revenues in the US. Despite this, the company reported strong positive results in Canada and Europe. Couche-Tard's shares are down 14% this year, citing concerns over the US convenience store industry and a stronger Canadian dollar.

images.alt_text: Seven & i is seeking to bolster its valuation through a series of strategic moves, including selling off underperforming retail assets, listing its US operations, buying back shares and appointing new leadership.
ACT and 7-Eleven operator Seven & i have signed a NDA that will give the former access to the retailer’s financial data as it seeks a US$47 billion acquisition.
Seven & i has more than 13,000 locations in the US and Canada under a variety of brands, including franchises and stores operated under license.
Seven & i has said it is engaging with Couche-Tard, but a core concern is that US competition authorities will not give the deal the green light given the overlap in the companies’ businesses.

site_title: Dubai and Abu Dhabi’s haven status tested by Middle East crisis
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE), particularly Dubai and Abu Dhabi, is facing a test of its neutral and open-for-business stance amid the Iran-Israel confrontation involving the US. Despite a brief airspace closure and a US base attack in Qatar, the financial centers of Dubai and Abu Dhabi have resumed normal business activity, with no signs of capital flight or firms considering a pullback. The UAE's haven status and internationalization drive remain intact, with stocks scaling new highs, and executives expressing optimism about the country's economic prospects.

images.alt_text: In 2024, the number of active companies in the Dubai International Financial Centre rose 25% on year to 6,920, with a record annual number of registrations of 1,823 new companies.
Demand for Dubai property has boomed since 2020 as the government’s handling of the pandemic and its liberal visa policies attracted scores of foreign buyers.
Mapletree Investments is hoping to deploy about US$2 billion in the Gulf region after opening an office in Abu Dhabi last year, sources say.

US President Donald Trump with US Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth, US Vice President JD Vance and US Secretary of State Marco Rubio as he delivers an address to the nation at the White House following US strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities.
Secretary of State Marco Rubio told Politico: “The bottom line is, they are much further away from a nuclear weapon today than they were before the president took this bold action.”
China, the world’s biggest importer, gets about 14% of its crude from Iran.

Excavators are used to clear the rubble outside the Evin prison complex in Tehran that was hit days ago by an Israeli strike, on June 25, 2025. The Israeli defence minister announced strikes on the prison and other domestic security agencies in Tehran on June 23. (Photo by Mostafa Roudaki / mizanonline / AFP)
U.S. President Donald Trump told reporters he was “not happy” with either side for violating the truce, particularly with Israel.
Emirates, the world’s largest international airline, said it would continue to operate its schedule, using flight paths well distanced from conflict areas after some journeys were rerouted on Monday.

Emergency workers check the damage caused to a building from an Iranian missile strike in Beersheba in southern Israel. The Israeli military has accused Tehran of violating a ceasefire announced earlier.

site_title: China will be able to navigate around restrictions imposed by others, emerge more resilient: PM Wong
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong stated that despite restrictions imposed by other countries, China will likely find ways to navigate around them by developing its own capabilities. China's response to geopolitical contestation involves developing indigenous technology, strengthening R&D, and emerging more resilient. Wong noted that countries trying to "weaponise economic interdependencies" may find alternatives, reducing the effectiveness of restrictions. He expressed hope for continued constructive engagements with China and the US, and emphasized the importance of building substance over just having good relations.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
PM Wong (left) at a dialogue session with WEF president and CEO Borge Brende at the “Summer Davos” in Tianjin on Jun 25.
PM Wong (left) and President Xi meet on Tuesday morning at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

site_title: Trump-backed crypto firm is planning stablecoin audit, new app
summary: US President Donald Trump's cryptocurrency platform World Liberty Financial (WLF) will issue an audit of its stablecoin "within days" and plans a new app, according to co-founder Zak Folkman. The company has generated hundreds of millions of US dollars in revenue for Trump's family business. WLF's governance token, WLFI, may become tradable in the coming weeks, Folkman hinted. The move comes amid criticism from lawmakers and ethics watchdogs, who argue it creates conflicts of interest due to the timing with the president's regulatory pullback.

images.alt_text: Stablecoin regulations are expected to help drive further adoption and institutional investment for issuers such as Circle.
Stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency designed to maintain a constant value, usually a 1:1 US dollar peg, are commonly used by crypto traders to move funds between tokens.
Trump,  reported US$57.35 million from token sales at crypto firm World Liberty Financial.

site_title: China’s collateral demands curbing emerging countries’ ability to manage finances: study
summary: A study by AidData, the Kiel Institute for the World Economy, and Georgetown University found that China's practice of securing loans to low-income nations through commodity revenue streams and restricted escrow accounts limits their ability to manage finances effectively. China has lent $911 billion to 57 countries, with nearly half secured by cash deposits in Chinese bank accounts, averaging 20% of annual debt payments. This restricts governments' control over their fiscal affairs, potentially causing debt distress and complicating debt restructuring.

images.alt_text: “China will redouble its efforts, as it’s already doing, to develop its own indigenous technology, strengthen its R&D (research & development) base – which is happening – and emerge more resilient from this process," says PM Wong.

Chinese Premier Li Qiang said that while the world was seeing a host of global trade frictions, China was positioned to “to cross cycles, move forward steadily, and continue to inject more stability and certainty into the world economy.
China, the world’s biggest importer, gets about 14% of its crude from Iran.
China is the biggest contributor to the AIIB and holds 26 per cent of the votes.

site_title: Billionaire Richard Li’s FWD Group seeks to raise HK$3.47 billion in Hong Kong IPO
summary: FWD Group, backed by billionaire Richard Li, is seeking to raise HK$3.47 billion (S$565.3 million) through a Hong Kong initial public offering. The insurer is offering 91.3 million offer shares at an offer price of HK$38.00 apiece. This comes after a rebound in Hong Kong listing volumes, following successful listings by CATL and Jiangsu Hengrui Pharmaceuticals. FWD's target valuation is up to US$9 billion, below its previous aim of at least US$10 billion.

site_title: Oil rebounds on signs of strong US demand
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 1% on Wednesday, rebounding from a sharp decline earlier in the week, driven by strong US demand and a ceasefire between Iran and Israel. Brent crude futures settled at $67.68 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) ended at $64.92. The recovery was fueled by data showing a decrease in US crude, petrol, and distillate inventories, and expectations of a Federal Reserve rate cut this year, which could spur economic growth and demand for oil.

images.alt_text: OCBC economists forecast that in a worst-case scenario, Brent prices could hit US$120 a barrel for a month, then retrace to US$100 for the rest of 2025.
Brent crude futures fell US$4.34, or 6.1 per cent, to settle at US$67.14 a barrel.

site_title: Oil price rollercoaster hammers South-east Asia’s top energy counters
summary: Oil prices plummeted below $70 per barrel after a US-led ceasefire between Israel and Iran, reversing a two-week rally driven by escalating tensions. Malaysian and Indonesian energy stocks, which had surged in recent days, reversed course, with the Bursa Malaysia Energy Index flat at 728.11 points. Upstream oil producers are expected to benefit from higher crude prices if tensions resurface, while downstream players may face margin pressure. Analysts warn that geopolitical risks persist, with a potential closure of the Strait of Hormuz posing a significant threat to global energy markets.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Tan Ai Leng
Brent crude futures closed US$5.53, or 7.2 per cent, lower at US$71.48 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude (WTI) eased US$5.53, or 7.2 per cent, to US$68.51 on Monday.
An interception takes place after Iran's armed forces say they targeted The Al-Udeid base in a missile attack in Qatar, June 23, 2025.
Food inflation eased to 1.1 per cent, from 1.4 per cent previously, as the prices of non-cooked food rose at a slower pace.
Some 84 per cent of the crude oil and condensate, and 83 per cent of the LNG that move through the Strait of Hormuz go to Asian markets in 2024, estimates the US Energy Information Administration.

Smoke billows from an explosion in southwest Tehran on June 16, 2025. Iran's state broadcaster was briefly knocked off the air by an Israeli strike and explosions rang out across Tehran on June 16, after a barrage of Iranian missiles killed 11 people in Israel on the fourth day of an escalating air war. (Photo by ATTA KENARE / AFP)
At 2335 GMT on Sunday, Brent was up 2.4 per cent up at US$78.83 per barrel and WTI was up 2.5 per cent at US$75.66.
The greenback has risen about 0.9 per cent since the conflict started, but it’s a relatively small move given the US currency’s traditional role as a haven in times of turmoil.

Smoke billows from an explosion in southwest Tehran on June 16, 2025. Iran's state broadcaster was briefly knocked off the air by an Israeli strike and explosions rang out across Tehran on June 16, after a barrage of Iranian missiles killed 11 people in Israel on the fourth day of an escalating air war. site_title: Four dead, five injured in fire at ASL Marine unit’s Batam shipyard
summary: A fire at an ASL Marine unit's shipyard in Batam, Indonesia, has claimed the lives of four workers and injured five others. All work on a floating storage and offloading vessel will be suspended until the cause of the fire is determined. ASL Marine, a Singapore-listed shipbuilder, will assist the affected workers and their families, working with authorities and the vessel's owner and subcontractor. Investigations are ongoing, and the incident has had a minimal impact on ASL Marine's shares, which rose 3.4% following the news.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: Hong Kong intervenes to defend FX peg as local currency drops
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) intervened to defend the Hong Kong dollar's peg to the US dollar, purchasing HK$9.4 billion (S$1.5 billion) to stabilize the currency, which had swung between its trading range of 7.75 to 7.85 per greenback. The move aims to protect the currency peg and make bearish bets more costly, as the HKMA signals it will defend the peg despite concerns about its sustainability. This intervention stands in contrast to other Asian central banks trying to cool their currencies' gains.

images.alt_text: Major tenors of forward points of the Hong Kong dollar, ranging from one-month to six-month, were all near their historic lows on Tuesday.

site_title: Thailand moves to recriminalise cannabis, shaking US$1b industry
summary: Thailand is moving to recriminalize cannabis, reversing its 2022 decision to decriminalize recreational use, after the government withdrew support for the policy change amid a political crisis. The new rules, expected to be published soon, will ban the sale of cannabis for recreational use and require a doctor's prescription for retail purchases. The move is estimated to impact the $1 billion cannabis industry, which has grown since the substance was removed from the narcotics list. Critics argue that the policy change will create social problems and stifle the industry's potential to transform Thai agriculture, medicine, and tourism.

images.alt_text: Under the draft legislation, cannabis or its extracts will be allowed for medical treatment and research by state agencies besides its use in herbal, food and cosmetic products.

site_title: Sembcorp unit’s acquisition of 49 MW Vietnam hydropower asset delayed
summary: Sembcorp Industries' unit, Sembcorp Solar Vietnam, has delayed the acquisition of a 49-megawatt hydropower asset in Vietnam due to regulatory uncertainties. The deal was part of the company's plan to acquire a 245 MW renewables portfolio in Vietnam, originally expected to be completed by the second half of 2024. The new timeline for the acquisition is now expected to be disclosed by the end of the year, with Sembcorp stating it will take regulatory uncertainties into account for future investments in the country.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Sembcorp says proceeds from the issuance will finance the general corporate purposes and working capital requirements of the company and its subsidiaries, after issue expenses are deducted.

site_title: This energy embargo has been going on for a decade
summary: A decade-long energy embargo is unfolding, with governments imposing restrictions on clean energy trade, such as tariffs and local content requirements. This has slowed the transition to renewable energy, with many countries failing to meet their 2030 targets. The barriers to clean power are justified by noble intentions, but in practice, they hinder competition and innovation. The world's reliance on fossil fuels is perpetuated, and the lack of immediate blowback from policies hampering renewables has made them feel consequence-free. A crisis may prompt the world to dismantle this embargo, prompting a shift towards cleaner energy sources.

images.alt_text: An Asean power grid can not only help the region decarbonise, but also insulate against energy shocks

site_title: Keppel partners AIIB for up to US$1.5 billion in Asia-Pacific green infrastructure deals
summary: Keppel, a Singapore-based asset manager, has partnered the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) to facilitate up to $1.5 billion in sustainable infrastructure investments and financing opportunities in the Asia-Pacific. The 5-year partnership, set to last until 2030, focuses on green infrastructure, connectivity, and technology-enabled projects, including power transmission, renewable energy, and transportation. The collaboration aims to address the region's significant infrastructure gap driven by rapid urbanization.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The manager of Keppel Infrastructure Trust is divesting a 24.6 per cent stake in Ventura Motors for A$130 million.

site_title: CEOs need to stop outsourcing politics
summary: US CEOs must develop a deeper understanding of politics to navigate the increasingly complex global landscape. The Trump administration's tariffs and China's retaliatory measures demonstrate the need for foresight in international relations. Unlike Apple, which anticipated and prepared for the deteriorating US-China relationship, many American companies are caught off guard by government actions. To adapt, business schools and boards must prioritize politics in their curricula and evaluations, while CEOs must acquire the necessary skills to make informed decisions on global government and politics.

images.alt_text: People walk past an Apple Store along a shopping street in Beijing on April 8, 2025. China vowed on April 8 to "fight to the end" against fresh tariffs of 50 percent threatened by US President Donald Trump, further aggravating a trade war that has already wiped trillions off global markets. (Photo by WANG Zhao / AFP)

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq approach record high as Middle East tensions ease
summary: US stock indexes approached record highs on Wednesday as Middle East tensions eased, with the S&P 500 rising 0.20% and the Nasdaq Composite up 0.51%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also increased 0.10%. Investors await comments from Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell amid the calm in the region, which has boosted market sentiment.

site_title: DBS targets hiring 40 private bankers for North Asia market
summary: DBS Group, Singapore's largest lender, plans to hire about 40 private bankers in Hong Kong and Singapore this year to cater to wealthy clients in North Asia, amid rising geopolitical tensions. The bank has already hired roughly half of that number, with a focus on mainland Chinese and Taiwanese clients seeking offshore wealth management opportunities. DBS has seen a 30% rise in private bank revenues and a 20% jump in assets under management in Hong Kong, driven by inflows from wealthy clients.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of DBS is pictured outside an office in Singapore January 5, 2016. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
Generic image of the Singapore skyline

site_title: Grab to pause changes to driver incentive scheme following backlash
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing service, has paused planned changes to its driver incentive scheme, Grab Monthly Bonus, amid a backlash from drivers over the impact on earnings and income stability. The revised scheme aimed to reward consistent drivers but would have reduced overall payouts for drivers completing 300-499 trips. Grab and the National Private Hire Vehicles Association (NPHVA) have agreed to address drivers' concerns before implementing further changes.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
FILE PHOTO: A Grab logo is pictured at the Money 20/20 Asia Fintech Trade Show in Singapore March 21, 2019. REUTERS/Anshuman Daga/File Photo

site_title: Board directors must be mindful of family dynamics in businesses, says panellist
summary: A panel discussion in Singapore emphasized the importance of independent directors in family-run businesses being mindful of family dynamics and power struggles. Experts advised directors to identify the decision-maker within the family and engage with top executives to clarify family disputes and voting patterns. They also suggested that directors "choose their battles" and consider becoming internal whistle-blowers or leaving the company if necessary. Ultimately, directors must prioritize the company's best interest, even if it means stepping down or facing re-election challenges.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (right) and his son and group CEO Sherman Kwek at the AGM on Apri 23..
CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and his son and group CEO Sherman Kwek.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, June 25, 2025
summary: Asian markets rallied on Wednesday as an Iran-Israel ceasefire held, and oil prices clawed back some losses. US President Trump made a sudden U-turn on China buying Iranian oil, causing market uncertainty. ST Engineering divested its entire equity interest in US-based construction player LeeBoy for US$290 million. The Asian market rally is attributed to the ceasefire, while Trump's U-turn has raised concerns.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney and Singapore leading the gains across Asia.
China, the world’s biggest importer, gets about 14% of its crude from Iran.

The ST Engineering logo on one of its hangars at Seletar Aerospace Park used for Passenger-to-freighter (P2F) aircraft conversion works.
