site_title: Ambani and Adani team up to use each other’s fuel pumps
summary: Billionaires Mukesh Ambani and Gautam Adani have partnered to sell transportation fuels using their respective groups' retail stations across India, bolstering their distribution network. Reliance Industries's Jio-bp venture will set up petrol and diesel dispensers at Adani Total Gas's compressed natural gas retail outlets, while Adani and TotalEnergies JV will install CNG dispensing units at Jio-bp's pumps. The agreement aims to expand Jio-bp's fuel network, which currently has 2,000 outlets, and may provide a fillip to the struggling company's plans to reach 5,550 stations in five years.

site_title: The man who painted Lee Kuan Yew – and the wife whom history forgot
summary: A new exhibition at The Private Museum in Singapore highlights the often-overlooked work of Lee Boon Ngan, the wife of renowned painter Chua Mia Tee. The exhibition, "The Art of Lee Boon Ngan: Celebrating 60 Years Of Singapore Through The Love Of Chua Mia Tee & Lee Boon Ngan," features nearly 50 artworks, including 15 floral paintings by Lee that have never been seen publicly. The show brings together the couple's works, as well as contributions from their daughter and granddaughter, and runs from July 10 to September 21.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Foo Kwee Horng's painting 'Majulah' (2016) is a spectral meditation on nationhood and memory.
Set in a near future, National Memory Project by Teater Ekamatra explores Artificial Intelligence, memory and loss.

site_title: Trade will always still exist, though patterns will change and evolve, says PM Wong at WEF
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized that trade will continue to exist despite changing patterns, citing the need for "flexible multilateralism" to address the realities of today's economy. He highlighted the importance of updating the World Trade Organization's rules to accommodate digital trade and agreed that bilateral and regional trade agreements can complement multilateral efforts. Wong acknowledged the challenge of a "big spaghetti bowl" of agreements but urged like-minded countries to work together to establish basic building blocks and remain open and inclusive.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

“It is the most complex geopolitical and geo-economic backdrop we’ve seen in decades,” says WEF President and CEO Borge Brende ahead of a meeting of the multilateral forum in the northern Chinese city of Tianjin.
The trip will be his first as prime minister.

site_title: Aviva hunts partner as it seeks to expand Spanish housing bet
summary: Aviva's investment arm is seeking a partner to expand its Spanish rental housing portfolio, which currently spans 1,000 units across five developments. The new capital, estimated at 150 million euros, will be used to increase the portfolio. This comes as Spanish cities like Madrid and Barcelona face major housing shortages, driving up rents and values. Aviva has formed a venture with Spanish developer Layetana Living to create a new operating company, Propia, with Aviva owning a minority stake.

images.alt_text: Tourists rest on a bench next to their luggage in the Juan Goytisolo square in Madrid, Spain, May 23, 2025. REUTERS/Nacho Doce

site_title: Nato summit commits to higher spending and collective defence
summary: NATO leaders have committed to increasing defense spending to 5% of GDP by 2035, a goal endorsed by US President Donald Trump. The 32-nation alliance aims to reduce its reliance on the US and bolster collective defense amid growing concerns over Russia's threat to European security following the 2022 Ukraine invasion. The new spending target, worth hundreds of billions of dollars annually, will be measured in two parts: 3.5% for core defense and 1.5% for broader defense-related measures.

images.alt_text: A member of the Dutch army patrols ahead of the NATO summit in The Hague, Netherlands June 23, 2025. REUTERS/Yves Herman

site_title: Singapore shares rise, tracking regional gains; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 3,925.98, following regional gains as the Iran-Israel ceasefire held firm. The Singapore Exchange was the top gainer, up 3.7%, while Yangzijiang Shipbuilding fell 1.4%. Global markets, including Japan's Nikkei 225, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, and South Korea's Kospi, also saw gains. Nigel Green, CEO of deVere Group, warned that global markets are "dangerously relaxed" and advised investors to adjust allocations for downside protection and diversification.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Generic image of SGX

Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) during afternoon trading on April 9, 2025 in New York. Wall Street stocks rocketed to close solidly higher Wednesday, with dramatic advances on all three major indexes as US President Donald Trump delayed steep new tariffs hours after they took effect. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 7.9 percent to 40,608.45, the broad-based S&P 500 Index rallied 9.5 percent to 5,456.90, and the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index jumped more than 12.2 percent to 17,124.97. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)
The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 1.11 per cent, hitting a one-week high during the session and notching its biggest single-day jump in over a month.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 225.3 points, or 0.53 per cent, at the open to 42,807.13.
Tokyo and Hong Kong stocks were up 1.4 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: Bank of Korea warns of housing, debt risks as easing continues
summary: The Bank of Korea has warned of risks to financial stability due to persistent housing price gains in South Korea, particularly in Seoul, which could accelerate debt accumulation and pose a threat to the financial system. The central bank has cautioned that cutting interest rates too quickly could spur a rebound in household debt. The housing market is diverging between Seoul and the rest of the country, with non-capital regions experiencing stagnant or falling prices, while Seoul's home values have jumped over 16% since 2023.

images.alt_text: The BOK governor says that Korea’s market-based measures are harder to interpret due to limited market depth.

Bank of Korea Governor Chang Yong-rhee says: “During the global financial crisis, the probability of negative growth was estimated at around 5 per cent. Now, that likelihood has risen to nearly 14 per cent on average.”
Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong said that all six members of the board are open to a rate cut over the next three months.

site_title: BOT holds rate, raises growth forecast despite risks
summary: The Bank of Thailand (BOT) maintained its one-day repurchase rate at 1.75% despite global risks, including US tariffs and the Middle East conflict. The central bank's seven-member Monetary Policy Committee voted 6-1 to hold the rate steady, while also raising its 2025 growth forecast to 2.3% due to improving exports and manufacturing. The BOT expects 2026 growth to slow to 1.7% and remains prepared to adjust monetary policy in response to future trends and risks.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Thailand logo is pictured in Bangkok, Thailand, January 30, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa
The new BOT governor will be appointed for a five-year term, and will succeed incumbent Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput (above), who will complete his tenure on Sep 30.

site_title: Trump declares Iran 'victory for everybody' despite doubts over damage
summary: US President Donald Trump declared the war between Iran and Israel "a victory for everybody" despite initial doubts over the damage inflicted by US strikes. Trump claimed Iran would not rebuild its nuclear sites and would pursue a diplomatic path towards reconciliation. However, Iran's president suggested reforms at home after the war, while Israel's leaders sought to capitalize on the demonstration of its military capabilities. A ceasefire has been in place since June 13, with residents expressing relief but apprehension over the future, and international efforts to resume negotiations on Iran's nuclear ambitions are ongoing.

images.alt_text: Secretary of State Marco Rubio told Politico: “The bottom line is, they are much further away from a nuclear weapon today than they were before the president took this bold action.”

site_title: Iran-Israel ceasefire holding, Trump envoy says talks with Iran 'promising'
summary: US President Donald Trump's ceasefire between Iran and Israel appears to be holding, with both sides claiming victory after 12 days of war. The US joined airstrikes in support of Israel, taking out Iran's uranium-enrichment facilities, and Trump's envoy says talks with Iran are "promising." Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu says the war removed the nuclear threat against Israel, while Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian calls it a "great victory." The US is hopeful for a long-term peace deal, and Trump has vowed to preserve the ceasefire, despite uncertainty over the extent of damage to Iran's nuclear programme.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Donald Trump told reporters he was “not happy” with either side for violating the truce, particularly with Israel.

site_title: Going around in circles: Do Singapore investors have the appetite for another telco listing?
summary: Singapore investors are skeptical about the potential listing of Circles.Life, a virtual telecommunications player, on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company, backed by Temasek and private equity firm Warburg Pincus, has reached breakeven and aims to list on SGX or Nasdaq in the US. Singtel, the largest telco player, holds a significant advantage over competitors, and its core businesses are expected to grow by over 300% in the next 12-18 months, according to DBS Group Research. Investors are hesitant to support another telco listing, favoring larger listcos and blue-chips amid market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
StarHub's revenue for the three months slid 2.4 per cent on-year to S$540.5 million, from S$553.9 million.
A rise in cross-border travel after the Covid-19 pandemic provided the initial impetus for “borderless” mobile plans.

With the initial public offering, it plans to expand its regional presence, expand its portfolio of interior fit-out and A&A projects in the high-end residential sector, and explore investment opportunities.

site_title: Not your average shophouse: A home built for a multi-generational household
summary: A Singaporean entrepreneur transformed a 1,500 sq ft shophouse into a 3,600 sq ft multi-generational home for his family, including his parents and grandmother. The project, led by architect Austen Chan, involved widening walkways to make the space wheelchair-friendly and restoring the facade to its original look. A three-storey plus attic rear extension was added, featuring a curved staircase, skylights, and a lift. The design allows for private spaces while maintaining a sense of community, with five rooms, including ensuites and self-contained units, and a mezzanine floor.

images.alt_text: The house has a striking facade of tiered arches and curves.
This old apartment in Laguna Park has been turned into a dual key home.

site_title: Barbie takes flight: Wings of Art repurposes dolls for showcase, aims to raise S$100,000
summary: A charity initiative called Wings of Art in Singapore features 60 repurposed Barbie dolls, part of a 60m-long runway, with proceeds going towards the Singapore Red Cross Young Hearts programme to support underprivileged children. The dolls were created by 60 local artists and will be auctioned off, with public donations and crafting sessions also contributing to the fundraising goal of S$100,000. The event promotes sustainability and diversity, and aims to raise awareness about the importance of inclusivity and supporting those with autism, such as the son of one of the artists, who created a doll with autism spectrum disorder.

images.alt_text: The artwork, Whispers of the Deep, was made from scraps found in the ocean and later restored by
SCM showcases vendors selling sustainable products.

site_title: TSMC unit to issue US$10 billion of stock to counter forex swings
summary: TSMC Global, a unit of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, plans to issue US$10 billion worth of new stock to hedge against volatile exchange rates, its largest such move since 2024. The move aims to increase capital flexibility and manage exchange rate risks. This is the third such deal by TSMC Global, which has been affected by the appreciation of the Taiwan dollar, which hurts exporters. The company's operating margin has fallen due to the stronger local currency.

site_title: Australia cashes in on record sheep prices as meat exports surge
summary: Australia is benefiting from record-high sheep prices due to strong global demand for lamb and mutton, with exports reaching 702,000 metric tons worth US$3.6 billion in 2024. This marks a significant increase from 2019 and a 10% higher shipment rate in the first four months of 2025. Australia's dominance in the global sheep meat market is expected to continue, as New Zealand's production stagnates due to declining flock numbers and land conversion for carbon credits.

images.alt_text: Farming impact of Australia's worst drought in living memory

site_title: Male bonding in Singapore
summary: In Singapore, men are seeking alternative ways to bond and relieve stress due to the pressures of the country's "hustle culture." Wellness counselors note that men's emotional well-being is stretched, leading them to explore non-traditional approaches to friendship and self-expression. This includes activities like axe-throwing, furniture destruction, and joining choirs. As men seek support networks, they are challenging traditional notions of masculinity and embracing a more emotional and expressive side.

site_title: Investment firm PAG raises 3.1 billion yuan in first yuan-denominated buyout fund: sources
summary: Asia-focused investment firm PAG has raised 3.1 billion yuan (S$553 million) at the first close of its inaugural yuan-denominated buyout fund, exceeding its target. The fundraising comes amid a slowdown in China's dealmaking due to economic headwinds and geopolitical tensions. PAG's current Chinese team will be responsible for both yuan and US dollar-denominated investments, focusing on mergers and acquisitions for a controlling stake and structural minority equity investments in various sectors.

images.alt_text: The deal highlights the broader troubles facing Hong Kong’s property market.

site_title: Banks have critical role in helping companies navigate heightened protectionism: DPM Gan
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong emphasized the critical role banks play in helping companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, navigate the effects of protectionism. He urged banks to deepen relationships with customers, supporting growth and expansion into new markets. Additionally, MAS and ABS launched a new entity, Singapore Payments Network, to oversee Singapore's 8 national payment schemes, including Giro, PayNow, and QR code, to facilitate smoother transitions to e-payments and enhance resilience in the banking and payments industries.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

All banks in Singapore will still stop issuing new corporate cheque books by Dec 31, 2025, but the deadline to cease processing of corporate cheques will be extended by an additional year to Dec 31, 2026.
Currently, PayNow is administered and governed by ABS.
Nets has a domestic merchant network of over 130,000 acceptance points, of which 96,000 can process QR transactions.

site_title: Singaporeans value work-life balance most in an ‘ideal employer’: Randstad survey
summary: In a survey of 2,522 working-age adults in Singapore, work-life balance has remained the top priority for employees in considering an ideal employer for a third year, ahead of salary and job security. This was followed by attractive salary and benefits, and job security. The survey found that work-life balance was the key motivator for employees to switch jobs, with 41% citing it as a reason for change. Having a strong work-life balance was also the top reason for respondents to feel motivated and engaged at work, as cited by 41%.

images.alt_text: From left: Fractional chief marketing officer David Lim, fractional chief HR officer Susan Chen, and fractional chief of staff Mark Mullinix.

site_title: China vows ‘forceful measures’ after Taiwan’s Huawei export curb
summary: China has vowed to take "forceful measures" in response to Taiwan's blacklisting of Chinese companies, including Huawei and SMIC, which limits their access to AI chip development technologies. Taiwan's move is part of a US campaign to curb China's technological ascent. Beijing condemned the decision as "despicable" and claims it will damage Taiwan's economy and competitiveness. US President Donald Trump's administration has urged Taipei to take more ownership over chip restrictions on China. China is expected to respond with measures to resolutely safeguard cross-strait economic and trade exchange.

site_title: Australia’s Star casino shareholders approve A$300 million rescue package
summary: Australia's Star Entertainment Group, the country's second-largest casino operator, has secured an A$300 million rescue package led by US casino firm Bally's Corp and the Mathieson family. The proposal was approved by over 98% of shareholders, allowing the embattled company to remain operational. The rescue deal includes convertible notes and subordinated debt instruments, with Bally's and the Mathieson family controlling around 56% of Star's issued capital. The move aims to put Star on a sustainable path after struggling with a growing debt crisis and regulatory investigations over the past two years.

images.alt_text: Star’s shares have been suspended since Feb 28, when the company failed to meet the deadline to lodge its accounts.
Sydney-based Star, Australia’s no.2 casino operator, has been scrambling to stave off bankruptcy as years of regulatory scrutiny and lawsuits following money laundering allegations.

site_title: Chinese firms boost exports to UK as Trump tariffs shift trade
summary: Chinese firms have boosted exports to the UK as US tariffs on Chinese goods have reduced, with exports of small parcels and electronics jumping in May. The shift could bring down inflation faster in the UK, but also undercut domestic manufacturers on pricing. UK Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds is monitoring the situation and stands ready to prevent dumping on the UK market. The data suggests that trade diversion from the US to the UK is a possible sign of a rerouting of exports to avoid US tariffs, which have been elevated at 55% since Trump's second term began.

images.alt_text: epa11468182 Shoppers on Oxford Street in London, Britain, 09 July 2024. The British Retail Consortium has released data showing a 0.2 percent fall in retail sales for June compared to this time last year. Poor weather and the cost of living crisis have kept shoppers off the high street.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

epa12122940 A shopper browses in a store in London, Britain, 21 May 2025. According to the Office of National Statistics the UK inflation rate has risen to 3.5% in April. It is the highest level since February 2025 driven by sharp rises in household bills, and higher food, vehicle duty and airfare costs.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL
FILE PHOTO: Shoppers walk on Regent Street in London, Britain, May 15, 2025. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: Vietnam’s imprisoned tycoon seeks government nod for 930 trillion dong restructuring plan
summary: Vietnamese imprisoned tycoon Truong My Lan is seeking government approval for a 12-year, 930 trillion dong (S$45.5 billion) restructuring plan to reduce her sentence by repaying at least three-fourths of the embezzled money. The plan involves asset recovery, project revenue generation, and strategic investor participation, including Rothschild, UBS, and Greenmark Construction. Lan has been ordered to repay 674 trillion dong to SCB and an additional 30 trillion dong to bond investors, with the goal of mobilizing capital to remedy losses and reduce her sentence.

images.alt_text: Jamille Tran
The new passenger terminal at Phu Quoc International Airport is designed by Singaporean consulting firm CPG Airport

The plan to restructure the troubled Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank is awaiting suggestions from relevant bodies before being submitted to the government and the Communist Party’s Politburo, the finance ministry’s Dau Tu newspaper has reported.

The State Bank of Vietnam, the country's central banks, directs certain established banks to take over underperforming lenders as part of a drive to overhaul the sector and ensure national financial security.

FILE PHOTO: A logo of Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank (SCB) is seen in front of an under-construction building in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, November 30, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio/File Photo
Truong My Lan has been working to pay back hundreds of millions in stolen bank funds, according to her lawyers.
Vietnamese property tycoon Truong My Lan in a Ho Chi Minh City court on Thursday (Oct 17), when she was giving a life term following a related trial on money laundering charges.

Truong My Lan (centre), the chairwoman of real estate developer Van Thinh Phat Holdings Group, was sentenced to death in April for her role in a financial fraud worth more than US$12 billion, Vietnam’s biggest on record.
The court ruled in April that Truong My Lan must compensate Saigon Commercial Bank a total of 674 trillion dong – an amount Lan appealed against but still committed to repay “at all costs”.
Truong My Lan sit during her trial at the Ho Chi Minh City People's Court in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, 11 April 2024.

site_title: Singapore Airlines CEO’s latest annual pay drops 14% to S$7 million despite record performance
summary: Singapore Airlines CEO Goh Choon Phong received a remuneration package of S$7 million for the latest financial year, a 13.5% decrease from FY2024. The package includes a S$1.5 million salary, S$3.1 million in bonuses, and S$2.3 million in shares, down from S$4.3 million in the previous year. Despite record performance, including a 3.9% rise in net profit to S$2.8 billion, the airline's CEO pay has decreased.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
In May, the Indonesian authorities recertified airports in Semarang, Palembang and resort destination Belitung (above) to allow them to operate international flights.

site_title: Japan’s NTT DATA Group targets July listing of data centre Reit on SGX: sources
summary: Japan's NTT DATA Group is targeting a July listing of its data centre real estate investment trust (Reit) on the Singapore Stock Exchange (SGX), which could raise up to $1 billion. The listing would be the largest in Singapore since 2021's $977 million Digital Core Reit IPO. NTT DATA Group is engaging cornerstone investors and has not disclosed the planned IPO amount, with its 2025 fiscal year running from April to March 2026. The company aims to list before the end of the year, pending review and approval by the Singapore Stock Exchange.

images.alt_text: Generic image of SGX
Hyatt Place Oklahoma City Airport
CMG20240409-HengYY01 / 王彦燕 / 拍Capitaland外观 [Amoy St]
Centurion says details of the IPO are still being finalised. The Reit it is aiming to establish will comprise some of the group’s worker and student accommodation assets.
Loh Hwee Long, CEO of Keppel DC Reit Management, says the Reit saw overall valuation gains in 2024, especially from its Singapore colocation assets.

site_title: Indonesia cuts outlay on giant free meals programme to 350 trillion rupiah
summary: Indonesia has reduced its spending plan for its free meals programme from $9.4 billion to $7.5 billion, cutting costs by 29% due to revised ingredient cost estimates. The programme, aimed at improving health outcomes for 83 million people, will now cost 350 trillion rupiah ($27 billion) next year, a 22% decrease. The government is relying on the private sector to set up kitchens to source food, but faces challenges in meeting demand and securing investment. President Prabowo Subianto has acknowledged the programme's challenges but sees it as a long-term investment in the country's future.

images.alt_text: Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong and Indonesia’s Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto at the 15th Singapore-Indonesia 6WG MM.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 25)
summary: Singapore is retooling its regional hubs and industrial estates to meet an evolving economy, according to the Draft Master Plan 2025. The Urban Redevelopment Authority unveiled plans for new neighbourhoods in various areas. Prime Minister Wong stated that trade will continue despite a shift towards self-sufficiency. Singapore shares rose, tracking regional gains, while the city-state's port ranked the world's top for the 12th consecutive year. The country is also exploring sustainable aviation and has set up a centre to advance this field.

site_title: Singapore’s next chapter: New models for regional hubs, industrial estates in URA’s Draft Master Plan 2025
summary: Singapore's Draft Master Plan 2025 aims to decentralize office spaces and industrial estates to meet evolving business needs. A new office hub is planned for Bishan, with community amenities and flexible zoning for non-industrial uses. Industrial estates near transport nodes in Jurong and Tuas will also be redeveloped for mixed-use districts, enhancing economic competitiveness. The plan also prioritizes building more homes, with over 80,000 public and private homes expected to be introduced across 10 new housing areas in the next 10-15 years.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

rydmp25 - An artist’s impression of the mixed-use hub planned for the new Paterson neighbourhood on top of Orchard MRT station.  

Credit: URA
Active participation by private property developers and more migration will help in Singapore's urban transformation.

site_title: Gold prices flat as fragile Iran-Israel ceasefire tempers safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $3,326.39 per ounce as a tentative ceasefire between Iran and Israel reduced safe-haven demand. The US dollar index hovered near a one-week low, making gold more attractive to overseas buyers. US consumer confidence unexpectedly declined in June, and Fed funds futures traders are now pricing in 61 basis points of rate cuts for 2025, with the first move expected in September.

images.alt_text: Spot gold slipped 0.6 per cent to US$3,349.89 an ounce, as of 0030 GMT, after hitting its lowest level since June 11.

site_title: China seizes moment to globalise yuan as US dollar doubts mount
summary: China is promoting the yuan's global role, seizing the opportunity to reduce US dollar reliance as the world's reserve currency faces challenges. Authorities plan to raise quotas for local residents to invest in overseas securities, increase the currency's international circulation, and ease capital controls. The measures aim to embed the yuan in investment flows, open China's financial markets, and challenge the US dollar's dominance. China's central bank governor envisioned a new global currency order with a reduced role for the US dollar, and the country is exploring the launch of digital yuan and domestic currency futures.

images.alt_text: Chinese assets overall have benefited from a diversification away from US markets as concerns about Trump’s tariffs and tax cuts sustain the “sell America” narrative.

site_title: Singapore-based engineers help golfers around the world improve their swing
summary: Singapore-based engineering company Rapsodo has developed data-tracking tools for athletes, with its products available in over 55 countries. Founded by Batuhan Okur 15 years ago, the company aims to democratize access to data in sports, offering affordable performance-analytics tools for golf, baseball, and softball. Its flagship product, SkyTrak, tracks ball speed and swing metrics, and has been successful since its launch over 10 years ago. The company is now targeting further international growth, with plans to expand into South-east Asia and other regions.

images.alt_text: Pitstop Tyres' second-gen owner Cordellia Tan joined the family business in 2020.

site_title: DBS, CapitaLand and other local stocks will be boosted by Singapore’s long-term wealth creation: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts Singapore's stock market capitalization will double by 2030, driven by the city-state's hub industries in energy, finance, transport, and data infrastructure. The bank forecasts a 5-year GDP compound annual growth rate of 3%, with household net assets nearly doubling to US$4 trillion by 2030. Stocks such as Sembcorp Industries, DBS, CapitaLand Investment, and Singapore Exchange are expected to benefit from Singapore's wealth creation. The city-state is also poised to emerge as a regional data and artificial intelligence hub, with plans to add 3 gigawatt of green hydrogen and gas-fired capacity by 2030.

images.alt_text: Generic image of Singapore's CBD, financial district

site_title: Green shipping, digital tools are key themes for Motion Ventures’ new US$100 million fund
summary: Motion Ventures, a four-year-old US$100 million venture capital fund, aims to foster collaboration between its portfolio companies and maritime corporate investors. The firm, led by Shaun Hon, is focusing on technologies that "will define the next generation" of maritime innovation, including decarbonisation, electric vessels, and digital tools. The fund has attracted over half of its target amount so far, following the success of its inaugural S$30 million fund. Hon sees the maritime industry as ripe for innovation, driven by the International Maritime Organization's goal of net-zero emissions by 2050.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Singapore’s berthing times averaged from 12 to 36 hours due to vessel bunching and congestion, said Hapag-Lloyd.

site_title: Daiwa plans 100 billion yen real estate fund as Japan market booms
summary: Daiwa Securities Group plans to launch a 100 billion yen real estate fund in collaboration with Samty Holdings and Hillhouse Investment, targeting Japanese rental housing and hotels assets. The fund aims to raise capital for domestic and overseas institutions, tapping into Japan's booming property market. Daiwa aims to increase its real estate asset management investment holdings by 25% to 2 trillion yen by 2030, boosting profitability and corporate value.

images.alt_text: Daiwa Securities is the largest shareholder of Aozora, holding 23.65 per cent of shares.

site_title: The magical thinking of Masa Son
summary: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son is pursuing a long-shot ambition to create a US$1 trillion artificial intelligence hub in the Arizona desert, dubbed "Project Crystal Land". Son, known for taking bold bets, claims to have found a new purpose in developing "artificial super intelligence" after reflecting on his father's passing. The project's feasibility remains uncertain, with some questioning the validity of Son's vision.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son speaks at the SoftBank World 2023 corporate conference, in Tokyo, Japan, October 4, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Tang/File Photo
The Japanese technology giant is offering 21.5 million shares for US$224 to US$228 each, the terms show.

site_title: China building ‘mega-sized consumption powerhouse’, premier says
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang expressed confidence that China can turn consumption into a driver for the economy, positioning the nation as a stabilizing force in a rapidly shifting global trade landscape. China is building a "mega-sized consumption powerhouse" despite weak consumer sentiment and deflationary pressures, with provinces quickly running out of funds from a government-subsidized home goods trade-in programme. Li also touted China's advances in electric vehicles and artificial intelligence, aiming to share indigenous technologies with countries worldwide.

images.alt_text: China's one-year loan prime rate (LPR) was kept at 3 per cent, while the five-year LPR was unchanged at 3.50 per cent.
The programme has been key to encouraging household purchases of a slew of consumer goods this year.

China's industrial output data, released by the National Bureau of Statistics, missed expectations for a 5.9 per cent increase in a Reuters poll and marked the slowest growth since November last year.
The US is threatening to raise tariffs on many countries from early July and on China from August.

site_title: Potential oil price spike may scupper Asean’s easing cycle, say economists
summary: Asean central banks may need to end their monetary easing cycles in the second half of 2025 due to a potential oil price spike, forecasted to reach $120 a barrel. This could delay rate cuts and widen trade balances, particularly for Thailand and the Philippines. Higher oil prices could also drag current account balances and push headline inflation, but fiscal measures such as subsidies and price stabilisation funds may soften these pressures. Indonesia and Malaysia are expected to be the most affected, while Malaysia and Thailand are less likely to raise interest rates due to their fiscal buffers.

images.alt_text: Evan See
FILE PHOTO: A view shows disused oil pump jacks at the Airankol oil field operated by Caspiy Neft in the Atyrau Region, Kazakhstan April 2, 2025. REUTERS/Pavel Mikheyev/File Photo

site_title: New private homes planned in Paterson, Newton areas
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has unveiled the Draft Master Plan 2025, which includes plans for new neighbourhoods in Paterson, Newton, and other areas. The plans include 1,000 new private homes in the Paterson area and 5,000 new homes in Newton, with a focus on mixed-use developments and public spaces. The Paterson development will be built on top of the Orchard MRT interchange, while the Newton development will feature a "village square" and a linear park. The plans aim to increase housing supply and improve connectivity in the areas, with some sites set to be released for sale under the government land sales (GLS) Programme.

site_title: China makes pitch for more private cash in cross-border projects
summary: China's Finance Minister Lan Fo'an urged a greater role for private investment in cross-border infrastructure development, citing a decline in international aid and a funding gap of $4.3 trillion for sustainable development. China has been expanding its overseas investment and construction projects, particularly through state-owned enterprises, and the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has committed $52 billion to 38 member countries. Lan called for the AIIB to strengthen communications with governments, reduce private investors' concerns over geopolitics and defaults, and leverage new technologies to improve project returns.

images.alt_text: Canada applied to join the AIIB in 2016 and formally entered the institution in 2018.
The logo of Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) is seen at its headquarter building in Beijing January 17, 2016.REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
This will be the first time AIIB enters the Asian venture capital market since its founding.

site_title: Draft Master Plan 2025 builds capacity; its success hinges on developers stepping up, skilled migrants bringing dynamism
summary: Singapore's Draft Master Plan 2025 aims to boost housing and workspace capacity, with plans for new prime private homes and office buildings. The plan also addresses climate change risks, nature conservation, and heritage preservation. Developers play a crucial role in bringing the plan to life, but face challenges due to economic uncertainty and high land costs. To boost development, the government could consider policy tweaks, such as lower land betterment charge rates and greater flexibility for developers to sell out housing inventory. The plan's success hinges on end-user demand, which will drive property development and ultimately bring the envisioned urban transformation to reality.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

A private housing site in Tanjong Rhu Road next to the Singapore Swimming Club is one of the 10 new sites on the H2 2025 confirmed list.

The Ministry of National Development announced the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme today.

site_title: Trump baffles with sudden U-turn on China buying Iranian oil
summary: US President Donald Trump unexpectedly announced on social media that China can continue to purchase oil from Iran, contradicting years of US sanctions. The move is seen as a sudden U-turn and may undermine Washington's Iran policy, which aims to cut the regime's main source of revenue. Oil prices fell 6% after the announcement, with China, the world's biggest importer, getting about 14% of its crude from Iran. Treasury officials stated that sanctions would continue to be enforced, despite the president's comments, and a senior White House official clarified that Trump's goal is to encourage China to import American oil rather than Iranian oil.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures fell US$4.34, or 6.1 per cent, to settle at US$67.14 a barrel.

site_title: Pop Mart shares suffer setback but analysts still bullish on Labubu maker’s growth
summary: Pop Mart International Group's shares slid 6% on Friday, but analysts remain bullish on the Chinese toy company due to its sustained popularity and intellectual property (IP)-centric business model. Despite a People's Daily report calling for stricter regulations on "blind cards" and "mystery boxes," which encourage addictive behaviors, analysts believe the company's exposure is minimal and its customer base is mainly adults. Nomura, Citi Research, and CGS International have maintained their "buy" ratings and target prices, expecting the company's US market to contribute significantly to its revenue growth.

site_title: Hong Kong developer sought loans backed by Picasso, Warhol art
summary: A Hong Kong property developer, Parkview Group, attempted to secure a loan of over HK$2.8 billion backed by 200 artworks, including pieces by Picasso, Warhol, and Chinese artists, through international auction house Sotheby's. However, talks stalled due to logistics concerns. This is part of Parkview's efforts to find new funding sources amid strained finances, following a loan default in March and refinancing talks with banks. Sotheby's has seen its art financing services expand globally, with loan volume doubling to over US$1.6 billion since 2021.

summary: Sembcorp Industries' wholly owned subsidiary Sembcorp Financial Services priced S$300 million worth of fixed rate guaranteed notes at 3.55% interest rate, with the offering nearly seven times oversubscribed. The notes, due on Jan 2, 2046, will be used to finance general corporate purposes and working capital requirements of the company and its subsidiaries. The issuance is the longest-tenured offering of unrated corporate bonds by a Singapore company in recent times.

The EU aims to end new internal combustion engine sales in 2035, but high prices and charging infrastructure concerns are deterring consumers. Tesla's market share in Europe fell to 1.1% from 2% last year, as consumers increasingly opt for alternative EV options from Chinese car firms.

The net proceeds will be used for new investments, distributions, financing asset enhancement works, and refinancing existing borrowings. The securities will be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Jul 3, 2025, and will pay a semi-annual distribution rate from Jul 2, 2025.

site_title: China’s wealth fund pulls plug on US$1 billion private equity sale
summary: China's sovereign wealth fund, CIC, has pulled its planned sale of $1 billion in US private equity stakes due to reduced pressure to divest amid US-China tensions. The decision comes after US and Chinese officials hammered out a framework to de-escalate tensions, potentially removing restrictions on rare earth shipments and tech exports. CIC had initially planned to sell stakes in firms such as Carlyle Group, KKR, and TPG to reduce its US exposure, but the deal is now on hold.

site_title: FedEx forecasts profits below analysts’ target, shares dive 5% after hours
summary: FedEx forecasted profits below analysts' target, with shares diving 5% after hours. The company predicted adjusted profit of $3.40 to $4 per share for the current quarter, short of estimates of $4.06 per share. FedEx is more exposed to China trade than rival UPS, whose shares fell less than 1%. The company cited volatile demand and evolving trade policies as factors, and declined to give full-year forecasts. FedEx reported adjusted profit of $1.5 billion for the fiscal fourth quarter, up from the previous year.

site_title: It’s not just barrels that oil markets are watching – it’s odds
summary: Oil markets are closely watching the Strait of Hormuz, a critical waterway for fossil fuel transportation, amid speculation that Iran may shut it down. A prediction platform, Polymarket, shows a 43% chance of Iran's closure before July, which has influenced oil prices. Despite US President Donald Trump's ceasefire announcement, the odds have nearly halved, and prices have surged. However, traders are trying to read intent, and a prolonged oil rally could lead to "stagflationary shock" in Asia, forcing policymakers to tighten policy instead of easing rates.

site_title: Trump’s chip tariff threat sparks pushback from auto industry to tech
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed 25% tariff on imported semiconductors has sparked widespread opposition from major industries, including the auto sector, technology, and boat makers. Over 150 stakeholders, including companies like Tesla, General Motors, and Intel, have submitted comments expressing concerns over the potential economic fallout. The tariffs could disrupt supply lines, increase costs for consumers, and hinder the production of critical components for industries such as 5G wireless, artificial intelligence, and autonomous driving. Industry leaders and trading partners, including Taiwan and Japan, have also voiced concerns over the impact of the proposed tariffs.

site_title: Bank of Japan board divided over rate pause and inflation risks, June summary shows
summary: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy board is divided over whether to raise interest rates, with some members calling for a pause due to uncertainty over US tariffs' impact on Japan's economy, while others see inflation rising at higher-than-expected levels. The BOJ will hold its next policy meeting on July 30 to 31, when it will release fresh quarterly growth and price forecasts. The central bank has signaled readiness to raise rates further, but US tariffs have forced it to cut its growth forecasts and complicate decisions on the timing of the next rate increase.

images.alt_text: The analysis comes amid heightening attention within the BOJ board on how persistent rises in food and raw material costs could affect underlying inflation, and households’ perception of future price moves.
Food inflation was a major driver, with the price of rice - Japan's staple food - jumping 102 per cent from a year earlier.

In a quarterly outlook report released on May 1, the BOJ cut its price forecasts and said underlying inflation will stagnate for some time as uncertainty on US trade policy weighs on the export-reliant economy.

summary: US President Donald Trump stated that Israel had called off its attack on Iran, despite Israeli media reporting new airstrikes near Teheran. The strikes occurred minutes after Trump's statement, contradicting his claim. Trump expressed frustration with Israel, which had announced major strikes on Teheran, and warned both sides against violating the ceasefire. The conflict between Israel and Iran has resulted in 606 deaths in Iran and 28 deaths in Israel.

site_title: ST Engineering divests entire equity interest in US-based construction player LeeBoy for US$290 million
summary: ST Engineering divests its entire equity interest in US-based construction equipment manufacturer LeeBoy for US$290 million. The sale's net proceeds, approximately US$246 million, will be used for debt repayment, resulting in interest expense savings of US$9 million. The transaction is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2025, subject to regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions. LeeBoy's disposal is projected to result in a net gain of about S$100 million, after taxes and transaction expenses.

site_title: More homes, business hubs and parks – what’s coming up in Singapore in next 10 to 15 years
summary: Singapore's Draft Master Plan 2025 outlines long-term plans for a sustainable and liveable future. The plan aims to create more homes, business hubs, and parks, with a focus on four themes: shaping a happy, healthy city; enabling sustainable growth; strengthening urban resilience; and stewarding Singapore's nature and heritage. Key developments include new housing estates in Newton, Paterson, and Greater one-north areas, as well as redevelopment of the Paya Lebar Air Base area. The plan also aims to support seniors' housing needs, enhance recreational spaces, and strengthen transport connectivity. Additionally, the government plans to decentralize commercial spaces, refresh business hubs, and safeguard the city's heritage.

site_title: Finding opportunities in disclosures
summary: MSCI Research found that companies with transition plans in the energy sector are planning to invest more in hydrogen, renewables, electric vehicles, and carbon capture and storage. The report identified clean-tech sectors with increased demand due to decarbonisation commitments, including hydrogen-related patents and clean transportation solutions. In the utilities sector, clean energy and hydrogen-fired generation are strategic priorities, with over 80% of transition plans indicating potential use of clean fuels. The increasing number of companies reporting transition plans is expected to improve data quality and enable broader trend analysis, potentially leading to profitable investment opportunities.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rally as Iran-Israel ceasefire holds, oil claws back some losses
summary: Asia stocks rallied on Wednesday after Iran and Israel agreed to a ceasefire, ending a week of hostilities. The US dollar struggled to recover from a sharp drop, while oil prices climbed despite being down 16% from their highs. The global rally was fueled by US President Donald Trump's announcement of the ceasefire, which also boosted optimism over a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. Stocks surged in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Singapore, while Tokyo edged down, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records.

images.alt_text: Tokyo and Hong Kong stocks were up 1.4 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: BlackBerry raises annual revenue forecast on robust demand for cybersecurity services
summary: BlackBerry raised its annual revenue forecast for fiscal year 2026, citing robust demand for its cybersecurity services amid growing online crimes. The company now expects revenue between US$508 million and US$538 million, up from its earlier forecast of US$504 million to US$534 million. This boost is attributed to companies investing heavily in cybersecurity, benefiting firms like BlackBerry. The company also raised its forecast for its secure communications segment, which provides intelligent security software to enterprises and governments.

site_title: US: Iran-Israel ceasefire lifts stocks
summary: US stocks surged 1.2% on Tuesday as an Iran-Israel ceasefire appeared to hold, boosting oil prices and lifting market sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 43,089.02, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes advanced 1.1% and 1.4%, respectively. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's testimony was seen as constructive, but he did not rule out a potential interest rate cut. The rally came despite a decline in US consumer confidence and mixed earnings reports from individual companies.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent higher at 42,581.78 on Monday.

This emergence of AI products, including DeepSeek, is expected to fundamentally change the Chinese economy and increase competition with the US in cutting-edge technologies. Despite US-China tensions and economic challenges, China's tech stocks have rallied, and the country's high-tech sector is expected to contribute around 15-18% to its GDP in 2024 and 2026, respectively.

site_title: Target explores factory-direct shipping model used by Temu
summary: Target is testing a factory-direct shipping model similar to Chinese e-commerce platforms Temu and Shein, aiming to offer lower prices and increase market share among discounters. The effort is part of the retailer's efforts to revive sales growth, which has been hindered by choppy store traffic, soft demand, and inventory missteps. site_title: Swiss losing ground faster to Asian rivals in wealth, BCG says
summary: Switzerland's position as the world's top wealth management centre is under threat from Asian rivals, according to a Boston Consulting Group report. Assets in Switzerland increased by 6% to $2.7 trillion in 2024, while Singapore and the UAE recorded the strongest growth at 11.9% and 11.1% respectively. The Swiss government has introduced stricter regulations, but investors such as Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund have expressed concerns about the nation's reputation as a safe haven.

summary: Oil prices dropped 6% on Tuesday, settling at a two-week low, amid a ceasefire between Israel and Iran that reduced Middle East supply risk. Brent crude futures fell $4.34 to $67.14 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell $4.14 to $64.37. The geopolitical risk premium had vanished after the US attacked Iran's nuclear facilities, and US President Trump's comments suggested China could continue to purchase oil from Iran.

summary: Thailand recorded a 4.24% year-over-year drop in foreign visitors from January 1 to June 22, with approximately 16.04 million foreign visitors. Malaysia was the largest source, followed by China. This decline is lower than the National Economic and Social Development Council's forecast of 37 million foreign tourists for the year.

site_title: Singapore shares rise on Israel-Iran ceasefire; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to 3,904.3 points, following a US-brokered ceasefire in the Israel-Iran conflict, which boosted global markets. Other Asian indices, including the Hang Seng and Nikkei 225, also increased. Market strategist James Ooi warned investors to remain cautious, citing potential inflation fears if the conflict escalates, while focusing on macro drivers such as tariffs and US President Donald Trump's policies.

site_title: It’s not just Labubu dolls. Chinese brands are booming
summary: Chinese brands, including those from companies like Pop Mart, Laopu Gold, and Chagee, are experiencing a surge in popularity, both domestically and internationally. Despite economic growth slowdown, consumers are flocking to local luxury firms, high-end make-up brands, and milk tea shops, driving sales and market share gains. Western brands, such as Starbucks and Tiffany & Co, are struggling to compete with their Chinese counterparts, which often offer similar products at lower prices. The trend is driven by Chinese consumers becoming more price-sensitive and seeking high-quality, "emotive" products with a distinct Chinese flair.

site_title: Singapore forms government coalition with UK, Kenya to grow carbon markets
summary: Singapore, the UK, and Kenya have formed a government-led coalition to grow carbon markets. The coalition aims to issue shared principles on the voluntary use of carbon credits, ensuring consistency across jurisdictions. The principles will give businesses confidence and incentives to invest in carbon credits, boosting investment in climate-positive businesses and sustainable development projects. The coalition will finalize the guidelines by November's COP30 climate conference and expand its membership to include countries that are sources of demand and supply for carbon credits.

site_title: Weakening economy supports prospects of US Treasuries
summary: Weakening US economy supports long-dated US Treasuries as negative factors have been priced in. Despite concerns over the US fiscal situation, including the "One Big Beautiful Bill" and potential erosion of the US dollar's role as a reserve currency, the market expects the Fed to cut interest rates twice this year, potentially more than expected. This could support long-term Treasury prices and inflation-protected bonds, making them attractive investments.

site_title: Siemens is battling Big Tech for AI supremacy at factories
summary: Siemens is developing its own industrial foundation model, a key component of artificial intelligence (AI) technology, to provide a tailored solution for manufacturing industries. The company aims to leverage its industrial expertise to create a safe and efficient AI infrastructure, differentiating itself from tech giants like Google and Nvidia. Siemens' strategy involves partnering with industrial companies to collect data, which will train the foundation model, and promises to provide engineering know-how, operations safety, and data security to manufacturers. This move pits Siemens against established AI players and raises questions about whether industrial companies with software experience can triumph over tech companies in the AI market.

site_title: New Zealand-based Xero forks out over US$2.5 billion to buy US fintech firm Melio
summary: Xero, a New Zealand-based information technology giant, has agreed to buy US fintech firm Melio for an upfront consideration of US$2.5 billion. The deal, funded through a US$1.2 billion placement and a US$400 million unsecured credit facility, aims to more than double Xero's group revenue by 2028. Melio, which provides digital bill payment solutions for small businesses, will also receive up to US$500 million in deferrals and rollovers over the next three years. The acquisition is expected to significantly boost Xero's top line and accelerate US revenue growth.

site_title: Travel chaos starts to ease as Gulf states reopen airspace
summary: Air travel disruptions in the Middle East have started to ease as Gulf states reopened their airspace following a ceasefire deal between Israel and Iran. National carriers in the Gulf, including Emirates, Qatar Airways, and Bahrain Airlines, resumed flights, while airports in Dubai and Doha reopened after briefly closing due to Iran's missile strike. Despite the easing of airspace restrictions, the hiatus in fighting remains tentative and fragile, with Israel accusing Iran of violating the ceasefire. Airlines have seen shares surge, with European carriers rising 4-10% on the news.

site_title: Powell reiterates no rush to cut as Fed awaits tariff clarity
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell reiterated that there's no rush to lower interest rates, citing uncertainty over the economic impact of President Trump's tariffs. The Fed left interest rates unchanged in a range of 4.25-4.5% last week and is waiting for more clarity on the tariffs' effects. Powell said the tariffs' impact on inflation could be short-lived or more persistent, depending on the level of tariffs and how long it takes for their effects to pass through into prices.

site_title: Thai party plans no-confidence vote against embattled PM
summary: Thailand's Bhumjaithai Party, which withdrew its support for the government last week, plans a parliamentary no-confidence vote against Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra and her cabinet next week. The motion, which requires the support of 30 lawmakers, aims to test the embattled premier's leadership amid a border row with Cambodia and public pressure over a leaked phone conversation. Despite the government's claims of having the backing of more than half of the house, the Bhumjaithai Party is inviting other opposition groups to back the motion, which could further destabilize the ruling coalition.

site_title: US consumer confidence drops on broad concerns about economy
summary: US consumer confidence dropped 5.4 points to 93 in June, erasing nearly half of the prior month's rebound, due to concerns about the economy, labor market, and personal finances. The decline was attributed to higher US import duties, despite modest inflation over the past three months. Consumers became more guarded about spending, with a 4.6-point drop in expectations for the next six months and a 6.4-point drop in present conditions. The share of consumers expecting higher interest rates increased to 57%, the highest since October 2023.

site_title: Five dos and don’ts when investing in the stock market
summary: Investing in the stock market requires a long-term mindset, discipline, and patience. Key dos and don'ts include avoiding treating the market like a casino, being cautious of excessive scepticism when share prices rise, not taking on debt to invest, and investing regularly using spare cash. Adopting a long-term perspective, understanding a company's true worth, and harnessing the power of compounding can help build wealth over time. Historically, stocks have outperformed other investment options, delivering greater returns than fixed deposits or savings accounts, and can help stay ahead of inflation.

images.alt_text: Four ways to identify promising growth stocks
SGX Ltd is an example of a stock that thrives in market volatility.

site_title: Shifting sands: Navigating the future of the world’s reserve currency
summary: The US dollar's dominance as the world's reserve currency is under scrutiny due to recent geopolitical shifts and evolving national policies. Despite a slight decline in its share of global reserves, the dollar faces significant hurdles to losing its dominant status. A paradigm shift would require sustained erosion of international confidence, emergence of a credible alternative, and developed financial markets. The euro and China are considered potential challengers, but strict capital controls and limited market access hinder China's path to dominance. A decline in dollar dominance would have implications for investors, with currency risks and asset allocation decisions being affected.

site_title: Indonesia’s sovereign wealth fund Danantara loans US$405 million to flag carrier Garuda
summary: Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund Danantara has loaned US$405 million to flag carrier Garuda Indonesia, with US$111 million going to Garuda and the remainder to Citilink for 15 grounded jets. The loan is part of a "comprehensive transformation" aimed at expanding Garuda's fleet to 120 aircraft over the next five years. The move comes after Garuda booked a net loss in 2024, following two years of profit. The loan will be repaid based on performance, with global expertise to be brought in to aid Garuda's business plans.

site_title: Three Arrows founders fail in appeal for orders to disclose crypto fund dealings to be set aside
summary: The Court of Appeal in Singapore dismissed an application by Three Arrows Capital founders Zhu Su and Kyle Davies to set aside orders requiring them to disclose their dealings with the now-defunct cryptocurrency fund. The court also overturned a lower court decision allowing liquidators to examine Zhu Su. The founders were ordered to disclose their dealings in 2022, and both were sentenced to four months' jail for contempt of court. The Court of Appeal ruled that Zhu and Davies deliberately chose not to comply with the disclosure order, and their delay in filing to set it aside was unreasonable.

site_title: Thailand shortlists two nominees for central bank governor role
summary: Thailand has shortlisted two candidates for central bank governor, a role set to succeed incumbent Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput on September 30. The two nominees, Sutapa Amornvivat and Somprawin Manprasert, will be appointed for a five-year term after a secret ballot among a seven-member independent selection panel. Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira will make the final pick, with the new governor expected to navigate the country's struggling economy, high household debt, and potential US tariffs. The appointment is seen as crucial for Thailand's monetary policy trajectory.

Bank lending dropped 1.3 per cent in the first quarter of 2025 from a year earlier, after an annual fall of 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter, says the Bank of Thailand.

On April 30, the Bank of Thailand’s monetary policy committee voted to cut the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 1.75 per cent, the lowest level in two years, and lowered its growth and inflation forecasts.

site_title: MMC Ports to file for biggest Malaysian IPO since 2012: sources
summary: MMC Port Holdings, a Malaysian port operator, plans to file for the country's largest initial public offering (IPO) since 2012. The company could raise approximately US$2 billion in a share sale as soon as September, valuing it at up to US$7 billion. MMC Ports operates seven ports along the Straits of Malacca, one of the world's busiest shipping lanes, and is the largest such operator in Malaysia. The IPO, if successful, would be the biggest in Kuala Lumpur in over a decade.

images.alt_text: An archive photo of Port Klang. It is one of the key transshipment hubs in South-east Asia, handling over 14.6 million TEUs in 2024.

site_title: Global de-dollarisation trend intact as safe-haven rally in US dollar peters out
summary: The US dollar's recent safe-haven rally has slowed, but analysts say a weaker greenback is still giving Asian central banks room to ease monetary policy. The dollar index briefly reached 100, driven by US President Trump's air strikes on Iranian nuclear sites, but reversed after a ceasefire was announced. Analysts agree that a de-dollarisation trend is intact, driven by growing alternative non-dollar pools of liquidity, but also say the dollar's safe-haven status remains intact due to its strong economy and institutional strength.

site_title: Investing in peak uncertainty: a view across asset classes
summary: Markets have entered a new era of turbulence, with the US economy potentially slowing and inflation adjusting after a one-off spike. Investors should diversify across asset classes, industries, and geographies, particularly globally. The US Federal Reserve remains cautious, while Europe and emerging markets may benefit from forced collaboration and reduced exposure to US trade policies. Fixed income investors should focus on diversifying and seeking opportunities in investment-grade credit, while equities should be evaluated based on company fundamentals rather than sectors. A thoughtful active management approach with a long-term view is recommended to navigate the uncertain environment.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit one-week highs on Middle East ceasefire
summary: European stocks rose to a one-week high on Tuesday, driven by a ceasefire between Israel and Iran, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index surging 1.11% and its largest single-day jump in over a month. Airlines and travel stocks soared, while energy stocks fell due to a 5% drop in oil prices. The US President announced the agreement, and Iran's President vowed to stick to the deal unless provoked by Israel. This optimism led to a rally in other bourses, including Germany's DAX and French and Spanish markets, with the Stoxx 600 set to close the month 1% lower.

images.alt_text: The European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.28 per cent lower at 535.03 on Monday, after touching its lowest level in over a month earlier in the session.

site_title: Why global imbalances do matter
summary: The US economy's reliance on global trade imbalances poses financial stability concerns. The main issue isn't manufacturing impact, but rather the potential for financial instability. To address this, implementing a tax on capital inflows could be a policy intervention. This approach would align with the goal of reducing the external deficit, achieved through higher taxes and lower spending commitments. Such a policy would also weaken the dollar, potentially boosting tradeable goods and services production. However, this contradicts Donald Trump's preference for low taxes and high spending.

images.alt_text: Many US companies operate on a global scale with dominant positions in the US and international markets. For instance, Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet hold more than 60 per cent of the global cloud market share.

Worry about the budget deficit picked up in May tied to a tax-cut bill moving through Congress. The House-passed version of the tax and spending bill would add US$2.4 trillion to US budget deficits over the next decade, according to an estimate from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.

site_title: US: Wall St indexes open higher after Trump's Israel-Iran ceasefire announcement
summary: US stock indexes opened higher on Tuesday after President Donald Trump announced a ceasefire between Israel and Iran, calming investor nerves following a 12-day conflict that hurt global risk assets and fueled inflation concerns. The Dow Jones rose 225.3 points, or 0.53%, to 42,807.13, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains, up 36.0 and 178.6 points, respectively. The announcement eased investor anxiety, leading to a positive market reaction.

site_title: Citi appoints Nathan Swami as new head of markets for Singapore
summary: Citi has appointed Nathan Swami as the new head of markets for Singapore, succeeding Smith Smithangura who is retiring at the end of June. Swami, with over 17 years of experience at Citi in Singapore, will assume the role effective immediately, subject to regulatory approvals. He will continue to serve as head of FX trading for Asia-Pacific. The bank described Swami as a "seasoned leader" and expressed confidence in his ability to partner across products and sales teams to deliver best-in-class solutions to clients and grow the business.

site_title: Israeli defence minister orders attacks on Iran after ceasefire 'violation'
summary: Israeli Defence Minister Israel Katz ordered military strikes on Iran after detecting missiles fired from the country, allegedly violating a ceasefire agreed upon by both nations. The ceasefire was supposed to be in effect after 12 days of war, following Israel's bombing campaign against Iran. Iran had confirmed it would halt retaliatory strikes if Israel stopped attacking. However, the Israeli military detected the launch of Iranian missiles, prompting Katz to order strikes.

site_title: Indonesian coal miners on shaky ground as global demand falters, rules tighten
summary: Indonesian coal miners face significant challenges due to a global supply glut and tightening regulations at home. The country's total coal exports dropped 19.7% in the first four months of the year, with export value falling 19.7% to $8.2 billion. Analysts expect medium to large-sized coal companies with strong cash reserves to weather the current challenges, but others may struggle. The industry's diversification strategy may need to be fast-tracked to capture growth in emerging markets, and miners may face squeezed margins due to rising regulatory pressures and declining demand from China and India.

summary: Asian stocks rose following US President Donald Trump's announcement of a ceasefire between Iran and Israel. However, oil prices plummeted 7% overnight after Iran attacked a US military base in Qatar, not tankers. Gold prices also fell more than 1% due to the ceasefire. These market movements were influenced by the news, leading to a mixed day for investors.

site_title: Deep China-Singapore relationship built even before establishing diplomatic ties 35 years ago: PM Wong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has reaffirmed the country's strong relationship with China, built on mutual respect and trust since diplomatic ties were established 35 years ago. During his official visit, Wong met with President Xi Jinping and third-in-command Zhao Leji, discussing cooperation in areas like the digital and green economies, and supporting a rules-based multilateral trading system. Both leaders also emphasized the importance of maintaining open and inclusive trade, and stressed the need for cooperation to enhance the relevance and effectiveness of global economic institutions.

site_title: Income Insurance to explore other share liquidity options after scuppered Allianz deal: departing chairman Ronald Ong
summary: Income Insurance's departing chairman Ronald Ong said the company is exploring share liquidity options, including a share-buyback program, after a proposed deal with Allianz was scuppered due to regulatory concerns. The board has proposed lead independent director Joy Tan to take over as chairman, subject to her re-election and regulatory approvals. Ong reiterated that the company prioritizes minority shareholders' requests, which include a viable liquidity option. Income Insurance's total assets grew 2.5% to S$43.4 billion, and net asset value per share stood at S$31.97 for the financial year ended Dec 31, 2024.

site_title: Big US banks expected to ace stress tests, boost dividends
summary: The Federal Reserve's annual stress tests on US banks are expected to show that the largest lenders have sufficient capital to withstand a severe economic downturn, allowing them to boost dividends and share buybacks. Analysts predict a 3% increase in dividends and share repurchases, driven by improved regulatory tone and favourable loan growth. However, banks may remain cautious due to ongoing uncertainty and regulatory reform. The stress tests' methodology is also expected to become less onerous, with the Fed planning to average results and provide more transparency.

site_title: Toyota crashes Indonesia’s used-car party with US$120 million bet
summary: Toyota has invested US$120 million in Astra Digital Mobil, gaining a 40% stake in used-car marketplaces OLX and OLXmobbi in Indonesia. The move comes as new-car sales in the country dropped 13.9% in 2024, while used-car sales rose 80,000 units. Toyota's entry into the used-car market could help it tap into a lucrative segment, but smaller players like Carro and Carsome face challenges from entrenched incumbents with deeper pockets. The market's fragmentation and the need for flexible financing options will be crucial in determining the outcome.

site_title: A US$4 billion Hong Kong family office makes first crypto foray

The investment is part of VMS' diversification efforts into more liquid investments, following the firm's focus on private equity and longer-duration strategies. The move comes as digital assets gain popularity, with Bitcoin rallying 50% since Donald Trump's election, and growing institutional support from jurisdictions and governments.

The five selected VC firms will deploy over RM200 million to nurture around 50 Malaysian startups, aiming to create a regional VC hub. summary: US District Judge Allison Burroughs has issued an injunction blocking President Donald Trump's administration from implementing a plan to bar foreign nationals from entering the US to study at Harvard University. The ruling extends a temporary order issued earlier, preventing the administration from enforcing a proclamation citing national security concerns. The judge ruled that the administration's actions likely violate Harvard's free speech rights under the US Constitution's First Amendment. The injunction allows Harvard to continue hosting international students and scholars while the case moves forward.

summary: Hong Kong's smaller developers face a US$22 billion risk for banks as lenders demand stricter refinancing terms, credit enhancements, and halt new lending. Smaller developers, including Lai Sun Development and Wang On Properties, are struggling with high interest rates and plunging asset values, resulting in a deepening property downturn in the city. The pressure threatens to erode bank margins, weigh on the local job sector, and send ripples through overseas markets. Several banks have stopped renewing financing terms with small to mid-sized real estate firms, forcing them to turn to private credit lenders.

site_title: PropertyBT: Selling Singapore’s new dream homes
summary: Singapore's new dream homes, developed by GuocoLand, are commanding high prices and selling quickly due to their modern designs, fresh tenure, and state-of-the-art facilities. site_title: Billionaire leaves ownership of Thai beermaker to five children
summary: Billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, Thailand's richest man, has distributed stakes in Thai Beverage, a 66% controlling stake in the Thai beer maker, to his five children. The move leaves the future of his business empire unclear, as the children's roles and succession plan are yet to be determined. The billionaire's son, Thapana, is currently CEO of ThaiBev, and the restructuring will see him share control with his siblings, including three sisters.

site_title: Korean consumer confidence jumps to four-year high on stimulus hope
summary: South Korea's consumer confidence has reached a four-year high, rising 6.9 points to 108.7 in June, driven by easing domestic political uncertainty, fresh fiscal stimulus, and hopes for pro-growth policies under the new administration. This marks a third consecutive month of improvement after plummeting to a 12-year low in December. The government's supplementary budget aims to revive growth and restore confidence, while the expected inflation rate has fallen to 2.4%, attributed to easing consumer price growth and price stabilisation efforts.

summary: US Federal Reserve Vice-Chair Michelle Bowman expressed openness to a July interest rate cut if inflation effects from President Donald Trump's tariffs remain limited. This comes after Fed Governor Christopher Waller also suggested a rate cut as soon as next month. Bowman noted that data has not shown clear signs of material impacts from tariffs and that ongoing trade negotiations have reduced the economic environment's risk. summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has rejected a request by former NTUC Income CEO Tan Suee Chieh to meet with chairman Gan Kim Yong over the proposed Allianz transaction to buy a controlling stake in NTUC Income. site_title: Gold hits near 2-week low as Trump announces Israel-Iran ceasefire
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a ceasefire between Israel and Iran, reducing safe-haven demand for gold, which hit its lowest level since June 11, slipping 0.6% to US$3,349.89 an ounce. The deal, brokered by Trump, requires Iran not to launch further attacks, and Trump stated the truce would be considered "ended" in 12 hours. This development led to a decline in gold futures and US interest rate speculation, with US Federal Reserve officials discussing potential rate cuts amid potential risks to the job market.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$3,371.30 an ounce.

site_title: Malaysia’s May CPI rises 1.2% y/y, less than forecast
summary: Malaysia's consumer price index (CPI) rose 1.2% in May from a year earlier, below the forecasted 1.4% increase. This is the second consecutive month of a lower-than-expected CPI, following a 1.4% rise in April. The data suggests a slowdown in inflation, which may provide relief for the Malaysian economy.

site_title: Nissan’s new CEO faces investor grilling over job cuts, losses and mounting debt
summary: Nissan's new CEO Ivan Espinosa is facing investor scrutiny over job cuts, losses, and mounting debt. The company plans to eliminate 20,000 jobs and close seven manufacturing sites, with a projected operating loss of up to $2.1 billion if US tariffs remain in place. Nissan's debt is expected to reach 800 billion yen ($6.9 billion) next year, and the company is seeking to raise funds through debt and asset sales. Espinosa's restructuring plan aims to turn the struggling Japanese carmaker around, but investors are questioning its viability.

site_title: Australia: Banks, miners lift stocks; Trump’s Iran-Israel truce announcement boosts sentiment
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.1% to 8,569.50 points, driven by gains in banks and miners, amid global investor sentiment lifted by US President Donald Trump's announcement of an Iran-Israel ceasefire. Financials reached a record high, while miners advanced 1.5% on stronger iron ore prices. Energy stocks fell, bucking the trend, as oil prices weakened.

images.alt_text: The European Stoxx 600 index closed 0.28 per cent lower at 535.03 on Monday, after touching its lowest level in over a month earlier in the session.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.9 per cent higher at 42,581.78 on Monday.

site_title: Oil settles down 7% after Iran attacks US military base in Qatar, not tankers
summary: Oil prices plummeted 7.2% on Monday after Iran attacked a US military base in Qatar in retaliation for US airstrikes on its nuclear facilities. Brent crude futures fell to $71.48 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude eased to $68.51 a barrel. Despite concerns of potential disruptions to oil exports, no Iranian attacks were detected on tankers or oil production facilities, and shipments from Qatar remained uninterrupted. The attack may be a step towards reducing tensions, but investors are still weighing the geopolitical risk premium.

site_title: Iran launches missiles at US bases in Qatar in retaliatory strike
summary: Iran launched a retaliatory strike against a US air base in Qatar, targeting The Al-Udeid base, which is the regional headquarters for US Central Command. The attack, which included at least six missiles, was intercepted and resulted in no casualties. The move comes after the US struck three major nuclear sites in Iran on Saturday night, prompting Iran to vow to retaliate "proportionately and decisively." Oil prices fell immediately after the attack, and the UAE and Bahrain closed their airspace as a precaution.

site_title: Jensen Huang starts selling Nvidia stock under US$865 million plan
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has started selling the company's stock under a plan to offload up to $865 million worth by the end of the year. Huang sold 100,000 shares for $14.4 million on June 20 and 23, as part of a 10b5-1 plan adopted in March. The plan allows him to sell up to 6 million shares by year's end, valued at $865 million at $144.17 per share. Huang's sales are part of a trend of billionaire executives selling Nvidia stock, with another board director, Mark Stevens, also disposing of shares recently.

site_title: World facing 'most complex' situation in decades: WEF
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has warned that the world is facing the "most complex" geopolitical situation in decades, impacting global growth. WEF President Borge Brende said that if growth doesn't revive, it could lead to a decade of lower growth. The warning comes amid the US' involvement in the Iran-Israel conflict, a global economy battered by a tariff war, and a slowdown in global growth forecasts. The WEF gathering in Tianjin, China, will discuss ways to address these challenges, with a focus on digital trade, services, and emerging technologies like artificial intelligence.
