Defence stocks may not be seeing the hype expected, analysts say. Rather, equities from regions such as Asia ex-Japan and Europe may deserve more attention from investors at this time.

site_title: SpaceX Starship explodes on Texas launch pad
summary: A SpaceX Starship rocket exploded during a routine ground test in Texas, causing a fireball and damaging the surrounding area. The incident occurred at the Starbase launch facility, where the company was preparing for the 10th test flight of Starship. Initial analysis suggests a potential failure of a pressurized tank, but the full data review is ongoing. Despite the setback, SpaceX remains committed to its long-term vision of building a human colony on Mars, with Elon Musk downplaying the incident as "just a scratch."

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said his relationship with Elon Musk was over after they exchanged insults on social media, with the Tesla and SpaceX CEO describing the president’s sweeping tax and spending Bill as a “disgusting abomination.”

Even if Elon Musk deserves credit for his part in SpaceX’s domination in both rocket launches and satellite communications, the feud’s weaponisation of space suggests innovation has taken a backseat to favouritism.
Some politicos in Washington speculate that Donald Trump (left) and Elon Musk will try to mend their relationship and limit the business and political damage from last week’s explosive bust-up.
The verbal punches erupted on Thursday after Trump criticised Musk in the Oval Office and the pair then traded barbs on their social media platforms: Trump’s Truth Social and Musk’s X.

site_title: EU countries back winemaker support plan, with 'low-alcohol' tweak
summary: The European Union's 27 governments have backed a plan to support winemakers, addressing challenges from falling demand, climate change, and global trade tensions. The plan includes reducing labelling requirements for exports, renaming "alcohol-light" products to "low-alcohol", and exempting exported wines from listing ingredients and nutrition data. The European Commission also aims to encourage tourism to European vineyards and extend EU financial support for advertising campaigns and climate change adaptation. The package must be negotiated and approved by the European Parliament before it can come into force.

images.alt_text: Take a rickshaw ride to see where beer brewing began in Japan.

site_title: C-suite on demand: Is Singapore ready to embrace fractional work?
summary: Singapore is embracing the concept of fractional work, where experienced executives offer their expertise on a part-time basis to organizations. Fractional leaders, such as David Lim, a former marketing executive, now work one to three days a week for companies, filling key roles like CMO, CFO, and CHRO. This flexible hiring model offers a win-win strategy, allowing executives to have better work-life integration and companies to access top-tier talent at a fraction of the cost. However, structural barriers persist, including lack of onboarding processes and unfamiliarity with the concept, which must be addressed to fully adopt this new hiring model.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Goh Aik Chuan, founder and managing partner of Garlic Equity Capital, aims to acquire an SME in Singapore or Malaysia by mid-2027.

site_title: South Korea’s Cuckoo set for Malaysia debut after scaling down IPO
summary: Cuckoo International (Mal), a South Korean home-appliance maker's Malaysian subsidiary, is set to debut on the stock market on June 24 after scaling down its initial public offering (IPO) due to market volatility. The company aims to raise RM395 million (S$119.4 million) with a revised offer price of RM1.08 per share. Cuckoo Malaysia's promising outlook and significant market share in the local home-appliance rental segment are expected to attract investors, despite market uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Bursa Malaysia said it is on track to meet its full year initial public offerings (IPO) target of 60 this year, the exchange has recorded 16 IPOs so far this year.

site_title: Stock to watch: SingPost
summary: SingPost, Singapore's national postal service provider, plans to divest 10 non-core assets, including 10 HDB shophouses, through a sale and leaseback strategy. The move aims to unlock shareholder value and maintain current post office services, which have been unprofitable in recent years. The properties are expected to fetch S$50 million in total. This follows a 0.9% gain in SingPost shares on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: At Art Basel, dealers reap rewards by sidestepping politics and war
summary: Art Basel 2025 featured a predominantly apolitical art market, with dealers opting for safe and neutral works amidst the current global turmoil. The fair's VIP days saw thick crowds but a relatively calm atmosphere, with many artworks priced at over $30 million selling quickly. Only a few pieces, such as Jonas Staal's protest against luxury yachts and Barbara Kruger's "WAR TIME, WAR CRIME," took a more overtly political stance. Despite this, the fair's overall tone remained optimistic, with many dealers reporting successful sales and a resilient market.

images.alt_text: At CHAT, Ari Bayuaji showcases beautiful tapestries weaved from discarded plastic ropes polluting Bali’s beaches. The artist is represented in Singapore by Mizuma Gallery.
A monumental artwork by Vajiko Chachkhiani reflects on the crisis of mass migration.
Art Basel Switzerland postponed till September

site_title: Japan’s prices climb by most in two years ahead of election
summary: Japan's core inflation hit a two-year high in May, exceeding the central bank's 2% target, with food inflation driving the increase. The core consumer price index rose 3.7% from a year earlier, with rice prices doubling in May. The Bank of Japan faces pressure to resume interest rate hikes despite economic headwinds from US tariffs and uncertainty over President Trump's trade policy. Economists expect the BOJ to weigh the impact of US tariffs and domestic labour shortages on inflation, with some predicting a rate hike in early 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past an electronic screen displaying stock quotation board in Tokyo, Japan April 15, 2025. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
The Tokyo exchange has emphasised since last year that its priority for listed firms is quality rather than a big numbers of companies.

In a quarterly outlook report released on May 1, the BOJ cut its price forecasts and said underlying inflation will stagnate for some time as uncertainty on US trade policy weighs on the export-reliant economy.

site_title: Flaming yakitori at Firebird by Suetomi
summary: Firebird by Suetomi, a Japanese eatery in Singapore, offers a unique dining experience with its show-stopping wood-burning grill. The menu features a straightforward selection of grilled chicken parts, side dishes, and claypot rice, but the quality of the chicken is a letdown due to sourcing issues. While the chefs' skill in achieving crispy chicken skin is impressive, it's not enough to elevate the overall experience. The restaurant's novelty and visually appealing atmosphere make it a decent option, but it falls short of its potential. Rating: 6.

images.alt_text: (Clockwise from top left) Fried chicken in yellow curry with coconut rice from Belimbing; cold noodles with local mussels in a savoury broth; roast suckling pig with roasted cherry apple from Sugarra; and chutoro or tuna belly sushi from Keijo.
Japanese scallops on a herb sauce.

site_title: MOF says SRS withdrawal process ‘can be improved’, will work with banks on this
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MOF) plans to improve the withdrawal process for Supplementary Retirement Scheme (SRS) funds, working with banks to smoothen the process. The current face-to-face requirement allows for tailored advice, but some have criticized the lengthy queues. The MOF will review the process in response to a forum letter, which called for a review of the requirement for retirees to physically visit a bank.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
The SRS is part of Singapore’s broader Central Provident Fund scheme.
The banks have flagged that the framework could raise competition concerns as they would be horizontal competitors in both the upstream and downstream markets for SRS products.

site_title: ArcelorMittal drops plans for green steel in Germany due to high energy costs
summary: ArcelorMittal, the world's second-largest steelmaker, has dropped plans to convert two German steel plants to carbon-neutral production due to high energy costs. The decision, worth 1.3 billion euros, comes as Germany struggles to transition from Russian gas to renewable energy sources. ArcelorMittal cited uncertainty over Germany's energy mix and high electricity prices as the reasons for the cancellation. The move casts doubt on Germany's green hydrogen strategy and highlights the challenges faced by the European steel industry.

images.alt_text: Canada is the largest supplier of foreign steel and aluminum to the United States, and PM Mark Carney (pictured) earlier this month had denounced the doubling of US tariffs on Canadian imports of steel and aluminum, calling them “unjustified” and “illegal.”

Nippon Steel said its annual crude steel production capacity is expected to reach 86 million tonnes, bringing it closer to Nippon Steel’s global strategic goal of 100 million tonnes of global crude steel production capacity.

site_title: Thailand PM apologises as crisis threatens to topple government
summary: Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra apologized for a leaked phone call with former Cambodian leader Hun Sen, sparking widespread anger and threatening her government's stability. Her main coalition partner, the Bhumjaithai party, quit, leaving her with a fragile majority in parliament. Calls for her resignation or an election are growing, putting the country in a fresh round of political instability. The military has expressed its commitment to democratic principles, but the crisis has raised concerns about a potential coup, making Paetongtarn the third member of her family to be ousted by the military.

images.alt_text: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra faces mounting calls to resign after a leaked phone call she had with former Cambodian leader Hun Sen provoked widespread anger and resulted in a key coalition partner to quit.
Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a parliament session on the budget for 2026 fiscal year in Bangkok on 28 May.

Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Thailand's prime minister, leaves a meeting at the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Monday, May 26, 2025. Southeast Asian leaders start two days of talks from Monday, seeking to deepen ties with China and Gulf nations, and mitigate the fallout from US President Donald Trump’s tariff hikes. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg
Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a parliament session on the budget for 2026 fiscal year in Bangkok on 28 May.
“The digital wallet has not been cancelled, but we need to review how to use this money to stimulate the economy as much as possible,” Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra said.

site_title: Chevron seeks buyers for 50% stake in Singapore refinery: sources
summary: Chevron is seeking non-binding bids for its 50% stake in Singapore Refining Company (SRC), including from joint venture partner PetroChina. The potential sale comes as Chevron restructures globally to streamline operations and reduce costs, which could lead to up to 20% layoffs. Chevron has appointed Morgan Stanley to explore the sale of SRC and other Asian assets, with estimated valuations ranging from $300 million to $500 million.

images.alt_text: Chevron announced plans to slash the global workforce in February in order to cut costs and simplify the business.
Chevron exited Indonesia in 2023 when it divested its stakes in Indonesia Deepwater Development (IDD) after a change in the facility’s design stalled development.
The purchases “reflect Chevron’s continuing confidence in the consummation of the pending acquisition of Hess”, the company says.
Chevron’s data centres are not expected to be connected to the grid and would be primarily powered by natural gas.

site_title: Grab-GoTo merger talks face Indonesian regulatory hurdles: sources
summary: Grab and GoTo, Indonesia's ride-hailing and food delivery companies, face regulatory hurdles as the Indonesian government examines how a potential merger would impact job welfare and market competition. The government has proposed conditions, including guarantees on benefits for riders and drivers, for the deal to proceed. The two companies now need more time to agree on a deal, which could value GoTo at around $7 billion. Protests in Indonesia earlier this year opposed a potential merger, citing fears of job cuts and price increases.

images.alt_text: Grab has increased its convertible note offering to US$1.5 billion.

Exterior facade of the building housing sovereign wealth fund, known as Daya Anagata Nusantara or Danantara, in Jakarta on February 24, 2025, which was earlier launched by Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto. Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto on February 24, 2025 launched a new sovereign wealth fund set to be the biggest in Southeast Asia's largest economy and give the ex-general greater control of the country's coffers. He wants to tap into the fund's assets -- planned to be more than $900 billion -- to boost Indonesia to developed economy status, despite expert concern about its governance. (Photo by Bay ISMOYO / AFP)
Danantara is said to be interested in participating in the Grab acquisition of GoTo reported Bloomberg.

site_title: Singapore stocks sink on Thursday after Powell signals higher inflation; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% on Thursday, closing at 3,894.18, after US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled higher inflation ahead. Powell warned against placing too much confidence in rate cuts and cautioned against the impact of the Trump administration's proposed import tariffs. The decline was led by Thai Beverage, with local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also in the red. The US Federal Open Market Committee left interest rates unchanged, citing a strong labor market and reduced economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
Fed still in wait-and-see mode, as impact of tariff war is not yet fully felt

In their latest meeting, the Federal Open Market Committee agreed to leave the central bank’s benchmark interest rate unchanged in the 4.25 to 4.5 per cent range, citing a healthy labour market and reduced uncertainty in the economic outlook.
(From right) Terence Ho, Geoff Howie and Claressa Monteiro.

site_title: DBS expects economic value from its use of AI to exceed S$1 billion in 2025
summary: DBS Bank expects its economic value from AI to exceed $1 billion by 2025, citing over 350 use cases and 1,500 models in production since focusing on AI. The bank's head of generative AI, Rajeev Hassamal, emphasized the need for employees to understand how the technology works. Meanwhile, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) cautioned that banks need sufficient guardrails as AI adoption increases in the sector, with a planned playbook to provide clarity on key risk considerations.

images.alt_text: Young Zhan Heng
The bank is in the midst of a corporate cost-saving programme called “Fit for Growth” as it aims to return US$1.5 billion more to shareholders.
DBS is the third-largest wealth manager in Asia, excluding mainland China.

site_title: China’s 618 shopping fest sets record, but daily spending slips
summary: China's 618 shopping festival, a month-long event, set a record with 855.6 billion yuan in gross merchandise value, a 15.2% increase from last year. Daily spending, however, decreased due to the extended sales period. Over 2.2 billion orders were placed across online, offline, and food delivery platforms. Despite upbeat figures, China's retail sector struggles due to employment concerns, wage growth, and the property crisis. Analysts attribute the sales growth to earlier start of the festival and government subsidies, but warn of potential impact from subsidy program pauses in July.

images.alt_text: Temu, Shein and Tiktok have offered to pay part or all of the shipping costs to European markets, as well as directly subsidising some purchases.
Amazon in April added a “Buy for Me” mode to its Rufus digital assistant, allowing users to command it to make purchases at retailer websites off Amazon’s platform.
Key winners of the growth in South-east Asia's e-commerce sector were consolidated with the largest platforms such as Shopee, Lazada and Grab.

A worker sorts packages on a JD.com delivery truck in Beijing, China, April 28, 2025. China's new turf war focused on speed is coming at a high cost in the short term as e-commerce giants look to entice consumers with hefty discounts.
The broadening of the strategic partnership between Alibaba and Xiaohongshu comes as China’s e-commerce giants vie for market share on multiple fronts.

site_title: Million-dollar HDB resale flat deals on track for record as supply crunch bites, demand holds steady
summary: Singapore's million-dollar HDB resale flat deals are on track for a record, with analysts projecting up to 1,500 deals this year. The proportion of million-dollar flats has risen to nearly 6% of year-to-date sales, driven by a tight supply and steady demand for larger units. Analysts attribute the surge to a mismatch between supply and demand, with the supply of flats reaching their minimum occupation period (MOP) falling since 2022. The number of million-dollar deals is concentrated in mature and central locations, with Bukit Timah and the central area seeing the highest proportion of such deals.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
A 0.59 ha site in Newton along Bukit Timah Road is expected to be hotly contested.
The Ministry of National Development announced the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme today.
Year to date, there have been 368 million-dollar transactions involving five-room and larger flats, up from 229 in the same period last year.
Both sites are expected to yield some 1,100 new homes.
Minister for National Development Chee Hong Tat is hopeful that HDB resale prices will moderate as supply increases.

site_title: Fed still in wait-and-see mode, as impact of tariff war is not yet fully felt
summary: US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell has left interest rates unchanged, despite economic data weakening and inflation remaining muted. Powell attributed the Fed's wait-and-see mode to the lagging impact of tariffs on inflation, despite rising inflation expectations. He emphasized that the Fed is monitoring the situation and is prepared to act if necessary, but for now, the economy remains solid. Powell's comments were seen as slightly hawkish, with economists predicting no rate cuts before the next meeting in September. The Fed's decision was largely influenced by the ongoing trade war and its uncertainty.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said it has taken time for goods tariffs to work through the distribution chain, noting many goods now being sold by retailers were imported months before tariffs were imposed. These will be replaced by newer imports that are subject to the duties.
Spot gold was up 0.3 per cent at US$3,378.86 an ounce.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington, D.C., June 18, 2025. Despite US President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut, Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent.

site_title: The Fed is just as confused as the rest of us
summary: The US Federal Reserve is uncertain about its next move due to ongoing policy uncertainty, including President Trump's tariff rates and changes in immigration and fiscal policies. Despite the uncertainty, Fed Chair Jerome Powell is staying in wait-and-see mode, but may need to respond quickly by autumn. The Fed's policy outlook is expected to shift quickly, potentially leading to rate cuts or hikes, and may be influenced by trade policy developments.

images.alt_text: Fed still in wait-and-see mode, as impact of tariff war is not yet fully felt

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, June 19, 2025
summary: Global stocks edged lower on Thursday, with investors seeking safe havens amid market uncertainty. The US dollar gained as financial markets await key central bank policy decisions from Europe. Market movements were influenced by the Federal Reserve's cautious outlook and the ongoing impact of the tariff war. Gold prices rose due to Middle East tensions, but gains were capped by the Fed's cautious stance.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led losses on Thursday, falling more than one per cent, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were also in the red.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 19)
summary: Singapore's fast food and cafe sales rose in June, reversing a decline seen in February. Globally diversified equities remain attractive, and the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged. The cut-off yield on Singapore's six-month T-bill fell to 2%. Insurers Prudential and AIA continue to offer pre-authorisation certificates for Mount Elizabeth hospitals. Meanwhile, Singapore Post put up 10 HDB shophouses for sale and leaseback, and local shares fell due to US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's warning of higher inflation.

site_title: Prudential, AIA still offering pre-authorisation at Mount Elizabeth hospitals despite Great Eastern’s shock move
summary: Insurers Prudential and AIA in Singapore are continuing to offer pre-authorisation certificates for admission into Mount Elizabeth Hospital and Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital, despite Great Eastern's surprise suspension of pre-authorisation certificates due to "significantly higher costs" at the hospitals. Prudential and AIA are taking steps to manage rising healthcare costs, with Prudential partnering with other hospitals and AIA focusing on value-based healthcare. The Ministry of Health is in talks with Great Eastern to understand the impact of its decision.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Great Eastern has temporarily suspended pre-authorisation facilities at Mount Elizabeth Hospitals.

site_title: Indonesia’s Prabowo pledges to strengthen ties with Russia
summary: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto pledged to strengthen ties with Russia, stating that relations between the two nations are developing "extremely actively." He made the commitment during a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in St. Petersburg, highlighting cooperation in space, energy, agriculture, and defense. This visit marks Prabowo's first state trip to Russia since taking office last year, as he seeks to deepen ties and diversify Indonesia's partnerships. Prabowo will also speak at the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum, where he aims to court investment and signal Indonesia's continued engagement with non-Western partners.

site_title: Oil prices up nearly 3% as Israel-Iran conflict escalates, US response remains uncertain
summary: Oil prices surged nearly 3% on Thursday, reaching their highest close since January 22, amid escalating tensions between Israel and Iran. Brent crude futures rose $2.15, or 2.8%, to $78.85 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $2.06, or 2.7%, to $77.20 a barrel. The US response to the conflict remains uncertain, with President Donald Trump set to decide on involvement in the next two weeks. Analysts warn that a wider conflict could disrupt trade flows and push oil prices to $120-$130 per barrel, although some predict the price surge will be temporary.

images.alt_text: In April, after the Attorney General’s Office arrested an employee of Wilmar Group in relation to the corruption case, the company said it was assisting with investigations.
Brent crude futures settled 25 cents higher at US$76.70 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore at 60: Lee Kuan Yew’s hidden sculpture and other artworks to know
summary: A private exhibition, "Artist's Proof: Singapore At 60," showcases nearly 100 provocative artworks that explore the country's history through the eyes of many artists and the collection of one man, Chong Huai Seng. The exhibition, curated by Chong and his daughter Ning, features a long-hidden bronze bust of Lee Kuan Yew created by British artist Sydney Harpley in 1982, as well as 11 newly commissioned pieces. The show brings together over 50 artists, spanning a wide emotional register and tackling topics such as nation-building, power dynamics, and historical silence.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Sophia Foo Chiao Lin's vivid and heartfelt painting 'Connection' is a previous winner of the 13-19 Art Prize.

site_title: Malaysia sues Telegram over alleged malicious content
summary: Malaysia has filed a civil suit against Telegram, the first legal action taken against a social media platform in the country, over allegedly disseminating malicious content. Two local Telegram channels, Edisi Siasat and Edisi Khas, were found to have violated Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia Act 1998. The Malaysian Communications and Multimedia Commission (MCMC) accused Telegram of a "serious failure to address content" and issued an injunction to stop the spread of the alleged offensive material. Telegram will be given space to present its defense, with MCMC warning that other social media platforms will be held accountable for their content.

images.alt_text: There are groups on Telegram that sell users’ data, are involved in drug trafficking, or have terrorist links, according to the government report.
Telegram has drawn the ire of authorities from the European Union to Iran over content shared on its platform and its unresponsiveness to takedown requests.

Singapore has clamped down on money mules, as they are the main way overseas scammers launder their ill-gotten gains and transfer it out of the city-state, said Sun Xueling, Minister of State for the Ministry of Home Affairs.

site_title: Tudor, Blancpain and Cartier give compact treatment to iconic watches
summary: Luxury watch brands Tudor, Blancpain, and Cartier are embracing smaller cases for their iconic timepieces, offering a more compact and intentional approach to watchmaking. The Tudor Black Bay 54 Lagoon Blue, Blancpain Fifty Fathoms 38mm, and Cartier Santos Petite showcase a balance between heritage and modernity, featuring smaller cases while maintaining classic designs and features. These watches prioritize a slower, more intentional pace of life, with water resistance and quartz movements ensuring weekend-proof resilience. The trend marks a shift towards a more relaxed and elegant approach to luxury watchmaking.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
The Ferrai F1 Racing team this season comprises Charles Leclerc and Lewis Hamilton.

site_title: Non-doms are trying to sell London homes, but no one wants them
summary: Wealthy individuals are selling London homes in a slump driven by the UK's abolition of tax breaks for non-domiciled residents. The number of £5 million-plus homes on the market rose 22% year-over-year, but there were 15% fewer deals compared to the same period last year. To attract buyers, vendors are offering 45% more price reductions, with values in most markets showing little growth. Reports suggest Chancellor Rachel Reeves may consider reversing the decision to charge inheritance tax on non-doms, which could ease the strain on London's luxury housing market.

images.alt_text: Home prices in Britain dropped by 0.3 per cent compared with a month earlier in Rightmove’s June period, which ran from May 11 to June 7 - the biggest drop since June 2011.
Sellers in the UK capital and other pricey regions are offering discounts to offset the impact of April’s increase in transaction costs.

site_title: Swiss watch exports slump in May as US tariffs shake market
summary: Swiss watch exports dropped 9.5% in May to 2.1 billion Swiss francs, primarily due to a 25% decline in US shipments. The slump reverses the previous month's surge and highlights the impact of President Trump's trade policies on the watch sector. Asia exports also declined, with shipments to China, Japan, and Hong Kong plummeting by double digits. The decline in foreign sales narrowed Switzerland's trade surplus by 42%, the largest in almost five years, as the industry faces a worsening consumer sentiment and "luxury fatigue."

images.alt_text: Blancpain's Fifty Fathoms for women.
Fashionista fathers will appreciate the fine details of the redesigned Louis Vutton Tambour watches.

site_title: Weaker greenback raises risk of currency mismatch for Asian insurers holding USD assets
summary: Taiwan's insurers face a currency mismatch risk due to the country's strong dollar, which has risen 8% against the US dollar, resulting in unrealized losses of $18 billion for every 10% appreciation. The weakened US dollar has increased hedging costs, putting pressure on insurers' earnings and capital. Fitch Ratings has downgraded Taiwan's life insurance outlook to "deteriorating" due to heightened risks to insurers' earnings and capital. Singapore insurers, however, have implemented hedging strategies to minimize currency mismatch risks, with some using currency swaps and hedging forward contracts to convert USD payments to SGD cash flows.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
A trend of “de-dollarisation” has taken hold in global markets as the greenback loses its charm among Asean investors and corporates.

site_title: South-east Asia’s budget airlines bet on travel demand, despite competition woes
summary: South-east Asia's budget airlines are expanding capacity despite rising costs and intense competition. Demand for air travel in the region is expected to grow faster than other areas, driven by Chinese tourists. However, margins are thin, with the International Air Transport Association (Iata) expecting a 1.9% net profit margin for Asia-Pacific airlines, compared to a global average of 3.7%. Airlines are adding more planes to their fleets, but costs such as labour and airport charges are rising, and a shortage of new planes is driving up leasing and maintenance fees.

images.alt_text: A three-digit order haul for Airbus’s smallest commercial jet would be a major boost to the A220 programme, which has been beset by slow sales and supply-chain issues that have impeded output.
Capital A CEO Tony Fernandes said the potential for South-east Asia, where much of the company’s exposure lies, to weather global geopolitical tensions may prove attractive to investors.

site_title: 🤯 It’s not that Gen Zs don’t want to be managers – they want to redefine the role
summary: Gen Z is redefining the management role, prioritizing purpose, autonomy, and impact over traditional titles. A survey found that 72% of Gen Zs prefer to be individual contributors, citing excessive stress for little reward. However, many Gen Zs are open to management, but on their own terms, viewing it as a way to mentor, guide, and learn from their team. To determine if management is right for you, consider questions such as enjoying people work, finding purpose in management, and being able to handle stress and make decisions.

site_title: India yet to decide where to analyse crashed plane’s recorders
summary: India is still deciding where to analyze the black box recorders from the fatal Air India plane crash, which killed 241 people on board and at least 30 on the ground. The Aircraft Accident Investigation Bureau (AAIB) will conduct a "due assessment" of technical, safety, and security considerations before making a decision. The US was initially considered, but the government did not rule out this option. The investigation is ongoing, with the AAIB working with local authorities and agencies to determine the probable cause of the crash.

site_title: Coinbase launches stablecoin payments service for e-commerce
summary: Coinbase is launching a stablecoin payments service for e-commerce, targeting online platforms such as Shopify and eBay. The platform aims to make stablecoins a go-to payment method, potentially threatening card networks and online payment services. Coinbase's new system mimics credit-card rails and offers faster settlement, lower fees, and immediate access to a global customer base. The company expects the service to add new revenue streams, diversifying its business beyond transaction fees. Shopify is its inaugural client, partnering with Coinbase and Stripe to allow merchants to accept stablecoin payments.

site_title: Globally diversified equities remain attractive amid yet another Fed pause: analysts
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged at 4.25-4.5% in its latest meeting, citing a healthy labor market and reduced economic uncertainty. Analysts continue to favor globally diversified equities, citing reduced volatility and international diversification as key strategies for managing uncertainty. Asia markets fell on rising inflation concerns and the Iran-Israel conflict, while Wall Street stocks ended flat. Experts recommend diversifying into equities outside the US, particularly in regions with strong fiscal support, and fixed income markets offer attractive opportunities for long-term investors.

site_title: Uber warns Hong Kong drivers and riders of possible new curbs
summary: Uber is warning Hong Kong drivers and riders about possible new regulations that could cap the number of drivers or vehicles allowed on the platform. The company claims that such limits would reduce earnings for drivers, lead to more cancellations, and longer wait times. Uber has proposed regulatory measures, including licensing platforms and drivers, to ensure safety and fair competition. The Hong Kong government is expected to release new ride-hailing regulations in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The so-called everything app offers food and grocery deliveries, car rentals and money transfers as well as laundry, home cleaning and donation services.

site_title: US recovers US$225 million stolen in crypto scam
summary: The US government has recovered $225 million in a cryptocurrency confidence scam, the largest seizure yet of stolen funds. Dozens of people in the US and over 400 victims worldwide were scammed, with the stolen money laundered through hundreds of thousands of transactions. The FBI and US Secret Service used blockchain analysis to track the money, but no arrests have been made. Officials hope the recovered funds can be returned to their rightful owners, and the scheme is believed to be one of the largest cryptocurrency investment frauds, causing over $5.8 billion in losses in 2024.

site_title: Singapore teens stand to win S$3,000 in 13-19 Art Prize
summary: The 13-19 Art Prize, now in its fifth edition, has increased its top cash awards, with winners receiving S$3,000, S$2,000, and S$1,000, respectively. The prize boost, made possible by a donation from The Culture Story, aims to encourage more teenage artists to participate. The competition, open to Singapore and South-east Asian teenagers aged 13-19, has also introduced a new "Art Without Limits" section for intellectually disabled artists. The increased prize money and extended competition deadline are part of efforts to nurture young artists and provide opportunities for all.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Lee Yu Xun's painting was one of the winners of the 13-19 Art Prize 2024.

site_title: Alibaba Cloud to start second data centre in South Korea by June
summary: Alibaba Cloud is set to open its second data centre in South Korea by the end of June, as part of a 380 billion yuan investment in AI and cloud infrastructure. The expansion follows growing demand for cloud and AI services in the country and comes as Alibaba pivots aggressively to AI. The new facility will operate alongside Alibaba's existing data centre in Seoul, serving customers including AI solutions provider Univa and Naver subsidiary Snow. This move is part of Alibaba's multibillion-dollar bet on AI and cloud computing.

site_title: Hot watches – timepieces on show
summary: Blancpain unveiled the new Fifty Fathoms, a women's diving watch designed specifically for female divers, marking the brand's first 38mm model. MeisterSinger's 24H Enamel Single-Hand showcases a relaxed approach to time with a hand-crafted enamel dial and 24-hour display. Greubel Forsey's GMT Balancier Convexe has been overhauled with a redesigned case, integrated power reserve, and enhanced ergonomics, available in a limited edition of 22 pieces.

images.alt_text: Czapek & Cie's Antarctique Tourbillon.

site_title: Indonesia central bank makes market intervention after rupiah depreciation
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, intervened in the foreign exchange market after the rupiah fell to a one-month low against the US dollar, down 0.6% at 16,400 per dollar. The intervention was due to the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision and rising geopolitical tensions. Bank Indonesia will continue to monitor global and domestic dynamics to maintain exchange rate stability and support economic recovery, following its decision to pause its easing cycle. The rupiah's depreciation was seen as a response to rising geopolitical tensions and the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

site_title: Microsoft prepared to abandon high-stakes talks with OpenAI: report
summary: Microsoft is prepared to abandon high-stakes talks with OpenAI, a chatbot maker, over the future of their alliance. The tech giant plans to rely on its existing commercial contract to maintain access to OpenAI's technology until 2030. OpenAI requires Microsoft's approval to transition into a public-benefit corporation, which it believes will facilitate capital raising. The companies are discussing revising the terms of Microsoft's investment, including its future equity stake in OpenAI.

images.alt_text: Microsoft has said it regularly reevaluates the organisational structure to make sure it’s investing for growth.
Microsoft and peers including Meta Platforms have touted the effectiveness of AI-assisted coding tools in speeding up the software development process.
Microsoft is focused on driving adoption of Copilot AI and is closely tracking what share of customer workforces are using the tools, CEO Satya Nadella said during the event.

site_title: Japan to cut super-long bond sales by 10% to calm markets
summary: Japan's government plans to cut sales of super-long bonds by 10% to calm market oversupply concerns, trimming overall bond issuance. The revised plan, set to be discussed with primary dealers on Friday, will reduce sales of 20-, 30-, and 40-year bonds, partly offset by increased issuance of shorter-term notes and bonds for households. The move aims to soothe market concerns and follows the Bank of Japan's decision to slow its bond purchase tapering.

images.alt_text: The BOJ will conduct a review of its current taper plan and come up with a subsequent programme at its next policy meeting on Jun 16 to 17.

site_title: Hong Kong Monetary Authority says outlook for local currency uncertain
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has expressed uncertainty over the direction of the Hong Kong dollar and interbank rates due to carry trades and other factors. The currency, pegged between 7.75 and 7.85 to the US dollar, has fluctuated in recent weeks. Analysts predict the currency may test 7.85, but the HKMA has sufficient foreign exchange reserves to defend it. The HKMA's comments come after the US Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged, which has had a ripple effect on Hong Kong's economy and currency.

images.alt_text: Some market watchers have called for switching Hong Kong’s US dollar peg to the yuan at a time when trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies have created uncertainty.
Major tenors of forward points of the Hong Kong dollar, ranging from one-month to six-month, were all near their historic lows on Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia’s Anwar says trade talks with US have been ‘excellent’
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim stated that trade talks with the US have been "excellent," with his ministers in Washington DC negotiating to lower US tariffs on Malaysia to below 10% for critical sectors. The tariffs, imposed in April, had a significant impact on Malaysia's global supply chains, with 60% of its semiconductor exports going to the US. Anwar described the tariffs as a "significant challenge" and emphasized the need to reduce them to support bilateral trade.

site_title: Diverging fortunes in Singapore’s F&B scene as diners turn to cheaper options
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) scene is experiencing diverging fortunes, with restaurant takings declining while other types of F&B outlets seeing improvements. Official statistics show a rise in sales for fast-food outlets and cafes since February. Consumers are opting for cheaper options, such as food courts and fast-food chains, rather than restaurants. This trend is evident in the 15% decline in sales at Chinese restaurant Ka-Soh since January.

images.alt_text: Food Innovators Holdings made its debut on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange on Oct 16, 2024, opening at S$0.20 – 9 per cent below its IPO price of S$0.22.
Euromonitor’s Asia Pacific insight manager for food, Emil Fazira, highlights that these brands, positioned in the middle ground price-wise, may fall short in these challen

site_title: Trump’s envoy to China calls out threat of foreign supply chains
summary: US Ambassador to China David Perdue called for revamping the US-China trading relationship by bringing supply chains back onshore to address vulnerabilities created by unfettered globalization. Perdue stated that American companies have become overly dependent on China for components and supply chains, echoing European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's criticism of China's "China Shock." Perdue emphasized the need for reciprocity, fairness, and respect in the trade relationship, and US President Donald Trump does not blame China for pursuing its own national interest.

images.alt_text: Beijing has sought in recent years to reduce its dependence on foreign sources for critical technology and products.
FILE PHOTO: Flags of U.S. and China are seen in this illustration picture taken August 2, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

(From left) US Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng shake hands as they pose for a photo during trade discussions at the Lancaster House in London, Britain, June 9, 2025.

site_title: Chandra Asri’s investment arm to raise over 2.3 trillion rupiah in IPO
summary: Indonesia's Chandra Daya Investasi (CDI), the investment arm of petrochemical producer Chandra Asri Pacific, plans to raise over 2.3 trillion rupiah (S$187.2 million) through its public listing in July. The company, which boasts a diverse portfolio in energy, ports, and logistics, aims to bolster the capital of several subsidiaries using the funds. CDI's shares will be listed on the Indonesia Stock Exchange on July 8, with a price range of 170 to 190 rupiah apiece.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
The chlor-alkali and ethylene dichloride plant in Cilegon, Banten, which is currently under development by Chandra Asri Group.

site_title: Shell is being ‘very careful’ with shipping in the Middle East: CEO
summary: Shell CEO Wael Sawan said the company is being "very careful" with shipping in the Middle East due to the escalating conflict between Israel and Iran. The Iran-Israel air war has added to uncertainty in the region, with 20% of global oil and fuel flows passing through the Strait of Hormuz. Sawan noted that electronic interference is disrupting commercial ship navigation systems, and the company is monitoring the possibility of US military action. Shell has plans in place should things deteriorate.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 25 cents higher at US$76.70 a barrel on Wednesday.

“This decision stands as a resounding vote of confidence from a world-class investor in our sound economic policies, clarity in our leadership, and promise in our future,”  Malaysia’s Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said.

site_title: Uncovering the elusive Chinese tech founders dominating SEA
summary: Chinese tech founders have dominated South-east Asia, with eight unicorns founded in the region, including Sea Group, the most valuable tech firm. These entrepreneurs have set up shop in Singapore, which has a progressive regulatory environment for blockchain companies, drawing criticism as "Singapore washing". Many Chinese founders, including those from tech giants like Alibaba and ByteDance, have relocated to Singapore, taking advantage of its favorable business environment.

images.alt_text: For business leaders, using AI goes beyond knowing how to “prompt” or ask questions on generative AI chatbots like DeepSeek.

site_title: Multiplier Holdings launches with US$27.5 million in funding to power AI support for professional services firms
summary: Multiplier Holdings, a Singapore-based technology company, has launched with $27.5 million in seed and Series A funding. The company aims to develop AI solutions for professional services firms, automating time-consuming tasks and delivering improved outcomes for clients. Multiplier acquires professional services companies and onboards them into its AI-driven platform, providing hands-on technical support and collaboration to improve scalability. The funding will be used to expand its portfolio and accelerate AI automation platform development.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
RTX business Pratt and Whitney expands geared turbofan maintenance, repair and overhaul capacity by two-thirds at Eagle Services Asia in Singapore.

site_title: China’s EV powerhouse BYD accelerates into Europe’s heartland
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer BYD has overtaken Tesla in European EV sales, thanks to its aggressive pricing and expansion into the market. BYD's European charge is led by executive vice-president Stella Li, who has pledged to spend up to $20 billion in the region. The company has made significant investments in its European operations, including a new factory in Hungary and hiring seasoned executives from rival manufacturers. BYD's success in Europe comes as Tesla faces declining sales and regulatory challenges. The company's ability to move quickly and cut out middlemen has allowed it to gain traction, but its aggressive pricing and reliance on plug-in hybrids raise concerns about its long-term sustainability.

images.alt_text: BYD has lost US$21.5 billion in market value since its shares peaked in late May.

Without naming BYD, the China Automobile Manufacturers Association said the move by a certain company started a new round of “price war panic” that was plunging the sector into a “vicious cycle” and threatening supply chain security.
The company is also ramping up overseas sales, delivering more than 89,000 units in May, its highest on record.

site_title: PEC delists from SGX on Jun 19 after US$165 million acquisition by Liberty Energy Solutions
summary: PEC Ltd., a Singapore-based engineering company, was delisted from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on June 19 after being acquired by Liberty Energy Solutions for US$165 million. The acquisition, which closed on June 17, sees Liberty Energy holding an 85% stake in PEC. PEC chairman Edna Ko and CEO Robert Dompeling will continue to manage the company as they join Liberty Energy. The deal aims to accelerate Liberty Energy's strategic development as a global platform for energy services.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
PEC receives privatisation proposal of S$0.64 per share and S$0.20 per share via special dividend

site_title: Japan firms exit Tokyo exchange at record pace in delisting rush
summary: Japanese companies are leaving the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) at the fastest pace in over a decade, with 59 firms delisting or announcing plans to do so in the first half of 2025. The trend reflects the TSE's push to make the Japanese market more appealing for foreign investors by ensuring high shareholder returns. The exchange has urged companies to improve valuations and cut overly close ties with other companies. This surge in deals and management buyouts is driven by pressure to make better use of capital and the threat of being taken off the exchange if companies fail to meet their goals.

images.alt_text: In a quarterly outlook report released on May 1, the BOJ cut its price forecasts and said underlying inflation will stagnate for some time as uncertainty on US trade policy weighs on the export-reliant economy.
Tokyo is scrambling to find ways to get Washington to exempt its automakers from 25 per cent automobile industry-specific tariffs.
Japan is struggling to reach a deal with Washington in tariff negotiations, clouding the outlook for its economy, which is heavily reliant on automobile shipments to the US.

site_title: Flights to Indonesia's Bali resume after disruption by volcano eruption
summary: Flights to and from Indonesia's Bali resumed on Thursday after being disrupted by the eruption of Mount Lewotobi Laki-laki. The volcano spewed ash 11 km high, affecting 87 flights, including 66 international and 21 domestic flights. All flights departed on schedule to Australia, Vietnam, Singapore, Malaysia, and China on Thursday, with airlines including Malaysia Airlines, Virgin Australia, and Singapore Airlines operating normally. However, Fransiskus Xaverius Seda airport in Maumere remains closed until Friday due to volcanic ash.

images.alt_text: Mount Lewotobi Laki-Laki has erupted on Jun 17, with the authorities raising its alert status to the highest level.

site_title: Swiss National Bank cuts interest rate to zero in effort to stop franc inflows
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) cut its interest rate to zero, its sixth consecutive move, to deter investors from pushing up the Swiss franc. The quarter-point reduction aims to counter lower inflationary pressure and is a response to the currency's role as a haven from turmoil, particularly due to US President Donald Trump's disruption to global trade. The SNB also lowered its inflation forecast for 2025 to 0.2%, and the Swiss franc rose 0.2% against the euro after the announcement, trading at a decade-high against the US dollar.

images.alt_text: epa12184804 Swiss National Bank's (SNB) Chairman of the Governing Board Martin Schlegel speaks during a media briefing at the SNB headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, 19 June 2025.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL BUHOLZER
Switzerland has long had an affinity for physical money and still has a 1,000 Swiss franc (S$1,522) note – one of the world’s highest-value notes.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield falls to 2%
summary: Singapore's six-month Treasury bill cut-off yield decreased to 2% in the latest auction, marking the seventh consecutive issuance with declining yields since March 26. The auction received S$15.9 billion in applications for the S$7.5 billion on offer, resulting in a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.13. This is a slight decrease from the previous auction and the lowest yield level in the year to date.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

site_title: NAB pays A$751,200 penalty on breaches of consumer data rights rules
summary: National Australia Bank (NAB) has paid a record A$751,200 penalty for alleged breaches of consumer data right rules. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) issued four infringement notices after NAB failed to disclose credit limit data in four separate requests from consumers. The lender had cooperated with the ACCC's review and resolved the data quality error. This penalty is the highest ever issued for alleged breaches of Consumer Data Right (CDR) rules, which aim to help consumers safely share data with businesses and compare products and services.

site_title: Fed’s Powell says he expects to see more tariff-driven price hikes in coming months
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell expects price hikes driven by President Trump's tariffs to continue over the summer, as goods now being sold by retailers were imported months before tariffs were imposed. The tariffs, including 25% on steel and aluminum and over 50% on Chinese goods, will be passed on to consumers, with the cost of the tariff ultimately being paid by businesses and foreign producers. Powell notes that increased inflationary impacts from tariffs will drive the pace and timing of any Fed decision to cut borrowing rates, with two quarter-point rate cuts projected this year.

images.alt_text: Many economists see residential construction struggling to contribute to economic growth over the course of the year.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.1 per cent at 42,171.66 on Wednesday.
Data next week on the number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid, a proxy for hiring, could shed more light on the state of the labour market in June.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington, D.C., June 18, 2025. Despite US President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut, Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent.

site_title: Paetongtarn Shinawatra: Youngest Thai PM faces swift end to short career
summary: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, 38, faces an abrupt end to her short career after a leaked phone call with former Cambodian leader Hun Sen sparked widespread anger, prompting her largest backer, the Bhumjaithai party, to quit. With barely enough votes for a parliamentary majority, Paetongtarn's coalition is on the verge of collapse, and she is mounting calls to resign. The move follows a tumultuous career marked by her family's history of power, protests, and coups, and comes as Thailand's military still wields significant influence in politics.

images.alt_text: Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a parliament session on the budget for 2026 fiscal year in Bangkok on 28 May.

Paetongtarn Shinawatra, Thailand's prime minister, leaves a meeting at the 46th Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) Summit in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Monday, May 26, 2025. Southeast Asian leaders start two days of talks from Monday, seeking to deepen ties with China and Gulf nations, and mitigate the fallout from US President Donald Trump’s tariff hikes. “The medical council never said Thaksin was not sick, the question was whether his conditions were critical or not,” says Thaksin’s lawyer, Winyat Chartmontri.

Despite not holding any formal position, Thaksin Shinawatra (centre) has cast a long shadow over the government, through meetings with foreign leaders, campaigning in local elections and weighing in on policy.

site_title: A global shift towards facial surgery
summary: A global survey of aesthetic plastic surgeons found that almost 38 million aesthetic procedures were performed worldwide in 2024, a 40% increase from 2020. The most common procedures were eyelid surgery, liposuction, breast augmentation, scar revision, and rhinoplasty. Most face and head procedures showed a 4.3% year-on-year growth, with eyelid surgery increasing by 13.4% and fat-grafting for the face rising by 19.2%. Non-surgical procedures, such as botulinum toxin and hyaluronic acid fillers, also saw significant growth.

images.alt_text: Aesthetic procedures are popular, but they're not without risks.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 2-week low as miners, gold stocks fall; Fed holds rate
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to a two-week low, weighed down by miners and gold stocks due to the US Federal Reserve's cautious tone on rate cuts and softer commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index hit 8516.2, its lowest level since June 4. Miners, including BHP Group and Rio Tinto, fell 1% and 0.1%, respectively, while gold stocks lost 1.7% due to the Fed's hint at a slower pace of future rate cuts.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said it has taken time for goods tariffs to work through the distribution chain, noting many goods now being sold by retailers were imported months before tariffs were imposed. These will be replaced by newer imports that are subject to the duties.

US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington, D.C., June 18, 2025. Despite US President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut, Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.36 per cent down at 540.33 on Wednesday, a near one-month low.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.1 per cent at 42,171.66 on Wednesday.

site_title: Philippines cuts key rate again as inflation stays below target
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) reduced its overnight target reverse repurchase rate to 5.25% for the second time this year, as inflation remained below the central bank's 2-4% goal for a third month. The move follows a slowing inflation trend and is in line with Governor Eli Remolona's signal for at least two more rate cuts this year. The BSP's decision aims to support the South-east Asian economy, which expanded slower than expected last quarter, partly due to weaker investment growth amid global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Gold rises on Middle East tensions, but Fed’s cautious outlook caps gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $3,378.86 an ounce due to safe-haven demand amid Middle East tensions, despite the US Federal Reserve's cautious outlook on future rate cuts. The Fed held interest rates steady, signaling a slower pace of rate cuts, while geopolitical tensions remained heightened following US President Donald Trump's refusal to confirm US involvement in Israel's bombardment of Iranian nuclear and missile sites.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was steady at US$3,386.59 an ounce.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s gloomy projections suggest no rate hike this year: ex-top economist
summary: The Bank of Japan is unlikely to raise interest rates this year unless a positive turn in US tariffs occurs, according to former top economist Seisaku Kameda. The BOJ cut its price forecasts and growth projections due to uncertainty on US trade policy weighing on Japan's export-reliant economy. Core consumer inflation is expected to hit 2.2% in 2026 before slowing to 1.7% the following year, but a rate hike is unlikely until January or March 2026, depending on corporate capital expenditure and wage hikes.

images.alt_text: Nippon Steel said its annual crude steel production capacity is expected to reach 86 million tonnes, bringing it closer to Nippon Steel’s global strategic goal of 100 million tonnes of global crude steel production capacity.
Tokyo is scrambling to find ways to get Washington to exempt its automakers from 25 per cent automobile industry-specific tariffs.

site_title: SingPost puts up 10 HDB shophouses for S$50 million in sale-and-leaseback bid
summary: Singapore Post (SingPost) is selling 10 HDB shophouses for S$50 million in a sale-and-leaseback bid, aiming to divest non-core assets. The shophouses are anchored by SingPost, which occupies 90.8% of the space, while the remaining is leased to external parties. The sale is part of SingPost's plan to unlock value for shareholders, following a proposal for a special dividend of S$0.09 per share for FY2025.

site_title: Seatrium partners with Solvang, Norway to establish Carbon Capture and Storage systems
summary: Seatrium and Solvang, Norway, have signed a letter of intent to establish Carbon Capture and Storage systems on Solvang's new series of very large gas carriers. The project is expected to commence in late 2026, furthering Solvang's fleet decarbonisation efforts. This marks a significant step towards sustainable maritime solutions and deepens the decade-long partnership between the companies. The project builds on the success of Seatrium's turnkey engineering, procurement, and construction solutions for the Clipper Eris project, the world's first full-scale CCS system retrofit.

site_title: Air India cuts foreign widebody flights by 15% after crash
summary: Air India has cut its foreign widebody flights by 15% due to the aftermath of a fatal Boeing 787 crash and ongoing geopolitical tensions. The airline will roll out the cuts until at least mid-July, citing safety inspections and enhanced checks on its Boeing fleet. Investigators are still trying to determine the cause of the crash, which killed all but one of the 242 passengers and crew. Air India chairman N Chandrasekaran has assured that the plane had a clean flight record and that both engines had been serviced.

images.alt_text: Domestic insurers have offloaded more than 95 per cent of their aviation insurance direct written premium, or DWP, to global reinsurers.
A bird flies over a logo of Air India airlines at the corporate headquarters in Mumbai, India, October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

In the world’s worst aviation disaster in a decade, an Air India Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner with 242 people on board bound for London took off from Ahmedabad on Thursday but crashed within about 30 seconds, erupting into a massive fireball.

site_title: Blackstone’s ASK plans to hire 70 wealth bankers in India
summary: Blackstone's ASK Group plans to hire 70 private wealth bankers in India, aiming to reach 175 bankers by March 2026. The company, with over $745 billion in assets, is expanding its team amid increased competition in the country's booming wealth management space. CEO Rajesh Saluja expects investors to focus on gold and fixed-income funds, while maintaining a presence in equity index funds and mutual funds. The hiring move is part of ASK's efforts to maintain its market share and adapt to the growing demand for wealth management services.

site_title: UK’s high-speed rail faces new delays, deemed ‘appalling mess’
summary: Britain's transport secretary has announced further delays to the country's high-speed HS2 train line, citing an "appalling mess" due to soaring costs. The project, initially estimated at £37.5 billion, has now ballooned to over £100 billion. The new timeline is uncertain, with Transport Secretary Heidi Alexander pledging to "sort it out." The project's delays and cost increases have sparked controversy, with the Labour party hoping to boost sluggish economic growth through big infrastructure spending.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump (lefft) and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer shake hands as they speak to reporters during the G7 Summit at the Pomeroy Kananaskis Mountain Lodge in Kananaskis, Alberta, Canada, June 16, 2025.

site_title: Blackstone snaps up stakes in office buildings leased by Meta
summary: Blackstone acquired a 40% stake in two office properties in Bellevue, Washington, leased by Meta Platforms, for a combined value of $545 million. The properties, Blocks 5 and 6, are valued at $272.5 million each. Blackstone's real estate business is focusing on newer buildings with strong tenant demand, following the president's statement that the office market had "bottomed" in January. The acquisition marks Blackstone's latest office deal, following a purchase in Manhattan's 1345 Avenue of the Americas earlier this month.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as Middle East tensions weigh; eyes on Fed decision
summary: European shares fell 0.36% to a near one-month low, weighed down by Middle East tensions and anticipation of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision. Defence stocks gained 0.6%, while investors avoided risk assets ahead of the Fed meeting, where officials are expected to hold interest rates steady. The Fed faces challenges from potential inflation risks and trade uncertainties, with investors closely watching policymakers' comments for signals on the central bank's plans.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.1 per cent at 42,171.66 on Wednesday.

site_title: US to screen social media of foreign students for anti-American content
summary: The US State Department has announced new guidelines requiring foreign students seeking to study in the US to make their social media profiles public, allowing for screening for anti-American content. Student visa applicants will be asked to adjust their privacy settings to "public" to facilitate the screening. This move comes after the Trump administration's efforts to vet foreign students, including rescinding thousands of visas and banning Harvard University from accepting international students. The new guidelines aim to ensure the screening of every foreign student attempting to visit the US.

Some of the grants paid for military-specific medical research, studies on countering weapons of mass destruction and research on lasers, among numerous other topics, Reuters found.

site_title: Big blow for Thailand’s PM as major party exits coalition
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's government has suffered a major blow as the Bhumjaithai Party, the second-largest coalition member, withdrew from the government due to a leaked phone call criticizing the military's handling of a border dispute with Cambodia. The Bhumjaithai Party, which holds 69 seats, cited the impact on the nation's sovereignty and integrity. With only a slim majority, Paetongtarn's government is now facing declining popularity and a potential collapse, leaving its future uncertain.
