site_title: Microsoft planning thousands more job cuts aimed at salespeople
summary: Microsoft is planning to cut thousands of jobs, primarily in sales, as part of its efforts to trim its workforce amid heavy spending on artificial intelligence. The expected layoffs will follow a previous round of 6,000 job cuts in May and are expected to be announced early next month. The company has been restructuring its teams and cutting costs to maintain its investment in growth, despite warning employees of reduced spending in other areas.

images.alt_text: A Microsoft store in New York. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
OpenAI needs Microsoft’s approval to complete its transition into a public-benefit corporation. But the two have not been able to agree on details even after months of negotiations, sources said.
Microsoft and peers including Meta Platforms have touted the effectiveness of AI-assisted coding tools in speeding up the software development process.
Microsoft is focused on driving adoption of Copilot AI and is closely tracking what share of customer workforces are using the tools, CEO Satya Nadella said during the event.

site_title: Oil settles higher as Iran-Israel conflict enters sixth day
summary: Oil prices rose 25 cents to $76.70 a barrel on Wednesday as investors weighed the potential for supply disruptions from the Iran-Israel conflict. Brent crude futures rose 30 cents to $75.14, with US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 30 cents to $75.14. The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, but signaled borrowing costs may fall later this year. Analysts warn that a direct US involvement in the conflict could disrupt oil flows and push prices to $120 a barrel, citing the Strait of Hormuz as a key concern.

images.alt_text: An explosion in Teheran amid an attack by Israel. There are concerns that the bilateral hostilities will spill into the wider region.
Brent crude futures settled at US$76.45 a barrel, US$3.22, or 4.4%.

site_title: Airbus hits US$21 billion orders at Paris Air Show as Boeing focuses on India crash
summary: Airbus secured 148 firm orders worth $14.2 billion and 102 provisional orders worth $6.7 billion at the Paris Air Show, raising its total to $21 billion. The European planemaker won orders from Taiwan's Starlux Airlines, EgyptAir, and logistics company MNG Airlines, while also announcing a deal for two A350 freighters. In contrast, rival Boeing opted not to announce new sales following last week's Air India 787 crash, and focused on the probe instead. Airbus underscored confidence about growing demand and hinted at higher dividends.

images.alt_text: A bird flies over a logo of Air India airlines at the corporate headquarters in Mumbai, India, October 19, 2021. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas
China and the US are at loggerheads over trade rules that Trump is determined to reset during his second presidential term.
Airbus is the main supplier of jets to Vietnam, accounting for 86 per cent of the planes currently operated by Vietnamese airlines.
Etiqa Insurance Singapore said the extended coverage applies to customers who purchased single-trip or annual travel insurance plans prior to Wednesday (Jun 11), 8 am.
Jetstar Asia is expected to post an underlying EBIT loss of A$35 million in the current financial year.
The airline is currently benefiting from a post-pandemic travel boom, which has boosted its earnings and cash flow.

site_title: Restoring European tech leadership
summary: The European Union needs to rethink its approach to technology to regain its global competitiveness. Despite recent regulatory efforts, Europe relies heavily on foreign tech companies, with 80% of its digital needs coming from the US and China. To counter this, Europe must invest in its own core capabilities, build strategic partnerships, and create a more favorable regulatory environment for innovation. This includes protecting human rights and workers in the use of generative AI and ensuring a level playing field for all participants in critical sectors.

images.alt_text: Many US companies operate on a global scale with dominant positions in the US and international markets. For instance, Amazon, Microsoft and Alphabet hold more than 60 per cent of the global cloud market share.

Tim Cook's tenure as Apple's CEO is seen as being marked by the steady ascendancy of “process over product”. Instead of flashy innovations, his hallmark has been metronomic reliability, especially with regard to financial performance.

site_title: Asia: Stocks drop after Fed warning, oil dips with Middle East in focus
summary: Asian stocks fell on Thursday after the Federal Reserve warned that US inflation and economic growth would likely be dampened by President Trump's trade war. The Fed kept borrowing rates on hold and cut its economic growth forecast for this year, but raised inflation and unemployment expectations. Oil prices edged down as investors awaited developments in the Israel-Iran conflict, with Trump considering whether to join Israeli strikes against Iran. The Fed's comments compounded market volatility, with Hong Kong leading losses of over 1% and other Asian markets also falling.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was down 0.2 per cent at 8516.2 by 0039 GMT on Thursday, hitting its lowest level since June 4.
Brent crude futures settled 25 cents higher at US$76.70 a barrel on Wednesday.
The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.36 per cent down at 540.33 on Wednesday, a near one-month low.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.1 per cent at 42,171.66 on Wednesday.

site_title: Malaysia FX reserves at three-year high to aid ringgit stability
summary: Malaysia's foreign exchange reserves have reached a three-year high of US$94.7 billion at the end of April, bolstering the country's currency stability. The reserves increased due to foreign inflows into local bonds and a weaker US dollar. This comes at a time of increased currency volatility due to US President Donald Trump's tariffs and Sino-American tensions. The reserve boost is expected to support the Malaysian ringgit, which is the top performer in South-east Asia this quarter. The central bank's decision to unwind its net short forward FX position also contributed to the increase in reserves.

images.alt_text: The ringgit is trading near its strongest level since October and is the top performer among emerging South-east Asian currencies this quarter.
A trend of “de-dollarisation” has taken hold in global markets as the greenback loses its charm among Asean investors and corporates.
The Malaysian ringgit is the second-biggest gainer among emerging market currencies in South-east Asia so far this year with a rise of 5 per cent.

site_title: DBS and Austrade ink deal to help Australian companies expand in South-east Asia
summary: DBS and Austrade signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to deepen investment links between Australia and South-east Asia, including Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The agreement will provide a suite of resources, including market insights and regulatory guidance, to help Australian companies expand into the region. DBS will offer advisory services on market entry strategies, financial planning, and risk management. This is the first MOU between the Australian trade agency and a Singapore bank, coinciding with DBS' 10th anniversary in Sydney.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
DBS CEO Tan Su Shan said that DBS’s Australian lending book was currently worth about A$11 billion (S$9.2 billion).

site_title: Chipmaker Wolfspeed nears bankruptcy deal with lenders including Apollo
summary: Wolfspeed, a US chipmaker, is nearing a bankruptcy deal with lenders including Apollo Global Management. The company will propose a prepackaged bankruptcy, allowing it to slash billions in debt while potentially allowing shareholders to recover up to 5% of their investment. Suppliers and vendors holding unsecured debt will be fully repaid. If the deal is not supported by creditors, Wolfspeed will file a traditional bankruptcy case, potentially leaving shareholders with nothing. The deal is expected to be announced soon, pending creditor approval.

images.alt_text: The company looks to capitalise on the growing demand for chips that are manufactured using silicon carbide technology.

site_title: Standard Chartered cuts jobs in Singapore; moves them to India: Finance jobs portal
summary: Standard Chartered has cut around 80 jobs in Singapore, with affected employees being offshored to India as part of the bank's "Fit for Growth" cost-saving programme. The move is part of the bank's plan to return US$1.5 billion to shareholders. This is the latest in a series of job cuts by the bank, following a reduction of about 100 jobs across its Singapore, London, and Hong Kong hubs in November 2024.

images.alt_text: Its revised interest rates, which took effect on Jun 1, is a 2 percentage point increase to 8.05 per cent, from 6.05 per cent previously.

What was once a niche alternative financial choice is rapidly gaining traction in today’s world, said Standard Chartered's head of banking and coverage for Singapore and Asean, Corporate and Investment Banking, Chow Wan Thonh.

site_title: From eyelid surgeries to Botox: Aesthetic procedures that are leading the charge
summary: Aesthetic procedures, including surgeries and non-surgical treatments, are gaining popularity in Singapore, driven by millennials and Gen Zs seeking natural-looking enhancements. The top surgical procedures include eyelid surgery, liposuction, and scar revision, while non-surgical procedures such as Botox, hyaluronic acid fillers, and laser facial rejuvenation are also in demand. The trend is expected to continue, with an increase in facial aesthetic surgery and male aesthetic surgeries anticipated, as people seek to look like a better version of themselves with less drastic changes.

images.alt_text: A survey of aesthetic plastic surgeons across 32 locations in the world found that almost 38 million aesthetic procedures were performed last year.

site_title: New Zealand’s economic recovery gathers pace as exports jump
summary: New Zealand's economy is recovering, with its GDP rising 0.8% in the first quarter of 2025, exceeding expectations. Exports surged 3.6% and manufacturing grew 2.4%, driven by farm production and high global commodity prices. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to pause its easing cycle, with interest rates expected to remain steady in 2025. The government views the economic recovery as a key priority ahead of the 2026 election, despite concerns about global trade tensions and the potential for a weakening expansion.

images.alt_text: The Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ’s seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) dipped to 47.5 from a revised 53.3 in April. New orders slumped to 45.3 from a revised 50.8 in the prior month.
Prices rose modestly in early 2024 but buyer optimism was not sustained as the central bank kept borrowing costs high and economic growth stalled.

site_title: US Fed keeps rates steady but pencils in two cuts by end of 2025; Powell sees ‘meaningful’ inflation ahead
summary: The US Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady, maintaining the benchmark rate of 4.25% to 4.5%, despite President Trump's call for a rate cut. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said policymakers expect "meaningful" inflation ahead due to planned import tariffs, but rate cuts might be in order if not for tariffs. New economic projections show a modestly stagflationary picture, with growth slowing to 1.4% in 2025, unemployment rising to 4.5%, and inflation ending the year at 3%. Policymakers still anticipate a single quarter-percentage-point cut in each of 2026 and 2027.

images.alt_text: Stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency designed to maintain a constant value, usually a 1:1 US dollar peg, are commonly used by crypto traders to move funds between tokens.
Data next week on the number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid, a proxy for hiring, could shed more light on the state of the labour market in June.
The Fed says that it plans to meet on Jun 25 to discuss the plan.
Trump has repeatedly called on the Fed and Powell (above) to lower rates.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended down 0.1 per cent at 42,171.66 on Wednesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, UOB, Sats, Far East Orchard, GuocoLand, Elite UK Reit
summary: DBS signed a memorandum of understanding with the Australian Trade and Investment Commission to deepen investment links between Australia and South-east Asia. UOB became a direct participant in China's Cross-border Interbank Payment System, enabling renminbi clearing and settlement services. Sats priced US$100 million in fixed-rate notes, while Far East Orchard secured £96 million in total committed capital for its private student accommodation fund. GuocoLand's subsidiary GLM Emerald Hills was directed to pay RM 5.5 million to a contractor in an arbitration matter. Elite UK Reit issued 13.6 million new private placement units at an issue price of £0.295 per unit.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Generic photo of SGX

site_title: Want to invest in nuclear energy? DBS cites opportunities in mining, utilities stocks
summary: DBS has cited opportunities in nuclear energy, calling it at the cusp of a new renaissance. Investors can gain exposure through physical uranium, uranium miners, utilities companies, and reactor manufacturers. The bank notes that nuclear power has a good safety profile, low-cost, high-energy return on investment, and is gaining traction due to the need to decarbonize and diversify energy sources. DBS recommends investing in these sectors, despite supply-chain risks and concerns over weapon proliferation, accidents, and radioactive waste disposal. The bank expects the sector to follow a "S-curve" growth trajectory similar to breakthrough innovations.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The region has a complicated history with nuclear power, and there are reasons for both optimism and caution.

site_title: Fidelity, BlackRock target Chinese demand for offshore funds
summary: Fidelity International and BlackRock are targeting mainland Chinese investors seeking higher returns from overseas funds, amid deflationary risks and low bank deposit rates at home. The companies are exploring products under the Mutual Recognition of Funds (MRF) scheme, which allows cross-border fund investments between mainland China and Hong Kong. Mainland investors have poured tens of billions of US dollars into Hong Kong-based funds, with some products seeing assets surge over 200% in just a few months. The move aims to capitalize on the interest rate gap between China and the US, with regulatory approvals and competition for the fund industry seen as potential bottlenecks.

images.alt_text: Dennis Quah, head of Singapore wealth at BlackRock, says the strategy aims to give an investor "non-market-driven returns".
Private credit holdings can make up 15% to 30% of some family offices’ portfolios.
BlackRock is aiming for its private markets and technology businesses to make up 30 per cent or more of the firm’s total revenue by 2030, up from 15 per cent in 2024.

site_title: COE woes: When emotions get in the way of efficiency
summary: Singapore's policymakers aim to optimize the allocation of Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices, but emotions often interfere with efficiency. Acting Transport Minister Jeffrey Siow argues that COEs should be allocated to private-hire car companies, which lower demand for private vehicles and serve more commuters. However, this approach sparks debate, with some citing concerns over congestion. The issue highlights the difficulty of applying logic to policy areas influenced by emotions, such as aspirations and social status, which cannot be solely addressed by policy.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
COE premiums for cars crept up after two consecutive rounds of declines.
Acting Transport Minister Jeffrey Siow says that private hire cars help ameliorate rising Certificate of Entitlement premiums by providing private transport to a larger number of individuals.
Autonomous vehicles can help address the public transport sector's shortage of bus drivers, says Acting Transport Minister Jeffrey Siow.

site_title: Warning signs on climate flashing bright red: top scientists
summary: Top scientists warn that climate change indicators are flashing "red" due to record-high greenhouse gas emissions, Earth's surface temperature breaching 1.5°C for the first time, and a significant increase in sea levels. The pace of these indicators is unprecedented and will lead to catastrophic climate impacts if left unchecked. The 1.5°C "carbon budget" will be exhausted in a couple of years, and the world is at risk of exceeding this limit, which was set as an aspirational goal in the 2015 Paris climate treaty.

images.alt_text: epa12178978 Members of Greenpeace stage a protest at the Chamber Hall during the Climate Change Conference in Bonn, Germany, 16 June 2025. The SB62 Climate Change Conference is the pre-sessional meeting for the COP30 Climate Change Conference to be held in Belem, Brazil in November 2025.  EPA-EFE/CHRISTOPHER NEUNDORF
Contrary to popular belief, nuclear power has a good safety profile, noted DBS
Despite the success and growth, certain countries and market dynamics are not as promising due to slower phaseouts of coal-fired power plants, such as China, Indonesia (above) and India.
Generic picture for ESG
Allah Rakha, a 40-year-old brick moulder, cools off in a groundwater pool during a heatwave in Shujabad, Pakistan, June 4, 2025.

site_title: US: Wall Street indexes open muted ahead of Fed's interest rate verdict
summary: US stock indexes opened muted on Wednesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 20.2 points, or 0.05%, to 42,236.03, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, with the S&P 500 rising 5.2 points, or 0.09%, to 5,987.93. The subdued market performance was attributed to ongoing investor uncertainty due to the Israel-Iran conflict, which entered its sixth day. The Federal Reserve's decision is expected to have significant implications for the economy and financial markets.

site_title: Building the bridge: How robust infrastructure will anchor the JS-SEZ’s success
summary: Malaysia and Singapore are set to release a full blueprint for the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) by end-2025, marking a crucial step towards the zone's success. Key infrastructure developments, such as digital customs, QR code clearance, and the Rapid Transit System (RTS) Link, are underway. However, the zone's long-term success will depend on addressing cargo movement, logistics, and utilities, with the two countries needing to coordinate efforts to achieve seamless integration. If done successfully, the JS-SEZ could become a high-performing trade platform and a model for bilateral supply chain collaboration in Asean.

images.alt_text: The Johor-Singapore Causeway is one of the busiest land border crossings in the world.
Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (second from left) meeting with business and government leaders on Monday.

site_title: Five listed construction companies could benefit from mega Changi T5 project
summary: Five Singapore-listed construction companies - Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, Hock Lian Seng, Huationg Global, Ley Choon, and OKP - are well-positioned to benefit from the mega Changi T5 project, given their solid track records on earlier airport projects and familiarity with Singapore's air hub. The companies, which have received awards worth S$4.8 billion, have a combined A1 grade from the Building and Construction Authority (BCA) for both building and civil engineering categories. Their involvement in previous works for Changi Airport may have contributed to their success in securing these deals.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Artist impression of an aerial view of Changi Airport Terminal 5.

site_title: Nike delays launch of women’s brand in partnership with Kim Kardashian’s Skims
summary: Nike has delayed the launch of its new women's activewear brand, NikeSKIMS, in partnership with Kim Kardashian's Skims. The delay is due to working to get the product right, with the initial plan to launch in the spring of 2025 now pushed to 2026. The brand is expected to include training apparel, footwear, and accessories for women, following a growing demand for premium products from Skims. The partnership aims to help Nike compete with brands like Lululemon and Athleta in the women's activewear market.

images.alt_text: Nike will increase prices on apparel and equipment for adults between US$2 and US$10, while footwear priced between US$100 and US$150 will see a US$5 hike, CNBC reported.
Nike chief executive officer Elliott Hill has made changes at the top of the organisation since coming out of retirement in October to lead the business.
The latest executive shifts come after many similar moves, with Hill naming new leaders for strategy, sports marketing, human resources and legal departments.

site_title: US: Stocks flat after Fed decision as markets eye Iran
summary: US stocks ended flat on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates steady, defying expectations. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 slipped less than 1%. Markets watched ongoing fighting between Iran and Israel, but investors believed "cooler heads will prevail." The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.1%. Despite this, shares of Visa and Mastercard fell 5% after the US Senate approved a bill regulating stablecoins, which could make them less attractive to investors.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on June 2, 2025, in New York City. Oil prices surged Monday over renewed concerns about Russia's war in Ukraine and relief over OPEC+ production, while stock markets mostly slumped as US-China trade tensions resurfaced. The dollar was under pressure while Wall Street opened mixed, with the Dow and the broad-based S&P 500 in the red while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: New US home construction falls to five-year low
summary: US residential construction declined 9.8% in May to a 1.3 million annualized rate, the lowest since the pandemic's start. High mortgage rates and elevated home inventories have restrained demand, prompting builders to offer incentives. Multi-family starts fell nearly 30%, while single-family home construction edged up to a 924,000 rate. Economists predict residential construction will be a drag on growth over the next few quarters, and the housing starts report is seen as volatile, with a 90% confidence range for a decline of 0.5-19.1%.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell holds a news conference following a Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington, D.C., June 18, 2025. Despite US President Trump’s call for an interest-rate cut, Powell announced that the central bank’s benchmark interest rate will remain unchanged at a range of 4.25 per cent to 4.5 per cent.
Data next week on the number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid, a proxy for hiring, could shed more light on the state of the labour market in June.
The unchanged reading in import prices last month followed an unrevised 0.1 per cent gain in April.

epa11610755 Consumers shop at Walmart in Los Angeles, California, USA, 17 September 2024. US retail sales unexpectedly rose by 0.1% in August. This release comes as investors expect the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates for the first time since 2020 on 18 September 2024.  EPA-EFE/ALLISON DINNER

site_title: JD.com billionaire unveils turnaround plan after five-year slump
summary: JD.com founder Richard Liu unveiled a turnaround plan after the company's five-year slump, vowing to compete with Meituan in new areas such as food delivery and travel. JD will roll out its e-commerce platform in Europe in 2026 and challenge Meituan in hotel and flight bookings with a three-year membership program. Liu emphasized the company's focus on leveraging its logistics network and high-quality products to drive growth, following a period of stagnation and losses.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: JD.COM logo is seen in this illustration taken, February 11, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Food delivery in China is dominated by Meituan and Ele.me, but JD.com’s high-profile entry into the field in February has intensified the competition.

A worker sorts packages on a JD.com delivery truck in Beijing, China, April 28, 2025. China's new turf war focused on speed is coming at a high cost in the short term as e-commerce giants look to entice consumers with hefty discounts.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, June 18, 2025
summary: Market updates for Wednesday show oil prices rising over 4% due to hostilities in the Middle East, while US retail sales fell. Despite initial risk-off moves, broad market volatility has eased. The conflict between Iran and Israel is escalating, with Trump calling for Iran's 'unconditional surrender'.

images.alt_text: It’s possible that Trump’s unorthodox ways of doing diplomacy, proposing a mix of threats and carrots, would make a deal involving Iran dismantling its nuclear programme more likely.
Brent crude futures settled at US$76.45 a barrel, US$3.22, or 4.4%.

site_title: LA Lakers to be sold in record-breaking US$10 billion deal: ESPN
summary: The Los Angeles Lakers are being sold in a record-breaking $10 billion deal, making the iconic franchise the highest-valued sports team in US history. Billionaire Mark Walter, who already owns a stake in the team, will purchase the controlling interest from the Buss family, ending their 47-year reign. Jeanie Buss will continue as Lakers governor. The sale surpasses the previous highest figure paid for a US sports team, the Boston Celtics' $6.1 billion sale earlier this year, and is seen as a positive move by Lakers legend Magic Johnson, who praises Walter's track record of winning and excellence.

images.alt_text: HOUSTON, TEXAS - APRIL 30: Luka Doncic #77 of the Los Angeles Lakers grabs a rebound against the Minnesota Timberwolves during the first quarter in Game Five of the Western Conference First Round NBA Playoffs at Toyota Center on April 30, 2025 in Houston, Texas. Skims has seen growing demand for its premium bras, loungewear and shapewear.
A street art mural showing PSG's Bradley Barcola and Ousmane Dembele holding the Champions League trophy after the club won the Champions League last weekend.
Inter Miami's Lionel Messi (centre) in action against Columbus Crew in a recent Major League Soccer match. The Argentina star is one of the biggest names at the Club World Cup.

site_title: Chasing beauty
summary: Millennials and Gen-Zs are increasingly seeking non-invasive beauty procedures, joining the ranks of middle-aged individuals. The pursuit of beauty has become a social trend, with the "Mummy Makeover" being a prominent example. As the International Society of Aesthetic Plastic Surgery congress convenes in Singapore, it's essential for individuals to research treatments and consider potential pitfalls before undergoing procedures.

site_title: Record seizure of 11.8 trillion rupiah from Wilmar marks Indonesia’s deepening crackdown on palm oil graft
summary: Indonesian authorities seized 11.8 trillion rupiah (S$928 million) from Wilmar Group, the country's largest asset confiscation, as part of a crackdown on palm oil graft. The funds, nearly two-thirds of Wilmar's net income last year, were handed over as a gesture of good faith and innocence. The seizure is part of Indonesia's broader push to reform its palm oil industry and has significant implications for Wilmar's reputation as a global sustainability leader in the palm oil industry. The case will be reviewed by Indonesia's Supreme Court, which will assess the lower court's judgment on points of law.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
In April, after the Attorney General’s Office arrested an employee of Wilmar Group in relation to the corruption case, the company said it was assisting with investigations.

site_title: Malaysia scores record flows as bond investors favour Asia
summary: Malaysia recorded its largest monthly foreign bond inflows since 2014, with US$3.15 billion invested in the country's bonds last month. This surge in foreign investment is driven by the combination of monetary easing and currency appreciation in Asian debt markets, which offer a haven for bond investors fleeing the US. Other Asian countries, including India and Indonesia, also saw significant foreign investment inflows. Analysts predict that this trend is likely to continue, with emerging markets expected to outperform developed markets as US interest rates drop and the US dollar weakens.

images.alt_text: Retail and industrial Reits remain top picks among analysts, with Pavilion Reit and Sunway Reit lead in the retail space, backed by high footfall and tenant quality.

site_title: Freer trade still delivers – if we share the gains wisely
summary: A majority of Americans support pursuing global free trade, while the European Union and other countries are striking free trade deals. Research by the Copenhagen Consensus economists shows that free trade is overwhelmingly good for rich countries, despite real costs, with a 7:1 return on investment. For poorer countries, free trade generates huge gains, with a $95 return on every dollar spent. However, governments must address the costs and ensure that the benefits are shared fairly, making freer trade a win-win for both rich and poor nations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk at a Walmart store in  Oceanside, California, U.S., May 15, 2025. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: 38 employers with 1,400 vacancies at NTUC-led job-matching exercise for Jetstar Asia workers
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has organized a job-matching exercise for 500 Jetstar Asia workers who lost their jobs after the airline announced its closure. 38 employers, including Singapore Airlines and Airbus, have participated in the three-day exercise, offering 1,400 job vacancies across various sectors. The employers include companies from the aerospace and aviation industry, and the NTUC will provide career guidance and support to the affected workers.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Customers impacted by Jetstar Asia's shutdown will be offered alternative flights or full refunds.

site_title: UBS, Pictet report data leak after cyberattack on provider, client data unaffected
summary: Swiss banks UBS and Pictet reported a data leak due to a cyberattack on a provider in Switzerland. Files containing details of tens of thousands of UBS employees were stolen, but no client data was affected. The leak occurred at Chain IQ, a business service company, which also targeted 19 other companies. The stolen data was published on the darknet, but steps were taken to contain the situation, and both banks stated they had protocols in place to prevent unauthorized access.

images.alt_text: The contentious and costly part for UBS is the demand that it should fully capitalise its foreign subsidiaries.
The government said its capital requirement proposal would allow UBS to reduce its holding of Additional Tier 1 (AT1) bonds by US$8 billion.

British companies, public bodies and institutions have been hit by a wave of cyberattacks in recent years, costing them tens of millions of pounds and often months of disruption.

site_title: Resorts World Sentosa commits S$200,000 to newly launched Sustainability Arts Fund
summary: Resorts World Sentosa (RWS) has committed S$200,000 to the newly launched Sustainability Arts Fund, a partnership with the National Arts Council (NAC) to support local arts organisations in creating immersive art experiences at the Singapore Oceanarium. Two local arts groups, Mural Lingo and TRDOco, will present art experiences, including a mural and immersive dance performances, to advocate for marine conservation. The fund aims to enhance the sustainability of small arts organisations and foster a culture of giving to support the arts.

images.alt_text: For its 12th anniversary, SEA Aquarium has specially curated zones to celebrate its impact on marine education, conservation and appreciation.

site_title: Malaysia to build 50% more gas-fired power capacity to meet data centre demand
summary: Malaysia plans to increase its gas-fired power capacity by 40-54% by 2030 to meet growing demand from data centres, with a total of 6-8 gigawatts of new capacity expected. The country is expected to see the fastest surge in data centre power demand in South-east Asia, with its share of electricity consumed by data centres tripling to 21% by 2027. This increase is driven by rising demand from technology giants such as Google and Microsoft, which have invested billions of dollars in Malaysia's infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Khazanah said to mull selling RM3.6b of listed firm stakes

site_title: GE proposal: OCBC minority shareholders’ perspective
summary: A group of OCBC shareholders, representing over 125,000 shareholders, expressed concerns over the bank's potential to up its offer for Great Eastern (GE) if the insurer's delisting fails on July 8. They argue that OCBC has already offered a fair price of S$30.15 per share, which is lower than GE's embedded value of S$38.08 per share. The shareholders believe that OCBC's current exit offer is in their best interests, as it allows the bank to strengthen itself as an integrated financial services group and unlock more value for long-term shareholders.

images.alt_text: After a long trading suspension, GEH’s minorities now have certainty: the insurer will either be delisted with an exit offer of S$30.15, or trading in its shares will resume.
OCBC’s offer for GEH last year did not satisfy the conditions for a voluntary delisting, but resulted in the insurer breaching the minimum free float rule
The offer comes months after OCBC first made a privatisation bid for Great Eastern through a voluntary unconditional general offer at S$25.60 per share.

site_title: ComfortDelGro, SBS Transit to move out of Braddell headquarters ahead of lease expiry in 2026
summary: ComfortDelGro and its subsidiary SBS Transit will relocate their Braddell Road headquarters ahead of a lease expiry in August 2026. Affected staff will be relocated from October, with operations gradually shifting to other locations. The new corporate headquarters' location has not been disclosed. Maintenance workshops for taxis and public buses will continue at other facilities. The Braddell site, owned by JTC Corporation, will remain zoned for transport facilities use.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall, but still elevated
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell 5,000 to 245,000 for the week ended Jun 14, but remain elevated. Economists expect data next week on continuing claims to shed light on labor market momentum in June. The claims are in the upper end of their range for the year, driven by layoffs and a challenging economic environment. Federal Reserve officials are expected to keep the benchmark interest rate steady, monitoring the economic fallout from tariffs and a conflict.

images.alt_text: SUNRISE, FLORIDA - APRIL 30: Kiaraliz Irizarry (L) recruits people for jobs at Triton Recovery during the Mega JobNewsUSA South Florida Job Fair held in the Amerant Bank Arena on April 30, 2025 in Sunrise, Florida. Over 150 local hiring managers & recruiters were at the job fair to recruit workers for 1000s of positions in Miami, Broward, and Palm Beach County.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JOE RAEDLE / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The unchanged reading in import prices last month followed an unrevised 0.1 per cent gain in April.

site_title: Indonesia antitrust agency gives 'conditional' go-ahead for TikTok's Tokopedia takeover
summary: Indonesia's antitrust agency has given TikTok's Tokopedia takeover a "conditional" approval, allowing the deal to proceed after agreeing to certain requirements. The agency had previously raised concerns over market concentration and potential price increases due to TikTok's dominance. The requirements include guaranteed open methods for payment and logistics, and measures to prevent predatory pricing. The agency will continue to monitor the implementation of these requirements until June 17, 2027.

images.alt_text: As ByteDance remakes Tokopedia in TikTok Shop’s image, merchants and employees worry it will be a hollowed-out version of its former self.

site_title: UOB becomes direct participant in China’s cross-border clearing and settlement system
summary: UOB has become a direct participant in China's Cross-border Interbank Payment System (CIPS), enabling the bank to provide cross-border renminbi clearing, settlement, and payment services to businesses and financial institutions within and outside China. This move will allow UOB clients to enjoy real-time gross settlement and remittance at lower payment and clearing costs, and expand its trading network globally. The direct access is expected to significantly enhance UOB's capability to serve regional clients in their renminbi businesses, following in the footsteps of Singapore-headquartered bank DBS China, which was the first to join CIPS in 2015.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
DPM Gan was speaking at the two-day 30th Nikkei International Forum on the Future of Asia, themed “Asia’s Challenge in a Turbulent World”.

The People’s Bank of China increased the floor ratio for renminbi-denominated trade transactions to 40 per cent from 25 per cent as part of its recent adjustment to the so-called Macro Prudential Assessment.

Asean – as well as UOB, which turns 90 this year – has weathered many crises before, and there are further opportunities for the region to emerge stronger, said UOB deputy chairman and CEO Wee Ee Cheong.
The banks stressed that the greater concern lies not in the direct impact of tariffs, but in the secondary effects.

site_title: Nippon Steel’s US$14.9 billion acquisition of US Steel closes, with big role for Trump
summary: Nippon Steel's $14.9 billion acquisition of US Steel closed on June 18, with President Donald Trump playing a significant role in the deal. The Japanese company acquired 100% of US Steel shares at $55 per share, and a national security agreement was inked with the Trump administration, granting the US government veto authority over corporate decisions. This agreement, which was seen as a concession to save the deal, has raised concerns about potential national security risks and may drive overseas investors away from US companies.

images.alt_text: Shares of Nippon Steel, the world’s fourth-largest steelmaker, gained 3 per cent to 2,915 yen by the mid-day break after being untraded with a glut of buy orders earlier in the day.
Shares of US Steel rose 3.5% on the news in after-the-bell trading as investors bet the deal was close to done.

site_title: Thai PM sparks turmoil after criticising military in leaked audio
summary: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra blamed her own military for escalating a border dispute with Cambodia, according to a leaked audio recording. The 17-minute call, leaked by former Cambodian leader Hun Sen, shows Paetongtarn attempting to ease tensions with softer remarks and a strategy to maintain peace. The leak has sparked fresh turmoil, with opposition groups calling for Paetongtarn's resignation and a potential dissolution of parliament. The crisis has also raised concerns among foreign investors, who have dumped a net $2.3 billion of Thai stocks this year.

images.alt_text: “At this stage, neither side wants war,” says Deputy Prime Minister Phumtham Wechayachai, who also serves as defence minister, after a meeting of the National Security Council.

site_title: European, North Asian companies also eyeing the potential of JS-SEZ: UOB banker
summary: European and North Asian companies are exploring opportunities in Singapore's Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), with some using Singapore as a base to tap into Johor's potential. Companies are considering the "plus-one" strategy, expanding beyond China, Vietnam, and Europe to other regions. The JS-SEZ offers tax incentives and opportunities in sectors like electronic manufacturing services, medical devices, and data centers. However, foreign investors are concerned about government policy changes and talent shortages, which require higher salaries. Experts recommend considering tax, immigration, and employment aspects when investing in the JS-SEZ.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
The Johor-Singapore Causeway is one of the busiest land border crossings in the world.
The causeway heading from Johor Bahru to Singapore is  the logistical and symbolic backbone of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone.
The SEZ may also present opportunities for Johor to build a Meetings, Incentives, Conferences, and Exhibitions (Mice) industry.
Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong (second from left) meeting with business and government leaders on Monday.

site_title: Amid ongoing investigations into its supply chain unit, how did Fu Yu’s board end up with only one director?
summary: Fu Yu Corporation, a Singapore-based components manufacturer, faces potential breaches of the Singapore Exchange's mainboard listing rules due to its board composition. The company's largest shareholder, Victor Lim, has been pushing to oust independent directors Royston Tan and Christopher Huang. After three independent directors resigned, CEO David Seow remains as the sole director, leaving the company at risk of breaching listing rules requiring at least one-third independent directors. Fu Yu is also investigating its supply chain unit, Fu Yu Supply Chain Solutions, over unverifiable payment arrangements and has launched claims against Lim and five others over the probe.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
David Seow, CEO, Fu Yu Corporation is the only remaining executive director on the board.

site_title: China’s rare earth exports slump in May as magnet sales curbed
summary: China's rare earth exports plummeted 61% in May to 2,117 tons, the lowest level since February 2020, due to export controls in place since early April. The controls, which cover not just individual rare earths but also magnets containing them, have choked shipments and threatened industries reliant on rare earth magnets. China produces 90% of the world's permanent rare earth magnets, and the US is watching how flows change in June following a meeting between American and Chinese negotiators.

site_title: Prudential Singapore commits S$880,000 to support vulnerable families and sustainability efforts
summary: Prudential Singapore has committed S$880,000 to support vulnerable families and sustainability efforts in Singapore. The insurer will distribute 1,100 hampers containing household essentials to ComLink+ families near its new office in Labrador Tower. The investment also supports the Healthy with KidSTART programme, community edible gardens, and the Prudential Longevity Pledge, aiming to make a lasting impact on the community.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of the Prudential logo seen on Aug 13, 2020.

site_title: Meta offered US$100 million bonuses to poach OpenAI employees: CEO Altman
summary: Meta offered US$100 million bonuses to poach OpenAI employees, but none have accepted, according to OpenAI CEO Sam Altman. Meta has invested billions in AI technology, with plans to spend at least US$60 billion this year, to compete with rivals OpenAI, Google, and Microsoft. Altman believes OpenAI has a better shot at delivering on superintelligence, and that Meta's approach to attracting talent may not be effective in creating a great culture.

images.alt_text: OpenAI needs Microsoft’s approval to complete its transition into a public-benefit corporation. But the two have not been able to agree on details even after months of negotiations, sources said.
AMD CEO Lisa Su holds the company's new MI300X chip at an event outlining AMD's artificial intelligence strategy in San Francisco, US, June 13, 2023.
Barbie doll maker Mattel is not licensing its intellectual property to OpenAI as part of the deal and remains in full control of the products being created.
The Orb scan creates a digital credential, called World ID, based on the unique properties of a person’s iris.

site_title: CEO’s wealth hits US$33 billion as unprofitable Chinese medicine firm’s stock soars
summary: Regencell Bioscience Holding, a Hong Kong-based traditional Chinese medicine company, has seen its CEO Yat-Gai Au's net worth surge to $33.3 billion after the company's stock price skyrocketed 82,000% since its low in February. Despite being a money-losing firm, Regencell sells herbal medicine treatments for ADHD and autism spectrum disorder. The company has never turned a profit and is still in the R&D phase. A 38-for-1 stock split and a 30% gain on Tuesday brought the stock price to $78, making Au's stake the largest fortune among billionaires.

images.alt_text: Its traditional Chinese medicine formula, which forms the basis of its product candidates, “contains only natural ingredients without any synthetic components”.

site_title: EDB, US aerospace giant RTX sign MOU to invest, partner in AI and skills development
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) and US aerospace conglomerate RTX have signed a 10-year memorandum of understanding (MOU) to collaborate on AI and skills development, affirming Singapore's role as a key hub for RTX's global operations. The deal aims to drive innovation and future growth in the aerospace sector, with strategic investments and partnerships in areas such as MRO, advanced manufacturing, and talent development. RTX has a significant presence in Singapore, with over 4,300 employees across 12 factories.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim

VDL Enabling Technologies Group Singapore's new SQ1 building in Jurong will house an office block,
warehousing and logistics space, and cleanroom manufacturing space.

site_title: Latest GLS programme designed to draw developers back to state tenders
summary: The Singapore government has announced plans to release land for 4,725 private housing units in the second half of 2025 through the confirmed list, a 6% drop from the 5,030 units in the first half of 2025. The government aims to provide stable land supply despite the uncertain global economic and political climate. The new confirmed list includes 10 sites, offering a mix of prime and city-fringe locations, with most sites being relatively small, making them more manageable for developers. This is expected to draw more developers to state tenders, increasing the likelihood of top bids and resulting in a higher likelihood of awarding sites to developers.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
The Ministry of National Development announced the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme today.
A 0.59 ha site in Newton along Bukit Timah Road is expected to be hotly contested.

site_title: Malaysia hopes to draw back talent to power JS-SEZ
summary: Malaysia aims to attract local talent to the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ) by offering more industry-relevant training and a lower cost of living. CEO of BizTech Asia, Brian Fernandez, notes that many Johoreans would be willing to work in Malaysia if their salaries were half of those in Singapore. This is not a competition with Singapore, but a "symbiotic relationship" that benefits both countries, according to Idzham Mohd Hashim, president and CEO of Iskandar Investment. The goal is to tap into the hundreds of thousands of Malaysians crossing the causeways daily.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin

The exchange of the SEZ document took place during the 11th Malaysia-Singapore Leaders’ Retreat on Jan 7 in Putrajaya, and was witnessed by Singapore’s Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) and Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, right, speaks during a press conference with Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the prime minister's office in Putrajaya, Malaysia, Tuesday, Jan. 7, 2025. Vincent Thian/Pool via REUTERS
In less than one month, Malaysia and SIngapore will be finalising the agreement for Johor-Singapore special economic zone, marking a new chapter for both countries' trade relationship.

site_title: Indonesia central bank keeps rates steady, leaves door open to more easing
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia (BI), maintained its interest rates steady at 5.5% as expected, while leaving the door open for further easing. The decision comes amid global headwinds, including US tariffs and geopolitical uncertainties. BI keeps its 2025 growth forecast at 4.6-5.4% and urges commercial banks to reduce lending rates and boost credit growth. The bank has cut interest rates three times since September and downgraded its outlook twice this year, citing slowing domestic demand and shaky global growth.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has pledged to increase its energy and agriculture imports from the US, as well as increase cooperation for the supply of critical minerals in the trade talks.
The currency remains the worst performer among major Asian peers this year, having depreciated by about 2.6 per cent against the US dollar.

The rupiah is the only major Asian currency to decline against the US dollar this year as concerns grow over President Prabowo Subianto’s controversial fiscal policies.

site_title: DBS aims to double Australian lending book in 5 years
summary: DBS Group aims to double its Australian lending book to A$20 billion in the next five years, with a current book worth A$11 billion. The bank has signed a pact with Austrade to facilitate trade and investment between Australian and South-east Asian businesses, particularly from Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Vietnam. DBS CEO Tan Su Shan believes this will help change the domestic-centric approach of Australian companies and attract more foreign investment. The bank's assets under management also reached a record high of S$432 billion in the first quarter, driven by strong market sentiment.

site_title: Grab’s US$1.5 billion convertible issue seen as prepping for competition and need for capital: Maybank
summary: Grab's US$1.5 billion convertible note issue is seen as a preparation for potential competition and capital needs, according to Maybank Securities. The move comes as the Asean digital sector faces increased competition, with Grab's net cash position rising to US$7.7 billion post-issue. The analysts also note that Grab may consider acquiring foodpanda, but a large transaction size could necessitate a capital raise. Meanwhile, rising threats from players like Vietnam's Green and Smart Mobility and Chinese giants like Meituan or Didi could intensify pricing and driver incentives, demanding financial agility.

He wants to tap into the fund's assets -- planned to be more than $900 billion -- to boost Indonesia to developed economy status, despite expert concern about its governance. Grab has increased its convertible note offering to US$1.5 billion.

site_title: Far East Orchard secures £96 million for private fund to develop UK student accommodation
summary: Far East Orchard's private student accommodation development fund has secured £96 million, exceeding its initial target of £100 million. The fund, which focuses on purpose-built student accommodation in the UK, has committed over 35% of its equity to two developments in Glasgow and Manchester. The company aims to pivot towards an asset-light model and grow recurring fee-based income, with institutional investors accounting for 63.5% of the fund's capital. This marks a significant step forward for Far East Orchard's strategy to build a resilient lodging platform.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Far East Orchard said that the group’s PBSA portfolio’s reservations stood at 92 per cent for the academic year commencing September 2024, reflecting “strong continued demand” for student accommodation.

site_title: Singapore shares dip ahead of Fed decision; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% or 9.83 points to close at 3,920.81, tracking mixed Asian markets ahead of the US Federal Reserve's policy decision. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC declined 0.3-0.5% each, while telco giant Singtel rose 1% following a settlement with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. Wilmar International dropped 2.7% after Indonesian authorities seized S$928 million from its parent company in a palm-oil graft case.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
Indonesian authorities are probing Wilmar Group and two other palm-oil companies, which they accuse of paying bribes to obtain export permits between January and April 2022.

Optus says that the penalty is fully provided for in the previous financial year ended Mar 31, 2025.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 18)
summary: Economists have cut their growth forecasts for Singapore to 1.7%, citing manufacturing sector decline. COE prices rose across categories, except motorcycles, with a 3.2% increase for Cat B premium. BlackRock launched a hedge fund for retail investors in Singapore and Hong Kong, focusing on Asia-Pacific equities. Singapore remains the world's top port for 12th consecutive year, while FedEx partners with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries. The country also set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: The Singapore private members' club is closed from Jun 17.

site_title: Wilmar to buy over Nigeria-incorporated palm oil business from British JV partner for US$70 million
summary: Wilmar International is acquiring its remaining 50% stake in Nigeria-incorporated palm oil business PZ Wilmar from British JV partner PZ Cussons for US$70 million. The acquisition aims to tap food and nutrition business opportunities in Nigeria, which has a large and growing population. Wilmar plans to develop the upstream palm plantation and downstream businesses in the country, with minimal impact on its consolidated net tangible assets and earnings per share. The transaction is expected to be completed in the last quarter of 2025.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: SIA flights from Changi Airport to Bali among dozens cancelled after Indonesia volcano eruption
summary: At least two dozen flights to and from Bali, including Singapore Airlines flights from Changi Airport, have been cancelled due to the eruption of Mount Lewotobi Laki-Laki in Indonesia's eastern region. The volcano's alert status was raised to the highest level on June 17, with ash tower reaching 10km into the sky. Flights to Jakarta appear unaffected, but several domestic flights to Labuan Bajo on Flores were cancelled. The eruption is the second time this year that the volcano has erupted, with nine people killed in November 2024.

images.alt_text: Mount Lewotobi Laki-Laki spews volcanic ash during an eruption in East Flores, East Nusa Tenggara, Indonesia, March 1, 2025.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands deploys autonomous robots for back-of-house deliveries
summary: Marina Bay Sands has deployed 12 autonomous mobile robots (AMRs) for back-of-house deliveries, marking the first such deployment in Singapore's hospitality sector. The robots, capable of carrying up to 300 kg and traveling at 84 meters per minute, have reduced labor dependency by 30%. The initiative follows a 35% increase in delivery volumes between 2019 and 2023 and is part of the resort's efforts to automate over 200 work processes, including uniform management and food-waste handling.

images.alt_text: The casino resort operator has “substantially completed” its US$1.8 billion redevelopment programme, according to a statement on Wednesday (Apr 23).
From left: Beatrice Liu, co-founder and CEO, Oriental Remedies Group; Koren Wines, managing director, Xero Asia; and Paul Gardner, CEO, Fresh Accounting.

site_title: Oil prices rise more than 4% as Iran-Israel conflict escalates
summary: Oil prices surged over 4% on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures reaching US$76.45 a barrel, as the Iran-Israel conflict escalated, raising geopolitical risk. Iran partially suspended gas production at a shared field and Israel hit an oil depot, despite no major oil flows being disrupted. Analysts attribute the price increase to a security premium of around US$10 a barrel, built into the price due to uncertainty about Iran's leadership. The International Energy Agency revised its world oil demand estimate downwards and increased supply estimates, but investors are also focused on central bank interest rate decisions.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled US$1, or 1.35 per cent, lower to US$73.23 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell US$1.21, or 1.66 per cent, to US$71.77 per barrel on Monday.

site_title: China consumer rush for subsidies overloads stimulus programme
summary: China's stimulus program to encourage consumer spending has led to a surge in retail sales growth, but authorities are struggling to manage the program's impact. Provinces are running out of funds, with some suspending or limiting the program. The government has distributed 162 billion yuan in two tranches, but economists warn that Beijing needs sustainable measures to maintain consumption momentum. Experts suggest relying on policies to lift business confidence, such as meeting government arrears to companies, to encourage private investment and hiring, potentially leading to stronger consumption in the long term.

images.alt_text: It is difficult to spot symptoms of repression among the Chinese shoppers in luxury stores from Shanghai to Paris.

China's industrial output data, released by the National Bureau of Statistics, missed expectations for a 5.9 per cent increase in a Reuters poll and marked the slowest growth since November last year.

In May 2025, despite a sharp 35 per cent drop in exports to the US, China's overall exports rose 4.8 per cent year on year.  From being Beijing’s largest trading partner, it is gradually becoming just one of many customers.
The US is threatening to raise tariffs on many countries from early July and on China from August.

site_title: Record-high satisfaction with property agents, but rising expectations on advice, compliance: CEA survey
summary: A record 92% of Singapore property consumers are satisfied with their agents' services, according to the 2024 Public Perception Survey by the Council for Estate Agencies (CEA). Despite increasing satisfaction, consumers expect property agents to improve in understanding client needs, providing relevant professional advice, and ensuring compliance with laws and regulations. The CEA has implemented recommendations to strengthen ongoing professional development for property agents, and plans to further digitalize property transaction processes. The Singapore Estate Agents Association (SEAA) and the Institute of Estate Agents (IEA) Singapore have also merged to form a unified industry body, the Singapore Institute of Estate Agents (SIEA).

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Desmond Tan, NTUC's deputy secretary-general, and ERA Singapore's chief executive Marcus Chu (right), sign MOU to uplift welfare and advance professional development in the real estate sector.
The enhanced compliance and penalty frameworks will target errant estate agents, salespersons and developers.

site_title: China’s central bank says to promote digital yuan, multi-polar currency system
summary: China's central bank governor Pan Gongsheng announced plans to promote the digital yuan and a multi-polar global currency system, where several currencies coexist and check each other. China will establish an international operation centre for e-CNY in Shanghai and launch yuan futures trading to provide a risk-hedging tool for investors. Pan expects several key global currencies to coexist, reducing reliance on the US dollar. The move comes amid US President Donald Trump's erratic policies and rising global interest in cryptocurrencies, highlighting the need for a more resilient and stable global financial system.

images.alt_text: China has been a leader among countries that are developing the CBDC – digital tokens issued by central banks, although adoption is still in the early stages.

site_title: Inside Wilmar’s graft probe: How a cooking oil crisis led to a multitrillion rupiah corruption scandal
summary: Indonesian authorities have seized 11.8 trillion rupiah (S$928 million) from palm oil giant Wilmar as part of an ongoing corruption case involving bribery to obtain palm oil export permits in 2022. Wilmar is accused of evading state-imposed export controls that aimed to curb a cooking oil crisis and domestic palm oil shortage. The company was acquitted by a lower court in March but the case is now under review by the Indonesian Supreme Court, which may determine if the earlier ruling will stand.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Thakral Corp, Fu Yu, IHH Healthcare
summary: Thakral Corp has launched an IPO of GemLife Communities, an Australian over-50s lifestyle resort operator, to raise up to A$750 million. Fu Yu is seeking to appoint independent non-executive directors after all its independent directors resigned. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

site_title: Monopoly maker Hasbro cuts 3% of total workforce amid higher tariff costs
summary: Hasbro, the toy maker, has cut 3% of its global workforce, amounting to about 150 employees, amid higher tariff costs on toys mainly sourced from China. The company is diversifying sourcing and reducing exposure to China as part of its long-term restructuring efforts. Hasbro sources half of its US toys from China, and the job cuts are part of a multi-year restructuring plan. The move aims to offset the impact of tariffs on consumer prices and profits.

images.alt_text: Hasbro has focused on controlling costs this year to weather a slump in demand for toys.

site_title: US Senate passes stablecoin bill in win for crypto, Trump
summary: The US Senate passed a bill to create a regulatory framework for US-dollar-pegged cryptocurrency tokens, known as stablecoins, in a bipartisan 68-30 vote. The bill, dubbed the Genius Act, requires tokens to be backed by liquid assets and for issuers to publicly disclose their reserves. The House of Representatives must pass its version of the bill before it heads to President Donald Trump's desk for approval. The move marks a significant milestone for the digital asset industry, with proponents arguing that stablecoins could be used to send payments instantly.

images.alt_text: Overseas, the Ant International arm established an independent board, setting the stage for a spinoff and potential IPO.
Circle’s IPO marks an eventful year in the sector’s push towards traditional finance under US President Donald Trump, who has promised lighter crypto regulations.
Circle will list on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol “CRCL”.
New York-based Circle and some existing investors are looking to raise up to US$624 million by offering 24 million shares priced between US$24 and US$26 apiece.

site_title: India developer’s US$1.3 billion luxury project sells out in one week
summary: India's largest real estate developer, DLF, sold luxury residences worth about $1.3 billion at a new high-rise project near New Delhi, generating the highest-ever revenue from a single project. The 1,164 units, valued over $1 million each, were sold within a week of starting bookings. This follows a 28% growth in sales of expensive top-end houses in India's top seven cities in the first quarter of 2025. The project, spread over 17.7 acres, is expected to be completed in about five years.

images.alt_text: At the palatial Oberoi Amarvilas, every room comes with a private panorama of the Taj Mahal.

site_title: China will hike quota for investors buying overseas assets
summary: China's central bank will increase the quota for local investors buying overseas assets under the qualified domestic institutional investors (QDII) scheme, allowing more funds to invest in foreign securities. The move follows a period of calm in the yuan's value against the US dollar, giving Beijing the opportunity to ease capital controls and promote the yuan's international use. The current quota of $167.79 billion will be lifted, with regulators also planning to explore yuan futures trading and establish a digital yuan operation centre.

images.alt_text: Pan’s call comes as US President Donald Trump’s erratic tariff and foreign policies have dented investor trust in US dollar assets.

site_title: From ambition to action: funding scalable carbon removal
summary: Standard Chartered's head of carbon markets, Chris Leeds, emphasized the need for innovation, collaboration, and action to scale carbon dioxide removal (CDR) solutions in Southeast Asia. The bank co-hosted the Puro.earth Apac Carbon Dioxide Removal Summit, which brought together over 170 participants to discuss CDR approaches and financing structures. Leeds highlighted the importance of fostering a culture of innovation and taking risks to deliver measurable outcomes. The summit also showcased innovative financing structures, such as a debt financing deal with British Airways, to accelerate CDR growth and bridge the region's US$50 billion funding gap.

epa11991565 Members of the 'Conquerors of Sarayburnu' jump in the water for their daily routine of swimming in the Bosphorus' cold waters during a rainy 1-degree Celsius morning in Istanbul, Turkey, 11 February 2025.
The Conquerors of Sarayburnu are a group of about 200 people that swim in the sea, off the historic Sarayburnu peninsula of Istanbul every morning, 365 days a year. Regardless of the weather, they meet every day and jump into the Bosphurus for an invigorating swim. Known in English as the Seraglio Point, the area is a promontory that separates the Golden Horn and the Sea of Marmara in Istanbul, Turkey.
Members of the group hail from at least 15 of Istambul´s different districts. After morning prayer at the Hagia Sophia Mosque, they meet at the seashore. Those who arrive first light a bonfire for all to stay warm at the water´s edge. Then they change into their swimsuits and walk about a kilometer to reach the point where they jump into the frigid waters. They swim for about 10 minutes against the current of the Bosphorus Strait. When they make it out, they gather around the fire to warm up. Sometimes during the summer months when the weather is nice, they swim between the Asian and European sides of Istambul.  EPA-EFE/ERDEM SAHIN  ATTENTION: For the full FOCUS ESSAY text please go to: https://epaimages.com/misc.pp?code=section-focus

site_title: WP co-opts 4 rookie MPs into CEC, NCMP Eileen Chong to head youth wing
summary: The Workers' Party (WP) has co-opted four rookie MPs, including Abdul Muhaimin Abdul Malik, Kenneth Tiong, Eileen Chong, and Andre Low, into its central executive committee. Eileen Chong will lead the party's youth wing, while Kenneth Tiong will serve as deputy treasurer. The appointments were made following a CEC meeting on June 17. The new members will play a vital role in serving Singaporeans and working for the country, according to the party. The WP has a total of 12 rookie MPs in Parliament.

site_title: London’s sky-high prices thin the ranks of room-to-rent seekers
summary: The number of people seeking to rent a room in London has declined, with 57,600 room sharers in May, a 6,500 drop from the previous year. The cost of renting a room has remained above £1,000 (S$1,726) since 2022, making it unaffordable for many. This decline may be due to prospective homeowners resuming searches as interest rates decrease, but also reflects young people opting to live with their parents due to unaffordable rent prices and poor job prospects.

site_title: Gold steady as Middle East tensions rise, Fed decision on tap
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$3,386.59 an ounce, as tensions between Israel and Iran entered their sixth day. The US Federal Reserve is expected to leave its benchmark interest rate unchanged, at 4.25-4.5%. The stronger US dollar and escalating Middle East tensions capped gains ahead of the Fed's decision. Meanwhile, spot silver fell 0.3%, platinum rose 0.2%, and palladium fell 0.4%.

site_title: EnterpriseSG, CapitaLand Investment launch challenge to foster, identify innovative retail concepts in Singapore
summary: EnterpriseSG and CapitaLand Investment launched the Retail Maverick Challenge to foster innovative retail concepts in Singapore. The challenge aims to identify brands that can develop compelling store concepts to meet consumer demand, with a focus on experiential and technology-driven solutions. Winners will receive up to 4,000 sq ft of free retail space, rental waivers, and funding up to 50% of supportable costs. The challenge closes on Aug 4, with the goal of strengthening Singapore's position as a vibrant retail and lifestyle destination.

site_title: Made in Vietnam: Hanoi cracks down on fake goods as US tariffs loom
summary: Vietnam is cracking down on counterfeit goods amid US concerns, with a three-month crackdown on fake products set to begin until mid-August. The country aims to avoid a 46% tariff imposed by the US in early July. Authorities have ordered tightening control over goods origin and seized over 7,000 cases of counterfeit products worth more than $8 million. The crackdown is seen as part of Vietnam's strategy to appease the US, with the country's trade ministry and public security ministry taking action to combat the trade.

summary: Wilmar International's shares fell 4% on June 18 after Indonesian authorities seized $928 million from its parent company, Wilmar Group, in a palm-oil graft case. This is the lowest share price in over five years. The Indonesian authorities are probing Wilmar Group and two other palm-oil companies for allegedly paying bribes to obtain export permits between January and April 2022.

site_title: Thai May export growth beats forecast with fastest pace in more than three years
summary: Thailand's exports surged 18.4% in May, beating expectations with a record $31 billion, driven by accelerated shipments ahead of a US tariff pause expiration in July. The commerce minister expects export growth to exceed 10% this year, with the US trade talks expected to go well. However, if a reduction cannot be negotiated, Thailand faces a 36% US tariff on its exports. The country's exports to the US and China rose 35% and 28% respectively in May, while shipments of computers and agricultural goods surged 104% and 6.8% respectively.

site_title: Morgan Stanley’s top Asia banker targets US$10 billion in revenue
summary: Morgan Stanley is aiming to increase its Asia revenue to $10 billion within five years, driven by a widening array of investment banking and trading initiatives across the region. Led by Asia chief Gokul Laroia, the bank is regaining traction in China, where it posted record Asia revenue of $7.64 billion last year, topping Goldman Sachs. Laroia's team is focused on executing the Asia strategy, with a growing presence in Japan and India, and a push to broaden its product suite across businesses in China to counter the deals slump.

site_title: Economists slash Singapore growth forecast to 1.7%, with manufacturing expected to shrink: survey
summary: Singapore's growth forecast for 2025 has been slashed to 1.7% by private-sector economists, citing worsening US-China tensions and a manufacturing contraction. Expectations for inflation also fell, with core inflation forecast at 0.8% and headline inflation at 0.9%. Economists predict a further easing of monetary policy in July, with 57.9% expecting a loosening of monetary policy. Despite this, growth forecasts remain within official ranges, and economists expect the impact of tariff shocks to be cushioned by the 90-day US tariff reprieve and de-escalating US-China tensions.

summary: Pitstop Tyres, a Singapore-based auto repair shop, has turned its fortunes around after going viral on TikTok, clearing S$400,000 of debt and now aiming to become Singapore's top auto shop. The second-generation owner, Cordillia Tan, applied her experience in scaling startups to help her father's business survive. Expanding services beyond tyre sales and repairs boosted revenue, and the shop now generates over S$1 million annually. Tan has set a goal to clear debt in two years and focus on customer service, with the aim of becoming the top automotive shop in Singapore.

site_title: The myth of the suppressed Chinese consumer
summary: China's economy is often criticized for its high investment-to-consumption ratio, but the country's private consumer spending has actually grown at a faster rate than any other economy, averaging over 8% a year since the 21st century began. In reality, China's consumption share of GDP is around 55%, closer to the global norm when investment growth is corrected for over-investment. The calls to "free the Chinese consumer" are misguided, as the country's real problems, such as over-investment and a huge debt load, cannot be solved by boosting consumption.

site_title: Amazon’s corporate workforce may shrink as AI takes over routine tasks
summary: Amazon's CEO Andy Jassy says the company's corporate workforce may shrink as AI takes over routine tasks, with the rollout of generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) and agents reducing the need for some jobs. The company is using AI to enhance efficiency and customer experience, including inventory optimization, customer service chatbots, and product detail pages. Despite uncertainty, experts agree that AI will not lead to mass unemployment, but rather a reshuffling of the workforce, with some roles being replaced by more complex tasks.

site_title: US plans to ease capital rule limiting banks’ Treasury trades
summary: The US Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency plan to ease a key capital rule limiting banks' Treasury trades, aiming to boost banks' roles as intermediaries in the market. The enhanced supplementary leverage ratio (eSLR) will be reduced by up to 1.5 percentage points for the largest lenders, from 5% to 3.5-4.5%, in an effort to address concerns that the current rule constrains their trading in the $29 trillion US Treasuries market. The proposal will be discussed on June 25.

summary: Ultra-rich individuals are turning Vietnam into a new hotspot for luxury yachts, driven by the country's rapid growth in wealth and tourism. Vietnam's US dollar millionaire population has nearly doubled between 2013 and 2023, making it a lucrative market for yacht manufacturers. Luxury yacht owners, such as Pham Van Toan, are investing heavily in the country, with plans to develop a luxury marina in Ha Long Bay and offer private charters. Yacht makers, including Azimut and Simpson Marine, are expanding their operations in Vietnam, catering to the growing demand for luxury yachts.

However, freight costs and insurance premiums may increase due to rising tensions and risks in the region. The Strait of Hormuz, a critical oil chokepoint, remains open, but a blockade could send oil prices soaring past $100 a barrel. The impact on shipping charges is expected to be nuanced, with potential rises in bunker prices and war-risk premiums.

site_title: Singtel’s Optus reaches settlement over alleged sales misconduct, including A$100 million proposed penalty
summary: Optus, a Singtel subsidiary, has reached a settlement with the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) over alleged sales misconduct. The ACCC accused Optus of manipulating credit check results, selling phones and plans to vulnerable customers, and engaging debt collectors to pursue customers despite knowing the contracts were created fraudulently. A proposed penalty of A$100 million (S$83.4 million) is included in the settlement, which also requires Optus to implement changes to its retail processes and systems.

site_title: China car trade-in subsidy halted in some areas as funds run low
summary: China's trade-in subsidy program, aimed at boosting electric and fuel-efficient vehicle sales, has been suspended in six provinces due to funds running low and concerns over 'zero-mileage' used cars. The program, which gave up to 20,000 yuan towards a new car purchase, was halted in cities like Guangdong and Henan. Authorities are scrutinizing practices that involve buying new cars in bulk, registering them, and then selling them without driving. This move adds to growing challenges for the Chinese auto industry, which has been affected by an extended price war and weakening economy.

images.alt_text: The programme has been key to encouraging household purchases of a slew of consumer goods this year.

site_title: Japan exports post first drop in eight months as US tariffs hit autos
summary: Japan's exports fell 1.7% year-over-year in May, marking the first decline in eight months, due to US tariffs on automobiles. The tariffs have threatened Japan's fragile economic recovery, with exports to the US plummeting 11.1% and those to China down 8.8%. The Bank of Japan kept interest rates steady and slowed its balance sheet drawdown, citing concerns about the tariff impact. The US has imposed 25% tariffs on Japan's autos, with a 24% reciprocal tariff set to start July 9 unless a deal is reached.

images.alt_text: Japan is struggling to reach a deal with Washington in tariff negotiations, clouding the outlook for its economy, which is heavily reliant on automobile shipments to the US.

site_title: Hoi Hup Realty clinches resolution to grant planning consent for London ‘High Holborn’ project
summary: Hoi Hup Realty has secured planning consent for its "High Holborn" project in London, a 0.6 hectare island site redevelopment. The project, spearheaded by Gleeds, will deliver over 370,000 sq ft of Grade A workspace, featuring a cultural venue, public pocket-park, and enhanced ground-floor amenities. The development aims for "Outstanding" sustainability ratings and will utilize smart systems and low-carbon materials. The project, assembled over four years, is expected to transform the Midtown location and is a significant investment for Hoi Hup Realty.

site_title: Thai baht, Taiwan dollar, and Korea won most at risk from oil price, Barclays says
summary: A surge in oil prices, particularly a 20% increase, is likely to trigger a depreciation in Asian currencies such as the Thai baht, Taiwan dollar, and Korean won. Sovereign bonds from Singapore and South Korea would be among the most affected, according to Barclays analysts. This risk is heightened by potential escalation in the conflict between Israel and Iran, which could disrupt global oil flows.

site_title: Airbus strikes deal for up to 150 planes with VietJet
summary: Airbus has struck a deal with Vietnamese budget airline VietJet to sell up to 150 single-aisle A321neo planes, with an option for 50 more. The agreement, valued at around $9.4 billion, is set to be delivered from 2030 onwards. VietJet chairwoman Nguyen Thi Phuong Thao said the deal represents a vital step in the airline's growth strategy as a multi-national aviation group. Airbus is the main supplier of jets to Vietnam, accounting for 86% of the planes currently operated by Vietnamese airlines.
