site_title: Pop Mart’s 200% stock rally spurs rush to hike price targets
summary: Pop Mart International Group shares surged 3.5% on Friday, setting a fresh record close, as analysts raised price targets by up to 90% due to the success of its Labubu dolls. The company's intellectual properties are gaining global influence, with sales of its toothy monster dolls generating over $537 million last year. Despite valuations being above peers, some analysts believe shares can continue to rise, driven by the company's strong performance on the MSCI China Index, which it is the best performer on this year.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People look at collectable designer art toy Labubu at a Pop Mart pop-up store in Siam Center shopping mall in Bangkok on May 6, 2025. On June 10, a teal sculpture depicting a Labubu character with a furry body and head fetched an eye-watering 1.08 million yuan ($150,260) at an auction held in Beijing, according to the auction house's app. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

Starting from a pop grocery store since 2010, Pop Mart successfully transformed from a toy retailer to an IP-centric platform, shifting from product sales to IP development and diversified operations.
The fervour for Pop Mart’s toys has turned it into a global phenomenon, with fans sometimes queueing for hours outside stores for new releases.
The performance of Labubu was “particularly impressive,” as sales of ‘The Monsters’ dolls rose to 3 billion yuan in 2024 compared to 368 million yuan before.

site_title: Singapore, Indonesia sign three MOUs for energy trade, decarbonisation, sustainability collaboration
summary: Singapore and Indonesia signed three memorandums of understanding (MOUs) to enhance energy trade, decarbonization, and sustainability collaboration. The agreements aim to facilitate clean energy transition, industrial decarbonization, and investments in sustainability-related activities. The MOUs cover cross-border electricity trade, carbon capture and storage, and a sustainable industrial zone in Bintan, Batam, and Karimun. The agreements reflect both countries' commitment to low-carbon and sustainability-focused initiatives, with a focus on creating win-win partnerships and generating investments.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Indonesia’s President Prabowo Subianto speaks during the launch of a new system for directly transferring allowances to regional public school teachers' bank accounts at the Primary and Secondary Education Ministry in Jakarta on March 13, 2025. (Photo by Yasuyoshi CHIBA / AFP)
Prabowo Subianto will visit Russia from June 18-20 to hold talks with Putin and attend an economic forum in Saint Petersburg.

site_title: Gold tops one-month high as Middle East tensions spur safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose to a one-month high on Friday, reaching US$3,428.28 an ounce, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid heightened Middle East tensions following Israel's strike on Iran. The metal has gained over 3.5% this week, with US gold futures up 1.4% to US$3,449.60. Analysts attribute the surge to investors' response to the escalation, with some predicting further upside if the tensions continue.

images.alt_text: The golden funerary mask of ancient Egyptian King Tutankhamun (1341-1323 BC) is displayed at the Tutankhamun gallery at the Egyptian Museum in Cairo's central Tahrir Square, Egypt, June 11, 2025.

site_title: Novo Nordisk overtakes SAP as Europe’s most valuable company
summary: Novo Nordisk has surpassed SAP as Europe's most valuable company, with a market capitalization of $365 billion. The Danish drugmaker's shares rose 2.3% after announcing plans to advance its experimental weight management treatment amycretin into late-stage development. This move comes after regulatory feedback and follows a series of setbacks for the company, including disappointing clinical trial results and competition from US rival Eli Lilly & Co.

site_title: Thai court to hear Thaksin hospitalisation case in July
summary: Thailand's Supreme Court will hear a case in July regarding the legitimacy of former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra's prolonged hospital stay in lieu of prison. The court will decide on the medical council's decision to punish three doctors who allowed Thaksin to avoid jail. Thaksin, 75, was initially sentenced to eight years in prison but was reduced to one year by the King. He was released on parole after six months in the hospital due to chest pains, sparking public outrage and questions over his ailment.

images.alt_text: Despite not holding any formal position, Thaksin Shinawatra (centre) has cast a long shadow over the government, through meetings with foreign leaders, campaigning in local elections and weighing in on policy.

site_title: Jetstar Asia shutdown: Income Insurance extends ‘goodwill’ coverage outside of ticket expenses
summary: Jetstar Asia, a Singapore-based budget airline, will cease operations by July 31 due to escalating operational costs and mounting competition. Affected customers can claim for unused and prepaid expenses, including accommodation, travel packages, and transport, through Income Insurance's goodwill coverage. Eligible customers with pre-trip cancellation cover can also receive a full refund within the policy limit if they fail to get a refund from service providers. The Consumers Association of Singapore is working with Jetstar Asia to clarify refund procedures and dispute resolution.

images.alt_text: Customers impacted by Jetstar Asia's shutdown will be offered alternative flights or full refunds.
Jetstar Asia is expected to post an underlying EBIT loss of A$35 million in the current financial year.

site_title: Millions of acres of public land sales slated for US tax Bill
summary: The US Senate has released a bill that would mandate the sale of around 1.2 million hectares of public land, including 3 million acres, to help pay for President Donald Trump's tax cuts and spending package. The land sales could raise up to $10 billion over 10 years, with the funds to be used for housing and economic development in western states. Environmental and conservation groups have criticized the plan, saying it would threaten wildlife and outdoor recreation access. The bill aligns with a Trump administration plan to identify areas of "underutilized" land for development.

images.alt_text: New York City renters who settle on apartments that have broker fees pay an average of nearly US$13,000 to secure the keys to a property.

site_title: UK hiring slows again in May but downturn might be easing, recruiters say
summary: British businesses hired staff at a slower pace in May, with demand for staff falling for an eighth consecutive month. However, recruiters report some signs that the downturn is beginning to bottom out, with spending on temporary staff increasing. The unemployment rate rose to 4.6% in April, the highest in nearly four years. Despite this, starting salaries for permanent staff rose at the quickest pace since August 2024, and wages for temporary staff increased by the most in a year. The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold next week, citing developments in the labour market.

images.alt_text: Thursday’s survey chimed with other measures of Britain’s property sector that have pointed to a slowdown, and Bank of England data which showed mortgage approvals dropped to their lowest in more than a year in April.

Rachel Reeves outside 11 Downing Street ahead of the presentation of the spending review in London. The chancellor’s choices will impact the quality of public services and voter perceptions through to the next general election in 2029.
Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves  will seek to depict the United Kingdom as a safe haven, as the global economy grapples with uncertainty around US trade policies.

site_title: Indonesia plans to start building US$80-billion giant sea wall
summary: Indonesia plans to build a $80 billion sea wall along Java island, spanning 500 kilometers, to prevent flooding and coastal erosion. The 20-year project, starting under President Prabowo Subianto, aims to protect cities from floods and land subsidence. However, experts raise concerns about the potential economic harm to fishermen and local communities, as well as the disruption to the marine ecosystem. The project's scale and cost also raise questions about Indonesia's ability to execute it, particularly with other costly initiatives planned during Prabowo's presidency.

images.alt_text: The money freed up for Prabowo’s signature programmes – including free school meals and public housing – remained largely unspent with programmes still in their infancy.

site_title: Oil settles lower as traders gauge Middle East tensions
summary: Oil prices settled lower on Thursday, with Brent crude futures down 41 cents to $69.36 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude down 11 cents to $67.97 a barrel. Traders booked profits after a 4% rally driven by concerns over worsening Middle East tensions. US President Trump said an Israeli strike on Iran "could very well happen" but prefers to avoid conflict. Rising tensions have oil traders worried about possible supply disruptions, particularly if the Strait of Hormuz is blocked.

images.alt_text: A drone view of a pump jack and drilling rig south of Midland, Texas, U.S. June 11, 2025. REUTERS/Eli Hartman
Brent crude futures settled US$2.90, or 4.34 per cent, higher to US$69.77 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate crude gained US$3.17, or 4.88 per cent, to US$68.15 on Thursday.

site_title: India battles container ship fire with ‘hazardous’ cargo
summary: India's coast guard is battling to extinguish fires on a container ship, MV Wan Hai 503, carrying 22 crew members and "hazardous" cargo off the southern coast. The 268-metre Singapore-flagged vessel caught fire on June 9, with four crew missing. Eighteen crew members were rescued, while seven vessels, including coast guard vessels and airplanes, are engaged in firefighting efforts. The situation remains critical, with the fire still active in the inner decks and near fuel tanks, posing a risk to the marine environment and regional shipping routes.

site_title: The Gangnam lifestyle eludes poor South Koreans living in shanties
summary: South Korea's affluent Gangnam district is home to a stark contrast of poverty, with over 2,400 people living in shanty village Guryong, built in the 1980s to accommodate workers displaced by Olympic development projects. The village is made from makeshift materials such as plywood, metal, and cardboard boxes. Rising social inequality and economic struggles continue to affect the poorer sections of society, with 327,000 poor households living in basements prone to flooding, mostly in Seoul and surrounding areas. The legacy of the country's military dictatorship also hinders efforts to address these issues.

images.alt_text: President Lee Jae-myung said “the most pressing matter is trade negotiations with the United States.”
(From left) Democratic Party presidential candidate Lee Jae Myung  and his wife Kim Hye Gyeong celebrate at the party's headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, June 4, 2025.

site_title: AMD unveils AI server as OpenAI taps its newest chips
summary: AMD unveiled its new AI server, "Helios," which will compete with Nvidia's flagship offerings. The Helios server features 72 of AMD's MI400 series chips, comparable to Nvidia's NVL72 servers. AMD's CEO Lisa Su emphasized the importance of open collaboration in AI development, and the company plans to make many aspects of the Helios servers openly available. OpenAI's CEO Sam Altman also announced that the company will adopt AMD's MI450 chips to improve their design for AI work. The move is seen as a direct challenge to Nvidia's dominance in the AI chip market.

images.alt_text: Barbie doll maker Mattel is not licensing its intellectual property to OpenAI as part of the deal and remains in full control of the products being created.
Besides Vietnam, Qualcomm operates R&D centres in Ireland and India, which are among its largest outside the US

The optimistic forecast from AMD could help reinforce investor confidence in its ability to compete against Nvidia.

site_title: Middle East tensions hit Asian and Asean markets; oil and gold prices spike
summary: Middle East tensions led to a surge in Asian and Asean markets, with oil and gold prices spiking. Israel launched strikes on Iran's nuclear and military infrastructure, causing investor confidence to wane. Markets in Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, Indonesia, Japan, and South Korea fell, with the Nikkei 225 index declining 0.9% and the Kospi dropping 0.9%. Oil prices rose 13% to a peak of US$78.50, while gold prices jumped 1.3% to US$3,422 per ounce.

site_title: Trump tells Iran to make deal after Israel blasts nuclear and military targets
summary: Israel launched a barrage of strikes on Iran, killing at least 20 senior commanders and 6 nuclear scientists, including the heads of Iran's armed forces and Revolutionary Guards. US President Donald Trump suggested Iran brought the attack on itself by resisting a US ultimatum to restrict its nuclear program. Iran promised a harsh response, and Israel said about 100 drones were intercepted. The strikes damaged Iran's main nuclear enrichment facility at Natanz and may be a prolonged operation to prevent Iran from developing an atomic weapon.

images.alt_text: The empty departures hall at Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport on Jun 13. The airport has been closed until further notice.
Brent crude futures settled down 41 cents, or 0.6 per cent, at US$69.36 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Home-grown and high-end: Malaysia’s smart farms rewrite the food map
summary: Malaysia's smart farms are revolutionizing the country's food industry by cultivating luxury crops such as Japanese Arus muskmelons and high-quality vanilla. Powered by technology and controlled environments, these farms are producing premium produce at more accessible prices. MeMe Farm in Selangor is one of the pioneers, harvesting 500 kg of vanilla beans per month and selling fermented beans for RM1,300 per kg. The farm is partnering with the Selangor state government to develop an agritourism destination, aiming to establish Malaysia as a premium vanilla producer. Meanwhile, Mono Premium Melon in Serdang is also leveraging smart farming techniques to cultivate premium melons, with a focus on quality control and traceability.

Vietnam and the Trump administration have been holding negotiations on a trade agreement, with Vietnam pledging to allow more US imports to narrow the trade gap between the two countries.
Philippines is facing a 17 per cent duty on its goods to the US, the lowest rate in South-east Asia – after Singapore – under US President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariff agenda.

site_title: Temasek joins Microsoft, BlackRock and MGX to develop AI infrastructure
summary: Temasek Holdings has joined a consortium backed by Microsoft, BlackRock, and MGX to invest in artificial intelligence infrastructure through the AI Infrastructure Partnership (AIP), a US$30 billion+ initiative focused on data centers and energy facilities. Temasek's participation comes after the Kuwait Investment Authority joined earlier in June, and AIP aims to mobilize up to US$100 billion for such investments in the US.

site_title: New York real estate industry appeals broker-fee case ruling
summary: The US Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has allowed New York City to enforce a law requiring landlords to pay fees for hiring listing brokers, rather than tenants. The City Council adopted the measure in November to end the practice of tenants paying broker fees. Real estate groups have challenged the law, arguing it interferes with exclusive agreements between landlords and brokers, and that it violates free-speech rights. The industry has filed an appeal after a federal judge denied their request to pause the law.

images.alt_text: New York City renters who settle on apartments that have broker fees pay an average of nearly US$13,000 to secure the keys to a property.

site_title: Investor rush for India exposure revs up block deals, IPOs
summary: India's share market has seen a surge in investor interest, raising US$6.4 billion in May, the highest monthly total since December 2024, according to Bloomberg. Block trades worth US$5 billion were the biggest contributors, and the momentum has carried into June. The central bank's interest rate cut and injection of liquidity into the banking system have supported a rally in Indian stocks, with the benchmark NSE Nifty 50 Index rebounding from its April lows. Investors are seeking exposure to India, with block trades remaining the quickest and most efficient way to get that exposure, and IPOs also moving ahead with tamer valuations.

site_title: US: Stocks close higher as bond yields retreat
summary: US stocks finished higher on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.2% to 42,967.62. The S&P 500 gained 0.4% to 6,045.26, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.2% to 19,662.49. Despite concerns over President Trump's trade rhetoric, a retreat in US Treasury yields helped boost markets. Boeing dropped 4.9% after an Air India crash, while Oracle surged 13.3% following an upbeat earnings report.

images.alt_text: A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on April 11, 2025, in New York City. Minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average slumped 0.3 percent and the S&P 500 lost 0.2 percent. But the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index was up 0.2 percent in a volatile morning. site_title: New Zealand manufacturing contracts in May amid economic uncertainties
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing activity contracted in May due to weak demand, rising costs, and low business confidence amid global economic uncertainties. The Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) fell to 47.5, down from 53.3 in April. New orders also declined to 45.3, a drop from 50.8 in the prior month. The contraction marks the first decline in four months, with economists warning that the New Zealand economy may face a slowdown in 2025.

site_title: Here’s why Trump’s tariffs won’t work
summary: Two new books, "Exile Economics" by Ben Chu and "Peak Human" by Johan Norberg, argue that narrow self-interest, or a focus on national security through self-sufficiency, ultimately leads to a country's downfall. The authors contend that exchange and openness, rather than isolationism, are key to building empires and achieving prosperity. They warn that the current anti-globalization sentiment threatens to undo decades of progress, and that the solution lies in reform, not retreat. The books highlight the risks of resource nationalism and the importance of interdependence in maintaining global stability.

A bank employee poses with USD 100 notes in Taipei on May 6, 2025. The dollar rose in Asia on May 6 fuelled by hopes for trade deals to avert Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs, while equities mostly rose as investors await the Federal Reserve's latest policy decision. (Photo by I-HWA CHENG / AFP)

site_title: BlackRock aims to grow revenue to US$35 billion and more by 2030
summary: BlackRock aims to increase revenue to $35 billion and more by 2030, with private markets and technology businesses expected to make up 30% or more of total revenue. The asset manager, which oversees $11.58 trillion, is also targeting a $280 billion market capitalization and $400 billion in cumulative fundraising in private markets by 2030. This growth is driven by the expansion of its private markets and technology businesses, following a series of acquisitions and investments in 2024.

site_title: Myanmar recovery dented by devastating quake, World Bank says
summary: Myanmar's economy is expected to contract 2.5% in 2025-2026 due to the devastating earthquake, which caused $11 billion in damage and displaced 207,000 people. The World Bank estimates the earthquake's impact will dent economic output by 4% of GDP in the fiscal year ending March 2026, exacerbating existing challenges such as a civil war, inflation, and a shortage of US dollars. Recovery efforts will be crucial to help the most vulnerable populations, according to the World Bank.

site_title: OCBC users hit by log-in, payment issues; services restored by 2.30 pm
summary: OCBC customers experienced difficulties logging in and making payments via the bank's mobile app and Internet banking services on Friday afternoon, with over 1,000 outage reports lodged on Downdetector. The issue affected mobile app functionality, including displaying account balances, and caused some PayNow transfers to fail, only to be processed later. Services were restored by 2:30 pm. This is the second digital service disruption involving a local bank in two weeks, following a similar issue with DBS and POSB customers on June 2.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Middle East tensions rise
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday as Middle East tensions rose, with the Dow Jones falling 128.4 points, or 0.30%, to 42,737.36. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 12.3 points, or 0.20%, to 6,009.9, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 37.0 points, or 0.19%, to 19,578.874. Investors sought more clarity on US trade deals with China amid rising tensions.

site_title: ‘I got up and ran’: How one man survived the Air India crash that killed 241
summary: A British man, Ramesh Vishwaskumar, survived the Air India crash near Ahmedabad Airport in India that killed 241 people. He was seated in the first row of economy class, just behind an emergency exit, and managed to escape the plane after it crashed. Vishwaskumar, 40, was injured but alive, and his survival is considered a miracle. The cause of the crash remains unknown, but investigators are reviewing the wreckage and data recorders to determine the cause. Vishwaskumar's survival may provide valuable clues to the accident.

site_title: SIA Group to ramp up flights post-Jetstar Asia exit; Scoot to take over Okinawa, Labuan Bajo routes
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its budget arm Scoot will increase flights to Asian destinations after Jetstar Asia ceases operations on July 31. Scoot will launch new flights to Okinawa and Labuan Bajo, while SIA will adjust its schedule and network to fill the gap. Scoot plans to increase flights to Bangkok, Penang, and Singapore-Manila, while SIA will add flights to Colombo, Jakarta, and Phuket. The move aims to support air travel demand in the region and comes after Jetstar Asia cited rising costs and competition as reasons for its closure.

images.alt_text: Customers impacted by Jetstar Asia's shutdown will be offered alternative flights or full refunds.

The confirmed-list sites will yield around 9,200 units, while the reserve-list sites will offer 4,475 units, a 29% increase from the first half. This brings the total pipeline supply of private housing units to about 56,700 units. The government aims to meet medium-term housing needs and has a robust pipeline of private residential units, including 2,000 EC units in the H2 confirmed list.

site_title: Damage is done: China exports to US in May see biggest drop since Covid as trade flows reroute to Asean
summary: China's exports to the US in May dropped 34.4% to $28.8 billion, the largest decline since the COVID-19 pandemic began in 2020. This is due to Beijing rerouting trade flows to Southeast Asia, where exports increased 4.8% to $316.1 billion. Meanwhile, Chinese imports from the US fell 17.9% to $10.8 billion. China's soybean purchases from the US surged to a record level in May, with 13.9 million tonnes worth $6.1 billion, as Beijing uses this as bargaining power amid trade talks.

site_title: Do world fairs still matter?
summary: The 2025 Osaka World Expo, the largest in the world, has opened with a record 3.91 million foreign visitors in April, a 28.5% increase year-over-year. The expo, which has an estimated US$66 billion price tag, features 158 national pavilions designed to showcase "Designing Future Society for Our Lives" as its theme. According to a World Expo historian, the modern expos lack the grandeur and impact of their predecessors, with many people recalling attending one in their childhood.

site_title: Global EV sales rise in May as China hits 2025 peak: Rho Motion
summary: Global electric vehicle sales rose 24% in May, driven by strong demand in China, which surpassed 1 million units for the first time this year. China's exports, particularly to Mexico and South-east Asia, boosted sales. European sales increased due to fleet incentives, while North American demand slowed due to US tariff uncertainty. US automakers have withdrawn their 2025 sales outlooks due to the 25% import tariff. Tax credits for EVs in the US will phase out from 2026, contributing to hesitation among buyers.

site_title: Cooked in Singapore: home-grown chefs’ struggle for success
summary: Singaporean chefs struggle to gain recognition and success in the local dining scene, despite the city's international culinary status. Foreign-born chefs dominate the industry, and local talent faces bias and skepticism from investors and diners. Many local chefs must prove themselves harder to gain backing for their ideas, and there is a stigma surrounding paying a premium for "mod-Sin" (elevated hawker food). However, some success stories, such as Nicolas Tam's one-Michelin-starred restaurant Willow, and chefs like Law Jia-Jun and Ng Guo Lun, show that local talent can thrive with perseverance and innovation. Efforts to promote local cuisine and support local chefs are underway, but the industry's uncertain climate and high costs continue to pose challenges.

site_title: Air India Dreamliner crashes into Ahmedabad college hostel, kills over 240
summary: An Air India Boeing 787-8 Dreamliner crashed into a medical college hostel in Ahmedabad, India, shortly after taking off, killing over 240 people. The only known survivor, a British national of Indian origin, was in seat 11A next to an emergency exit. The cause of the crash is under investigation, with one problematic sign being the plane's landing gear being down during a phase of flight when it typically should be up. The incident is the world's worst aviation disaster in a decade, and it marks India's first fatal plane crash since 2020.

Air India’s growth is also set to slow because of a retrofit programme that will temporarily remove some jets from its fleet, and a plan to phase out some Airbus models.
India is the third-largest domestic aviation market in the world after the US and China, and it is also the fastest-growing market, with IndiGo and Air India the top two airlines.

site_title: AI bias by design
summary: A leaked system prompt from Anthropic's Claude large language model (LLM) reveals how AI tools can reinforce cognitive and structural biases in investment analysis. The prompt, which spans 22,600 words, aims to deliver a consistent user experience but biases the model toward safe, consensus views and user affirmation. Four amplified cognitive biases (confirmation bias, anchoring bias, availability heuristic, and fluency bias) are embedded in the prompt, introducing risks such as mistaken terminology, flawed assumptions, and the over-trust of weakly grounded inferences. To mitigate these biases, alternative prompts are proposed, highlighting the need for investment leaders to fully address the challenges accompanying AI integration.

site_title: MAS order prompts unlicensed crypto exchanges to plan exit
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set a deadline of June 30 for unlicensed crypto exchanges to cease activities, refusing to allow transition time. summary: China has extended its 240-hour transit visa-free policy to 55 countries, including Indonesia, Russia, and Britain, allowing tourists and business travelers to engage in activities during their stay. The policy change, effective Thursday, aims to boost tourism and trade.

site_title: Mattel taps OpenAI to help it design toys, other products
summary: Mattel, the maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars, has signed a deal with OpenAI to use its artificial intelligence tools to design and create toys and other products based on its brands. The collaboration is at an early stage, with the first release expected later this year. site_title: King Tut gold mask to leave Cairo museum after nearly 100 years
summary: The golden funerary mask of King Tutankhamun is set to leave the Egyptian Museum in Cairo after nearly 100 years, moving to the new Grand Egyptian Museum near the Giza Pyramids. The mask, along with over 5,000 artefacts, will be relocated on July 3. The museum's director confirmed that 26 objects, including the mask and two coffins, will remain on display until the transfer, but no official date has been announced. The move is part of a US$1-billion megaproject to house over 100,000 artefacts, including treasures from King Tut's tomb, in a state-of-the-art facility.

site_title: Asia: Shares stumble after Trump’s latest trade threat
summary: Asian markets plummeted on Thursday, reversing a recent rally fueled by a US-China trade deal framework, after US President Donald Trump announced he would impose unilateral tariffs on partners in two weeks, reigniting trade war fears. The news sparked concerns about a regional conflict in the Middle East and Iran's nuclear talks, leading to losses in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other markets. site_title: 🤹 Want their jobs? These are the skills they say you need

Key skills mentioned include advanced data analytics, digital agility, human fluency, growth mindset, and adaptability. Many experts recommend courses in data manipulation, statistical analysis, and soft skills such as empathy and active listening. The SkillsFuture Credit scheme for individuals already makes some differentiation for groups such as older workers. This could be extended to other vulnerable groups too.

site_title: DBS raises target price for Sheng Siong on steady earnings growth, margin superiority
summary: DBS Research raised its target price for Sheng Siong to S$2.30 from S$2, citing strong earnings growth and resilient margins despite a volatile macroeconomic environment. Analysts attribute the supermarket operator's industry-leading margins to its no-frills, disciplined investment approach and lean cost structure. Sheng Siong's projected store network expansion is expected to drive earnings growth, with the brokerage maintaining a "buy" rating and 25% upside potential.

images.alt_text: Sheng Siong's net profit rose 6.1 per cent to S$38.5 million in the first quarter ended Mar 31.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 12)
summary: Lower prices of 1-13% year-over-year followed corrections in Asia-Pacific markets in 2024. Steel rebar prices are expected to fall 13% in Q2, while new tariffs may disrupt global supply chains. Grab raised US$1.5 billion through convertible notes for general corporate purchases and possible acquisitions. Sembcorp's renewables unit won a 50MW round-the-clock power project in India, increasing its capacity to over 6.5 GW. Singapore ranked the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year, with FedEx partnering a startup to deploy robots for deliveries.

images.alt_text: Jetstar Asia is expected to post an underlying EBIT loss of A$35 million in the current financial year.

site_title: Boustead Singapore reviews assets for potential sale to Reit for listing
summary: Boustead Singapore is conducting a strategic review to sell its stake in logistics and industrial real estate assets to a real estate investment trust (Reit) for listing on the Singapore Exchange. The review is part of the company's "ordinary course of business" to unlock shareholder value. However, Boustead notes that there is no certainty that any transaction will materialise as a result of this process.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

site_title: Deutsche Bank's deal-making business weaker than expected, CEO says
summary: Deutsche Bank's origination and advisory business fell 8% in the first quarter, weaker than expected due to US tariff policies delaying deal-making. CEO Christian Sewing said deals won't be cancelled, but rather postponed, and revenue in the fixed-income and currency business is expected to rise. Despite this, Sewing remains optimistic about the bank's other business lines and sticking to its cost and profitability targets.

images.alt_text: A Deutsche Bank AG bank branch in Berlin, Germany, on Wednesday, July 24, 2024. Deutsche Bank AG said it will most likely refrain from conducting a second share buyback this year, after suffering its first quarterly loss in four years. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
Deutsche Bank, Germany’s largest lender, recorded net profit attributable to shareholders of 1.78 billion euros (S$2.66 billion) in the quarter, up from 1.28 billion euros a year earlier.

site_title: Protests spread across US despite Trump threats
summary: Protests against President Trump's hardline immigration tactics spread across the US, with demonstrations reported in over a dozen cities, including Los Angeles, Spokane, and several Democratic-run states. Despite Trump's threat to deploy the National Guard, protesters remained peaceful, with some calling the deployment a "crass political stunt." The deployment, which cost taxpayers $134 million, has been met with resistance from California Governor Gavin Newsom, who claims it's an attempt to escalate the confrontation for political gain.

images.alt_text: Police arrested 25 people on suspicion of violating the curfew as of Tuesday evening.

site_title: Europe: Shares drop as trade optimism wanes, geopolitical tensions rise
summary: European stocks declined for the fourth consecutive day as trade optimism waned and geopolitical tensions rose, with the Stoxx 600 closing 0.33% lower at 549.84. The decline was driven by the lack of clarity surrounding global trade policy, particularly between the US and EU, despite recent talks with China. Geopolitical worries fueled market caution, with rising tensions with Iran and the Middle East. Energy stocks rose, led by utilities, while travel and leisure sectors declined.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.2 per cent at 42,967.62 on Thursday.

site_title: Gold prices climb as Middle East tensions rise, US inflation eases
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $3,364.10 an ounce as Middle East tensions boosted demand for safe-haven assets, while US inflation data showed a 0.1% increase, below expectations, sparking calls for a potential interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The US dollar index edged lower, making gold cheaper for overseas buyers. Investors sought safe-haven assets amid rising geopolitical uncertainty, with traders expecting a 50-basis-point rate cut by year-end.

images.alt_text: Spot gold rose 0.2 per cent to US$3,328.89 an ounce, as of 0153 GMT. US gold futures were up 0.2 per cent to US$3,349.80.

site_title: UK economy shrinks by the most in nearly two years
summary: The UK economy contracted by 0.3% in April, the largest monthly drop since October 2023, due to shockwaves from US President Donald Trump's tariff announcement. Despite expanding by 0.7% in the first quarter, the economy's growth is being impacted by declining exports and activity in sectors such as real estate and car manufacturing. The Bank of England has revised down its growth forecast for 2026 to 1.25%, citing the expected impact of tariffs on British output.

images.alt_text: Private-sector wage growth – the measure watched most closely by the Bank of England – slowed to 5.1 per cent from 5.5 per cent.

site_title: Last call: Holland Village mainstay Wala Wala seeks to exit lease, plans to close
summary: Wala Wala Cafe Bar, a 30-year-old indie nightspot in Singapore's Holland Village, is set to close due to financial struggles. The restaurant-bar has been operating at a loss for four years, with declining sales and rising business costs. Owner Stanley Yeo plans to exit his lease and find a new tenant, with the last day of operations potentially in late August. This marks the end of a three-decade chapter for the beloved nightlife stalwart.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Rents in prime malls along Orchard remain supported by the limited availability of space in the shopping district.
Holland Village is full of buzz and is pet-friendly, thanks mainly to the new One Holland Village development. But the area has lost its quirky mix of shops.
With dwindling foot traffic, Holland Village businesses are struggling to stay afloat.

site_title: Manhattan renters already paying record prices face more hikes
summary: Manhattan renters face increased pressure as demand surges with expiring leases and students entering the city. The median rent on new leases signed in May reached $4,571, a record high, exceeding the previous peak by $71. With the Fairness in Apartment Rental Expenses Act banning broker fees, landlords are expected to raise prices further. This follows a competitive market where nearly 24% of new leases were signed after multiple offers, and inventory increased 31% from last year in Manhattan.

images.alt_text: Renter demand remains high and very few new units are under construction across the city, especially in Manhattan.

site_title: UK surveyors report weakest house price growth in nearly a year: RICS survey
summary: Britain's housing market lost momentum last month, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' house price balance dropping to -8 in May, its weakest since July 2024. The survey attributed the decline to increased property transaction taxes and concerns about global trade tensions. Mortgage approvals also dropped to their lowest in over a year in April, according to Bank of England data. Economists expect a gradual recovery in sales activity, but the pace and extent depend on interest rate cuts from the BOE.

images.alt_text: Priory Court in Dover. The acquisition of three government-leased assets will enhance tenant diversification and strengthen the stability of Elite UK Reit's portfolio, said Joshua Liaw, chief executive of the Reit's manager
Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves  will seek to depict the United Kingdom as a safe haven, as the global economy grapples with uncertainty around US trade policies.
The country attracted foreign investment for 73 finance projects last year, down by 32 per cent on the prior year.

site_title: Sembcorp’s renewables unit wins 50MW round-the-clock power project from Indian public-sector company
summary: Sembcorp's renewables unit, Sembcorp Green Infra, has won a 50MW round-the-clock power project from Solar Energy Corporation of India. The project, valued at around 300MW, will be integrated with solar and wind energy, battery energy storage solutions, and will supply renewable power to SECI. The project is expected to be completed within 24 months and will expand Sembcorp's renewables capacity in India to over 6.5GW, bringing its global renewables portfolio to 18GW.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
The Philippines and Indonesia face the highest natural disaster risks in the world, based on the World Risk Index.

site_title: China likely to ditch low-grade coal from Indonesia due to glut
summary: China is likely to cut imports of low-grade coal from Indonesia due to a glut in the market, with imports falling for a third straight month in May. The decline is expected to accelerate over the rest of 2025, weighing heavily on Indonesian suppliers. China's benchmark coal price has slumped to a four-year low, driven by record domestic production and a decrease in power demand. The government's tighter emission controls will further reduce demand for low-quality coal, marking progress in reducing emissions to meet climate goals.

images.alt_text: Papuans hold placards reading "revoke all nickel mining permits in Raja Ampat immediately" during a protest march to the Southwest Papua Governor’s office in Sorong on June 10, 2025. Indonesia revoked permits on June 10 for four of the five mining companies operating in the eastern archipelago of Raja Ampat after activists shared videos of islands damaged by nickel extraction. (Photo by AWAKIRAYA / AFP)
Excavators unloading coal from rail cars into a coal storage facility in Shandong province. Coal accounts for more than half of the electricity generated in China.
Indonesia plans to add 6 GW of coal-fired power capacity over the next nine years.

site_title: Eating out loses its shine; some listed F&B players are in the red on wilting demand, high costs
summary: Listed food and beverage operators in Singapore are struggling due to declining demand, high costs, and uncertain economic outlook. Mid-market operators like Tung Lok Restaurants and Japan Foods Holding (JFH) cited subdued economic conditions and geopolitical tensions as reasons for their poorer performance. Rising costs, falling outlet numbers, and consumers' shift towards value-for-money meals and brand-agnosticism are major challenges. Analysts predict that growth by independent food services will surpass that of chain operators in 2025, and investors should focus on operators serving affordable or essential offerings.

images.alt_text: Rents in prime malls along Orchard remain supported by the limited availability of space in the shopping district.
SGX Centre during lunch hour, with office workers walking by.

site_title: Greenback fades as Singapore dollar, ringgit, baht shine in Asean foreign exchange shift
summary: The US dollar is losing charm among Asean investors and corporates, contributing to a trend of 'de-dollarisation' in global markets. Despite US-China trade agreement talks, market uncertainty persists, with implied volatility returning to pre-Liberation Day levels. Regional currencies, such as the Singapore dollar, ringgit, and baht, are strengthening, while US dollar outflows accelerate amid ongoing tariff tensions. This shift reflects investors' decreased confidence in the greenback, driven by policy reversals and uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Evan See
Thailand, the second-largest exporter of rice, is among the most vulnerable across the region to sharp currency spikes, which will hurt its exports over time.

Movements in the broad US dollar and yuan have for some time now been critical in determining Asian foreign exchange moves, MUFG Bank’s senior currency analyst Michael Wan noted that even more domestic-oriented economies, such as Indonesia, are increasingly responding more to the yuan
The US dollar has long anchored the global monetary system. Now its advantages, including US economic power and deep and liquid capital markets, are no longer absolute.

site_title: Grab prices and increases convertible notes offering to US$1.5 billion
summary: Grab has upsized its five-year convertible note offering to US$1.5 billion, with proceeds to be used for general corporate purchases, share repurchases, and possible acquisitions. The notes will be listed on the Singapore Exchange, marking the largest equity-linked offering. Grab plans to repurchase Class A ordinary shares worth US$273.5 million at a price of US$4.68 per share, under its US$500 million share buyback program. The conversion rate is subject to adjustment and may be redeemed if certain conditions are met.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Exterior facade of the building housing sovereign wealth fund, known as Daya Anagata Nusantara or Danantara, in Jakarta on February 24, 2025, which was earlier launched by Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto. Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto on February 24, 2025 launched a new sovereign wealth fund set to be the biggest in Southeast Asia's largest economy and give the ex-general greater control of the country's coffers. He wants to tap into the fund's assets -- planned to be more than $900 billion -- to boost Indonesia to developed economy status, despite expert concern about its governance. (Photo by Bay ISMOYO / AFP)
Danantara is said to be interested in participating in the Grab acquisition of GoTo reported Bloomberg.

site_title: Ant unit to seek stablecoin permits in Hong Kong, Singapore: sources
summary: Singapore-based Ant International, backed by Jack Ma, plans to apply for stablecoin licenses in Hong Kong and Luxembourg as soon as the cities' Stablecoins Ordinance and regulatory framework go into effect in August. The move aims to bolster the fintech firm's blockchain operation, which processes over $1 trillion of global transactions annually. Ant International's stablecoin issuance is seen as a strategic step to expand its cross-border payment and treasury management services, with the potential for an IPO valuation of $8-24 billion.

site_title: Airbus revises up 20-year jet demand forecast despite trade tensions
summary: Airbus has revised up its 20-year demand forecast for commercial jets, expecting 43,420 planes to be delivered between 2025 and 2044, a 2% increase from its previous forecast. The forecast includes 42,450 passenger jets and 970 freighters, despite trade tensions and tariffs imposed by the US. Airbus attributes the revised forecast to the industry's resilience to shocks and growing demand for single-aisle planes and long-haul jets.

site_title: Thai panel upholds suspension of doctors who helped ex-PM Thaksin dodge jail
summary: Thailand's medical council upheld the suspension of two doctors who helped ex-PM Thaksin Shinawatra avoid jail by staying in a hospital for six months, despite public outrage. The decision came ahead of a Supreme Court case that could see Thaksin jailed for abuse of power. Thaksin, who is still influential despite not holding a formal government role, was granted parole without serving his full sentence due to health concerns. The decision has added to the challenges faced by the current government, which is struggling with a border dispute with Cambodia and economic woes.

site_title: Harvard crackdown: Can Singapore become its own intellectual leader?
summary: US President Donald Trump's crusade against top American universities, including Harvard, threatens to erode the country's intellectual leadership and global scientific prowess. This could have far-reaching consequences, including a brain drain and potential curtailment of research capabilities. Singapore, which has benefited from the return of US-trained scholars, may reconsider its reliance on the US for intellectual leadership and instead look to Europe, China, and its own universities to build its own intellectual capacity.

Some of the grants paid for military-specific medical research, studies on countering weapons of mass destruction and research on lasers, among numerous other topics, Reuters found.

site_title: Tariff tensions cloud global property outlook, but Apac a bright spot amid uncertainty
summary: The Asia-Pacific region remains a promising investment landscape despite global uncertainty, driven by long-term demographic and structural trends. Real estate values have corrected by 16% since 2022, reducing risk and positioning the market for recovery. Key sectors with potential include living, logistics, and healthcare, particularly in countries like Australia, Japan, and South Korea. Experts predict a bright future for data centers, which are trading at a discount, and the office sector, with low vacancies and limited new supply. Non-traditional real estate debt investment is also gaining traction.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Foreigners are returning to the stock market, helping to push the benchmark Kospi Index into a bull market on Lee Jae-myung’s first day in office.

site_title: Tencent said to study deal for US$15 billion game developer Nexon
summary: Tencent Holdings is studying a potential $15 billion deal to acquire South Korean game developer Nexon, according to people familiar with the matter. The Chinese internet giant has reached out to Nexon's late founder Kim Jung-ju's family to discuss the acquisition, which would bolster Tencent's gaming operations. Nexon's shares have climbed over 10% this year, giving the company a market value of around $15 billion, and the company has explored a sale of its Nexon stake in the past, but a deal has yet to materialize.

images.alt_text: The move comes as China is widely expected to lift its nearly decade-old unofficial ban on K-pop performances in mainland China.

site_title: China stocks soar on AI, trade hopes. Which are the country’s ‘Terrific 10’ firms?
summary: Chinese stocks have surged, driven by optimism over artificial intelligence, strong earnings, and expected stimulus. The "Terrific 10" firms, including Alibaba, Tencent, and BYD, have seen significant gains, with Tencent's share price rising 24% since the beginning of the year. This reversal comes after a lengthy bear market, with investors shifting their focus to Chinese equities amid US market volatility. Analysts attribute the resurgence to the potential for China to end deflationary price wars and the growing importance of AI in the country's economy.

Alibaba has been releasing AI products at a frenetic pace since going all-in on the technology this year.
Confronting persistent housing woes and deflationary pressures, Chinese policymakers unveiled a central bank-led stimulus blitz in late September.

site_title: Apac data centre boom straining power grids; reliability key to site selection: report
summary: A report by construction consultancy Linesight found that the Asia-Pacific region's growing demand for energy-intensive sectors such as data centres, semiconductor manufacturing, and pharmaceutical production is straining power grids, threatening reliability and increasing costs. Reliable electricity supply is now a key factor in site selection for these facilities, with many countries investing in renewable energy and upgrading their power grids to meet this demand. The region is expected to account for half of the world's electricity consumption by 2025, with advanced economies such as Singapore, Japan, and Australia experiencing significant strain on their power grids.

site_title: US Treasury chief does not see himself replacing Fed chair
summary: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent stated he wishes to remain in his current position, despite being considered for the Federal Reserve chair. He expressed happiness with his role and plans to stay through 2029, citing "great progress" at Treasury. Trump is set to name a new Fed chair, with Powell's term ending in May 2026, and Bessent's comments come after a Bloomberg report suggested he was a contender for the position.

site_title: Nvidia marks Paris tech fair with Europe AI push
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang announced a major push into Europe at the Vivatech conference in Paris, aiming to increase AI computing capacity in the continent by a factor of 10 within two years. The company will partner with French AI champion Mistral AI, investing in a multi-billion-dollar cloud computing platform powered by 18,000 high-end chips. French President Emmanuel Macron hailed the partnership as a "historic" opportunity, calling for increased European sovereignty in AI development.

site_title: Thai consumer confidence hits 27-month low in May over US tariffs
summary: Thai consumer confidence hit a 27-month low in May, falling to 54.2 due to concerns over US tariffs and a sluggish economy. The country's consumer index, as measured by the University of the Thai Chamber of Commerce, dropped from 55.4 in the previous month. Thailand faces a 36% US tariff if negotiations fail, with estimated damage to the economy from lost exports and tourism revenues at around 150-200 billion baht. The country's state planning agency slashed its growth forecast range to 1.3-2.3% this year, warning of the impact of tariffs lasting for two years.

site_title: New World bondholders want more disclosure on financing plans
summary: New World Development, a Hong Kong-based builder, is facing pressure from bondholders over lack of financial disclosure as it works to complete an HK$87.5 billion loan refinancing deal. The company has less than three weeks to complete the deal before a covenant waiver expires. Debt advisers are urging noteholders to resist a potential liability management exercise, which could cut recovery ratios for unsecured bond investors. The company's perpetual bonds have lost 40% of their value over the past three months, and some bondholders have expressed frustration over the lack of communication with the company.

site_title: Meta taps top researchers from Google, Sesame for new AI lab
summary: Meta Platforms has recruited top engineers from Google and Sesame AI to form a new "superintelligence" team focused on achieving artificial general intelligence. The team, led by Jack Rae from Google DeepMind, aims to improve Meta's AI offerings, particularly Llama 4, and gain ground on rivals like Google and OpenAI. Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg is offering compensation packages worth tens of millions of dollars over several years to attract top talent. The move is part of an ambitious effort to bolster Meta's AI capabilities, with a multibillion-dollar investment in data labeling startup Scale AI also in the works.

site_title: The making of a Singaporean chef
summary: Singaporean chefs face a competitive dining landscape with restaurant closures and economic uncertainty, yet young chefs continue to enter the profession. Established veterans and up-and-coming talents share their experiences, highlighting the need to define themselves and bring more Singaporean chefs into the spotlight. The article explores the challenges and future prospects of this "thankless profession," showcasing the talents of local chefs and their unique contributions to the Singaporean culinary scene.

site_title: Trump willing to extend Jul 8 deadline for trade talks, but not likely necessary
summary: US President Donald Trump said he would extend a July 8 deadline for completing trade talks with about 15 countries, including South Korea, Japan, and the European Union, but believes it may not be necessary. Trade negotiations continue with dozens of other countries, and the US will send out letters outlining trade deal terms in one to two weeks. Trump's willingness to extend the deadline comes as US tariffs are set to take effect on July 8.

site_title: Toyota chairman re-elected against backdrop of US$33 billion buyout bid
summary: Toyota Motor shareholders re-elected Akio Toyoda as chairman with an estimated 96% of votes, despite criticism from overseas shareholders over the US$33 billion buyout bid of Toyota Industries. For the first year in three, Toyoda was not opposed by leading proxy advisory firms, which had previously flagged governance concerns. The acquisition, which will see Toyoda invest 1 billion yen, aims to spur restructuring of Japan's most powerful corporate group and deepen collaboration among group companies.

BYD's aggressive sales tactics in China have come under scrutiny as dealers there show the strain. Will the same happen in South-east Asia?
Singapore's sixth taxi operator will be launching its taxi services with 40 new fifth-generation electric hybrid Toyota Prius vehicles.

site_title: AI bets that fuelled Big Tech’s surge now threaten rich profits
summary: Big Tech companies like Alphabet, Amazon, Meta Platforms, and Microsoft are projected to spend $311 billion on capital expenses in their current fiscal years, with a 60% increase in the first quarter. Most of this money is going towards artificial intelligence computing, including semiconductors, servers, and networking equipment. However, this gear loses value quickly, potentially dragging down profits. Investors are questioning whether these investments will pay off, as companies face increased pressure to show bigger returns.
