Microsoft’s cloud revenue was up 20% compared with last year, much of the boost attributed to the Azure platform and AI use within that.

Apple will try to mitigate tariffs by shifting production of US-bound iPhones to India, but it is likely to keep price increases to a minimum to avoid losing market share and would have to stomach any elevated costs.
Due to tariffs, prices for Nvidia chips, which are mostly produced abroad, are set to rise for American customers, which may cool the firm’s red-hot growth.

site_title: SGX securities turnover rises 1% in May, volume down 18%
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) securities market turnover rose 1% in May to S$26.9 billion, supported by institutional hedging activity and demand for safe-haven and dividend-yielding stocks. However, the total market turnover volume dropped 18% to 22.3 billion shares. Derivatives trading increased 6% to 25.4 million contracts, while the Straits Times Index (STI) advanced 1.6% to 3,894.61. Market participants favored safe-haven and higher dividend-yielding stocks, with ETFs recording 22% year-on-year growth.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
Derivatives traded volume also increased 24 per cent to 29.9 million contracts on record foreign exchange (FX) futures activity.

site_title: Singapore needs to embrace Bitcoin to maintain status as financial hub: Jeremy Tan
summary: Singapore needs to welcome Bitcoin-related businesses to maintain its status as a global financial hub, according to retired businessman Jeremy Tan. He proposes creating a Singapore dollar-denominated Bitcoin exchange-traded fund (ETF) and recognizing Bitcoin as a separate entity from other cryptocurrencies. Companies trading Bitcoin earn from its volatility, and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can benefit from investing their reserves in Bitcoin, Tan said. If the Singapore government does not reform its Bitcoin laws, the advisory services industry will not grow, and SMEs will not be able to structure their businesses to store their treasuries in Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: Young Zhan Heng
Bitcoin’s latest milestone comes as Trump prepares to meet with the biggest holders of his memecoin at a dinner at his golf club just outside Washington on Thursday.
JPMorgan will begin taking wealth-management clients’ crypto holdings into account when assessing their overall net worth and liquid assets.
SocGen’s crypto arm SG-FORGE says the new digital currency, named “USD CoinVertible”, will be issued on both the Ethereum and Solana blockchains, with public trading expected to start in July.

site_title: Haidilao operator Super Hi swings to US$11.9 million Q1 profit on forex gains, delivery growth
summary: Super Hi International, the operator of Haidilao's international business, posted a net profit of US$11.9 million for Q1, reversing a net loss of US$4.5 million last year. Revenue rose 5.4% to US$197.8 million, driven by a 37.9% increase in delivery revenue to US$4 million. The company attributed the growth to sustained investment and marketing efforts in the delivery business and expansion of its delivery network.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
Haidilao restaurant operator Super Hi is back in the red with a net loss of US$11.6 million in Q4.
The Yarwood Avenue good class bungalow owned by Three Arrows Capital co-founder Zhu Su (pictured).
A Haidilao International hotpot restaurant in Beijing. The total number of Super Hi's Haidilao restaurants expanded to 122 as at end-June, from 115 the year before.

site_title: IFAs should hew to thinking of the market
summary: Singapore Paincare's shareholders face an exit offer of S$0.16 per share, a 63.6% discount to its net asset value. The offeror's independent financial adviser (IFA) has deemed the offer "fair and reasonable," but investors question the valuation method. The IFA's advice is scrutinized, especially when companies have depressed valuations. A similar case of Sinarmas Land's IFA was criticized for its evaluation of a take-private offer, which resulted in a 63.6% discount to NAV. The Singapore Exchange Regulation has urged IFAs to clearly explain their opinions on lowball offers.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
Boards and investors should scrutinise the work of IFAs, and push them to justify their views and recommendations.
Sinarmas Land will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange after the acquisition is completed. PHOTO: BT FILE
Independent financial adviser to the deal Ernst and Young said OCBC's new exit offer for Great Eastern is fair and reasonable.
Singapore Paincare CEO Dr Bernard Lee (above) and COO Dr Jeffrey Loo are looking to take the company private at S$0.16 per share.

site_title: Singapore retail vacancy creeping up with more tenants looking to exit
summary: Retail space vacancy in Singapore increased to 6.8% in Q1 2025, up from 6.2% in the previous quarter, according to government data. Net take-up slowed, with 323,000 sq ft of new space entering the market and net demand for retail spaces at a negative 129,000 sq ft. This reversal marks five quarters of positive take-up. Leasing agents report more tenants looking to exit their leases due to ongoing cost pressures.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Euromonitor’s Asia Pacific insight manager for food, Emil Fazira, highlights that these brands, positioned in the middle ground price-wise, may fall short in these challen
The amount of revenue eaten up by rent for F&B outlets could be in the low double-digits.
A bird's eye view of Singapore's financial district.
A total of 3,793 new brands entered Singapore's F&B scene in 2024.
Popular Chinese hotpot chain Haidilao shuttered three restaurants earlier this year in Bedok (above), Pasir Ris and Punggol, after a period of rapid expansion.
Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.
Shoppers at BHG Bugis Junction as on June 3, 2025.
Japanese chain Isetan said on May 6 that it would shut its Tampines Mall outlet when the lease ends in November, after nearly 30 years.

site_title: US: Stocks rally fades after China trade framework
summary: US stocks closed lower on Wednesday, despite a positive US-China trade framework agreement, as investors "sold the news" on a breakthrough that had been largely priced in. The S&P 500 fell 0.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.5%. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent warned a broader deal with China would take a "longer process," and analysts pointed to market overboughtness and concerns over a potential "shadow" Federal Reserve Chair.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on June 2, 2025, in New York City. Oil prices surged Monday over renewed concerns about Russia's war in Ukraine and relief over OPEC+ production, while stock markets mostly slumped as US-China trade tensions resurfaced. The dollar was under pressure while Wall Street opened mixed, with the Dow and the broad-based S&P 500 in the red while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong funds plan to cut Treasuries if US loses AAA score: sources
summary: Hong Kong pension fund managers are planning to cut their US Treasury holdings within three months if the US loses its AAA credit rating, citing local regulations that require managers to invest no more than 10% of their funds in Treasuries. The move is a response to Moody's downgrade of US sovereign debt, leaving Japan's Rating & Investment Information as the only remaining approved firm with the highest score. The plan would shift allocations to other sovereign bonds with AAA ratings, potentially impacting the global market for US Treasuries.

images.alt_text: Heightened uncertainty grips US financial markets as punitive tariffs on key trading partners spark investor fears of rising inflation and a potential economic slowdown.
Moody's said the change reflects expectations that interest rate cuts and sustained moderate economic growth will stabilise bank asset quality and drive profitability.

A trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on June 2, 2025, in New York City. Oil prices surged Monday over renewed concerns about Russia's war in Ukraine and relief over OPEC+ production, while stock markets mostly slumped as US-China trade tensions resurfaced. The dollar was under pressure while Wall Street opened mixed, with the Dow and the broad-based S&P 500 in the red while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)
Fed officials have telegraphed that they intend to hold rates steady at their Jun 17 to Jun 18 policy meeting.

Worry about the budget deficit picked up in May tied to a tax-cut bill moving through Congress. The House-passed version of the tax and spending bill would add US$2.4 trillion to US budget deficits over the next decade, according to an estimate from the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office.

Containers at the Port of Los Angeles in Los Angeles, California, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Recent data showed a slump in trade across the Pacific Ocean, fueling worries that Trump's broad tariff agenda could hit American consumers with higher prices and fewer choices and spur a global downturn. Photographer: Tim Rue/Bloomberg
US President Donald Trump has imposed levies on many US imports and threatened even higher tariffs on key US trade partners.
The losses came in the four trading days between Apr 3 and Apr 8, following US Trump’s announcement on global tariffs.

site_title: US consumer prices rise moderately in May
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.1% in May, a moderate increase, after a 0.2% rise in April. Over the past 12 months, prices have increased 2.4%, down from 2.5% forecasted by economists. The core CPI, excluding food and energy, rose 0.1% and 2.8% year-over-year. Despite President Trump's tariffs, inflation is expected to accelerate in the coming months due to retailers' accumulation of pre-tariff merchandise. The Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged.

images.alt_text: Fed officials have telegraphed that they intend to hold rates steady at their Jun 17 to Jun 18 policy meeting.

site_title: AirAsia’s 100-jet Paris order pits Airbus A220 against Embraer
summary: AirAsia is set to order around 100 regional jets, with negotiations between the airline and manufacturers Airbus and Embraer nearing completion. The airline is deciding between the Airbus A220 and Embraer's E2, with attractive financing playing a key role in the decision. This order would be a significant boost to the A220 program, which has struggled with slow sales and supply-chain issues. The deal, expected to be unveiled by AirAsia CEO Tony Fernandes in Paris, would be a major comeback for the budget airline, which scaled back operations during the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: Capital A CEO Tony Fernandes said the potential for South-east Asia, where much of the company’s exposure lies, to weather global geopolitical tensions may prove attractive to investors.

FILE PHOTO: A ground crew member of AirAsia, a subsidiary airline of Capital A, walks on the tarmac of Kuala Lumpur International Airport Terminal 2 (KLIA2) in Sepang, Malaysia, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

An AirAsia plane undergoing maintenance at Subang, Malaysia, July 15, 2024. Flight AK128, an Airbus A320, was on its way to Shenzhen but turned back to Kuala Lumpur International Airport due to “an abnormal indication in one of the engines”.
Capital A plans to retain 18 per cent of the resulting AirAsia airline group, and the group’s non-aviation businesses.
AirAsia is seeking funds to reboot its growth ambitions after years of Covid-induced losses.

site_title: ‘Ridiculous and frustrating’: Jetstar Asia staff blindsided by abrupt layoff notice
summary: Jetstar Asia, a Qantas Group-owned budget carrier, will cease operations on July 31, laying off over 500 employees in Singapore. Employees were informed of their retrenchment just hours before the public announcement, describing it as "ridiculous and frustrating." Customers affected will be offered alternative flights or full refunds.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Renald Yeo
Jetstar Asia is expected to post an underlying EBIT loss of A$35 million in the current financial year.

site_title: Factory work is overrated. Here are the jobs of the future
summary: The US manufacturing sector is declining, with the number of jobs expected to fall and skilled trades and repair workers seeing a 5% growth over the next decade. Despite efforts to revive manufacturing, the old jobs are not coming back, and new jobs in skilled trades, repair, and security are more attractive to working-class Americans. These jobs offer decent pay, unionization, and require no degree, with median wages of $25 per hour and demand expected to rise as America upgrades its infrastructure. The future is drifting away from factories, and the focus should be on boosting the productivity of growing jobs, such as those in healthcare and personal care.

images.alt_text: Trump and TSMC announce US$100 billion plan to build five new US factories

site_title: Malaysia's April industrial production up 2.7% y/y, below forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production rose 2.7% in April from the previous year, below the forecasted 3.9% growth. This follows a 0.3% increase in May. The country saw a 3.7% rise in approved investments to RM89.8 billion in the first quarter, with foreign investments accounting for RM60.4 billion.

site_title: Huawei launches Pura 80 smartphone series in next step of China comeback
summary: Huawei launched its Pura 80 smartphone series, marking the company's efforts to reclaim its top spot in China's premium smartphone market despite US sanctions. The series includes four models with advanced camera capabilities and AI features, starting at 6,499 yuan for the Pro series. The launch comes as Apple faces declining market share in China, and Huawei's resurgence intensifies pressure on the US company.

images.alt_text: Huawei invests 180 billion yuan (S$32.3 billion) in research annually and sees promise in compound chips - or chips made from multiple elements - CEO Ren Zhengfei said in an interview.
The formal guidance, dated May 13, says using Huawei’s Ascend chips “risks” violating export controls.

A Huawei sign is displayed at their stand at the MWC (Mobile World Congress), the world's biggest mobile fair, in Barcelona on March 3, 2025. Surrounded by investment and innovation projects, the Mobile World Congress (MWC) kicks off today in Barcelona amid a context of euphoria but also tensions over artificial intelligence (AI), whose rapid advancement is shaking up the tech sector. (Photo by Josep LAGO / AFP)
Huawei is phasing out Windows on its PC product line as China drifts away from American technologies that it can replace.
Tensions over Huawei’s next-generation of chips underscore how fragile trade talks remain between the US and China.
The training of AI models involves bombarding them with data to teach them to recognise patterns.
Energy storage is “essential” to overcome the intermittency of renewable energy sources such as solar power, said Keppel's Cindy Lim
Huawei and its Chinese peers have struggled for years to match Nvidia in building top-end chips that could compete with the US firm’s products for training models.
The proceeds from the debt sales will be used to supplement operating funds of Huawei’s headquarters and its subsidiaries
Huawei’s insistence on maintaining control over its intelligent driving ecosystem also means that it’s unlikely to be able to sign up customers overseas.

site_title: Pay, perks and CEO prerogatives
summary: US CEOs enjoy high pay packages, averaging $16 million, with perks such as luxury cars and personal jets. Disclosure rules require companies to report these figures, but reducing disclosure to cut red tape carries risks. Warner Bros. Discovery CEO David Zaslav's pay increased 4.4% despite the company posting a $11.5 billion loss and having its bond rating cut to junk. Similar high pay packages and perks are seen in other companies, such as Chewy's $29.3 million package and CrowdStrike's $35 million package, which includes personal jet usage and sponsorship of a professional race car.

images.alt_text: The median pay for a FTSE-100 company CEO rose 2.2 per cent to £4.19 million last year, think tank the High Pay Centre said, though it added CEO pay growth had slowed compared with the previous two years.
Median pay for the heads of FTSE 100 companies rose by more than a third last year to £3.41 million (S$5.6 million), according to research published on Monday.
CrowdStrike expects annual revenue to be between US$3.89 billion and US$3.90 billion, compared with its prior expectations of US$3.98 billion to US$4.01 billion.

site_title: Vietnam passes historic redrawing of provincial map; Ho Chi Minh City trebles in size, becomes megacity
summary: Vietnam has passed a historic redrawing of its provincial map, cutting the number of provinces and cities from 63 to 34. Ho Chi Minh City, the country's southern metropolis, has tripled in size by absorbing nearby industrial and port hubs. The reorganization aims to streamline governance and enhance efficiency, with a focus on modern governance and sustainable growth. The changes will take effect on July 1, with 11 provinces and cities remaining unchanged and the remaining 52 merged into 23 new administrative units.

images.alt_text: Jamille Tran
An aerial view shows the Landmark 81 skyscraper (C) and the city skyline of Ho Chi Minh City on April 26, 2025. (Photo by NHAC NGUYEN / AFP)

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open near record levels after May inflation data
summary: US stocks opened near record levels on Wednesday, June 11, as a cooler-than-expected inflation report calmed concerns about tariff-driven price pressures. The Dow Jones rose 16 points, or 0.04%, to 42,882.86, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose 10.6 and 64.4 points, respectively, or 0.18% and 0.33%. The inflation report fueled expectations for interest rate cuts, boosting market sentiment and leading to record-level openings.

site_title: Canadian G7 summit gears up around geopolitics
summary: The Canadian-hosted G7 summit from June 15-16 will focus on geopolitics, with Prime Minister Mark Carney prioritizing "protecting our communities and the world" through strengthening peace and security, countering foreign interference, and transnational crime. Key topics include preserving Ukraine's prosperity, regional stability in the Middle East, Asia-Pacific security, and supporting stability in Haiti, Venezuela, Sudan, and the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Sanctions and countering hybrid warfare will also be discussed.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump is tearing apart the glue that holds the G7 together, and it now faces the question of whether it can even continue, or function properly, at least, over the next four years while he is in the top job.
Bessent would seek to get the G7 “back to basics and focused on addressing imbalances and non-market practices in both G7 and non-G7 countries.”

site_title: US cities brace for more protests; downtown Los Angeles under curfew
summary: US cities are bracing for nationwide anti-Trump demonstrations on Saturday, with Los Angeles under curfew after five days of unrest. Over 197 people have been arrested in Los Angeles, with the deployment of National Guard troops and Marines sparking a national debate on the use of military on US soil. President Trump claims the deployment prevented violence, but California's governor Gavin Newsom says it was an abuse of power. Nationwide protests are expected to take place, with concerns over a national crisis and the Trump administration's efforts to deport migrants living in the country illegally.

images.alt_text: The turmoil comes as Los Angeles saw a fourth night of clashes between police and demonstrators rallying against a rising number of raids by Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents.
The remains of multiple burned Waymo vehicles are seen in the street following a night of protests in response to federal immigration operations in Los Angeles, on Jun 9.

site_title: Oversupply from China to further tamp down Singapore construction material prices in Q2
summary: Construction material prices in Singapore are expected to fall by 1-13% year on year in Q2, driven by oversupply and competitive exports from China. Steel rebar prices are forecast to decline 13%, while prices for copper, cement, and diesel are expected to drop between 1-13%. However, new tariffs may disrupt global supply chains in the near term. The construction industry is expected to grow steadily across the Asia-Pacific, with strong activity in data centres, infrastructure, and renewable-energy projects, driven by government spending and large-scale projections.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Construction work taking place next to the Clifford Pier, as seen from the NTUC Income building on Marina Boulevard. Workers preparing a structure of steel rebar before concrete is poured.
The growth of energy-intensive sectors, such as data centres, has put power grids in Asia Pacific under strain, threatening reliability.
This sentiment survey coincided with the announcement of tariffs imposed on many trading partners of the United States.
Building and Construction Authority chief executive Kelvin Wong also encouraged companies to differentiate themselves by identifying their unique competencies as well.

site_title: Japan’s business mood worsens as US tariff uncertainty takes toll
summary: Japan's business sentiment worsened in the April-June quarter, marking the first time in five quarters, due to uncertainty over US tariff policy. The business confidence index fell to -1.9, down from +2.0 in January-March. Manufacturers expect a 1.2% drop in recurring profits and auto parts makers anticipate a 19.8% plunge in fiscal 2025 profits, citing concerns over US tariffs. The decline in business confidence is attributed to the ongoing uncertainty over US tariff policy, affecting Japan's export-heavy economy.

site_title: Why China biotech is getting a DeepSeek moment, too
summary: Big pharmaceutical companies are increasingly partnering with Chinese biotech companies, with recent deals including a record $1.25 billion upfront payment from Pfizer to license an experimental cancer drug from 3SBio. This trend is driven by China's growing biotech industry, low costs for human trials, and a desire to cut expenses in response to US President Donald Trump's economic policies. As a result, the Hang Seng Biotech Index has risen 60% this year, outpacing the S&P biotech index, which has fallen 6.5%.

images.alt_text: President Trump said that his plan would see the US “pay the same price as the Nation that pays the lowest price anywhere in the World”.
China has a long history as an outsourcing hub for foreign pharmaceutical companies and as a producer of “me too” drugs that mimic what’s already on the market.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as markets unfazed by US-China deal
summary: Europe's shares slipped 0.27% to 551.64 points, marking its third straight day of losses, as investors remained cautious despite a framework agreement between the US and China on trade talks. The Stoxx 600 index fell short of expectations for more substantial progress, with analysts citing a month-old reiteration of previous agreements. Despite this, the utilities sector led the gains, while retailers declined due to disappointing sales forecasts.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500, which rose the last three days, finished 0.3 per cent lower at 6,022.24 on Thursday.

site_title: Centurion shares hit all-time high on submission to list Reit on SGX
summary: Centurion shares reached an all-time high of S$1.53 on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after announcing its listing application for a real estate investment trust (Reit). The Reit will comprise worker and student accommodation assets. The IPO details are still being finalized, and the company is awaiting regulatory approvals. This marks the highest price Centurion shares have risen to since 1995.

images.alt_text: Revenue for the second half stood at S$129.2 million, 18 per cent higher from S$109.3 million in the year before.

Centurion's  Q1 FY2025 revenue rose 13 per cent year-on-year to S$69 million, driven by higher rental rates for its Singapore dormitories.  Pictured is the company's chief executive, Kong Chee Min. PHOTO: BT FILE

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, June 11, 2025
summary: US and Chinese officials agree on a plan to reduce trade tensions. Jetstar Asia to shut down on July 31, resulting in over 500 job losses. Centurion shares hit an all-time high after submitting to list on the Singapore Exchange.

images.alt_text: Trump said the deal is subject to final approval by him and President Xi Jinping.
Jetstar Asia is expected to post an underlying EBIT loss of A$35 million in the current financial year.
Centurion says details of the IPO are still being finalised. The Reit it is aiming to establish will comprise some of the group’s worker and student accommodation assets.

site_title: Oil prices jumps 4% to 2-month high as tensions rise in Middle East
summary: Oil prices surged 4% to a 2-month high on Thursday, with Brent crude futures reaching $69.77 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude reaching $68.15 a barrel. The increase was driven by heightened security concerns in the Middle East, including the US' potential evacuation of its Iraqi embassy, which surprised traders and fueled demand for crude futures. Despite OPEC's plans to increase oil production, ongoing tensions with Iran and a trade deal between the US and China are expected to support oil prices in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Opec expects a 24 per cent increase in the world’s energy needs between now and 2050, with oil demand surpassing 120 million barrels per day over that time period.
Brent crude futures slid 17 cents, or 0.3 per cent, to settle at US$66.87 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 31 cents, or 0.5 per cent, to settle at US$64.98 on Tuesday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 11)
summary: Qantas' low-cost airline Jetstar Asia will shut down on July 31, affecting over 500 staff. The airline faces challenges due to escalating supplier costs, airport fees, and increased competition. Meanwhile, Singapore is ranked the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year, and local stocks fell 0.4% despite regional gains. FedEx partnered a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas, and a new grant of up to S$100,000 is available for tariff-hit businesses.

site_title: Gold rises as US-China trade uncertainty persists, investors eye inflation data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $3,328.89 per ounce amid US-China trade uncertainty, with investors awaiting inflation data and awaiting approval of a trade framework. The US and China agreed on a framework to resolve export restrictions and tariffs, but uncertainty lingers. The World Bank slashed its global growth forecast to 2.3% due to higher tariffs and uncertainty. The US inflation data, set to be released later, will provide further market direction.

images.alt_text: Gold bullion can be seen after being removed from casts at the ABC Refinery smelter in Sydney on April 29, 2025. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)
Gold serves as a symbol of political neutrality and security in times of fragmentation and independence from the liabilities of any one issuer.
Spot gold fell 0.5 per cent to US$3,311.16 an ounce, as of 0125 GMT.

site_title: DayOne raises RM15 billion in green financing to develop Johor data centres
summary: DayOne Data Centers has secured RM15 billion in dual-tranche green financing to develop its Johor data centers, setting a record for sustainable data center funding in Malaysia. The deal, which includes a RM7.5 billion Murabahah term financing facility and a US$1.7 billion offshore term loan, will support the development of DayOne's data centers that meet or exceed LEED "Gold" certification standards. The funding was oversubscribed two times and drew interest from local and international banks, with OCBC and Maybank acting as joint coordinators and mandated lead arrangers.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
The Nongsa Digital Park in Batam, Indonesia, aims to strengthen digital connectivity between the economies of Singapore and Indonesia.
data centre Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

FILE PHOTO: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration taken, February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The deals underscore the industry’s appeal in attracting a range of investors – from banks to real estate players – as the AI boom drives demand.
Malaysia is turning into a beneficiary of Asia’s growing need for data centres to support the boom in artificial intelligence.

site_title: Musk says some of his posts about Trump ‘went too far’
summary: Elon Musk apologized for some of his critical posts about US President Donald Trump, saying they "went too far". Musk deleted some of the posts, including one signaling support for Trump's impeachment, after Trump ended their relationship, citing insults on social media. Musk had previously bankrolled Trump's 2024 presidential campaign and was involved in efforts to downsize the federal workforce. Musk's apology and deleted posts led to a 2.7% rise in Tesla shares, and Trump expressed no interest in repairing their relationship.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Donald Trump and Elon Musk attend a press conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S., May 30, 2025. REUTERS/Nathan Howard/File Photo

Even if Elon Musk deserves credit for his part in SpaceX’s domination in both rocket launches and satellite communications, the feud’s weaponisation of space suggests innovation has taken a backseat to favouritism.
Traders dumped Tesla in heavy trading after Elon Musk quickly responded to US President Donald Trump’s criticism with social media posts that stepped up criticism of the president’s tax bill.
Following Elon Musk’s announcement, Nasa spokeswoman Bethany Stevens said on X that the government space agency would “continue to execute upon the President’s vision for the future of space.”
Tesla scion Elon Musk has called US President Donald Trump's "big, beautiful bill"  a “disgusting abomination.”
Some politicos in Washington speculate that Donald Trump (left) and Elon Musk will try to mend their relationship and limit the business and political damage from last week’s explosive bust-up.

US President Donald Trump said in a televised Oval Office diatribe that he was "very disappointed" after his former aide and top donor Elon Musk criticised his "big, beautiful" spending bill before Congress. The pair then hurled insults at each other on social media -- with Musk even posting, without proof, that Trump was referenced in government documents on disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
The verbal punches erupted on Thursday after Trump criticised Musk in the Oval Office and the pair then traded barbs on their social media platforms: Trump’s Truth Social and Musk’s X.

site_title: Singapore shares buck regional trend to close lower; STI falls 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 3,919.05, marking its second consecutive decline, as investors expressed concern over the lack of details in US-China trade talks. The benchmark index was also affected by the upcoming US Treasury auction on June 12, which is expected to gauge demand for 30-year government bonds. Top gainers included Venture Corp, while ST Engineering was the biggest loser, falling 1.9%. Markets in most of Asia, however, closed higher, with South Korea's Kospi up 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks were among the best performers on Wednesday.

site_title: Balloon Museum Singapore is the escape all adults need
summary: The Balloon Museum Singapore's latest attraction, "Pop Air: Art is Inflatable," has been praised as a top-rated immersive experience, offering a unique and joyful experience for adults. The exhibit features 17 installations spread across 6,000 square meters, including a "pool" of floating balls, a tornado of balloons, and a smoke-filled bubble environment. The museum's curators have chosen artists who understand how to build mood and narrative into their work, elevating the experience from a spectacle to a theatre of childhood emotions. The exhibit runs until August 31 at Marina Bay Sands.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Make this year's Father's Day the best he's ever had.
Valerie Koh, a mother of four, calls her Crybaby plushies "mood boosters".

site_title: Designed to maximise volume: A four-level house within a 2.5-storey exterior
summary: A Singaporean couple, the Angs, gave their architect the freedom to design their semi-detached house without dictating their wants and needs. The result is a unique four-level house within a two-and-a-half-storey exterior, maximizing internal volume. The house features a double-volume living and dining area, a mezzanine level for entertainment and yoga, and a stacked volume for three bedrooms. The design incorporates natural light, ventilation, and seamless connections to the outdoors. The couple has made modifications along the construction journey, including keeping the mezzanine floor open to improve airflow and creating a flexible attic space for future needs.

images.alt_text: The house has a striking facade of tiered arches and curves.
This old apartment in Laguna Park has been turned into a dual key home.

site_title: Trump says China will supply rare earths, US to allow in Chinese students
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a trade deal with China, agreeing to a 55% tariff on Chinese imports and a 10% tariff on US exports. In exchange, China will supply rare earth minerals and magnets to the US, and the US will allow Chinese students in its colleges and universities. The deal, reached after two days of negotiations in London, is subject to final approval by Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.3 per cent at 42,866.87 on Tuesday.

(From left) US Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng shake hands as they pose for a photo during trade discussions at the Lancaster House in London, Britain, June 9, 2025.

On the first of likely two days of talks, officials from the two superpowers were meeting at the ornate Lancaster House to try to get back on track with a preliminary agreement struck last month in Geneva.

site_title: Fitch warns of rising mortgage-bond risk due to extreme weather
summary: Fitch Ratings is integrating physical climate risks into credit assessments, warning of rising mortgage-bond risk due to extreme weather events caused by climate change. The recent glacier collapse in Switzerland's Blatten village is a fresh example of the devastating impact of climate change on property values. Fitch expects physical climate events to occur more frequently and intensely, with potential consequences for the US$3.4 trillion covered bond market. Regulators and banks are responding with increased transparency and climate-related disclosures, aiming to better understand and mitigate climate risks.

site_title: South-east Asia’s polymer production crisis worsens as US-China trade shift looms
summary: South-east Asia's polymer production crisis worsens due to a US-China trade shift. Research firm Argus expects region's prices to remain depressed. US polymer exports to the region are anticipated to increase, driven by cost-competitiveness and low likelihood of retaliatory tariffs. This could further strain the export-dependent finished goods sector, putting indirect downward pressure on polymer demand. China's expanding polymer production capacity also threatens the crisis, with the country increasing its exports to Asean nations and deepening the region's existing polymer production crisis.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
China's industrial output in April rose by 6.1 per cent, surpassing expectations for a 5.5 per cent increase in a Reuters poll of 24 analysts.
A gauge of production at factories declined to 46, the lowest level since May 2020, from 47.9 in November.
Realising the regional power grid blueprint, which was first brought up in the late 1990s, is not smooth sailing.
The expected influx of high-grade iron ore from Simandou might worsen an oversupply situation as China’s demand growth softens, which would put more pressure on iron ore producers.

site_title: Labubu doll fetches 1.08 million yuan at China auction as demand rages
summary: A human-sized Labubu doll fetched 1.08 million yuan (S$193,341) at an auction in Beijing, China, in a record-breaking sale that highlights the popularity of the collectible toy. The sale, which also included 47 other Labubu items, attracted thousands of buyers and pushed the shares of Pop Mart, the toy's maker, up over 180% this year. The toy's popularity has led to a surge in demand, with some buyers willing to pay inflated prices, and has prompted the regulator to ban the use of Labubu as free gifts to lure depositors.

images.alt_text: xxx
Valerie Koh, a mother of four, calls her Crybaby plushies "mood boosters".

Starting from a pop grocery store since 2010, Pop Mart successfully transformed from a toy retailer to an IP-centric platform, shifting from product sales to IP development and diversified operations.
Revenues at Gen Z favourites such as toymaker Pop Mart International Group, jewellery firm Laopu Gold and drinks chain Mixue Group have soared, fuelling breakneck moves in their stock prices.
The fervour for Pop Mart’s toys has turned it into a global phenomenon, with fans sometimes queueing for hours outside stores for new releases.

site_title: Singapore’s tech talents unleash transformative automation and AI solutions at Workato’s Work Revolution National Developer Challenge
summary: Singapore's tech talents showcased transformative automation and AI solutions at Workato's inaugural National Developer Challenge. Over 100 developers from across the region participated, with the top three winners taking home prizes for their innovative ideas. Team (我)rk 爱 AI emerged as the winner with an AI-assisted volunteer onboarding system for AWARE Singapore, reducing vetting time from months to days. The challenge, supported by the Infocomm Media Development Authority, aims to foster innovation and talent development in the enterprise automation and AI space, solidifying Singapore's reputation as a hub for technological talent and innovation.

site_title: DBS, OCBC and UOB to recognise CPF Life payouts as income in credit card applications
summary: DBS, OCBC, and UOB are introducing policies to recognize CPF Life payouts as income for credit card applications. From June 11, individuals aged 65 and above can use their CPF Life payouts as proof of income for DBS and OCBC credit cards, while UOB plans to implement the policy in the near future. This move aims to make credit more accessible to retirees and ensure they can enjoy a fulfilling retirement. The banks' push comes after the Monetary Authority of Singapore confirmed that CPF Life payouts can be considered as an income source.

images.alt_text: The CPF retirement scheme can provide everyone with the foundation for a comfortable retirement.
Central Provident Fund (CPF) members will earn an interest of 4 per cent per annum for their Special, MediSave and Retirement Accounts (SMRA) in Q3 of 2025

site_title: PT Kawasan Industri Jorong signs EPC Contract with ECEC for landmark Ammonia & Urea Chemical Plant in Indonesia
summary: PT Kawasan Industri Jorong (KIJ) signed a contract with East China Engineering Science and Technology Co., Ltd. (ECEC) for the development of an Ammonia & Urea Chemical Plant in South Kalimantan, Indonesia. The project, valued at approximately USD 478 million, will create a 6,370-hectare industrial hub with an estimated annual production capacity of 300,000 tons of ammonia and 520,000 tons of urea. Construction is set to begin in February 2026, with the plant expected to generate substantial economic benefits and create thousands of local employment opportunities.

site_title: Beach Boy Brian Wilson, surf rock poet, dies at 82
summary: Brian Wilson, co-founder of The Beach Boys, has died at 82. Wilson, who masterminded the group's success and crafted hits like "Surfin' USA" and "God Only Knows," was placed under a conservatorship last year due to a neurocognitive disorder. Despite struggling with depression and mental health issues, Wilson produced the group's iconic album "Smile" and was hailed as a "genius" by Paul McCartney. Wilson's family announced his death on Instagram, saying they are "at a loss for words" and grieving the loss of their beloved pop visionary.

images.alt_text: The move comes as China is widely expected to lift its nearly decade-old unofficial ban on K-pop performances in mainland China.
BTS members V and RM, who have been discharged from South Korea’s mandatory military service, pose for photographs, Chuncheon, South Korea, June 10, 2025.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says former head quit over funding dispute
summary: Former New Zealand central bank governor Adrian Orr resigned suddenly in March over disagreements with the treasury over proposed cuts to the bank's operating budget, citing insufficient funding as a major concern. Orr's seven-year term had become contentious due to high interest rates that led to a recession. The cuts were part of a 25% reduction in the central bank's budget, set at NZ$150 million for the next five years. Orr's decision was seen as a personal choice, not directly related to the discussions on regulatory capital for banks.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand cut the number of its policy meetings to seven from eight in 2016, which has allowed policymakers to enjoy a nearly three-month year-end break.
Prices rose modestly in early 2024 but buyer optimism was not sustained as the central bank kept borrowing costs high and economic growth stalled.

site_title: Chinese carmakers vow to make timely supplier payments as backlash to price war grows
summary: Chinese carmakers BYD, Chery, Geely, Guangzhou Automobile Group, FAW Group, Xpeng, and Xiaomi have pledged to make timely supplier payments within 60 days, responding to regulatory pressure and a backlash to a price war that has been ongoing since early 2023. The pledges come after the industry ministry told automakers to end the price war and excessive competition, which have put pressure on the supply chain. The move aims to alleviate liquidity pressure and profit margins for steel companies and suppliers, who have been struggling due to deepening price cuts and delayed payments.

images.alt_text: BYD has lost US$21.5 billion in market value since its shares peaked in late May.
Geely Holding owns multiple automotive brands including Geely Auto, Zeekr and Volvo.
In overall terms the Model Y feels better to drive, but the Sealion 7 feels like it would be better to live with.

Without naming BYD, the China Automobile Manufacturers Association said the move by a certain company started a new round of “price war panic” that was plunging the sector into a “vicious cycle” and threatening supply chain security.

site_title: FranzWood carves out a niche in Singapore’s conservation sector
summary: Singapore-based SME FranzWood has carved a niche in the country's conservation sector through multidisciplinary work on heritage sites. Founded in 2008 by managing director Francis Lim, the firm offers a range of services including restoration, engineering, and innovation. FranzWood has worked on high-profile projects such as the restoration of the 113-year-old St Joseph's Church and has developed a chemical spread to accelerate patination on copper domes, suitable for Singapore's hot and humid environment. The company aims to expand into regional markets, particularly in ASEAN, where there is limited expertise in conservation, to preserve heritage sites for future generations.

images.alt_text: Nelson Yap, founder of Benjamin Barker. Post-pandemic, the company then began offering seasonal, capsule collections of curated pieces.
Daniel Rouquette, CEO of Villa Finder. A large part of Villa Finder's revenue growth has since come from their bustling ski-focused base in Japan, contributed by the winter seasons of 2022 to 2024.

site_title: Japan’s wholesale inflation slows, taking pressure off BOJ
summary: Japan's wholesale inflation slowed to 3.2% in May, down from a 4.1% rise in April, as import costs for raw materials decreased. The drop in wholesale prices may ease pressure on the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates. However, food and beverage prices rose 4.2% in May, indicating simmering inflationary pressure. The Bank of Japan has signaled its readiness to raise rates again if inflation accelerates, but a Reuters poll suggests most economists expect the central bank to hold rates steady through September.

images.alt_text: The Japanese government shelved the idea of cash handouts in April as questions arose over the effectiveness of the handouts. But the plan has come back as the LDP resists growing calls from some opposition parties for tax cuts, which could weigh on the state finances more heavily.

The Bank of Japan has said underlying inflation, or demand-driven price pressure measured by various indicators, remains short of its 2 per cent target - even though the broader core consumer inflation has exceeded that level for three years.
Japan is contending with a barrage of US tariffs, including a blanket 10 per cent duty on its goods that will rise to 24 per cent in early July barring a trade deal.

site_title: Rachel Reeves vows nationwide ‘renewal’ for UK in spending review
summary: UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves has outlined a three-year spending review aimed at renewing Britain's infrastructure and public services. The plan includes £113 billion for public investment, with £39 billion for affordable homes, £86 billion for British science, and £15 billion for new transport infrastructure. The review also includes £3.5 billion for the Transpennine rail project and £2.5 billion for a line linking Oxford and Cambridge. The spending review aims to boost public services and voter perceptions, particularly ahead of the 2029 general election.

site_title: CapitaLand China Trust to divest retail property for 748 million yuan
summary: CapitaLand China Trust is divesting its 49.9% stake in CapitaMall Yuhuating, a mature retail asset in Changsha, China, for approximately 748 million yuan (S$134.9 million). The proceeds will be used to participate in the listing of CapitaLand Commercial C-Reit on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, with the trust intending to allocate around S$20.7 million to subscribe for 5% of the C-Reit's IPO units. The divestment aims to realise value from a mature asset while maintaining exposure to China's retail sector and strengthening the trust's balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Capitaland China Trust is proposing unlock value through a divestment of CapitaMall Yuhuating, for no less than the minimum floor price of 748 million yuan (S$134.9 million).

site_title: Holland Village, Boat Quay and other destinations that have seen better days
summary: Holland Village, a former Singaporean favorite destination, has lost its quirky mix of shops and charm. The area has become a dining hotspot, with many restaurants and cafes, making it less unique compared to other locations. Competition from nearby areas like Dempsey and the rise of upscale developments has contributed to its decline. The transformation is a result of changing inhabitants and community needs, highlighting the need for sensible placemaking visions from authorities to ensure the evolution of public spaces.

images.alt_text: Lee Su Shyan
With dwindling foot traffic, Holland Village businesses are struggling to stay afloat.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Raffles Medical, Amara, Koh Brothers Eco Engineering, SIA
summary: Raffles Medical Group has inked a strategic cooperation agreement with First Affiliated Hospital in Chongqing, China, to deepen medical partnerships between the two. Meanwhile, Keppel Infrastructure Trust is divesting a 24.6% stake in Australian bus service business Ventura Motors for A$130 million, and Amara will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange after a 97.74% privatization offer was accepted. Koh Brothers Eco Engineering has secured a S$999 million contract for Changi Airport's Terminal 5 construction.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

site_title: Blackstone plans US$500 billion Europe investment: CEO
summary: Blackstone plans to invest up to $500 billion in Europe over the next 10 years, according to CEO Steve Schwarzman. This move underscores the continent's growing appeal to investors amid geopolitical uncertainty. Schwarzman's comments coincide with the 25th anniversary of Blackstone's London operations, which has grown to become the world's largest alternative asset manager, with $1 trillion in assets under management. The investment is part of Blackstone's expanding presence in European real estate and follows similar calls from other investment firms.

images.alt_text: BlackRock is betting it can conquer a more opaque and exclusive part of finance by homing in on private markets.
Blackstone informed Warehouse Reit's board earlier this month it would not proceed with its offer following its due diligence procedures.

site_title: Hong Seafood casts a wider net with its own brands
summary: Hong Seafood, a Singapore-based frozen seafood distributor, has expanded its business model by sourcing directly from overseas suppliers. Under the leadership of Loh Guo Pei, the son of its founder, the company has grown into a global player, supplying over 300 customers in Singapore and exporting to over 10 countries. Hong Seafood now also builds its own brands, transforming from a single chest freezer in 1986.

images.alt_text: Pastry chef Daniel Tay launched Old Seng Choong in 2016 as an homage to his late father’s now-defunct old-school bakery Seng Choong Confectionery.

site_title: France’s Mistral launches Europe’s first AI reasoning model
summary: France's AI startup Mistral has launched Europe's first AI reasoning model, which uses logical thinking to create a response, aiming to compete with American and Chinese rivals. The model, Magistral Small, is available for download and can reason in multiple languages. This move could help Mistral catch up with rivals, as the traditional approach of building large language models is hitting limitations. Mistral's open-sourced approach is in contrast to proprietary offerings from OpenAI and Google.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s digital economy began to emerge in the early 2000s, but it advanced significantly with the Smart Nation initiative in 2014.
Besides Vietnam, Qualcomm operates R&D centres in Ireland and India, which are among its largest outside the US
Huawei invests 180 billion yuan (S$32.3 billion) in research annually and sees promise in compound chips - or chips made from multiple elements - CEO Ren Zhengfei said in an interview.

(From left) US Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng shake hands as they pose for a photo during trade discussions at the Lancaster House in London, Britain, June 9, 2025.

site_title: Asia: Equities rally after China-US framework on trade
summary: Asian stocks rallied on Wednesday as investors welcomed a China-US framework to lower trade tensions, with Hong Kong and Shanghai leading the gains. The agreement, reached after high-profile talks in London and Geneva, aims to reduce tariffs and address issues like rare earth exports. While analysts warn that markets may be relying on faith, the news provided relief after US President Donald Trump accused Beijing of violating a previous deal. The framework must still be approved by Xi and Trump, but the development has boosted markets and eased trade uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed unchanged for the second straight day at 553.12 points.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.3 per cent at 42,866.87 on Tuesday.

site_title: Record 3.5 million Switch 2 consoles sold in first four days, says Nintendo
summary: Nintendo's Switch 2 console has broken records, selling 3.5 million units in its first four days, becoming the fastest-selling console ever. The upgraded console features a bigger screen and more processing power, and was released to sold-out pre-orders and midnight store openings. Analysts say the high price of the console, at $449.99, may impact sales, but Nintendo forecasts 15 million units will be sold in the current financial year. The company's success will depend on sustaining engagement with new titles and attracting casual gamers in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: A customers purchases a Nintendo Switch 2 at an electronics retailer in Tokyo, Japan, June 5, 2025.
Apple is also planning a Mac version of the app that can tap into games downloaded outside of the App Store.
The US comprises the bulk of PlayStation 5 sales, which is mostly produced in China.

The games industry is struggling to develop a sustainable economic model, with many publishers and studios in recent times cancelling projects and cutting staff after the pandemic-driven boom in entertainment faded.
In a blog post on Thursday, Xbox said it will raise prices of its products in the United States, Europe, Australia and the United Kingdom.

site_title: World Bank slashes global growth forecast as trade tensions bite
summary: The World Bank lowered its global growth forecast for 2025 to 2.3% due to higher tariffs and heightened uncertainty, affecting nearly 70% of economies, including the US, China, and Europe. The forecast cut is attributed to US President Donald Trump's trade policies, which have increased the effective US tariff rate and triggered retaliation from China and other countries. The bank expects global trade growth to decline to 1.8% in 2025, down from 3.4% in 2024.

images.alt_text: New York’s Dow and S&P 500 indices were lower, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose slightly in early trading.

site_title: Irish government eases rent cap to boost home supply
summary: Ireland's government has approved new rental control reforms to boost apartment completions and tackle the country's acute housing shortage. The annual rental cap will be expanded nationwide, but newly built apartment developments will be exempt with a cap linked to the Consumer Price Index. Landlords will have the right to reset rent where it is below market at the end of a tenancy. The measures aim to lure more apartment investors to the market and meet the government's target of building over 300,000 new homes by 2030.

images.alt_text: London remains the least affordable UK region, with 90 per cent of local authorities recording house prices equal to over 12 times annual earnings.

site_title: Netflix to invest 1 billion euros in Spain productions to 2029
summary: US streaming giant Netflix plans to invest over 1 billion euros in productions in Spain over the next four years, with co-CEO Ted Sarandos stating the move will contribute to the Spanish economy, create more jobs, and tell more great stories made in Spain. This investment supports over 20,000 jobs in the country, solidifying Spain's position as a hub for European audiovisual creation.

images.alt_text: Netflix's recent price increase is reflective of a wider strategy to increase prices and ad-tier offerings to boost monetisation.
Netflix has been ramping up South Indian titles in languages such as Telugu and Tamil that reach broader audiences beyond Hindi-based Bollywood film fan bases.

site_title: Oil prices hold near 7-week high as market waits for news from US-China trade talks
summary: Oil prices held near a seven-week high on Tuesday as the market awaited direction from US-China trade talks. Brent crude futures slid 17 cents, or 0.3%, to settle at US$66.87 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 31 cents, or 0.5%, to settle at US$64.98. Analysts expect a trade deal between the US and China could boost prices by supporting global economic growth and increasing oil demand. However, OPEC's planned output increase may not result in much additional supply, and US sanctions on Iran could reduce crude prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 57 cents higher, or 0.9 per cent, to US$67.04 a barrel on Monday.

site_title: Scott Bessent emerging as a contender to succeed Fed’s Powell
summary: US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent is emerging as a contender to succeed Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, with President Donald Trump saying he will name a successor "very soon." Bessent has been leading Trump's efforts to kickstart the US economy with sweeping changes to trade, taxes, and regulation, and is seen as a dark horse candidate by some. Other potential candidates include Kevin Warsh, a former Fed official, and Kevin Hassett, the White House's National Economic Council director. The choice of Fed chair will be crucial in maintaining the central bank's independence from political meddling.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trimp has repeatedly berated Fed Chair Jerome Powell for not cutting rates as he desires. The two men met face-to-face for the first time last week, with Trump telling Powell he was making a “mistake” by not lowering rates.

site_title: Musk is the US$350 billion Rocket Man who fell to Earth
summary: Elon Musk's feud with Donald Trump and other countries is threatening the US$630 billion space economy, with SpaceX's market share and government contracts at stake. Musk's actions, including halting the Dragon capsule and using Starlink satellites for geopolitical leverage, are seen as favoritism over innovation. The spat carries costly lessons for a space economy dependent on one firm, with competitors like Blue Origin and Eutelsat Communications stepping up their game. A prolonged conflict could make space a "chillier" place for everyone, with Nasa facing budget cuts and Europeans struggling to close the gap in military space spending.

images.alt_text: Some politicos in Washington speculate that Donald Trump (left) and Elon Musk will try to mend their relationship and limit the business and political damage from last week’s explosive bust-up.

site_title: Trump tariffs may remain in effect while appeals proceed, US Appeals court decides
summary: A US Federal Appeals Court has allowed President Donald Trump's tariffs to remain in effect while it reviews a lower court decision blocking them, citing Trump's authority under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act. The tariffs, imposed in February on Canada, China, and Mexico, and in April on most US trading partners, were challenged by small businesses and states, who argued they exceeded Trump's authority. The appeals court has yet to rule on the tariffs' legality, but allowed them to remain in place while the appeals process unfolds.

images.alt_text: The largest importer of vehicles into the US, GM is seeking to mitigate an estimated US$5 billion exposure to Trump’s tariffs.
Trump said the deal is subject to final approval by him and President Xi Jinping.
Tokyo led gains in Asian markets, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington and Jakarta stocks also up on Tuesday.

The Bank of Japan has said underlying inflation, or demand-driven price pressure measured by various indicators, remains short of its 2 per cent target - even though the broader core consumer inflation has exceeded that level for three years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat as investors await outcome of US-China talks
summary: European stocks closed flat for the second day in a row, unchanged at 553.12 points, as investors await the outcome of US-China trade talks in London. Despite President Trump's upbeat comments, the talks' progress remains unclear, keeping markets cautious. Energy stocks rose, led by higher oil prices, while healthcare stocks advanced due to vaccine maker news. The US-China trade dispute continues to weigh on markets, with a 90-day pause's implications still unclear.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.3 per cent at 42,866.87 on Tuesday.

site_title: GM dodges tariffs with production shift to US from Mexico
summary: General Motors (GM) plans to invest $4 billion in its US plants over the next two years to boost output of top-selling gas-powered vehicles, aiming to mitigate a $5 billion exposure to US tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump. The move will expand finished vehicle manufacturing at factories in Michigan, Kansas, and Tennessee, allowing GM to assemble over two million vehicles annually. Production of several top-selling models, including the Chevy Silverado pickup and Chevrolet Equinox SUV, will be shifted from Mexico to US factories.

site_title: Oil demand growth to continue, no peak in sight, Opec Secretary General says
summary: Opec Secretary General Haitham Al Ghais says oil demand growth will continue over the next two and a half decades, with a 24% increase in the world's energy needs and oil demand surpassing 120 million barrels per day by 2050. There is no peak in oil demand on the horizon, and the organization is warning of the dangers of inadequate global investment in oil and gas. Opec estimates $17.4 trillion in capital investment is needed in the global energy sector over the next 25 years to meet projected demand growth.

site_title: The G7 is at a critical crossroads
summary: The Group of Seven (G7) is facing a critical test of cohesion and credibility at the upcoming Kananaskis summit, as US President Donald Trump's divisive policies and rhetoric threaten to unravel the alliance. Trump's attacks on European unity, trade policies, and NATO have strained relations with longtime allies, while his support for authoritarian leaders and disregard for Ukraine's sovereignty have raised concerns. The G7's revival under former President Joe Biden's administration is at risk, and the summit may be a "frigid affair" despite its sunny location.

images.alt_text: Bessent would seek to get the G7 “back to basics and focused on addressing imbalances and non-market practices in both G7 and non-G7 countries.”

site_title: Singapore stocks snap 5-day winning streak on Tuesday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% on Tuesday, snapping a five-day winning streak, due to concerns about the US-China trade talks. Chinese stocks also declined, with the Shanghai Composite falling 0.4% and the Shenzhen Component shedding 0.9%. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic about the sustained dialogue between the two countries, with some speculating that the negotiations may not be progressing smoothly.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck

(From left) US Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng shake hands as they pose for a photo during trade discussions at the Lancaster House in London, Britain, June 9, 2025.

site_title: About 5,400 cars have encountered issues with ERP on-board unit after installation
summary: Around 5,400 cars in Singapore have encountered issues with their Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) on-board units (OBUs) since their installation began in November 2023, with 1.8% of over 300,000 vehicles affected. The problems include unresponsive units and issues with wiring, prompting return visits to workshops. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) advises motorists to return to the workshops that installed their units for effective troubleshooting.

images.alt_text: The Electronic Road Pricing On-Board Unit to be installed in all Singapore-registered vehicles. The unit is mounted roughly where the current in-vehicle unit typically sits.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 10)
summary: Singapore and Johor Regent agreed to transfer 13 ha of land to the government in exchange for 8.5 ha of state land. The move aims to relocate the Regent's planned development further away from the Botanic Gardens. Meanwhile, a center to advance sustainable aviation in Asia was set up, and the government established a new grant for tariff-hit businesses. Graduates are advised to remain calm despite early data showing better employment rates.

images.alt_text: GCB Area bungalows sit at the apex of Singapore's residential property market.

site_title: Raffles Medical partners Chongqing hospital to enhance healthcare services
summary: Raffles Medical Group has partnered with the First Affiliated Hospital of Chongqing Municipality in China to enhance healthcare services through the combination of international expertise and local strengths. The partnership aims to establish a new healthcare collaboration ecosystem focused on value co-creation, talent exchange, and equipment sharing. The two institutions will also explore new models of cooperation such as dual-appointment talent systems and alignment with international medical standards. The partnership is seen as a "Chongqing Model" for international medical cooperation under the Belt and Road Initiative, further consolidating Chongqing's status as an international medical hub city.

site_title: Neo Group buys over bakery chain PrimaDeli’s operations for undisclosed sum
summary: Neo Group has acquired PrimaDeli's operations for an undisclosed sum, with PrimaDeli continuing to operate under its existing brand. The acquisition marks a new era of growth and innovation for Singapore's first home-grown bakery franchise. Neo Group Bakery, a new entity under Neo Group, will oversee the bakery-related businesses and retain PrimaDeli's employees. The company aims to elevate PrimaDeli's offerings and presence through its expertise, infrastructure, and technology.

位于兀兰长堤坊的百得利（PrimaDeli）糕饼专卖店。

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust to divest 24.6% stake in Australian bus service business for A$130 million
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust is divesting 24.6% stake in Australian bus service business Ventura Motors for A$130 million, a 19% premium from its acquisition price. The divestment will leave KIT with a 73.1% share in the company, with private investment funds managed by Samsung Asset Management acquiring the remaining shares. The move aims to bolster KIT's financial strength and agility, and enhance its ability to capture further opportunities through strategic capital recycling.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Ventura Motors is the largest bus-service business in the state of Victoria in Australia.
Loh Hwee Long, CEO of Keppel DC Reit Management, says the Reit saw overall valuation gains in 2024, especially from its Singapore colocation assets.

site_title: Consortium’s privatisation offer for Amara closes with 97.74% valid acceptances
summary: A consortium led by Hwa Hong successfully privatized Amara hotel and property group, with 97.74% of shares accepted. The offeror, DRC Investments, will compulsorily acquire remaining shares at S$0.895 a share, delisting Amara from the Singapore Exchange. The company will become a wholly owned subsidiary of DRC, with chairman and CEO Albert Teo holding 30% of shares. The offer price represents a 27% premium over Amara's closing price and a 33% premium over its net asset value per share.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
