Market watchers told The Business Times that delisting activity has been significantly influenced by recent equity market volatility, amid rising geopolitical tensions, tariffs, and broader global economic uncertainties.

site_title: South-east Asia’s tech unicorns may look more like banks in the future
summary: South-east Asia's tech unicorns, such as Grab and Sea, are expanding into banking services, potentially making up the bulk of their revenue. MariBank, Sea's subsidiary, and GXS Bank, GX Bank, and Superbank, are among the financial institutions under the tech companies' belts. This shift could mark a significant change in the region's tech landscape, with banking and financial services becoming a major focus area for growth and sustainability.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
BT
Keeping MariBank true to its mission is a focus for Natalia Goh, CEO, MariBank.

site_title: Societe Generale becomes first major bank to launch dollar-pegged stablecoin
summary: Societe Generale has become the first major bank to launch a dollar-pegged stablecoin, named "USD CoinVertible", which will be issued on both the Ethereum and Solana blockchains. The stablecoin will be regulated under the European Union's MiCA regulation and will be backed by reserves held by BNY Mellon. The move follows growing demand for regulated stablecoins, with the sector seeing rapid growth driven by companies like Tether, which has issued $155 billion of dollar-pegged tokens.

images.alt_text: SocGen has planned a higher-than-expected share buyback programme of 872 million euros, although its dividend, at 1.09 euros per share, was slightly below expectations.

site_title: Qantas’ Jetstar Asia to shut down on Jul 31; over 500 staff to lose jobs
summary: Qantas is shutting down its Singapore-based unit Jetstar Asia on July 31, affecting over 500 staff and 16 intra-Asia routes. The carrier cited escalating supplier costs, airport fees, and aviation charges, as well as growing competition, as reasons for the closure. The 13 Airbus A320 aircraft will be redeployed to Qantas' Australian and New Zealand businesses. Customers will be offered a full cash refund or alternative flights, and the airline will provide retrenchment packages and support to affected staff.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Tay Peck Gek
Renald Yeo
Artist impression of an aerial view of Changi Airport Terminal 5 (T5).
Delta Airlines warned that the proposed tariffs could disrupt its current growth path.
Virgin Australia will sell 236.2 million shares in the IPO to value the company at A$2.32 billion on a fully diluted basis, the term sheet showed
Airfares in Asia are coming down from post-pandemic record highs as the region’s airlines continue to restore seat capacity.
Loyalty programmes of Delta, United and American Airlines were each valued at more than US$20 billion in 2023, according to consulting firm On Point Loyalty.

site_title: Australia regulator trials faster IPO process as listings hit decade low
summary: Australia's securities regulator, ASIC, will trial changes to speed up initial public offerings (IPOs) that are at a decade low, aiming to reduce the typical 20-week process to 19 weeks. The trial, set to last two years, will allow companies to submit confidential prospectuses 14 days before formal lodgement for ASIC review. The changes are part of a broader review of regulatory settings, as funds raised through IPOs have hit a decade low, with only A$4.2 billion raised last year.

images.alt_text: Virgin Australia will sell 236.2 million shares in the IPO to value the company at A$2.32 billion on a fully diluted basis, the term sheet showed

site_title: Tesla’s public robotaxi rides set for tentative June 22 start: CEO Musk
summary: Tesla is tentatively set to begin offering public robotaxi rides on June 22, CEO Elon Musk announced. The service, which will start with a limited area in Austin, Texas, will initially operate with 10-20 Model Y SUVs under remote human supervision. The company plans to expand operations to other US states, including California, later in the year. A successful launch is crucial for Tesla, which has seen sales soften due to rising competition and a backlash against Musk's political views.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.3 per cent at 42,866.87 on Tuesday.
Some politicos in Washington speculate that Donald Trump (left) and Elon Musk will try to mend their relationship and limit the business and political damage from last week’s explosive bust-up.

US President Donald Trump said in a televised Oval Office diatribe that he was "very disappointed" after his former aide and top donor Elon Musk criticised his "big, beautiful" spending bill before Congress. The pair then hurled insults at each other on social media -- with Musk even posting, without proof, that Trump was referenced in government documents on disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

Even if Elon Musk deserves credit for his part in SpaceX’s domination in both rocket launches and satellite communications, the feud’s weaponisation of space suggests innovation has taken a backseat to favouritism.

site_title: Learning how to cope with losing is an integral part of an investor’s journey
summary: Investors in Singapore are facing increased financial market volatility, which may lead to losses. Despite this, embracing more risk by switching from safe instruments like Singapore dollar fixed deposits and Treasury bills to equities and corporate bonds can result in gains. However, investors must learn to cope with handling losses and be resilient in a more volatile world. With rising life expectancy, investors need to save and invest for retirement, making financial habits like reducing discretionary spending and investing in high-quality equities essential. Ultimately, learning to handle losing is crucial for long-term investment success.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Trump has repeatedly postponed or pulled back tariffs he has announced since his inauguration, causing the market to quickly rebound after big sell-offs.
Rather than letting cash sit idle, consider treating it as part of your overall portfolio strategy.

site_title: United House relaunched for sale at S$166 million
summary: United House, a freehold commercial development in Singapore's Orchard Road area, has been relaunched for collective sale with a reserve price of S$166 million. The site, which spans 1,193 square meters, can be redeveloped into a 10-storey commercial building with a gross floor area of up to 62,900 square feet. The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has granted in-principle approval for the site to be redeveloped for hotel use, with a land rate of S$3,054 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr). The tender for United House will close on July 1, while the tender for Upper Serangoon Shopping Centre will close on September 9.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

The 99-year leasehold plot, next to Lakesiide MRT station, is zoned for residential with commercial at first storey.. It can yield about 575 private homes. The commerical component is capped at 10,764 sq ft gross floor area.
Located in District 11, the development has about 50 years left on its lease, which dates back to 1975.
Thomson View’s collective sale was met with a stop order in March.

site_title: Reimagining portfolios amid midsummer uncertainty
summary: The US-China tariff reprieve has sparked a risk rally, with investors reimagining portfolios amid midsummer uncertainty. As the July deadline for the 90-day tariff reprieve approaches, elevated volatility is expected. Industry-specific targets, including tariffs on aluminium and steel imports, will impact US businesses and metal exporters. US fiscal risks and non-tariff measures, such as the "One Big Beautiful Bill Act," also pose concerns. Investors are advised to take a strategic approach to building long-term portfolios, using dislocations as opportunities for rebalancing, and diversifying across global markets to mitigate structural risks.

images.alt_text: (From left) US Secretary of Treasury Scott Bessent and Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng shake hands as they pose for a photo during trade discussions at the Lancaster House in London, Britain, June 9, 2025.

On the first of likely two days of talks, officials from the two superpowers were meeting at the ornate Lancaster House to try to get back on track with a preliminary agreement struck last month in Geneva.

site_title: ‘Must earn a living like ordinary Malaysians’: Johor royals’ business empire spans real estate, telco and more
summary: Malaysia's Johor royal family, led by King Sultan Ibrahim Sultan Iskandar, controls an estimated US$5.7 billion in assets through various business ventures, including real estate, telecommunications, and infrastructure. Sultan Ibrahim, who has said he "must earn a living like ordinary Malaysians," has expressed his intention to pass on his business interests to his sons. The family's business empire includes Forest City, a US$100 billion property development project, as well as stakes in U Mobile, REDtone Digital, and Knusford. The Johor royal family also owns significant land in Johor, including major reclamation projects in Pengerang and Tanjung Piai.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
With dwindling foot traffic, Holland Village businesses are struggling to stay afloat.
New tenants are moving into Holland Road Shopping Centre.
Forest City will be the first location in Malaysia to offer zero per cent tax rate for family offices.
Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan (left) and the Regent of Johor, Tunku Ismail, during the commemoration ceremony held at the midpoint of the Causeway on June 28.
The Johor ruler Sultan Ibrahim Sultan Iskandar is known as a outspoken and hands-on leader.

site_title: Don’t fall for the trap of the Taco trade
summary: The Taco trade, a market strategy based on US President Donald Trump's tariff threats, has gained popularity among investors. However, experts warn that it's a flawed approach, as timing the market based on Trump's actions can lead to missed opportunities and poor returns. Research shows that even proven formulaic strategies can fail if the masses pile into the stocks, driving up prices. In contrast, investing in solid, growing companies like the FAANG stocks (Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google, and Apple) has proven to be a more reliable approach, with average returns of over 900% over the past decade.

images.alt_text: The US Capitol in Washington, DC. The US is embarking on financial deregulation at a time of high leverage and financial risk-taking. It is also continuing with high fiscal deficits while attacking its creditors via trade and fiscal policy.

site_title: US: Wall St muted at open as US-China trade talks in focus
summary: US stocks opened subdued on Tuesday as investors awaited the outcome of US-China trade talks, aiming to cool a tariff dispute. The Dow Jones fell 23.5 points, or 0.05%, to 42,738.27, while the S&P 500 rose 4.0 points, or 0.07%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 28.9 points, or 0.15%. The market's muted response was largely due to the ongoing trade talks, which have been a major concern for investors this year.

site_title: Trump says Los Angeles would burn ‘to the ground’ if no troops sent
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that deploying marines to Los Angeles was preventing the city from "burning to the ground" amid protests against immigration crackdowns. The deployment sparked outrage among Democrats, with California Governor Gavin Newsom calling Trump "dictatorial." The Trump administration escalated its response to anti-deportation protests with the mobilization of 700 marines, while California sued the administration for mobilizing National Guard troops. The situation has spread to other cities, with clashes between police and protesters reported in San Francisco, Chicago, and Washington.

images.alt_text: The remains of multiple burned Waymo vehicles are seen in the street following a night of protests in response to federal immigration operations in Los Angeles, on Jun 9.

site_title: Temasek chairman-designate Teo Chee Hean resigns from GIC board
summary: Singapore's Temasek chairman-designate Teo Chee Hean is resigning from the board of directors and International Advisory Board of the Government Investment Corporation (GIC) on June 30. Teo, 70, served on GIC's board for 14 years, including as chairman of the International Advisory Board since 2015. His departure comes after it was announced that he would become Temasek chairman on October 9, with Lim Boon Heng stepping down in his role. Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong praised Teo's contributions to GIC, citing his "calm presence" and "thoughtful interventions" during significant global developments.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Teo announced his retirement from politics on Apr 23 – shortly after nomination proceedings for the May 3 general elections closed – marking an end to a career that spanned 33 years.

Residents are transported on boats through flood waters after days of heavy rain in Tumpat in Malaysia's Kelantan state on November 30, 2024. More than 122,000 people have been forced out of their homes as massive floods caused by relentless rains swept through Malaysia's northern states, disaster officials said November 30. (Photo by MOHD RASFAN / AFP)
Bryan Yeo (left) will assume the role of CIO, while Boon Chin Hau will take on the role of CIO for infrastructure. Both appointments take effect on Apr 1.
In a Facebook post thanking SM Teo Chee Hean (left) and DPM Heng Swee Keat for their contributions, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong described them as giants in public service.

site_title: Jumbo ventures beyond chilli crab to bring famous Siji Minfu Peking duck chain to Singapore
summary: Jumbo, a Singaporean seafood restaurant group, has partnered with Chinese roast duck brand Siji Minfu to bring its signature Peking duck to Singapore. The restaurant is expected to open at Resorts World Sentosa, featuring traditional Beijing-inspired settings and flavors. This marks Siji Minfu's first overseas outlet, adding to its existing 20+ locations in China. The joint venture aims to capitalize on the growing global food and beverage sector in Singapore, aligning with Jumbo's growth strategy.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
The group noted that heightened competition in the local food and beverage sector continued to affect dining demand.

site_title: Elite UK Reit to acquire three UK government-leased assets for £9.2 million
summary: Elite UK Reit has entered into a conditional sale-and-purchase agreement to acquire three government-leased assets in the UK for £9.2 million, raising the Reit's portfolio to 151 assets. The deal is expected to be 0.6% distribution-per-unit accretive and reduce gearing by 20 basis points. The acquisition will enhance tenant diversification and strengthen the Reit's portfolio stability, with the properties generating £0.8 million in annual gross income and a 9.2% gross rental income yield.

images.alt_text: Great Western House, Birkenhead, which is part of Elite UK Reit's portfolio.

site_title: DBS raises DFI Retail Group Holding’s target price, citing strong potential to grow earnings
summary: DBS bank has raised its target price for DFI Retail Group from US$3 to US$3.60, citing a stronger and more focused business strategy. The bank maintains a "buy" rating, citing improved operational efficiency and potential for earnings growth. DFI has streamlined its operations, exiting low-margin businesses and selling stakes in associates, resulting in a 28.6% upside from its previous closing price. DBS estimates gains of over US$100 million for DFI, driven by improving operational efficiency and reduced debt levels.

images.alt_text: Scott Price, DFI Retail’s group chief executive, said the transaction representing a “significant step” in DFI’s evolution as an operating company.

site_title: Indian coast guard battles blaze on container ship
summary: The Indian Coast Guard is battling a fire on the Singapore-flagged container ship MV Wan Hai 503, which broke out on Monday off India's southern coast. The 879-foot vessel, carrying 22 crew members, is listing at 10-15 degrees and experiencing "fires and explosions." Eighteen crew members have been rescued, while four remain missing. The ship's cargo, including EVs, is reportedly damaged, and the coast guard is working to extinguish the flames with water jets. This is the second vessel to experience trouble off India's southern coast in weeks.

images.alt_text: While such ships haul thousands of vehicles at a time across the world’s oceans, a handful of significant blazes have raised concerns about transporting them.

site_title: The Day of The Jackal author Frederick Forsyth dies, aged 86
summary: British thriller writer Frederick Forsyth, known for books like "The Day of the Jackal" and "The Odessa File", has died at 86 after a brief illness. He sold over 75 million copies worldwide and many of his novels were adapted into films. Forsyth attributed his success to "luck" and credited his journalistic background for his writing style, which kept his novels contemporary and fresh. He is survived by his second wife, Sandy Molloy, and two sons.

images.alt_text: (FILES) British writer Frederick Forsyth poses for a portrait before an interview with AFP in London on September 13, 2016. 'The Day of The Jackal' author Frederick Forsyth has died at the age of 86 after a brief illness, his literary agents Curtis Brown said, June, 9. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: Private-capital funds: Depressed distributions with no end in sight
summary: Private-capital funds are facing depressed distributions with no end in sight, forcing limited partners to adjust their plans. Despite a rebound in public equities, distributions remain low due to assets acquired at premium valuations and a lack of liquidity. Recent vintages of private-capital funds are drifting from the script, with some vintages experiencing a prolonged slowdown, while others appear to be navigating a new course. The lack of distributions is bottling up assets that were once reliable candidates for exits, and LPs are increasingly looking to more mature corners of their portfolios for liquidity.

images.alt_text: Bruce Flatt, CEO, Brookfield Asset Management
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Claims that private equity consistently outperforms public markets fail to account for survivorship bias or the lack of appropriate benchmarks.

site_title: May 2025 second warmest on record: EU climate monitor
summary: The European Union's climate monitoring service reported that May 2025 was the second warmest month on record globally, with the planet's average surface temperature 1.4 degrees Celsius above preindustrial levels. This is just shy of the record set in May 2024. Ocean heatwaves drove marine species to migrate and damaged ecosystems, while the oceans' surface temperature reached 20.79 degrees Celsius, second only to May 2024. The 1.5 degree Celsius threshold, set by the 2015 Paris Agreement, is expected to be exceeded again in the near future due to continued climate warming.

images.alt_text: Allah Rakha, a 40-year-old brick moulder, cools off in a groundwater pool during a heatwave in Shujabad, Pakistan, June 4, 2025. REUTERS/Adrees Latif
FILE PHOTO: The Amazon logo is seen outside its JFK8 distribution center in Staten Island, New York, U.S. November 25, 2020. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

Nike joins a growing list of companies that includes JPMorgan Chase, Constellation Brands and Akamai Technologies that are either cancelling or delaying publication of their so-called sustainability or corporate impact reports for shareholders.
Carbon markets have been facing integrity challenges over the last few years as reports of greenwashing scandals have emerged.

site_title: The next growth engine
summary: Singapore's digital economy has advanced significantly with its Smart Nation initiative, positioning the country as a regional leader in AI. The government has committed to AI research and development, nurturing a 15,000-strong AI talent pool, and implementing strict data governance protocols to address distortions and biases. Transparency and explainability are key to building trust in AI systems, with Singapore promoting explainable AI and international cooperation through frameworks such as the Asean Guide on AI Governance and Ethics. The country is also making sustained efforts to close the digital skills gap and ensure AI growth benefits society, with initiatives such as SkillsFuture and TechSkills Accelerator.

images.alt_text: 资讯通信媒体发展局与万态保育集团（Mandai Wildlife Group）合作，2025年第一季在万态野生动物世界推出可安排在户外和全地形的自主移动机器人（Autonomous Mobile Robots，简称AMRs）试点计划。右为礼宾机器人“丹”，它将在动物园入口处和停车场的上下车点之间服务，与游客通过语音互动、推荐景点、指路与路径导航等。左为巡逻机器人，它将在动物园与河川生态园外围2025年首季开放、长达3.3公里的木步道上巡逻。

site_title: Gold’s status from ‘theoretical’ to ‘tactical’ hedge
summary: Gold's status as a hedge has shifted from theoretical to tactical, with central banks now treating it as a strategic asset due to its representation of political neutrality and security. The metal has seen consecutive years of elevated demand, with net purchases of 365 tonnes in the final quarter of 2024, driven by concerns over trade tensions, fiscal profligacy, and global partnerships. As a result, gold is emerging as a core pillar of portfolio stability, with many central banks planning to increase their gold allocations, marking a long-term strategic shift in reserve management strategy.

images.alt_text: Spot gold fell 0.5 per cent to US$3,311.16 an ounce, as of 0125 GMT.
FILE PHOTO: Gold bars are displayed at a gold jewellery shop in the northern Indian city of Chandigarh May 8, 2012. REUTERS/Ajay Verma/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: UK employment drops most since 2020 and wage growth cools
summary: UK employment dropped the most since 2020, with 276,000 fewer employees on payroll as of May, following Labour's payroll tax hike and minimum wage increase. Private-sector wage growth slowed to 5.1% from 5.5%, the lowest pace in seven months. The decline in employment and wage growth ease concerns about inflation fuelled by higher wage growth.

site_title: Thai tech services outlook remains positive amid recession fears: analyst
summary: Maybank Securities analyst Wasu Mattanapotchanart has highlighted tech consulting company Bluebik as the top pick for growth in Thailand's technology services sector. The company is expected to see 16% and 25% core profit growth in FY2025 and FY2026, respectively, driven by increased engagement with core clients and government projects. Bluebik's revenue contribution from government projects is projected to rise from under 5% in FY2024 to approximately 10% in FY2025. The analyst also reiterated a "buy" call on Bluebik with a target price of 39.9 baht, citing the company's competitive pricing and expansion into foreign markets.

images.alt_text: Young Zhan Heng
“The digital wallet has not been cancelled, but we need to review how to use this money to stimulate the economy as much as possible,” Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra said.
Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a parliament session on the budget for 2026 fiscal year in Bangkok on 28 May.
Thailand faces challenges including the tariff threat from the US, as well as structural issues such as ageing and high household debts, notes Euben Paracuelles of Nomura.

site_title: Changi Airport awards S$999 million contract for T5 intra-terminal tunnels
summary: Changi Airport Group has awarded a S$999 million contract to a joint venture between Penta-Ocean Construction and Koh Brothers Eco Engineering for the construction of intra-terminal tunnels at Terminal 5. The tunnels will support passenger and baggage transfer across concourses and facilitate utility routing. The project, expected to take over four years to complete, will also include a ventilation building and future underground infrastructure tunnel. The terminal's completion is expected to increase Changi Airport's annual capacity to 140 million passengers, solidifying its position as one of Asia's "mega airports".

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Height restriction requirements around airports are being revised after a review, which aims to free up more airspace for developments.
Passenger movements in Changi Airport reached a record 68.4 million in FY2024.
An artist’s impression of Changi Airport Terminal 5.

site_title: Why is modern commerce corrosive?
summary: Philosopher Alasdair MacIntyre argued that modern commerce is corrosive because it prioritizes profit over shared values, community, and excellence. He described two fishing crews: one focused solely on profit, and the other on excellence, skill, and social bonds. MacIntyre's ideas have been explored in various works, including his book "After Virtue," which posits that clear thinking and virtuous action require a social context. The author cites examples, such as Lehman Brothers and ICI, where prioritizing profit led to failure, and argues that profitability can also rest on shared values and practices.

images.alt_text: In the 1990s, the Lego Group suffered a crisis as management diversified into clothes, watches, publications, TV, learning labs and theme parks, even as low-cost competitors attacked its core business of building blocks.

site_title: Top India dealmakers earn 37% more than Singapore peers
summary: Senior dealmakers in India earn 37% more than their counterparts in Singapore and 24% more than those in Hong Kong, according to a Bloomberg Intelligence report. This is due to a rebound in investments and global firms boosting pay to attract top talent in India, the world's fastest-growing major economy. Despite higher income tax rates, India's lower cost of living may be a draw, with foreign lenders expanding in the country and merger and acquisition volumes picking up.

images.alt_text: The cuts are meant to give the Barclays more capacity to invest in priority areas.

site_title: Malaysian Court grants Anwar bid to pause civil lawsuit
summary: A Malaysian Court of Appeal granted Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim's application to pause a civil lawsuit by a former aide, Yusoff Rawther, who alleges he was sexually assaulted in 2018. The court decision, made in a unanimous decision, temporarily stays proceedings of the trial. Anwar is appealing a High Court decision that had set a June 16 trial date and is separately appealing a court decision on whether a sitting prime minister can be sued. The pause gives Anwar time to appeal the High Court decision and seek clarity from the Federal Court on the issue.

site_title: US: Stocks advance as China trade talks drag on
summary: US stocks advanced on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.3% to 42,866.87, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 0.6% each. The US-China trade talks continued in London without a concrete announcement, despite upbeat comments from Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick. The World Bank lowered its 2025 global GDP growth forecast to 2.3% due to trade tensions and policy uncertainty. Individual stocks such as Disney, Tesla, and Intel also saw significant gains.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on June 2, 2025, in New York City. Oil prices surged Monday over renewed concerns about Russia's war in Ukraine and relief over OPEC+ production, while stock markets mostly slumped as US-China trade tensions resurfaced. The dollar was under pressure while Wall Street opened mixed, with the Dow and the broad-based S&P 500 in the red while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Tencent Music to buy Chinese audio platform Ximalaya for US$2.4 billion
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group agreed to acquire Chinese audio platform Ximalaya for approximately $2.4 billion in cash and stock. The deal includes $1.26 billion in cash and up to 5.20% of Tencent's outstanding shares. Ximalaya, which has 303 million monthly active users, counts Tencent, Baidu, and Sony as backers. The acquisition aims to expand Tencent's content library and attract more paying users. US-listed shares of Tencent rose 7% following the announcement.

site_title: Prudential, Sino Biopharm among top stock picks for Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian has updated its alpha picks for June, focusing on domestic catalysts and high-growth opportunities in Hong Kong, Indonesia, and Malaysia. In Hong Kong, Prudential and Sino Biopharm have been added to the "buy" list, driven by strong clinical progress and innovative drugs. In Indonesia, the focus has shifted to consumer-related, "safe-haven" and high-growth stocks, with picks including Central Omega Resources, Cisarua Mountain Dairy, and Sumber Alfaria Trijaya. In Malaysia, domestically driven catalysts such as the Penang LRT project and strong earnings from Duopharma and NorthEast are expected to drive growth.

images.alt_text: Digital Core Reit's data centre in Osaka.  UOB Kay Hian believes the advent of new reasoning AI models will drive the next wave of demand for data centres.
The sale of South Beach development would have unlocked S$465 million in disposal gains for the property development firm

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Kim Heng
summary: Independent directors of Great Eastern Holdings are recommending shareholders accept OCBC's conditional exit offer, leading to the insurer's delisting on Jul 8. OCBC shares rose 0.6% on Monday. Kim Heng, an offshore marine services contractor, has partnered with Singapore Energy Interconnections to cooperate on submarine power projects in the Asean region.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng to plead guilty on Jul 3, in case involving former minister Iswaran
summary: Property tycoon Ong Beng Seng is expected to plead guilty on July 3 to two charges related to former transport minister S Iswaran. Ong faces one charge of abetting offences under Section 165 of the Penal Code and one charge of abetting the obstruction of justice. He allegedly offered Iswaran a trip to Doha in December 2022, worth $13,137, and instructed the Singapore GP director to bill Iswaran for a business-class ticket. Ong has been diagnosed with multiple myeloma and his guilty plea was rescheduled to allow him to obtain further medical reports.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Former transport minister S. Iswaran was placed on the Home Detention Scheme on Feb 7.

site_title: Community Chest has had to evolve to meet society’s increasingly complex needs: Chew Sutat
summary: Community Chest, a Singapore-based philanthropic organization, is evolving to meet the complex needs of society. Chairman Chew Sutat notes that while the government funds most social services, budgets are limited, making private and public collaborations crucial. To address this, Community Chest is transitioning from just fundraising to a long-term resourcing approach, pooling resources with various sources for larger projects. Collaboration between the public, private, and people sectors is key, according to Chew, who emphasizes that "doing good is good business" and that institutionalizing giving back to society is essential for a sustainable economy.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
About 1,000 bamboo sticks are strung together to light up the Bridge of 1,000 Dreams.

site_title: US tech giant Qualcomm opens AI R&D centre in Vietnam, its third largest after India, Ireland
summary: Qualcomm has opened its third-largest artificial intelligence (AI) research and development centre in Hanoi, Vietnam, following its acquisition of a GenAI unit from Vietnam's Vingroup in April. The new centre aims to develop generative AI and agentic AI solutions for various sectors, leveraging Vietnam's talent pool. This move strengthens Qualcomm's presence in Vietnam and aligns with the country's strategy to attract global tech giants. The centre will be led by Dr. Bui Hai Hung, former CEO of VinAI, and will contribute to shaping Qualcomm's AI research at the global level.

images.alt_text: Jamille Tran
The latest deal is expected to expedite Qualcomm’s creation of advanced AI solutions for products such as smartphones, PCs, and software-defined vehicles, says the US tech firm.

From left to right: Nvidia Executive Vice President for Worldwide Field Operations Jay Puri, Nvidia Chief Executive Officer Jensen Huang; Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, and Minister of Planning and Investment Nguyen Chi Dung
Vietnam lures global tech giants with high-tech workforce push
Truong Quoc Hung, chief executive at VinBrain and Kimberly Powell, vice president of healthcare at Nvidia at the headquarters of Nvidia in the US in March, 2023.

site_title: All the wrong moves for British homeowners
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a severe crisis, with homelessness nearly 40% higher than France and a 14% annual growth rate in those without a permanent home. The law of unintended regulatory, fiscal, and monetary consequences has stopped investment in its tracks, with average home values stagnating or falling in real terms. Housing associations, which provide social housing, are struggling to maintain their portfolios due to increased costs and are unable to expand, resulting in tens of thousands of new homes going unsold. To alleviate the crisis, local councils and the central government are providing limited grants to help housing associations, but the fundamental issue remains that private investors are being discouraged from playing a role, leading to a contraction in UK building activity.

images.alt_text: The figures chime with other housing market indicators pointing to its resilience despite a rise in the stamp duty at the start of April after a temporary cut expired.

site_title: China, South Korea must safeguard free trade, Xi tells Lee
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping urged South Korea's new President Lee Jae Myung to work together to uphold free trade and defend "multilateralism" in a phone call, aiming to strengthen their strategic cooperative partnership. Xi emphasized the importance of maintaining a healthy and stable relationship between China and South Korea, which aligns with the trend of the times. The call comes as South Korea navigates its trade relationship with China and the US, which has been affected by US President Donald Trump's tariff blitz.

images.alt_text: The rare-earths dispute revealed how important those supplies, which Beijing dominates, are for the US economy.
Foreign tourists shop at an Olive Young store in Seoul, South Korea, April 28, 2025.

site_title: Oil prices hit multi-week highs amid US-China trade talks
summary: Oil prices reached multi-week highs, with Brent crude futures rising 57 cents to $67.04 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rising 71 cents to $65.29 a barrel. The stronger US dollar and a weaker dollar helped boost prices, while investors await news from US-China trade talks, which could support the global economic outlook and fuel demand. A potential trade deal could also outweigh concerns over increased OPEC+ production.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were flat at US$66.47 a barrel.

site_title: New Zealand finance minister would like RBNZ to return to eight meetings a year
summary: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis has expressed her desire for the Reserve Bank of New Zealand to return to its eight meetings a year, citing the lengthy gap between meetings, particularly during the summer. The current seven meetings a year have resulted in a nearly three-month year-end break. Willis believes this more frequent meeting schedule would provide policymakers with more flexibility to respond to economic conditions.

The decision was in line with a Reuters poll where all but one of the 30 economists surveyed forecast the Reserve Bank of New Zealand would cut the cash rate for the sixth successive meeting.
The RBNZ will publish its decision at 2 pm local time on Wednesday and governor Christian Hawkesby will hold a press conference an hour later.

site_title: Europe: Equities ease as US-China trade talks grip markets
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 closed slightly lower at 553.24 points on Monday, ending its four-session winning streak, as investors remained cautious ahead of US-China trade talks in London. The utilities sector declined, pressured by a slide in Eurozone bonds. China offered to accelerate rare earth exports to EU firms, but markets remained cautious, with analysts citing the potential for rapid changes in the talks. The sector of automakers, vulnerable to rare earth supply disruptions, remained flat.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished flat at 42,761.76 on Monday.

site_title: China-led deflation looms as Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia see declining inflation
summary: Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia are experiencing declining inflation, with Thailand's May inflation rate falling 0.57% for the second straight month. Experts believe this deflation may be premature, attributed to easing supply-side pressures rather than weakening demand. US tariffs have led to inventory buildup in China, potentially forcing producers to cut prices in export markets, including Asean countries. This could have a positive impact on economies in the region, but the Bank of America warns of underlying economic slack.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, June 10, 2025
summary: Asian markets continued their gains on Tuesday, driven by China-US trade talks, with Australia shares closing at a record high. Oil prices surged to multi-week highs amid the talks, while China-led deflation looms in Thailand, Indonesia, and Malaysia. In Singapore, the Q3 hiring outlook remains mixed, according to ManpowerGroup.

images.alt_text: Tokyo led gains in Asian markets, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington and Jakarta stocks also up on Tuesday.
The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.8 per cent to 8,587.20 points, a closing high.

site_title: Grab, GoTo deny merger discussions but speculation fuels fears over foreign control, state involvement
summary: Indonesia's tech giants GoTo and Grab have denied merger talks, sparking concerns over foreign control and state involvement in the digital economy. The potential merger has raised worries about market concentration, regulatory uncertainty, and employment fallout. The Indonesian government's involvement through its sovereign wealth fund, Danantara, has added complexity, with analysts warning that state-backed investments could blur the lines between regulator and operator. The episode has also highlighted the need for fair market practices and the protection of domestic interests in the face of foreign influence.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Danantara is said to be interested in participating in the Grab acquisition of GoTo reported Bloomberg.

site_title: Ho Bee Land shares surge after Chua Thian Poh buys spark talk of privatisation plan
summary: Ho Bee Land shares surged 5% after founder Chua Thian Poh increased his stake in the company to 75.68%, raising speculation about a potential privatisation plan. Chua and his son Nicholas, CEO, have been buying shares in recent months. The company's shares closed at S$1.89, with its UK portfolio valued at £1.7 billion (S$3 billion). The sudden increase in Chua's stake has sparked talk of a potential privatisation plan, although the company has not made any official announcements.

images.alt_text: Ho Bee Land reported a net profit of S$109.7 million for the year ended December 2024 driven by the growth of development property sales in Australia and contributions from the sale of a 49 per cent stake in Elementum.

site_title: Hong Kong leader says national security scrutiny of restaurants is necessary
summary: Hong Kong's leader, John Lee, announced that the city will intensify screening of catering premises to ensure compliance with national security laws. This move is seen as targeting pro-democracy businesses that have displayed solidarity with the embattled movement. Civil servants are expected to prioritize national security when evaluating licence approvals. The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department will follow the law in considering new and existing licences. The crackdown on dissent has drawn criticism from countries such as Australia, Britain, Canada, and the US.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong chief executive John Lee speaking at the opening of the Asian Financial Forum in Hong Kong on 11 January 2023.
Some market watchers have called for switching Hong Kong’s US dollar peg to the yuan at a time when trade tensions between the world’s two largest economies have created uncertainty.

site_title: German consumers’ pessimism rises amid economic, political concerns: survey
summary: German consumers' economic and political sentiment worsens, with 62% viewing the economic situation negatively, up 10 percentage points from last year. Two-thirds express dissatisfaction with the political climate. Concerns about personal finances rise to 31%, despite declining inflation rates. However, 70% fear further price increases, while geopolitical risks are perceived as lower. Experts attribute consumers' pessimism to underestimating the impact of trade conflicts on prices and supply.

images.alt_text: There is a “window of opportunity” to increase the international role of the euro, according to ECB.

“The problem is this lack of predictability, which is doing us massive damage – it prevents companies from investing, hiring and training people,” Federal Employment Agency chief Andrea Nahles told the newspaper.
Although the revision will be welcome, US President Donald Trump’s volatile trade policy still threatens to hurt economic growth in the EU.

site_title: Indonesia revokes licences of four nickel miners in tourism hot spot Raja Ampat amid environmental backlash
summary: Indonesia has revoked the mining licenses of four nickel producers in Raja Ampat, a tourism hot spot known for its biodiversity, amid public protests over environmental concerns. The four companies, which had operated in the region since 2017, failed to comply with administrative regulations and submit work plan proposals. The government has also temporarily suspended the permit of Gag Nikel, a nickel miner operating outside the geopark, but will maintain close oversight to ensure compliance. The move aims to protect the region's marine life and conservation areas.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
Indonesia plans to add 6 GW of coal-fired power capacity over the next nine years.

site_title: Bank of Japan vows to keep raising rates if underlying inflation accelerates
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has reaffirmed its commitment to raising interest rates if underlying inflation accelerates, with governor Kazuo Ueda stating the central bank will continue to adjust monetary support until demand-driven price pressure reaches 2% target. The BOJ has kept real interest rates negative to achieve this goal, despite core consumer inflation exceeding the target for three years. The next policy meeting is expected to keep interest rates steady at 0.5%, but Ueda emphasized the need to be mindful of the zero lower bound to avoid limiting tools in case of a recession.

images.alt_text: Japan is contending with a barrage of US tariffs, including a blanket 10 per cent duty on its goods that will rise to 24 per cent in early July barring a trade deal.

Renewed rise in food prices, particularly a 90 per cent spike in the price of rice, is pushing up not just headline but underlying inflation, which is typically influenced mostly by improvements in the economy and a tight job market, Kazuo Ueda said.

site_title: Huawei chips are one generation behind US but firm is finding workarounds: CEO
summary: Huawei's CEO, Ren Zhengfei, stated that the company's chips are one generation behind those of US peers, but is finding workarounds through methods like cluster computing. Despite export controls, Huawei has marketed its Ascend series of artificial intelligence chips, competing with US rival Nvidia. Ren acknowledged the US has exaggerated Huawei's achievements, but believes the company can improve performance through research and innovative methods.

On Monday, Starmer will announce an £187 million programme to improve the AI skills of British workers and students.

US President Donald Trump’s trade policies have created much uncertainty for the global chip industry and TSMC, the top producer of the world’s most advanced semiconductors whose customers include Apple and Nvidia.

site_title: Trump says China ‘not easy’ as trade talks to resume on Tuesday
summary: US President Trump said China "is not easy" as trade talks between the two nations resume on Tuesday, with the US delegation led by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick meeting Chinese Vice-Premier He Lifeng in London. The talks aim to ease tensions over technology and rare earth element shipments, with the US potentially removing restrictions on some tech exports in exchange for assurances from China. Trump expressed optimism, stating "we are doing well with China" and promising that any export controls will be eased and rare earths will be released in volume after the talks.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished flat at 42,761.76 on Monday.

New York’s Dow and S&P 500 indices were lower, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose slightly in early trading.

site_title: Japan’s ruling camp to pledge cash handouts in election campaigns: local media
summary: Japan's ruling coalition, the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), has agreed to include a plan for cash handouts in their election campaign pledges to help households cope with inflation. The plan, which was shelved in April due to concerns over its effectiveness, aims to distribute cash to recipients without an income threshold. The move is seen as a response to growing calls from opposition parties for tax cuts, which could strain the government's finances. The LDP and its junior partner Komeito will discuss details of the plan, including the amount of the handouts.

site_title: Apple plays it safe on AI despite Wall Street pressure
summary: Apple has played it safe by not embracing generative AI at its annual Worldwide Developers Conference, despite Wall Street pressure. The company announced incremental updates to its Apple Intelligence software, allowing app makers to access device AI capabilities, but Siri's AI makeover remains under development. Analysts warn that Apple's cautious approach may be costly in the long term, as rivals like Google and Samsung move ahead with on-device AI capabilities. The stock has declined 17% since the start of the year, wiping over $600 billion from its market value.

images.alt_text: Tim Cook's tenure as Apple's CEO is seen as being marked by the steady ascendancy of “process over product”. Instead of flashy innovations, his hallmark has been metronomic reliability, especially with regard to financial performance.

site_title: Employers in Singapore see more hirings and firings in Q3, says ManpowerGroup
summary: Singapore's hiring outlook for the third quarter of 2025 is mixed, with 43% of employers expecting an increase in hiring, but 19% anticipating a fall in staffing levels. The healthcare and life sciences sector has the brightest employment outlook, while the consumer goods and services sector has the weakest. Employers cited company expansion and the need for skills to stay competitive as primary drivers of hiring, while economic challenges and adapting to market changes were cited as top reasons for workforce reductions. The net employment outlook fell to 24% for Q3, from 27% in the previous quarter.

site_title: A luxury travel bubble is swelling
summary: The luxury travel industry is facing an economic bubble that may burst as aspirational travelers, defined as those with $100,000 to $1 million in net worth, spend $84 billion on high-end vacations in 2023, expected to grow to $107 billion by 2028. However, economic uncertainty and a cultural shift normalizing luxury travel may lead to a decline in spending. Industry experts warn that the ultra-rich may continue to book luxury travel even in a slowing economy, but aspirational travelers may trade down to economy-class seats or budget hotels, potentially causing a bubble to burst.

site_title: Singapore and Johor Regent swop prime Holland Road land plots as royal family eyes development
summary: Singapore and the Regent of Johor have agreed to swap a 13-ha state land parcel along Holland Road for a 13-ha plot in the same area belonging to the Johor royal family. The land swop aims to minimize disruption to the Singapore Botanic Gardens UNESCO site. The Regent will own 16.6 ha of land after the swop, and the state land parcel will be transferred to the Regent with a freehold tenure. The development plans for the Regent's land are expected to be less disruptive to the gardens.

site_title: China taps pool of funds worth 10.9 trillion yuan to prop up housing market
summary: China's housing provident fund, worth 10.9 trillion yuan, is being tapped to prop up the housing market amid profit challenges faced by banks. The fund, which allows employees and employers to contribute monthly into a pool that gives out mortgages at lower interest rates, has outpaced banks in giving out loans. As banks cut back, the provident fund has become an increasingly important means of financing home purchases, with 33% of residential mortgages in Beijing financed by the fund last year. The central bank recently cut interest rates on provident fund mortgages, making it 0.9 percentage points cheaper than bank mortgages.

site_title: Asia: Markets extend gains as China-US talks head into second day
summary: Asian markets extended gains on Tuesday as US-China trade talks entered their second day, with optimism growing over potential agreements. Tokyo led the gains, followed by Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other Asian stocks. Donald Trump's top economic adviser, Kevin Hassett, expressed confidence in a "big, strong handshake" and eased export controls, potentially easing rare earth mineral exports. The US stock market also edged closer to a record high, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh levels.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed slightly lower at 553.24 points on Monday, after four straight sessions of gains, its longest consecutive winning streak in three weeks.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished flat at 42,761.76 on Monday.

site_title: Can Tim Cook stop Apple going the same way as Nokia?
summary: Tim Cook's leadership at Apple has been marked by steady financial performance, but the company's AI strategy has failed to deliver, with Siri's overhaul postponed and Apple Intelligence struggling to compete with other voice-activated AI assistants. Apple's shares have lagged behind its tech peers, and the company faces new legal and regulatory challenges, including a potential suspension of payments from Google due to antitrust concerns. Cook's tenure may be likened to that of Jack Welch, CEO of General Electric, which eventually lost its way. Apple's response is expected to be incremental, with Cook possibly rethinking the company's obsession with privacy and exploring new AI opportunities.

images.alt_text: Apple has been working on adding cameras to its AirPods and smartwatches, aiming to turn those products into AI products well.

site_title: Gold falls as traders watch US-China trade talks in London
summary: Gold prices fell 0.5% to $3,311.16 an ounce as US-China trade talks in London entered their second day, with discussions on tariffs and rare earth restrictions. US President Donald Trump reported progress in the talks, but market participants remain cautious. If a broader trade deal is reached, safe-haven demand for gold could ease. Investors await US inflation data on Wednesday for further cues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy path.

site_title: Australia business activity stalls in May as retailers squeezed: survey
summary: Australian business activity stalled in May, with National Australia Bank's survey showing its index of business conditions edged down 2 points to 0, below the long-run average of +6. Retail businesses reported increased pressure on profit margins, while consumers remained reluctant to spend despite interest rate cuts. The sales index dipped a point to +5, employment dropped 4 points to 0, and profitability stayed weak at -4. The survey suggests the Reserve Bank of Australia may need to ease again in July to support the economy.

site_title: US-China trade talks in London hang over markets
summary: US-China trade talks in London on June 9 aimed to ease tariff tensions between Washington and Beijing. The negotiations, following a call between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, led to Asian stocks rising and Wall Street trading mixed. China's exports to the US grew at a slower pace than expected, while the US dollar remained largely unchanged due to concerns over higher US inflation. The outcome of the talks will be crucial for market sentiment, with easing China's export controls on rare-earths seen as key for Washington.

images.alt_text: The US is threatening to raise tariffs on many countries from early July and on China from August.

site_title: Global convergence of sustainability disclosure standards – what boards need to know
summary: Global sustainability disclosure standards have converged, providing a clear, transparent, and comparable framework for companies to report their ESG impacts, risks, and opportunities. The International Sustainability Standards Board (ISSB) has established a global baseline of sustainability disclosures tailored to capital market needs, streamlining reporting for companies and enhancing comparability for investors. Board directors must grasp the technical details of these disclosures, especially under IFRS S2, which requires companies to disclose both qualitative and quantitative financial impacts of climate-related risks and opportunities. The convergence aims to empower investors and capital providers to make smarter decisions.

site_title: China’s solar industry gathers as gloom deepens over demand
summary: China's solar industry faces a looming demand drop, threatening an already oversupplied market. The industry's record growth in China masks brutal economics, with collapsing margins and mounting protectionism. Despite a surge in installations in April, driven by developers front-loading projects, demand is likely to decline in the second half of the year. Equipment makers may struggle to recognize boom conditions, with five of the biggest names reporting a combined loss of over 8 billion yuan in the first quarter. However, the government's commitment to renewables and market-based pricing may help the industry recover later in the year.

site_title: Vietnam attracts global manufacturers despite US tariff increases
summary: Vietnam continues to attract global manufacturers despite US tariff increases, driven by policy incentives, improving infrastructure, and its strategic role in the global supply chain shift away from China. The country's manufacturing sector has shown early signs of stabilization, with its May manufacturing purchasing managers' index recovering slightly. Foreign investment surged 39.9% year-over-year, with US$8.9 billion flowing into manufacturing and US$2.8 billion into real estate. However, challenges remain, including complicated approval procedures, land acquisition issues, and poor inter-regional connectivity. Vietnam's land supply system differs from China's, with higher prices and longer acquisition timelines.

site_title: Shareholders to vote on Great Eastern delisting on Jul 8
summary: Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) will hold an extraordinary general meeting on July 8 to vote on a conditional exit offer by OCBC, which would lead to the insurer's delisting if approved by 75% of shareholders. The independent financial adviser EY has advised that the exit offer price of S$30.15 per share is "fair and reasonable." If the delisting proposal is not accepted, shareholders will vote on two alternate resolutions to facilitate GEH's resumption of trading.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The Great Eastern Life Insurance buliding
After a long trading suspension, GEH’s minorities now have certainty: the insurer will either be delisted with an exit offer of S$30.15, or trading in its shares will resume.
The offer comes months after OCBC first made a privatisation bid for Great Eastern through a voluntary unconditional general offer at S$25.60 per share.

site_title: Asia healthcare assets risk overvaluation as private investors scoop them up
summary: Private equity investors are pouring money into Asian healthcare assets, with some observers concerned that the sector could soon overheat due to macroeconomic uncertainty and high valuations. Recent deals include KKR's US$400 million purchase of a stake in India's Healthcare Global Enterprises and TPG's acquisition of a nursing operator in Singapore. Despite rising valuations, market participants point out that there is still room for growth in the sector, driven by demand for healthcare services in countries such as Japan, South Korea, and India. However, investors will need to have a clear plan to create meaningful impact and value over the life of their investments to avoid overvaluation.

site_title: Australia shares close at record high
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.8% to a record high of 8,587.20 points, driven by gains in banks and energy stocks amid optimism over US-China trade talks. The benchmark closed on Monday for a public holiday. Heavyweight financials led gains, with the country's "Big Four" banks rising 0.9-1.5%. Energy stocks also surged, fueled by rising oil prices and signs of easing trade tensions. The rally was seen as a positive outcome for investors, who are hopeful that a deal would spur economic activity in China and brighten prospects domestically.

images.alt_text: Shareholders of Great Eastern, OCBC's insurer arm, will be voting on the company's delisting on July 8.

site_title: End of the bromance: Will Trump and Musk kiss and make up?
summary: US President Donald Trump and billionaire Elon Musk's public feud has escalated, with Musk calling Trump's signature tax-and-spending bill a "disgusting abomination". The break-up between the two is seen as inevitable, but some in Washington speculate that they may try to mend their relationship to limit business and political damage. The exact reason for the delay is unclear, but the public spat has been described as an "entertaining, if astonishing, political spectacle".

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said in a televised Oval Office diatribe that he was "very disappointed" after his former aide and top donor Elon Musk criticised his "big, beautiful" spending bill before Congress. The verbal punches erupted on Thursday after Trump criticised Musk in the Oval Office and the pair then traded barbs on their social media platforms: Trump’s Truth Social and Musk’s X.

site_title: Barclays cuts more than 200 investment bank jobs to reduce costs
summary: Barclays is cutting over 200 jobs in its investment bank, about 3% of its headcount, to reduce costs and boost profitability. The move primarily affects managing directors and staff in investment banking, global markets, and research. The cuts aim to give the bank more capacity to invest in priority areas, including European rates, equity derivatives, and securitised product trading. The reduction is part of CEO CS Venkatakrishnan's plan to achieve £2 billion in efficiency savings by 2026 and boost earnings.

images.alt_text: The strong performance from Barclays’ investment bank matched US rivals that have reported bumper profits so far this year.

site_title: DBS tops US$100 billion market value in Singapore Exchange first
summary: DBS Group Holdings has become the first listed company in Singapore to surpass a US$100 billion market value, driven by a softer US currency and gains in its wealth management business. The bank's market capitalisation reached S$129.2 billion, with a 4% gain this year, making it the third-largest wealth manager in Asia, excluding mainland China. At 22nd among global banks, DBS ranks ahead of Tokyo-based Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group but behind HSBC Holdings.

site_title: Two BTS megastars released from South Korea military
summary: K-pop megastars RM and V from BTS were released from South Korean military service on June 10, 2025, after 18 months of mandatory service. The two members, who are part of the world's most popular boy band, expressed their desire to perform again soon, stating they are working hard on a new album. The release of RM and V marks the beginning of the end of BTS's hiatus, with four members expected to complete their service this week. Fans gathered outside the military bases, eager to welcome their idols back to civilian life, and analysts expect a BTS reunion tour and comeback this year.

site_title: China’s WeRide, Malaysia’s Causeway Link among firms bidding to run driverless public buses in S’pore
summary: Four companies, including WeRide (Singapore) and a Malaysian consortium led by Causeway Link, have submitted bids to participate in a trial of autonomous public bus services in Singapore. The Land Transport Authority (LTA) plans to start the trial in mid-2026, initially operating alongside existing manned buses for three years. The trial will assess the feasibility of self-driving technology for public bus services, with the aim of addressing manpower challenges in the sector. The LTA will evaluate proposals based on technology maturity, record, and operational needs, and may expand the trial to two more routes if successful.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as US-China trade talks begin
summary: US stocks rose at the open on Monday, June 9, as investors watched US-China trade talks begin. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 23.3 points, or 0.05%, to 42,786.19, while the S&P 500 rose 4.3 points, or 0.07%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 43.2 points, or 0.22%. The positive start is attributed to hopes for a resolution in the trade rift, which has impacted financial markets.
