site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 9)
summary: Singapore's residential property market remains a key focus, with Good Class Bungalows (GCB) Areas at its peak. OCBC made a conditional exit offer for Great Eastern, while CapitaLand Investment secured additional capital commitments for its lodging private fund. City Developments Ltd (CDL) sold its majority stake in South Beach, but high debt and interest costs remain a concern. Local stocks rose ahead of US-China trade talks, and Singapore ranked as the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year.

site_title: Warner Bros plans to split streaming, cable TV businesses
summary: Warner Bros Discovery is splitting into two publicly traded companies: one with its HBO Max streaming service and film/TV business, and the other with its struggling cable business, Global Networks. The split aims to pursue investment opportunities and drive shareholder value, with CEO David Zaslav heading the streaming business and CFO Gunnar Wiedenfels leading the cable division. The move is expected to be completed by mid-2026 and will unwind the 2022 merger between AT&T's WarnerMedia and Discovery.

images.alt_text: The Shanghai venture would mark Warner Bros’ third “Harry Potter Studio Tour” worldwide after sites in London and Tokyo.
The studios and OpenAI have not settled on a deal framework that would work for both sides financially.
The abrupt move comes just days after Disney appeared to have removed one legal obstacle to the deal, agreeing to merge smaller streamer FuboTV .

Arriving in Asia after its peers, New York-based Warner Bros is partnering with local platforms to efficiently build loyalty for its streaming content and increase subscribers without heavy initial investments.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, June 9, 2025
summary: Asian markets rallied ahead of China-US trade talks, with key gains seen in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Taiwan. Japan confirmed its GDP contraction, aligning with the Bank of Japan's cautious stance on monetary policy. CapitaLand Investment expanded its fund with a 30 billion yen Japan asset acquisition. These developments suggest a positive sentiment in the region, driven by the upcoming trade talks and economic data.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.
Optimism that the two sides will make a breakthrough boosted Asian markets, with Hong Kong up more than one per cent, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Manila also advanced.
Japan is contending with a barrage of US tariffs, including a blanket 10 per cent duty on its goods that will rise to 24 per cent in early July barring a trade deal.

The newly acquired asset is located in Shinjuku, one of Tokyo's most popular districts for shopping, entertainment and business. The property comprises of hotel, residential, and ancillary office and retail components.

site_title: Is Ho Bee Land privatisation back on cards with founder Chua Thian Poh raising stake?
summary: Ho Bee Land's founder Chua Thian Poh increased his stake in the real estate company to around 75.68% after buying 137,900 shares for S$248,220. The company's shares rose 5% on the news, with some speculating that this could be a sign of a potential privatization offer. Despite the recent increase in his stake, Chua declined to comment on whether the company plans to go private. The company has been making changes to its board and staff in recent months, leading some to speculate that it may be shifting towards a more corporate structure.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
Elementum, Ho Bee Land’s landmark biomedical life-science development.

site_title: Starbucks joins China price war with discounts for tea drinks
summary: Starbucks has launched a price cut campaign in China, offering discounts on tea-based beverages such as Frappuccinos, iced teas, and tea lattes. The price reductions, averaging 5 yuan (S$0.89 cents), aim to appeal to Chinese consumers and compete with local tea chains. The move is part of Starbucks' strategy to diversify its offerings and meet the changing needs of Chinese customers, who increasingly prefer non-coffee drinks during the summer months.

site_title: S&P downgrades Warner Bros bonds deeper into junk status
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded Warner Bros Discovery's unsecured bonds to BB, the second-highest junk rating, from BB+ due to the media company's plan to split up and refinance $14 billion of debt using secured bridge financing. This move negatively affects the recovery prospects for the company's unsecured debt, which totals $35.5 billion. The downgrade follows the announcement of the breakup, which separates the fast-growing streaming business from struggling legacy media channels.

site_title: EV maker VinFast’s Q1 loss widens on higher spending as deliveries rise
summary: Vietnamese electric vehicle maker VinFast reported a net loss of $712.4 million for the first quarter, widening 15% from the previous year. Revenue jumped 150% to $656.5 million, driven by a 300% increase in deliveries to 36,330 vehicles. VinFast continues to face challenges due to weak consumer demand, competition, and a 25% US tariff on imported vehicles. The company is shifting focus to Asia and intensifying promotional efforts domestically to boost sales.

images.alt_text: VinFast has been bleeding cash since it shipped its first vehicles to the US in late 2022.
Startup VinFast is pursuing an aggressive but costly expansion strategy in Vietnam, where it can rely on a growing market of nearly 100 million people.
BYD’s entrance in July into Vietnam underscores both the opportunities and challenges Chinese companies face as they seek to push into South-east Asia.
The new VinFast VF 6 at India's auto show in New Delhi; the company not disclose pricing for the VF6 and VF7 cars that it plans to launch in India.
The automaker delivered 44,773 cars during the first nine months of this year, just over 55 per cent of its target of 80,000 units for the year.

site_title: Malaysia to expand services tax from July 1 to trim deficit
summary: Malaysia is expanding its sales and service tax to include construction and financial services sectors, effective July 1, in an effort to narrow its fiscal deficit target to 3.8% of GDP. The tax rates will be 8% for financial services and 6% for construction services, with exemptions for certain sectors. The move aims to generate additional revenue without burdening the majority of the people, with the additional revenue expected to benefit the entire country.

images.alt_text: The Thai economy will probably post growth of 2.4 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier, down from the previous forecast of a 2.8 per cent expansion.
Amidst a Q1 economic growth meeting expectations but Bank Negara's caution over trade policy uncertainties dampening the outlook.
While the economy had performed well in the first quarter, the balance of risks to the growth outlook was tilted to the downside, Bank Negara Malaysia said.
Rafizi said he welcomes challengers to the deputy presidency position that he currently holds in the People’s Justice Party’s polls scheduled for May 23.
Malaysia’s exports rose a better-than-expected 6.8 per cent in March from a year earlier, with shipments to the United States rising to a record high of RM22.66 billion (S$7 billion).

site_title: UK’s spending review may provide political reset for government
summary: The UK's Comprehensive Spending Review (CSR) on Wednesday will provide a rare opportunity for Prime Minister Keir Starmer's government to redefine its political agenda and reset its priorities. Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will seek to depict the UK as a safe haven amidst global economic uncertainty, while also outlining a forward-looking vision for the country's future. The review will include significant increases in public spending, particularly for the NHS and defence, with the NHS set to receive a 2.8% annual increase and defence spending to reach 2.5% of GDP.

images.alt_text: Thursday’s figures from the Office for National Statistics were the first to estimate the impact of the large hike in employer social security payments, which came into effect in April.

site_title: CDL’s high debt and interest costs continue to weigh on stock despite South Beach sale
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) sold its 50.1% majority stake in South Beach for S$834.2 million, yielding S$465 million in disposal gains. The sale is expected to trim CDL's bank borrowings and improve net gearing by 14 basis points. Analysts note that while the sale unlocks capital, CDL's high debt and interest costs, and high gearing levels, pose challenges. Despite this, CDL's other financial ratios offer upsides, and the sale aligns with its strategic focus on capital recycling.

images.alt_text: The complex in Singapore’s central business district includes retail space, a 34-storey office tower, and a 45-storey building housing a JW Marriott Hotel.
The IOI Central Boulevard Towers are part of IOI Property Group's investment portfolio in Singapore

site_title: WealthBT: Crafting a lasting legacy of values over valuables
summary: WealthBT, a podcast by The Business Times, explores the concept of legacy planning, which goes beyond distributing wealth to loved ones. Host Genevieve Cua discusses legacy planning with Christopher Tan, CEO of Providend, emphasizing the importance of reflecting on personal values and beliefs to leave a lasting impact. Key takeaways include the need for continuous legacy planning, common mistakes such as providing too much to children, and the use of a Letter of Wishes to guide future generations. The podcast provides practical strategies for parents to prepare their children to inherit wealth responsibly.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
True legacy planning starts with deciding what you want people to remember you for.
Over the long run, equity markets give annualised returns of about 10 per cent.
Are you worried about how market fluctuations will impact your investments?

site_title: Kim Heng inks deal with Singapore Energy Interconnections on submarine power projects
summary: Kim Heng, an offshore marine services contractor, has signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Singapore Energy Interconnections (SGEI) to cooperate in submarine power projects within the Asean region. The partnership covers operating, repairing, and maintaining submarine power cable systems. This comes after SGEI's deal with Singa Renewables to develop a sub-sea interconnector for low-carbon electricity imports from Indonesia to Singapore, supporting Singapore's target of importing up to 6 gigawatts of low-carbon electricity by 2035. The MOU is valid until June 1, 2028.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Kim Heng had incorporated Zale Offshore in August 2020 to undertake marine salvage and commercial diving activities.
Thomas Tan, CEO,Kim Heng Marine

site_title: Banks want staff back at the office. There aren’t enough desks
summary: Banks and financial firms in London are facing a real estate squeeze as they struggle to find enough office space for their growing staff. Despite a surge in remote work during the pandemic, many companies, including HSBC and JPMorgan Chase, are now experiencing shortages of desks. The shortage has led to a reversal of plans to cut back on office space, with some firms seeking to lease additional buildings to accommodate their growing teams. The demand for office space is being driven by the growth of Wall Street firms in Europe and the need for face-to-face communication and mentorship.

images.alt_text: A view of the Canary Wharf financial district and residential houses in London, Britain, January 23, 2025. REUTERS/Hannah McKay
Let a property group create a new landmark by redeveloping the OCBC Centre cluster of buildings.
The top three floors of 20 Collyer Quay in District 1 changed hands for S$91.8 million on Mar 10.

site_title: Alibaba, Tencent freeze AI tools during high-stakes China exam
summary: China's annual "gaokao" college entrance examinations have temporarily disabled AI tools, including picture recognition, to prevent cheating. Alibaba's Qwen, Tencent Holdings' Yuanbao, and Moonshot's Kimi have suspended photo-recognition services during the exams. The move aims to ensure fairness and prevent students from using devices during the hours-long tests. The exams, considered a rite of passage for millions of aspiring graduates, are highly competitive and strictly controlled. The disability affects over 13.4 million students taking part in this year's exams.

images.alt_text: Alibaba’s e-commerce operations have also been affected by Trump’s decision to close a tariff loophole for small parcels from mainland China and Hong Kong.
The news deals another blow to Alibaba, whose shares have been falling in the past few sessions as its quarterly revenue missed estimates.
Alibaba reported revenue of 236.45 billion yuan (S$42.6 billion) in its fiscal fourth quarter ended Mar 31.

site_title: Nomura to shut branch in China as it scales back wealth business
summary: Nomura Holdings is closing one of its four branches in China, marking a scaling back of its wealth management business in the country. The closure comes four years after the Japanese securities firm opened the office in 2021, aiming to expand in areas with rich Chinese populations. The decision follows years of losses at Nomura's Shanghai-based venture, which narrowed its losses by 30% in the latest year-end report. The firm is instead prioritizing expansion in brokerage and asset management.

images.alt_text: A name change would help the company return to the principles of its founder after the firm went through a series of scandals, according to the shareholder.
Compensation paid in the year ended March to Nomura’s seven executive officers totaled 4.6 billion yen (S$41.3 million), up 3 per cent from the previous year when there were eight such officers.
While Nomura’s struggles in China are shared by other global firms that have had to temper their initial exuberance, its prior losses have exceeded many of them.
Prime brokerage has become an increasing money maker for Wall Street in recent years due to high equities prices and the growth of multi-strategy hedge funds.

site_title: ‘Most unloved bonds’ turn routine US auction into crucial test
summary: The US Treasury will auction $22 billion of 30-year government bonds on Thursday, with yields at a near two-decade high of 5.15% and expected to remain above 4.94%. Higher yields indicate funding pressure, as the US borrows more and government spending remains high. Market demand for 30-year US debt has soured, and investor appetite is seen as "unloved." The auction results will provide insight into market sentiment, with experts warning of a "problem" if demand is weak.

images.alt_text: The BOJ will conduct a review of its current taper plan and come up with a subsequent programme at its next policy meeting on Jun 16 to 17.
Reserve managers are likely to shift toward the Singapore dollar market over time given it’s the only AAA market in Asia, according to Goldman Sachs.
Japan’s yields have been on the rise as the Bank of Japan scales back its bond purchases, while life insurers are failing to fill in that gap.

site_title: Doing away with SGX watch list may help the firms focus more on the long term: market watchers
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is considering removing its financial watch list, which targets companies with three consecutive years of pre-tax losses and a six-month average market capitalization below S$40 million. The move aims to encourage companies to focus on business growth without the burden of public stigma. Experts believe investors are becoming more sophisticated and can conduct their own due diligence, reducing the need for the watch list. The removal of the watch list may raise concerns about reduced transparency, but proponents argue it will promote market dynamism and allow companies to execute long-term plans without market pressure.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty

site_title: China’s factory-gate deflation worst in 22 months as economic headwinds mount
summary: China's producer deflation deepened to 3.3% in May, its worst level in 22 months, as trade tensions and weak consumption fueled deflationary pressures. Consumer prices also declined, with the CPI falling 0.1% from a year earlier. The slowdown in retail sales growth and stagnant new home prices have raised concerns about the economy, with expectations of more policy stimulus to combat deflation. The US-China trade talks are set to resume, with US President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping discussing trade tensions and critical minerals.

images.alt_text: The Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers’ index rose to 51.1 in May from 50.7, remaining above the 50-mark that separates expansion from contraction.
Holiday spending is an important yardstick for the strength of Chinese consumption.
Companies’ defiant mindset is being put to the test as US-China tensions are rising again, following a brief surge of relief induced by the tariff truce last month.
China has been expanding its visa policy, with citizens of 43 countries granted visa-free access, while visa-free transit for up to 240 hours in China is available for 54 countries.

site_title: Sam Altman’s eyeball-scanning identification tech expands to UK
summary: Tools for Humanity, co-founded by OpenAI's Sam Altman, is expanding its eye-scanning technology, Orb, to the UK. The spherical devices, which create a digital credential called World ID based on iris scans, will be available in shopping malls and high streets. The company aims to prove its technology can distinguish humans from AI systems, a concern amid increasing AI mimicry. The UK rollout follows a global expansion and follows regulatory meetings with the Information Commissioner's Office and privacy advocates.

OpenAI set a new record for a venture-backed acquisition by a private buyer this week.

site_title: China is redefining the bounds of innovation
summary: China's technology sector is experiencing a resurgence, driven by breakthroughs in artificial intelligence (AI) and the country's inherent advantages in research and development, talent, and data. Despite US chip export bans and tariffs, China's AI models, such as DeepSeek, are demonstrating impressive performance at a fraction of the cost of pioneering models, and are open-source, making them accessible globally. This has prompted a reassessment of investment opportunities in the sector, with potential areas including AI applications, domestic technology substitution, and select software companies integrating AI into their offerings.

images.alt_text: In the short term, businesses can outsource entry-level work to AI and cut costs; but that means missing out on capturing AI-native talent, says the writer.

site_title: US and Chinese officials meet in London for pivotal trade talks
summary: US and Chinese officials met in London for pivotal trade talks, aiming to revive a preliminary agreement struck last month in Geneva. The talks come as both economies face strain from US tariffs and China's slowdown. The US seeks China's commitment to resume rare earth shipments, while China wants export controls eased. The meeting follows a phone call between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping, who agreed to let rare earth minerals flow to the US. The outcome is uncertain, with some experts predicting little prospect for a breakthrough deal given broader decoupling trends.

images.alt_text: The US is threatening to raise tariffs on many countries from early July and on China from August.
Trump’s reprieve on US tariffs for Chinese goods runs out in August, unless he decides to extend it.
The rare-earths dispute revealed how important those supplies, which Beijing dominates, are for the US economy.

Last month, Japan’s trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said US defence equipment purchases, shipbuilding technology collaboration, a revision of automobile import standards and an increase in agricultural imports could be bargaining chips in tariff talks with the US.

The scheduling of the meeting comes a day after US President Donald Trump spoke to Chinese President Xi Jinping in a rare leader-to-leader call amid weeks of brewing trade tensions and a battle over critical minerals.
The last conversation between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping took place in January before the US president’s inauguration.
New York’s Dow and S&P 500 indices were lower, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose slightly in early trading.

site_title: Bust attributed to Donatello splits Slovakia
summary: A Renaissance-era bust attributed to Italian sculptor Donatello has resurfaced in Slovakia, sparking controversy after the country's nationalist government removed it from a museum and relocated it to an undisclosed location. The 15th-century sculpture of Cecilia Gonzaga is believed to be the eighth confirmed work by Donatello worldwide. Art historians and critics are calling for expert conservation and research to confirm its authenticity, as the government claims it is "safe and protected." The move has dismayed those seeking to preserve the artwork, which has a significant cultural and historical value.

images.alt_text: A pot discovered at the Uaxactun archeological site in the Maya Biosphere, Peten department, Guatemala.

site_title: US: Stocks end mostly up as markets eye trade talks
summary: US stocks ended mostly up on Monday as markets awaited key economic data and high-stakes trade talks between the US and China. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished flat at 42,761.76, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 0.3%. US trade representatives held talks with Chinese counterparts on Monday and will meet again on Tuesday, with no breakthroughs reported. Individual companies such as Apple and Warner Brothers Discovery fell after releasing updates on artificial intelligence and a plan to split into two companies, respectively.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on June 2, 2025, in New York City. Oil prices surged Monday over renewed concerns about Russia's war in Ukraine and relief over OPEC+ production, while stock markets mostly slumped as US-China trade tensions resurfaced. The dollar was under pressure while Wall Street opened mixed, with the Dow and the broad-based S&P 500 in the red while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Income Insurance chairman Ronald Ong to retire from role after seven years at helm
summary: Income Insurance chairman Ronald Ong, 69, is retiring after seven years at the helm. He will continue to lead the private investment portfolio within NTUC Enterprise, his parent company. The board has begun a succession process to appoint a new chairman, with further details to be shared at the upcoming annual general meeting on June 24. Ong led the corporatisation of NTUC Income Insurance Co-operative to Income Insurance in 2022 and navigated the company through the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: NTUC supported the creation of the Workplace Fairness Act, which ensures a level playing field for all workers, the message says.

site_title: Xiaohongshu joins wave of Chinese firms releasing open-source AI models
summary: Xiaohongshu, a popular Chinese social media platform, has released an open-source large language model called dots.llm1, available for download on Hugging Face. This move joins a wave of Chinese tech firms making their AI models freely available, allowing them to demonstrate technological capabilities and spread influence globally. The model performs comparably to Alibaba's Qwen 2.5 series in coding tasks, but trails more advanced models. This approach contrasts with US tech giants, which have kept their most advanced models proprietary, amid export restrictions on advanced semiconductors.

images.alt_text: The broadening of the strategic partnership between Alibaba and Xiaohongshu comes as China’s e-commerce giants vie for market share on multiple fronts.

Australian politicians are using social media including Xiaohongshu, a Chinese lifestyle app also called RedNote, and other campaign strategies to appeal to Chinese communities who will again be a crucial bloc in the upcoming election.

site_title: Hong Kong to maintain US dollar peg despite geopolitical tensions
summary: Hong Kong's leader, John Lee, has confirmed that the city will maintain its US dollar peg despite escalating geopolitical tensions. The decision comes after sharp volatility in the Hong Kong dollar, with the city's de-facto central bank intervening multiple times to defend the peg. Lee said the US dollar peg has been a key factor in Hong Kong's success, and the city will strengthen its role as the global offshore yuan hub while maintaining the peg. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has injected HK$129.4 billion into the market to purchase US dollars and maintain stability.

images.alt_text: There is a “window of opportunity” to increase the international role of the euro, according to ECB.

site_title: Greenback’s reign isn’t over, but cracks are showing
summary: The US dollar's dominance in the global financial system is being tested, with cracks forming in its foundation. Despite remaining the undisputed heavyweight, the dollar's advantages, including US economic power and deep capital markets, are no longer absolute. International investors are increasingly hedging their bets, and rising US debt, policy unpredictability, and regional currency use in trade are contributing to a weaker dollar. The dollar's share in global reserves, debt markets, and transactions may continue to erode, with gold emerging as a potential winner in a de-dollarization push.

site_title: China says it may speed up rare earths application approvals from EU
summary: China has agreed to accelerate the approval process for rare earth exports to the European Union, marking progress in its relationship with the EU after a year of tensions. The move comes after China suspended exports of rare earths and related magnets in April, affecting global supply chains. China also plans to deliver a verdict on its trade investigation of EU brandy imports by July 5. Additionally, price commitment consultations between China and the EU on Chinese-made electric vehicles have entered a final stage, with both sides working to facilitate and promote compliant trade in high-tech products.

images.alt_text: Trump’s reprieve on US tariffs for Chinese goods runs out in August, unless he decides to extend it.

site_title: Global demand jumps for emerging Asia bonds on rate-cut bets, FX
summary: Global investors have poured US$2.9 billion into Malaysian government bonds in May, the largest monthly inflow since 2013, driven by rate-cut bets and stronger local currencies. Foreign funds also bought US$1.7 billion and US$2.1 billion into Thai and Indonesian bonds, respectively. Emerging Asian currencies strengthened this quarter due to a decline in the US dollar, and investors are betting on rate cuts in countries like Malaysia and South Korea to boost economic growth. This has driven sovereign yields lower, with Thailand's 10-year benchmark falling to nearly four years' lowest.

images.alt_text: While the economy had performed well in the first quarter, the balance of risks to the growth outlook was tilted to the downside, Bank Negara Malaysia said.

Many investors have been unsettled by turmoil surrounding China’s trade relationship with the United States, even as better performance from Chinese stocks means some are reluctant to remove them from funds altogether.
Some are still wary about buying emerging-market local-currency bonds, saying the relatively high US interest rates will limit flows into the securities.
The Treasury is set to sell US$22 billion of 30-year government bonds on Thursday, part of its regularly scheduled borrowings.
The BOJ will conduct a review of its current taper plan and come up with a subsequent programme at its next policy meeting on Jun 16 to 17.
Reserve managers are likely to shift toward the Singapore dollar market over time given it’s the only AAA market in Asia, according to Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Geely chairman says global auto industry faces ‘serious overcapacity’
summary: Geely Chairman Li Shufu stated that the global automotive industry faces "serious overcapacity." Chinese automakers, such as BYD, Chery Auto, and Great Wall Motor, have built plants abroad due to a brutal price war in China. Geely will not build new manufacturing plants and instead plans to use Renault's existing facilities in Brazil, taking a minority stake in the business. This decision comes as Chinese regulators have called for a halt to the industry's expansion. The move aims to address the industry's overcapacity issue.

site_title: The US$30 million plan to overhaul tourism around Egypt’s pyramids
summary: Egypt has spent $30 million to revamp its tourism experience around the Pyramids of Giza, aiming to double annual visitors to 30 million within a decade. The revamped site features a network of buses, upgraded facilities, and fine dining options, and officially debuts on July 3. The project, led by Orascom Pyramids Entertainment, marks a significant stride in Egypt's tourism efforts, coinciding with the opening of the Grand Egyptian Museum. Visitor numbers have already increased, with a 24% rise in April, and the Egyptian government hopes the revamped site will help achieve its goal of becoming one of the most-visited countries in the world.

images.alt_text: Lower-tier cities and local destinations have become attractive to foreign travellers, beyond popular destinations such as Beijing and Shanghai.
China has been expanding its visa policy, with citizens of 43 countries granted visa-free access, while visa-free transit for up to 240 hours in China is available for 54 countries.
Greater Bay Airlines and Hong Kong Airlines have both scaled back some flights to Japan this month as officials implore the general public not to give stock to the rumours.

site_title: Bank of England risks repeat of Brexit pessimism as growth signals diverge
summary: The Bank of England risks underestimating the UK economy's strength due to conflicting signals from business surveys and official growth data. Despite a strong 0.7% GDP growth in the first quarter, the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) shows a stagnant picture, with a sharp drop in April before rebounding in May. BOE Governor Andrew Bailey is placing more emphasis on the PMI, but economists warn against repeating the error made after the 2016 Brexit referendum, when officials eased policy based on downbeat surveys.

images.alt_text: A shopper browses in a store in London, Britain, May 21, 2025. According to the Office of National Statistics, the UK inflation rate rose to 3.5 per cent in April. It is the highest level since February 2025 driven by sharp rises in household bills, and higher food, vehicle duty and airfare costs.
BOE governor Andrew Bailey says: “The past few weeks have shown how unpredictable the global economy can be. That’s why we need to stick to a gradual and careful approach to further rate cuts.”

site_title: Oil prices hold gains ahead of US-China trade talks
summary: Oil prices held steady at $66.47 and $64.59 per barrel for Brent and US West Texas Intermediate crude, respectively, ahead of US-China trade talks in London. The talks, following a rare call between the two countries' top leaders, supported prices as investors awaited China's inflation data. A potential trade deal could boost economic growth and oil demand, outweighing concerns over Opec+ supply hikes. However, HSBC expects Opec+ to accelerate supply hikes in August and September, posing downside risks to oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$66.47 a barrel, up US$1.13, or 1.73 per cent on Friday.

site_title: US, China to resume trade talks with focus on rare earth exports
summary: US and Chinese trade negotiators will hold fresh talks in London on June 9, aiming to revive talks on rare earth exports and trade tensions. The talks follow a May agreement in Geneva that aimed to dial back the trade war, but both sides accused each other of reneging on the deal. The US has threatened to restore tariffs unless a deal is reached, while China has approved some rare earth exports without specifying which countries or industries are involved. The talks offer a glimmer of hope for a de-escalation of tensions between the world's two largest economies.

images.alt_text: The scheduling of the meeting comes a day after US President Donald Trump spoke to Chinese President Xi Jinping in a rare leader-to-leader call amid weeks of brewing trade tensions and a battle over critical minerals.
The last conversation between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping took place in January before the US president’s inauguration.
China mines about 60 per cent of the world’s rare earths and makes 90 per cent of rare earth magnets.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, Goldman expect resilient economy to support stocks
summary: US stock strategists at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs are optimistic about the economy, expecting resilient growth to limit any pullback over the summer. Morgan Stanley's Michael Wilson raised his year-end target for the S&P 500 Index to 6,500 points, implying an 8% gain. Goldman Sachs' David Kostin notes that investors are pricing an optimistic growth outlook, with economically sensitive sectors outperforming defensive peers, despite potential near-term equity declines if macro data deteriorates. This suggests a sustained recovery in soft data could support equity returns.

Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Amid management changes, Lim Kok Thay remains a constant in Genting’s shifting landscape
summary: Genting Group, a Malaysian conglomerate, faces investor pressure due to weak earnings, leadership changes, and corporate governance issues. Shares across Genting's four listed arms declined 8.4-18.2% in the year to date. Lim Kok Thay, the group's executive chairman, took on acting CEO role at Genting Singapore, while Lee Shi Ruh will become CEO of RW Sentosa. The group's diversified portfolio includes gaming, hospitality, plantations, power, and biotechnology, with an estimated net worth of US$1.8 billion for Lim Kok Thay. Analysts watch for valuation unlocking, dividend sustainability, and operational challenges, particularly in the UK and US.

On Thursday, it was announced that Lim Kok Thay will step down as chief executive of Malaysia’s Genting after nearly two decades at the helm.
The 73-year-old Lim Kok Thay will remain as executive chairman of Genting Bhd.
Genting breaks ground at its first stem cell facility, Fontaine Vitale, in Bali, Indonesia.

Genting Singapore operated Resorts World Sentosa. Singapore sees most of its gaming crowd from China and neighbouring countries such as Malaysia and Indonesia.

site_title: Atome to get US$75 million from Lending Ark as credit demand grows
summary: Atome, Southeast Asia's largest buy now, pay later provider, secured a US$75 million asset-backed financing facility from Lending Ark to broaden its credit offerings and expand financial access in the Philippines. As traditional credit markets falter, private credit investors are turning to emerging markets, drawn by stronger growth and higher returns. Atome's revenue jumped 45% to US$280 million in 2024, with the financing expected to help the company expand its services. This deal follows Lending Ark's deployment of over US$1 billion across the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: China exports to US fall most since 2020 despite trade truce
summary: China's exports to the US fell 34.4% in May, the largest decline since 2020, despite a record trade surplus of $516 billion for the year so far. The decline was largely offset by a 11% rise in exports to other countries. The US is threatening to raise tariffs on China from August, which could further weaken demand for Chinese products. Despite this, China's overall export growth is expected to continue supporting the economy, but risks to global trade may drag on growth in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Retail sales growth slowed last month as spending continued to lag amid job insecurity and stagnant new home prices.
The Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers’ index rose to 51.1 in May from 50.7, remaining above the 50-mark that separates expansion from contraction.
Holiday spending is an important yardstick for the strength of Chinese consumption.

site_title: BYD unleashes an EV industry reckoning that alarms Beijing
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) industry is experiencing a price war, with market leader BYD at the center, causing share prices to tumble and prompting government intervention. Analysts warn that the industry's overcapacity and weaker demand will lead to massive consolidation, forcing weaker brands to fold. BYD has lost $21.5 billion in market value since its shares peaked in May. The government has tried to intervene, but analysts say it's too late, and investors expect few automakers to escape unscathed. The price war has also raised concerns over supply chain finance risks and dealership network disruptions.

images.alt_text: Without naming BYD, the China Automobile Manufacturers Association said the move by a certain company started a new round of “price war panic” that was plunging the sector into a “vicious cycle” and threatening supply chain security.
The company is also ramping up overseas sales, delivering more than 89,000 units in May, its highest on record.
BYD's aggressive sales tactics in China have come under scrutiny as dealers there show the strain. Will the same happen in South-east Asia?

site_title: College grads are lab rats in the Great AI Experiment
summary: Artificial intelligence is increasingly replacing entry-level work in various industries, leaving college graduates struggling to find jobs. Companies are outsourcing grunt work to AI, cutting costs but missing out on capturing AI-native talent. Some young professionals, however, are adapting to the new landscape, using AI tools to streamline tasks and focus on higher-level work. To mitigate the impact, businesses must observe how AI helps and hinders their new recruits, train them to work with AI, and encourage strategic thinking beyond AI output.

images.alt_text: Microsoft and peers including Meta Platforms have touted the effectiveness of AI-assisted coding tools in speeding up the software development process.
Brookings Institution research projects that about 30% of the workforce could see at least half of their tasks disrupted by generative AI.
Many companies say that what they need most is not cleverer AI models, but more ways to make the technology useful.
Earlier this year, Salesforce planned to cut over 1,000 employees as it hired for AI-focused roles, particularly in sales.

site_title: ‘Very clever’; ‘lost confidence’: Shareholders react to OCBC’s latest exit offer for Great Eastern
summary: OCBC has made a conditional exit offer of S$30.15 per share for Great Eastern's 6.28% stake, exceeding its previous offer of S$25.60 per share. The independent financial adviser deemed the deal "fair and reasonable." However, some shareholders, including minorities, have expressed disappointment and frustration with the offer, citing concerns over the structure of the exit and the potential dilution of their shares. The fate of Great Eastern now lies in the hands of significant shareholders, including the Lee family and Wong siblings, who collectively hold around 3% of the insurer's holdings.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
SGX in 2019 mandated, among other measures, that for a delisting to be approved, offers must be both fair and reasonable.
The Great Eastern Life Insurance buliding
After a long trading suspension, GEH’s minorities now have certainty: the insurer will either be delisted with an exit offer of S$30.15, or trading in its shares will resume.
OCBC on Friday (Jun 6), at the request of the insurer, made a S$900 million conditional exit offer at S$30.15 per share for the 6.28 per cent stake in Great Eastern it does not own.
Independent financial adviser to the deal Ernst and Young said OCBC's new exit offer for Great Eastern is fair and reasonable.

site_title: Singapore stocks close Monday higher ahead of US-China talks; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.1% to 3,936.32 on Monday, driven by hopes for easing US-China tensions. Investors also digested China's latest inflation and trade data, which showed a 0.1% year-on-year drop in consumer prices and a 3.3% decline in producer prices. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB led gains, while DFI Retail was the biggest loser. The broader Asian market followed suit, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rising 1.63% and South Korea's Kospi gaining 1.55%.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
DBS is the third-largest wealth manager in Asia, excluding mainland China.
Sasseur Reit's Hefei outlet. The manager of the Reit said a wholly owned subsidiary of its sponsor has entered into an unsecured sponsor loan agreement of up to 508 million yuan (S$91.1 million).

site_title: Private assets giant Brookfield expects alternative investments to replace public markets in 25 years
summary: Private assets giant Brookfield expects alternative investments to surpass public markets within 25 years. With over $1 trillion in assets under management, Brookfield predicts that 50% of retail investors will hold private investments, making the asset class "mainstream." The company, led by billionaire CEO Bruce Flatt, is expanding its presence in Singapore, with a new office and plans for more deals. Brookfield's Asia-Pacific assets total $146 billion, and the company expects to capture a significant share of the growing private markets, which are predicted to outperform public markets.

images.alt_text: Wong Chia Peck
The agreement with National Grid gives Brookfield a portfolio of operating projects and others in advanced stages of development.

Brookfield Place, which contains the Brookfield Asset Management headquarters, in New York. Brookfield agreed last week to buy a S$535 million portfolio from a Reit backed by Singapore state investor Temasek Holdings

site_title: China’s copper boom under threat as miners test bargaining power
summary: China's copper processing capacity has expanded to a record high, threatening the bargaining power of miners. Despite trade tensions and a global slowdown, Chinese copper output has surged, with state-owned producers and low-cost smelters driving the growth. Spot treatment charges have plummeted to negative levels, making it difficult for smelters to secure ore. Analysts predict that the industry's high-cost facilities will be forced to cut production, while the less-efficient ones may be at risk. China's resilient output is attributed to its economic model, which prioritizes job protection and economic stability.

images.alt_text: A copper electrolysis plant in Longyan, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Commodity traders in the last few months have been chasing gains from Trump’s copper tariff threat, which has drawn cargoes to US warehouses and left the rest of the world short.
The rush to get copper to the US accelerated after President Donald Trump ordered his Commerce Department in February to conduct a probe into potential tariffs on copper products.
Trump has threatened to impose a duty of as much as 25 per cent on all copper imports.

site_title: Trump’s China gambit belies rocky road ahead on tariff deals
summary: US President Donald Trump secured a rare phone call with Chinese President Xi Jinping, paving the way for new trade talks in London. However, progress remains uncertain, with the US and China still far apart on key issues like rare-earth minerals. Trump's 90-day tariff deadline on the European Union expires on July 9, and China's reprieve extends until August. Talks with India, Japan, and the EU are ongoing, but no tangible signs of progress have emerged. The administration's approach to trade negotiations is marked by Trump's mercurial style, with varying positions among his team.

images.alt_text: Trump’s reprieve on US tariffs for Chinese goods runs out in August, unless he decides to extend it.

The scheduling of the meeting comes a day after US President Donald Trump spoke to Chinese President Xi Jinping in a rare leader-to-leader call amid weeks of brewing trade tensions and a battle over critical minerals.
The last conversation between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping took place in January before the US president’s inauguration.

site_title: Shein and Reliance reportedly aim to sell India-made clothes abroad within a year
summary: Shein, a Chinese e-commerce firm, and Reliance Retail, an Indian retailer, plan to expand their Indian supplier base to 1,000 factories within a year, with the goal of selling India-made Shein-branded clothes abroad. The partnership aims to raise suppliers from 150 to 1,000, with a focus on on-demand manufacturing and replicating Shein's global best-sellers at lower costs. The expansion is driven by the need to diversify sourcing due to US tariffs on Chinese imports and the success of Shein's Indian app, which has been downloaded 2.7 million times.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Shein logo is pictured on the label on a childs top in Manchester, Britain, December 11, 2024. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo
Temu, Shein and Tiktok have offered to pay part or all of the shipping costs to European markets, as well as directly subsidising some purchases.
Shein’s use of gamification, drawing shoppers to use the app regularly, has helped drive its success.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, CapitaLand Investment, Sasseur Reit, Thakral
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies saw new developments on June 9. OCBC made a S$900 million conditional exit offer for Great Eastern's 6.28% stake, which will resolve the insurer's 11-month suspension in share trading. CapitaLand Investment raised S$470 million from new and existing investors for its value-add lodging private fund. Sasseur Reit entered an unsecured sponsor loan agreement of up to S$91.1 million to repay offshore loans, resulting in cost savings. Thakral Corp's associate GemLife is considering an initial public offering on the Australian Securities Exchange in the form of stapled securities.

site_title: Gold falls on strong US jobs data and improved trade outlook
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $3,303.19 an ounce as a strong US jobs report and optimism over easing trade tensions between the US and China reduced safe-haven demand. The US economy added 139,000 jobs in May, surpassing expectations, while wage growth exceeded forecasts, dampening the likelihood of imminent interest rate cuts. Investors now anticipate one rate cut in October, down from previous expectations.

images.alt_text: Gold bullion can be seen after being removed from casts at the ABC Refinery smelter in Sydney on April 29, 2025. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)

site_title: Starmer calls on Nvidia’s Huang to train up Britons on AI
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer will announce a £187 million program to improve AI skills of British workers and students, backed by major tech companies including Nvidia, IBM, and Microsoft. The initiative aims to boost economic growth, following a crucial week for the Labour government's spending plans, which will prioritize the National Health Service and military capabilities. Chancellor Rachel Reeves faces pressure from opposition parties and colleagues over expected cuts, but Downing Street focuses on growth plans with £86 billion in funding for British science.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has become an AI powerhouse in the past two years.
The new chip’s price, specifications and production timing have not previously been reported.
The data centre is expected to be fully operational by mid-next year, and Oracle has agreed to lease the site for 15 years, the report says.

site_title: Demand for AI-related talents increasing globally across sectors
summary: Global demand for AI-related talent is increasing across various sectors, with top-level appointments reported in industries such as manufacturing, energy, and logistics. Tech-enabled businesses initially led the way, but traditional companies are now also setting up AI departments. Human resource specialists caution against over-hiring, advising companies to focus on strategic AI use cases and prioritize relevant soft skills, such as critical thinking and learning agility, to ensure a successful AI integration.

images.alt_text: Speaking at the Bloomberg Tech conference in San Francisco, Pichai said he will continue to invest in engineering in the near future.
A Zoox at Amazon's headquarters in Foster City, California.  The self-driving vehicles were recalled after a crash in Las Vegas exposed flaws in how the AI handled other drivers.
Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat says that deep tech is “both difficult and expensive to get right”, and a strong ecosystem is needed to aid innovators and startups in this field.

site_title: Japan confirms GDP contraction, backing Bank of Japan’s cautious stance
summary: Japan's economy contracted by 0.2% in the first quarter, according to a revised estimate, as US tariffs continue to weigh on the country. The contraction, driven by weak domestic demand, supports the Bank of Japan's cautious stance and keeps pressure on Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba ahead of a key election. Economists expect the central bank to maintain its wait-and-see stance, with a majority anticipating no change in the coming months, as the fragile domestic economy and precarious trade diplomacy pose a major challenge for Ishiba.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending fell 0.1 per cent in April from a year earlier, data from the internal affairs ministry showed on Friday. That was worse than the median market forecast for 1.4 per cent growth and March’s 2.1 per cent increase.
People walk through a popular covered shopping district in central Hiroshima on May 30, 2025. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)
Business spending holds the key to the country’s economic growth as inflation keeps a lid on household spending and  Donald Trump’s tariff campaign clouds the trade outlook.

site_title: Chinese managers take reins at TikTok Shop in US as sales miss goal
summary: ByteDance, the parent company of TikTok, has replaced US-hired staff near Seattle with Chinese managers to replicate its e-commerce success in Asia after sales fell short in the US. Over 100 employees have been fired or left amid confusion between leaders, worsening the work environment. The company initially set a goal to increase its US e-commerce business tenfold, but drastically lowered its objective to around $9 billion. The cultural transition coincides with its fight for survival in the US, where a national security law requires TikTok's US business to be spun off from its Chinese parent company or face a ban.

images.alt_text: Despite TikTok Shop’s quick growth, the video app’s future in the US is in doubt, given the continued threat of a ban should it fail to sell the US portion of its business.

site_title: GEH, OCBC’s proposals a victory of sorts for minorities who have held out, endured suspension
summary: Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) and its controlling shareholder OCBC have proposed a plan to resolve the insurer's trading suspension, offering a two-pronged approach. GEH will attempt to delist its shares with an exit offer of S$30.15 per share, or trading will resume. The plan includes a one-for-one bonus issue of new shares to restore the insurer's free float. While the exit offer is deemed "fair and reasonable," it is less than the embedded value of GEH's shares, and the lifting of the trading suspension may only be a temporary reprieve.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
The offer comes months after OCBC first made a privatisation bid for Great Eastern through a voluntary unconditional general offer at S$25.60 per share.

SGX in 2019 mandated, among other measures, that for a delisting to be approved, offers must be both fair and reasonable.
OCBC on Friday (Jun 6), at the request of the insurer, made a S$900 million conditional exit offer at S$30.15 per share for the 6.28 per cent stake in Great Eastern it does not own.

site_title: MoneyHero expands into digital assets in partnership with OSL
summary: MoneyHero, a personal finance platform, has partnered with OSL Group to enter the digital asset space, allowing users to compare a range of financial products, including digital assets licensed by Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission. The move aims to empower consumers with smarter financial choices amid growing interest in digital assets in the region, where nearly 8% of Hong Kong retail investors held virtual assets in 2023. The partnership reflects MoneyHero's entry into the sector and positions the company as a leading digital acquisition partner in Greater South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Nasdaq-listed MoneyHero has seen an exodus of senior executives since it went public. It is due to release its full year results on Apr 29.

site_title: Meta in talks for Scale AI investment that could top US$10 billion
summary: Meta Platforms is in talks to invest up to $10 billion in AI startup Scale AI, a data labelling services provider, making it one of the largest private company funding events. Scale AI has become a key beneficiary of the generative AI boom, with customers including Microsoft and OpenAI. The deal would be Meta's biggest external AI investment and a rare move for the company, which has prioritized AI development under CEO Mark Zuckerberg, aiming to spend up to $65 billion on related projects this year.

images.alt_text: Meta does not have a cloud business, and it is unclear what format Meta’s investment will take..
Meta plans to let advertisers personalise ads using AI, so that users see different versions of the same ad in real time, based on factors such as geolocation
Meta unveiled its first standalone AI assistant app on April 29, giving users a direct path to its Gen AI models.

site_title: Differing funding objectives an obstacle to mobilising more philanthropic capital in blended finance
summary: Philanthropic capital in South-east Asia remains untapped due to differing funding objectives between blended finance initiatives and philanthropies. Blended finance transactions focus on clean energy infrastructure, while wealthy families prioritize social impact projects such as nature-based solutions, health, and education. To overcome this misalignment, Convergence suggests developing a toolkit for philanthropies to deploy capital towards infrastructure projects and promoting local mobilization through home-grown solutions, local currency financing, and regulatory intervention.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Generic photo for stories regarding Green Buildings and Sustainable Buildings. Part of Singapore Green Plan 2030 to change the way people live, work, study and play
While there is impending pain for solar panel makers, there is also an opportunity for the survivors to focus more on domestic markets.
Mr Chia Der Jiun, Managing Director, Monetary Authority of Singapore, at the Singapore FinTech Festval.

site_title: Crown close to A$80 million sale of Sydney penthouse: report
summary: Crown Resorts is close to selling a six-bedroom penthouse in its Sydney skyscraper, One Barangaroo, for approximately A$80 million. The 800-square-metre duplex was initially priced at A$90 million, but the sale price was reduced by 10% after the target market disappeared. A local buyer is set to secure the property through a structured deal, marking a significant sale for the complex. The penthouse was conceived in an era of high asset prices fueled by Chinese cash, but the market has since declined.

site_title: UK finance leads in foreign investment yet deals fall across Europe: EY
summary: The UK maintained its lead in foreign investment in the finance sector, attracting 73 projects last year, a 32% decline from the prior year. Germany took second place with a 16% drop in deal volumes, while Europe saw a 11% decline overall. London remained the most attractive European city for financial services investment, despite US President Donald Trump's tariff announcements, which lowered investor confidence in the US. Competition for financing remains fierce, according to EY.

site_title: Will deglobalisation and business uncertainty hurt buying power in Good Class Bungalow properties?
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) property market is under uncertainty due to global trade tensions. High-end detached homes in GCB areas are seen as a status symbol and store of value, with recent sales including a S$93.9 million purchase and a S$45.8 million sale. As negotiations between the US and trading partners unfold, concerns arise about the impact on buying power in GCB properties. The market's performance may be affected by business uncertainty and deglobalisation.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The Yarwood Avenue good class bungalow owned by Three Arrows Capital co-founder Zhu Su (pictured).
Peirce Hill bungalow
The propety being transacted, the one in the middle, has redevelopment potential.
Singapore GCB market sees interest picking up amid global uncertainty

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market experienced mixed performance this week, with the VLCC market plunging but finding a floor in the Middle East Gulf and West Africa. The Capesize market surged, driven by strong demand and tightening tonnage in the Pacific, South Brazil, and North Atlantic. Panamax rates improved, particularly in the Atlantic, while Ultramax/Supramax and Handysize markets remained flat. The LR2 market held steady, with MRs experiencing downward pressure. Suezmax owners pushed rates up in the Atlantic, and Aframax rates recovered in the Mediterranean. The LNG market saw muted activity, with freight rates posting losses on longer Pacific routes.

images.alt_text: The LNG market softened further this week, with small declines across both spot and period markets as sentiment turned cautious.

site_title: Traders scour for ‘elusive’ catalyst to push S&P 500 to record
summary: US stocks remain close to a record high, with the S&P 500 Index 2.3% away from its all-time high. Despite solid corporate earnings and low recession concerns, traders are seeking a catalyst to push the index to new heights. Sticky inflation, with core CPI expected to rise 0.3% in May, and uncertainty over President Trump's tariff policy are key concerns. Some traders are bracing for potential volatility, while others are cautiously optimistic about the market's trajectory.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MAY 13: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on May 13, 2025 in New York City. Markets opened lower following the announcement that the Labor Department's Consumer Price Index (CPI) rose 0.2% on the month.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The S&P 500 is trading at 21 times earnings projected over the next 12 months, up from a low of 18 times in April and well above the average of 18.6 times over the past decade.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 1.1 per cent to 42,762.87 while the broad-based S&P 500 Index added 1.0 per cent to 6,000.36 on Friday.

site_title: Can US ports handle a freight spike or will they be overwhelmed?
summary: US ports, particularly Los Angeles and Long Beach, are expected to face a freight spike in June, with container volumes projected to top 100,000 TEUs a week. The surge is driven by Chinese exports, with capacity from Asia to North America reaching 2.4 million TEUs in June, a 17% year-on-year rise. However, industry experts are divided on whether the ports can handle the influx, with some suggesting the tariff deferral may not trigger a pandemic-style shipping boom. Elevated cargo volumes lasting only two to three weeks are manageable, but prolonged congestion risks increase sharply if imports climb more than 20% above normal.

images.alt_text: About 40 per cent of the imports that enter the US via the Port of LA hail from China.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally ahead of latest China-US trade talks
summary: Asian markets rallied ahead of the latest China-US trade talks, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, and Manila all advancing. Optimism over a potential breakthrough boosted the markets, following strong lead from Wall Street after the US jobs data beat expectations. The gains come as tensions between the two economic superpowers ease, with recent news including Beijing's approval of rare-earth exports and Boeing's first commercial flights to China since April.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong dropped after three days of strong gains while Shanghai and Taiwan also retreated on Friday.

site_title: Trump’s travel ban on 12 countries goes into effect early Monday
summary: US President Donald Trump's travel ban on 12 countries, including Afghanistan, Myanmar, and Sudan, takes effect on June 9, restricting entry to the US for citizens of those countries. The ban aims to protect the country from "foreign terrorists" and is part of Trump's immigration policy. Seven other countries will face partial restrictions. Officials and residents in affected countries express dismay and concern, with some threatening to retaliate. Democratic lawmakers also criticize the policy as "draconian and unconstitutional."

images.alt_text: Law enforcement clashes with demonstrators during a protest following federal immigration operations, in the Compton neighborhood of Los Angeles, California on June 7.

The travel ban is likely to face legal challenges, just as its first-term predecessor did and with many of Trump’s other immigration actions during his current White House stint already being litigated in the courts.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: The travel hacks edition 2025
summary: Cyndi Hui, a travel trends and destination expert from Skyscanner, shares valuable data-driven insights on how Singaporeans are planning their vacations despite global tensions and economic uncertainties. She reveals mid-year holiday deals, tips to maximize travel budget, and explores lesser-known destinations. Hui also provides strategies for families and affluent travelers, including booking early and using price alerts, and shares upcoming travel trends such as astro-themed travel and sports tourism.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
What are the market conditions which favour ETFs?
Are Reits a better bet than bank stocks now?
Defensive sectors such as consumer staples, healthcare, and utilities tend to perform well during volatile times.

site_title: Disney’s ‘Lilo & Stitch’ tops North America box office for third week
summary: Disney's 'Lilo & Stitch' topped the North America box office for the third week in a row, earning $32.5 million in ticket sales. The live-action remake has grossed $335.8 million domestically and $436 million internationally. 'Ballerina', a 'John Wick' spinoff, debuted in second place at $25 million, while 'Mission: Impossible - The Final Reckoning' took third place with $15 million.

images.alt_text: Chris Sanders again provides the voice of the chaos-creating blue alien Stitch.
The film, starring Florence Pugh, Sebastian Stan and Julia Louis-Dreyfus, raked in an additional US$33 million for the three-day period.
The first original film from Ryan Coogler has Michael B Jordan playing twins who encounter a sinister force as they return home to Jim Crow-era Mississippi.

site_title: Little known sweet potato producer Zixin Group could be a treat for investors
summary: Zixin Group, a Catalist-listed company in Singapore, is gaining attention from investors due to its exposure to China's growing sweet potato cultivation and sale business. The company researches and produces sweet potatoes, as well as manufactures sweet potato snacks. Analysts at RHB Bank believe the stock could be a treat for retail investors, offering growth and expansion opportunities in the Chinese sweet potato market. Zixin Group's stock has seen a 3.23% increase, making it a potential investment opportunity.

images.alt_text: Smaller companies like Grand Venture Technology (GVT) and Frencken Group are well-positioned to benefit from this wave, said Ang Wee Seng, executive director of SSIA.

site_title: Vietnam’s big bet: Tax shake-up to unlock growth of 5 million household businesses
summary: Vietnam's government has introduced a tax shake-up requiring around 37,000 household businesses with annual revenues exceeding one billion dong to issue electronic invoices. The move aims to formalize the informal economy, increase tax revenue, and encourage businesses to adopt proper bookkeeping practices. The new regulation, which took effect on June 1, is part of a broader push to develop the country's private sector and achieve double-digit GDP growth. Analysts believe the policy could lead to increased tax transparency, a level-playing field for businesses, and growth for the informal sector, but also faces challenges and potential disruptions.

images.alt_text: Jamille Tran

This photo taken on December 23, 2024 shows vendors waiting for customers at a street market outside the Pouyuen Vietnam factory, owned by Taiwanese shoemaker Pou Chen, in Ho Chi Minh City. Vietnam is among the world's largest exporters of clothing, footwear and furniture and Ho Chi Minh City and its hundreds of thousands of migrant workers have for decades helped power its manufacturing boom. But as living costs surge, a wave of workers are rejecting the commercial hub for a quieter life back home -- leaving city businesses struggling to fill their ranks. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP) / TO GO WITH: Vietnam-economy-labour-lifestyle, FOCUS by Tran Thi Minh Ha

site_title: Indonesia expects to conclude free trade talks with EU by end of June
summary: Indonesia expects to conclude free trade talks with the European Union by the end of June 2025, after nine years of negotiations. Chief Economic Minister Airlangga Hartarto met with EU Commissioner for Trade Maros Sefcovic in Brussels, stating that the two sides have agreed to conclude outstanding issues. The EU is Indonesia's fifth-largest trade partner, with total trade reaching $30.1 billion last year, and the country aims to diversify its export destinations amid US tariff challenges. Details of the agreements reached are not disclosed.

images.alt_text: Danantara is said to be interested in participating in the Grab acquisition of GoTo reported Bloomberg.
Indonesia's Finance minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said on Monday the package would spur economic activity, with the incentives in force during the school holidays.

site_title: Trump says decision on Fed chair will be out soon
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that a decision on the next Federal Reserve chair will be made soon, with a good Fed chair expected to lower interest rates. Trump expressed his desire for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates by a full percentage point and reiterated his criticism of current Fed Chair Jerome Powell. Trump previously met with Powell and told him he was making a "mistake" by not lowering rates. Former Fed governor Kevin Warsh is considered a frontrunner for the position.

site_title: BHG downsizes Bugis Junction flagship outlet as department stores face shaky future
summary: BHG, a Singapore department store, is downsizing its flagship Bugis Junction outlet from three to two levels as part of its efforts to adapt to a declining market. The move follows the closure of its Junction 8 store in March and four other stores since 2022. Experts attribute the decline to increasing competition from online shopping and changing consumer preferences, citing the need for personalized, curated, and experiential retail experiences. BHG is exploring ways to revamp its stores, including introducing new brands, enhancing omnichannel integration, and investing in technology such as augmented reality and artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: Japanese chain Isetan said on May 6 that it would shut its Tampines Mall outlet when the lease ends in November, after nearly 30 years.

site_title: Meta in talks for scale AI investment that could top US$10 billion
summary: Meta is in talks to invest up to $10 billion in AI startup Scale AI, its largest external AI investment. The deal would value Scale at over $14 billion, making it one of the largest private company funding events. Meta's investment would be a rare move for the company, which has focused on in-house research and development. The investment is part of Meta's $65 billion AI push, led by CEO Mark Zuckerberg, and comes as Scale generates $870 million in revenue and expects sales to double to $2 billion in 2025.

site_title: Arina East Residences sells 10 out of 107 units at average price of S$3,000 psf as booking opens
summary: Arina East Residences, a freehold development in Singapore, sold 9% of its 107 units at an average price of S$3,000 psf during its booking period. The majority of buyers are believed to be Singaporeans, and the project's strong potential for capital appreciation is seen as a factor in its success. The sale price is higher than competitors, according to Mogul.sg's Nicholas Mak, who notes that market sentiment remains uncertain due to the economic climate.

site_title: Income Eco Run raises S$70,000 for WWF-Singapore
summary: The Income Eco Run in Singapore raised S$70,000 for WWF-Singapore's pilot programme to reduce single-use food and beverage packaging. Nearly 5,500 runners participated in the 5 km and 10 km categories, with Income Insurance matching S$1 for every kilometre clocked. The event, held in conjunction with Income Insurance's 55th anniversary, featured eco-friendly measures such as compostable cups and reduced waste. The funds will support the programme's goal to reduce waste sent to landfills by 30% by 2030.

site_title: Tech giants’ indirect emissions rose 150% in 3 years as AI expands, UN agency says
summary: The indirect carbon emissions from the operations of Amazon, Microsoft, Alphabet, and Meta rose 150% on average from 2020 to 2023, driven by the demands of power-hungry data centers. The emissions grew at 182% for Amazon, 155% for Microsoft, 145% for Meta, and 138% for Alphabet. The International Telecommunication Union report attributed the increase to the vast amounts of energy required to power data centers, which will continue to drive emissions up to 102.6 million tons of carbon dioxide equivalent per year.

images.alt_text: Major South-east Asian economies have 2.9 gigawatts (GW) of data centre capacity in the pipeline, Ember noted

site_title: Goldman CIO service suddenly catches on in Japan after 10 years
summary: Goldman Sachs has successfully landed its first client for its outsourced chief investment officer (OCIO) service in Japan after a decade of trying. The company has since secured a second pension client and is in talks with 10 more potential customers, driven by Japan's increased willingness to hire third-party asset managers amid the return of inflation. The OCIO industry is expected to grow 7.9% annually to 2028, and Goldman is positioning itself as a key player in the Japanese market, competing with established firms like BlackRock and Mercer.

Even though its earnings fell, Goldman Sachs’s local unit kept its spot as the most profitable among foreign banks that close their books in December.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment expands fund with Japan asset acquisition at 30 billion yen
summary: CapitaLand Investment has expanded its fund with the acquisition of a 30 billion yen (S$267.2 million) prime mixed-use asset in Tokyo, Japan. The asset, comprising hotel, residential, and office components, will be repositioned into a 179-unit serviced residence managed by Ascott. The acquisition increases funds under management by around S$470 million, with CLI holding a 20% stake in the fund. The move reflects strong investor interest in the fund's strategy to reposition under-utilised assets into high-performing living assets in key Asia-Pacific cities.

site_title: Group CEO Ng Chin Siau increases stake in Q & M
summary: Singapore stocks saw a net institutional outflow of S$32 million over five trading sessions, with the highest net outflows in Reits and telecommunications. 19 primary-listed companies made buybacks totaling S$46 million. Notable director and CEO increases in stake include Q & M Dental Group (54.23%), Uni-Asia Group (1.4%), and Wing Tai Holdings (61.85%). In contrast, Singtel's independent director Yong Ying-I acquired 150,000 shares, while DBS, Singapore Airlines, and Keppel led net institutional inflows.

images.alt_text: From a sector perspective, telecommunications and Reits experienced the highest net institutional outflow, while financial services and industrials saw the most net institutional inflow.

site_title: US aerospace industry anxious as tariffs loom
summary: The US aerospace industry is anxiously awaiting the outcome of proposed tariffs on civil aircraft and parts, which could disrupt its growth path. The proposed tariffs of 10-20% have been met with resistance from airlines and manufacturers, who argue that the tariffs would harm the domestic supply chain and risk reversing decades of industrial progress. The Aerospace Industries Association and Airlines for America have expressed concerns that the tariffs would not only hurt US manufacturers but also lead to a competitive disadvantage for US airlines, such as Delta, which relies heavily on foreign suppliers.

images.alt_text: IndiGo has emerged as a major winner of the push by foreign firms into the market, inking partnerships with some of the global industry’s biggest names.
Airfares in Asia are coming down from post-pandemic record highs as the region’s airlines continue to restore seat capacity.
Loyalty programmes of Delta, United and American Airlines were each valued at more than US$20 billion in 2023, according to consulting firm On Point Loyalty.

site_title: US companies delay impact reports with DEI, ESG under attack
summary: Several major US companies, including Nike, JPMorgan, Constellation Brands, and Akamai Technologies, are delaying or canceling the publication of their sustainability reports, which typically highlight efforts to improve diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) practices. This trend is attributed to growing opposition from GOP lawmakers and activists who have pressured companies to scale back such efforts. The delay may impact corporate transparency and shareholder reliance on these disclosures, with some executives seeking flexibility in what information they release this year to avoid potential backlash.

images.alt_text: The Trump administration has already moved to freeze funding and block Harvard’s ability to enrol international students in an intensifying battle.

site_title: Nasdaq 100 sees mixed signals amid trade optimism and technical divergence
summary: The Nasdaq 100 Index has seen a strong rally from April to early June 2025, driven by optimism over US-China trade negotiations and positive technical indicators. However, recent market volatility, including a public dispute between Trump and Tesla CEO Elon Musk, has emerged, weighing on investor confidence. The index is now approaching a key resistance level at 22,220, with support levels at 20,880 and 20,050. A bullish scenario suggests further gains if the index sustains its position above the 20-day SMA and breaks through the resistance level, while a bearish scenario warns of a deeper correction if the index fails to break above the resistance and falls below the 21,000-support level.

site_title: Trump says Musk has ‘lost his mind’ as feud fallout mounts
summary: US President Donald Trump criticized his former aide and billionaire Elon Musk, calling him "lost his mind" after Musk criticized Trump's "big, beautiful" spending bill. The feud escalated with Musk posting unsubstantiated claims about Trump's alleged ties to Jeffrey Epstein. Trump responded by threatening to cancel SpaceX contracts and accused Musk of having a "problem." The dispute raises political and economic risks, and Musk's wealth could impact Trump's 2024 campaign and 2026 midterms. Trump is now considering giving away the cherry red Tesla he bought from Musk.

Trump and Musk's unlikely political marriage exploded in a fiery public divorce on June 5, 2025. The President Trump said in a televised Oval Office diatribe that he was "very disappointed" after his former aide and top donor criticized his "big, beautiful" spending bill before Congress. The pair then hurled insults at each other on social media -- with Musk even posting, without proof, that Trump was referenced in government documents on disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Following Elon Musk’s announcement, Nasa spokeswoman Bethany Stevens said on X that the government space agency would “continue to execute upon the President’s vision for the future of space.”

site_title: Global funds bet on South Korean stocks’ big break on reform tailwinds
summary: Global investors are optimistic about South Korea's stock market, with foreign funds adding positions or upgrading their outlook on local stocks after President Lee Jae-myung's election. Lee's push for shareholder-friendly policies and corporate governance reforms is expected to boost returns, reminiscent of Japan's similar drive. The Kospi Index has entered a bull market, with foreign investors returning to the market, and companies taking proactive measures to improve shareholder value, such as increasing dividend payouts and share buybacks. However, challenges remain, including tax reform and economic issues, which may impact the market's trajectory.

Oil prices surged Monday over renewed concerns about Russia's war in Ukraine and relief over OPEC+ production, while stock markets mostly slumped as US-China trade tensions resurfaced. The dollar was under pressure while Wall Street opened mixed, with the Dow and the broad-based S&P 500 in the red while the tech-heavy Nasdaq rose. (Photo by ANGELA WEISS / AFP)

site_title: Japan trade negotiator Akazawa says he made progress in US tariff talks
summary: Japan's chief tariff negotiator Ryosei Akazawa reported progress in the fifth round of trade talks with US officials aimed at ending tariffs hurting Japan's economy. The talks, held in Washington, focused on resolving tariffs on autos, steel, aluminum, and other goods, which have doubled to 50% in some cases. Akazawa declined to specify the progress, but emphasized the need for a deal before the G7 summit on June 15, where US President Donald Trump is expected to meet Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba. A deal is crucial to avoid a 24% tariff rate starting in July.
