site_title: StanChart brings maximum interest rate on savings account to record 8.05%
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has raised its interest rates on savings accounts to a record 8.05% per annum, the highest available in the industry for comparable savings accounts. This follows a two percentage point increase from 6.05% previously. The bank's flagship deposit account, Bonus$aver, features a tiered interest rate structure, rewarding clients who engage with the bank through activities such as salary crediting and card spend. Account holders must meet certain criteria to earn the bonus interest rates, including a minimum monthly salary and spending on eligible credit and debit cards.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Standard Chartered bank logo is seen at their headquarters in London, Britain, July 26, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Nicholls/File Photo

What was once a niche alternative financial choice is rapidly gaining traction in today’s world, said Standard Chartered's head of banking and coverage for Singapore and Asean, Corporate and Investment Banking, Chow Wan Thonh.

site_title: As birthrates fall, Turkey's government steps in
summary: Turkey's birthrate has fallen to 1.48 children per woman in 2025, down from 2.38 in 2001, prompting President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's declaration of 2025 as "Year of the Family" and plans for a "Decade of the Family" starting in 2026. Erdogan has blamed women and LGBTQ+ individuals for the decline, but critics argue that economic crisis, lack of education, and high inflation are major factors. The government has introduced financial incentives, including interest-free loans and a monthly allowance, but feminist activists argue that these policies are insufficient and oppressive.

images.alt_text: The previous law allowed only one or two children per family, except in special cases.

site_title: Acrophyte Hospitality Trust proposes disposal of Michigan hotel for US$6.7 million
summary: Acrophyte Hospitality Trust has proposed the sale of its 127-room Hyatt Place Detroit/Auburn Hills hotel in Michigan to AHM Hospitality for US$6.7 million, a 5% discount from its estimated valuation of US$7 million. The sale is expected to generate net proceeds of US$6.2 million after costs, which will be used to acquire higher-yielding properties, reduce debt, and fund working capital needs. The divestment will allow the stapled group to reallocate resources towards higher-performing assets and avoid unnecessary capital outlay.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Hyatt Place Oklahoma City Airport is in Acrophyte's portfolio. The trust currently operates 33 hotels in the US.
Hyatt Place Oklahoma City Airport

site_title: Procter & Gamble to cut 7,000 jobs over two years in new restructuring plan
summary: Procter & Gamble plans to cut 7,000 jobs, approximately 6% of its workforce, over two years, citing uneven demand due to tariff uncertainty. The company also plans to exit certain categories, brands, and product forms in individual markets, potentially leading to brand divestitures. The restructuring aims to simplify the organizational structure, reduce costs, and increase productivity. The job cuts and portfolio changes are part of a broader strategy to adapt to a challenging market environment and mitigate the impact of tariffs, which have led to muted consumer demand and higher costs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A plant wall with Procter & Gamble's logo is pictured at the entrance to the company's highly automated cleaning products factory in Tabler Station, West Virginia, U.S., May 28, 2021. Picture taken May 28, 2021. REUTERS/Timothy Aeppel/File Photo
Influencers on Chinese shopping app Douyin entice shoppers with deep discounts.

site_title: Why property giant New World’s debt woes have Hong Kong on edge
summary: New World Development, one of Hong Kong's top real estate developers, is struggling to secure a multibillion-dollar loan deal, putting the city's already beleaguered real estate market at risk. The company's debt burden has reached 96% of shareholder equity, and investors are skeptical about its ability to manage debt. A failed refinancing effort could lead to a default, triggering a domino effect in the property sector, with home prices potentially falling by up to 7%. The company's shares have slumped 90% from their peak in 2019, and its credibility in capital markets would be severely damaged.

site_title: US: Stocks slump as Tesla shares tank on Trump-Musk row
summary: US stocks slumped on Thursday as Tesla shares plummeted 14% amid a public row between US President Donald Trump and Tesla boss Elon Musk. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3% and the S&P 500 Index lost 0.5% as Trump expressed disappointment with Musk's criticisms and threatened to take away the tech tycoon's government contracts. The decline in Tesla's share price had a ripple effect on the broader market, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Tesla scion Elon Musk has called US President Donald Trump's "big, beautiful bill"  a “disgusting abomination.”
The last conversation between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping took place in January before the US president’s inauguration.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 60.2 points, or 0.14 per cent, at the open to 42,487.89.

site_title: DBS, UOB back 6.7 trillion rupiah loan facility for data centre campus in Batam’s Nongsa Digital Park
summary: DBS and UOB have jointly provided a 6.7 trillion rupiah (S$530 million) loan facility to finance the development of a new data centre campus in Batam's Nongsa Digital Park, Indonesia. The campus will house three data centres and support the region's growing demand for data centre computing power, expected to triple to 6.5 gigawatts by 2030. The project aims to strengthen digital connectivity between Singapore and Indonesia's economies, positioning both markets to capture regional demand for computing power.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Nongsa Digital Park in Batam, Indonesia, is a dedicated special economic zone aimed at becoming a hub for digital investment.
The causeway heading from Johor Bahru to Singapore is  the logistical and symbolic backbone of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone.
Oracle already has two cloud computing centers in Singapore, and last year announced a US$6.5 billion plan to build a similar facility in Malaysia.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise as US data feeds rate-cut hopes
summary: Most of Asia rose in early trade on Thursday, driven by soft US economic data and hopes of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut. The US payroll firm ADP reported a slowdown in private-sector jobs, while a survey showed the services sector contracted in May for the first time since June last year. Markets are now pricing in two potential rate cuts by the end of the year, with the first in September. Despite ongoing US-China trade tensions, investors remain optimistic, with the Singapore stock index up 0.4% and the won rising 0.4% in Seoul.

images.alt_text: Early on Wednesday, US President Donald Trump appeared to dampen hopes for a quick resolution with China.
US President Donald Trump has imposed levies on many US imports and threatened even higher tariffs on key US trade partners.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.2 per cent to 42,427.74 while the broad-based S&P 500 Index was flat at 5,970.81 on Wednesday.

site_title: Gold edges higher as soft US data lifts safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $3,377.79 an ounce, driven by weaker-than-expected US economic data and global uncertainty. The ADP National Employment Report showed US private employers added the fewest number of workers in over two years, while the services sector contracted for the first time in nearly a year. The Federal Reserve reported a slowdown in US economic activity, citing rising costs and prices, and US President Trump urged Fed chair Jerome Powell to cut interest rates. The moves lifted demand for safe-haven assets.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index fell 0.1 per cent, making greenback-priced bullion less expensive for overseas buyers.

site_title: Peter Kwee, son and firm sued for over S$71 million over insolvency of Laguna club operator
summary: Motoring tycoon Peter Kwee and his son Kevin, along with their firm Laguna Hotel Holdings, have been sued for allegedly perpetuating a fraudulent scheme against the insolvent Laguna National Golf and Country Club, resulting in over S$71.5 million in damages. The golf club's liquidators claim the defendants diverted value to enrich themselves, causing significant loss and damage to the firm. The lawsuit alleges breaches of fiduciary duties, including setting the club up for failure and setting the hotel up for success.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Peter Kwee owns Group Exklusiv's 60 per cent shares, with the company being the owner of Laguna Golf Resort Holding that acquired Laguna National Golf and Country Club in 2001.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, Far East Orchard
summary: ThaiBev announced a US$2 billion multicurrency debt issuance programme, issuing notes and perpetual securities to be used for general corporate purposes. The company's shares rose 1.1% on Wednesday. Far East Orchard's joint venture agreement with Real Hospitality Group Asia in China was terminated due to post-pandemic recovery challenges. The company's shares remained unchanged.

site_title: Starbucks reshuffles leadership to accelerate turnaround bid
summary: Starbucks is reshuffling its leadership to accelerate its turnaround bid, following disappointing results last quarter. Mike Grams, head of North America stores, becomes chief operating officer, while Meredith Sandland and Sanjay Shah's responsibilities expand. The company is also merging its global brand and coffee teams to emphasize coffee as its core focus. CEO Brian Niccol stated the changes aim to bring teams closer together and speed up decision making. These changes follow the company's earlier decision to cut 1,100 corporate jobs and cut its reliance on duplication.

images.alt_text: Prospective bidders are expected to submit initial feedback in the next few weeks, the sources say.
Starbucks says it’s taking actions such as diversifying its coffee sources and redirecting shipments to minimise tariffs.
Both suits seek damages over what they say are problems caused by scalding liquids slopped over customers at drive-throughs.

site_title: China warns BYD, rivals to self-regulate as price war heats up
summary: China's top leaders have summoned the heads of major electric vehicle makers, including BYD, to address concerns about the long-running price war. Officials told EV makers to "self-regulate" and not sell cars below cost or offer unreasonable price cuts. The move comes amid concerns the price war is becoming unsustainable and could send weaker companies into bankruptcy. The gathering was attended by senior executives from over a dozen manufacturers, including Zhejiang Geely Holding Group and Xiaomi, and did not result in a mandatory directive.

images.alt_text: A BYD Co. automobile showroom in Coulsdon, UK, on Wednesday, May 28, 2025. BYD sold more electric vehicles in Europe than Tesla Inc. for the first time, overtaking the American brand that long led the continent’s EV segment. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
From a macroeconomic perspective, everything is going well; cut-throat competition is driving efficiency and innovation.
The company is also ramping up overseas sales, delivering more than 89,000 units in May, its highest on record.
The steep price cuts have taken some of the gloss off what has so far been a stellar year for BYD.
BYD offered discounts on 22 of its electric and plug-in hybrid models that it sells in China until the end of June, fanning the flames of a renewed sector-wide price war.
BYD outsold Tesla by an even wider margin when including the carmaker’s plug-in hybrid electric vehicles.

site_title: China’s power prices nosedive, providing relief to tariff-hit factories
summary: China's power prices have plummeted, providing relief to tariff-hit factories. Coal prices have dropped 30% over the past year, and the shift to market-based pricing for renewables has weakened rates. The average price in Jiangsu province fell 24% to 313 yuan (S$56) per megawatt-hour, while in Guangdong it dropped 8.3% to 373 yuan. The government's drive for energy security has been successful in power markets, but the relief is not universal due to the structured market.

images.alt_text: Holiday spending is an important yardstick for the strength of Chinese consumption.
Companies’ defiant mindset is being put to the test as US-China tensions are rising again, following a brief surge of relief induced by the tariff truce last month.
China's new export orders shrank for the second straight month in May and at the fastest pace since July 2023. Producers said the US tariffs restrained global demand.
The new orders sub-index rose to 49.8 in May from 49.2 in April, while the new export orders sub-index rose to 47.5 from 44.7.

site_title: Syfe raises US$53 million in expanded Series C funding round
summary: Syfe, a digital wealth management platform, has raised US$53 million in an expanded Series C funding round. This is the latest in a series of investments, following a US$27 million raise in August 2024. The funding will be used for regional expansion, strategic hires, and automation. The company aims to strengthen its leadership position in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Australia, with its total assets under management now exceeding US$10 billion. Existing investors, including UK family offices and Unbound, participated in the round alongside new investors.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Syfe's founder and CEO Dhruv Arora said: "We see immense potential in combining our strengths to deliver greater value to those who matter most – the end customer."
Dhruv Arora, founder and chief executive of Syfe, founded the company in 2019, with the aim of making investing more accessible.

site_title: Citi to cut 3,500 tech jobs in China in global revamp
summary: Citi is cutting 3,500 tech jobs at its China Citi Solution Centres in Shanghai and Dalian, mainly full-time roles, to simplify and shrink global tech operations. The reduction is expected to be completed by early Q4 this year. The move follows internal plans to reduce reliance on IT contractors and hire thousands of employees for IT. Citi will have around 2,000 staff in China after the cuts, and the bank remains committed to its clients in the market.

images.alt_text: Alvin Lee, country CEO of Maybank Singapore, said while digitalisation remains a core focus for the bank, the human touch is crucial in a highly competitive market.

site_title: China’s May services activity grows despite US tariff concerns: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector expanded at a slightly faster pace in May, with the Caixin/S&P Global services purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 51.1, above the 50-mark that separates expansion from contraction. New orders grew more quickly than in April, while new export orders declined due to US tariff uncertainty. The economy grew faster than expected in the first quarter, but analysts warn that US tariffs could dampen momentum, with the government maintaining its annual growth target of around 5%.

images.alt_text: Excavators unloading coal from rail cars into a coal storage facility in Shandong province. Coal accounts for more than half of the electricity generated in China.

site_title: Singapore Paincare up 12.1% as Sias urges shareholders to await IFA report
summary: Shares of Singapore Paincare rose 12.1% to S$0.176 on Thursday, amid a recommendation by Securities Investors Association (Singapore) to hold off selling shares before an independent financial adviser (IFA) report is released. The association valued the company at S$0.36 to S$0.37 per share, more than double the S$0.16 privatisation offer price. Sias warned that selling shares before the report could result in missed gains if the offer price is revised upward.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh

Mr David Gerald on Nov 13, 2024. David Gerald, a former criminal lawyer and magistrate who founded the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) in 1999 to help small investors take on the Malaysian government on the CLOB shares issue in 1999. Now 25 years old, SIAS is a key instituition not just in protecting small investor interests but bolstering investor education, advocacy and corporate governance.
Singapore Paincare CEO Dr Bernard Lee (above) and COO Dr Jeffrey Loo are looking to take the company private at S$0.16 per share.

site_title: Indonesia rolls out US$1.5 billion stimulus package after growth slows
summary: Indonesia has launched a $1.5 billion stimulus package to boost economic activity after its economy grew 4.87% in the first quarter, its slowest rate in over three years. The package includes discounts on transportation and tolls, additional social aid, and cash transfers to low-income workers. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati aims to maintain economic growth near 5% in the second quarter, despite US President Donald Trump's threatened 32% tariffs. The measures are set to take effect during the school holidays.

site_title: Europe moves on from economic “peak pessimism”
summary: The European Union has seen a shift in positive perceptions about its economic and political prospects, despite ongoing challenges. The European Central Bank is expected to cut interest rates for the eighth time in a year, while the new German government has surprised on the upside with reform plans. The region's trade liberalization agenda has also seen progress, including a big deal with the Mercosur bloc. However, challenges such as the Ukraine war, competitiveness issues, and right-wing populism remain, and the region's future economic and political pathway is characterized by intense volatility and uncertainty.

site_title: Japan’s April real wages slump for fourth month as inflation bites
summary: Japan's real wages fell 1.8% in April, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline due to inflation. Despite a 2.2% rise in regular pay, prices continued to outpace pay hikes, with the consumer inflation rate remaining around 4% for five months. The Bank of Japan faces challenges in normalizing monetary policy amid global trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: With US credit downgrade, Singapore’s AAA bills offer an opportunity for US carry trade
summary: Singapore's AAA-rated government bonds offer investors a yield pickup over US Treasuries, following the US credit downgrade. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a record $345.5 billion in 3-month bills, attracting investors seeking a safe-haven asset. The yield on MAS bills is around 13 basis points over similar-tenor US government debt, making them an attractive option for those looking to diversify their holdings and hedge against US dollar fluctuations. This trend is driven by concerns over the US fiscal deficit and Trump's proposed tax and spending bill.

site_title: Korean beauty startups bet booming US demand outlasts tariff pain
summary: South Korean beauty startups are expanding their US presence, despite tariffs, as they capitalize on the country's mass appeal and lower prices. Brands like Tirtir, d'Alba, and Beauty of Joseon are in talks with major retailers to stock their US shelves. The US market has been a key driver of exports, with four-fifths of South Korea's $13 billion cosmetics output going to the US. Executives believe that strong demand will offset the impact of tariffs, and some companies are already seeing success, with sales growth outperforming the overall US market.

site_title: New Zealand house prices fall further even as loans get cheaper
summary: New Zealand house prices fell 0.1% in May from April, marking the second straight month of decline. Despite interest rates hitting three-year lows, the property market remains sluggish due to a large overhang of unsold houses. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's interest rate cut to 3.25% has yet to boost prices, with economists predicting a further rate decrease in the third quarter. Home lending is increasing, but affordability remains a concern, with prices only slowly falling 1.6% from the year-earlier month.

images.alt_text: The decision was in line with a Reuters poll where all but one of the 30 economists surveyed forecast the Reserve Bank of New Zealand would cut the cash rate for the sixth successive meeting.

site_title: Tariffs and potential slowdown of global economy weigh on property players’ minds: NUS poll
summary: Singapore real estate leaders experienced a significant decline in sentiment in Q1 2025, with the National University of Singapore's Composite Sentiment Index falling to 4.3 from 6 in the previous quarter. The main concerns include a slowdown of the global economy, job losses, and rising construction costs. Despite this, 90-day tariff pauses announced by the US may hold the potential for a trade war de-escalation. The survey also found that property executives expect new launch prices to remain at the same level, and the number of residential units to remain relatively constant in the next six months.

site_title: Stablecoin issuer Circle raises US$1.05 billion in upsized US IPO
summary: Circle, a stablecoin issuer, raised US$1.05 billion in its upsized US IPO priced at US$31 per share, valuing the company at roughly US$8 billion. The IPO, one of the biggest of the year, marks a growing trend of late-stage cryptocurrency firms entering traditional finance. Institutional demand for stablecoins and other less-volatile crypto assets is driving the market, with Circle's USDC stablecoin having a market capitalization of over US$61 billion. The company will start trading on the NYSE under the symbol "CRCL" on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Circle will list on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol “CRCL”.
New York-based Circle and some existing investors are looking to raise up to US$624 million by offering 24 million shares priced between US$24 and US$26 apiece.

Stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency designed to maintain a constant value, usually a 1:1 US dollar peg, are commonly used by crypto traders to move funds between tokens.

site_title: Mercedes, BMW step up response to China export curbs to avoid shortages
summary: Automakers Mercedes-Benz and BMW are taking steps to mitigate potential shortages of rare earth materials used in electric car motors and combustion engine vehicles due to China's export curbs. The companies are discussing stockpiling and alternative sourcing with suppliers, with Mercedes-Benz considering physical buffers. Ford Motor has also been affected, with shipping costs rising and factory production impacted. Industry analysts predict a potential impact on US auto production within weeks if the situation isn't resolved, with a major supply shock similar to the global semiconductor crisis.

site_title: From marketplace to mess: Tokopedia unravels after merger
summary: Tokopedia, an Indonesian e-commerce platform, is struggling after its merger with TikTok Shop. Merchants and employees are concerned about the platform's transformation into TikTok Shop's image, fearing it will become a hollowed-out version of its former self. The integration has led to massive layoffs, with some divisions losing up to half of their team. Sellers are also facing issues with auto-accepting orders, free delivery promos, and limited control over logistics providers. The platform's market share has slipped behind Shopee and Lazada, and there are concerns about anti-competition. Despite this, Tokopedia's reputation and brand value are unlikely to be retired, as employees believe the risks outweigh the benefits.

images.alt_text: ByteDance Inc., the parent company of TikTok, is preparing significant job cuts and a substantial reduction in operations at Tokopedia.
Aside from the payment integration between TikTok and Tokopedia, branding across the new entity’s platform has been made consistent to the Shop | Tokopedia brand.
At US$15.6 billion, TikTok Shop's estimated gross merchandise value for 2023 is more than twice as much as Tokopedia’s US$6.6 billion.

site_title: Vingroup seeks private loan to buy KKR’s stake in Vinschool
summary: Vingroup is seeking a $300 million private credit loan to purchase KKR's 38% stake in its education subsidiary Vinschool, a K-12 education system operating in Vietnam. This financing will help KKR exit its investment in Vinschool, which has 54 campuses educating around 49,000 students. The deal marks Vingroup's second use of private debt markets, following a $250 million loan obtained by its real estate arm in 2023.

images.alt_text: Vietnam plans to begin construction of the US$67 billion high-speed railway in 2026 and put it into operation from 2035. The bullet train will travel about 1,500 kilometres across 20 cities and provinces at a speed of 350 kilometres an hour.

site_title: US will not give Vietnam reprieve on tariffs as it’s pathway for China exports: US commerce chief Lutnick
summary: US Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick stated that Washington will not reciprocate if Vietnam removes all tariffs on American goods, citing the country's significant re-export of Chinese products to the US. Vietnam exported $136.6 billion to the US in 2024, while only importing $12.5 million in worth of American products. Lutnick called this a "pathway for China to us" and suggested there might be room for negotiations if Vietnam stops re-exporting Chinese goods.

site_title: Indonesia’s latest green energy plan still makes room for coal
summary: Indonesia's 2025-2034 power supply plan aims to add 60 GW of power generation capacity, with 42.6 GW from renewable sources, but also includes 6 GW of new coal-fired capacity, casting doubt over its net-zero path. The plan, which includes 17 GW of new solar energy capacity, faces hurdles due to a rooftop solar cap and lack of enforcement mechanisms for meeting renewable energy targets. Analysts warn that the country's continued reliance on coal will push emissions higher, and Indonesia may miss its 2040 coal phase-out targets, with emissions projected to rise 45% to 681 million tonnes of CO2 over the next decade.

Singa Renewables, which aims to achieve commercial operations from 2029 onwards, received conditional approval from EMA in September 2024.

site_title: UK home sales hit three-year high, defying slowdown fears
summary: The UK property market saw its busiest month in over three years in May, with home sales up 6% year-on-year, defying slowdown fears. This increase was driven by lower mortgage costs and attractive property prices. London saw mixed results, with some areas experiencing sharp sales growth, while the capital as a whole saw a 1% increase. The data supports other housing market indicators showing resilience despite a rise in stamp duty.

site_title: Statista, TIA to award Singapore’s Top Fintech Companies for 2026
summary: Singapore's top fintech companies for 2026 will be recognized by Tech in Asia and Statista. The award, open to both startups and established tech firms, will honor innovative fintech companies across various sectors such as payments, neobanking, and digital assets. Applications will be accepted from June 3 to August 1, 2025, with winners announced in early November 2025. The evaluation criteria will include growth rates and sector-specific KPIs, ensuring that startups and large companies are on equal footing.

site_title: Employers should encourage employees to start retirement planning early
summary: Employers can play a crucial role in encouraging employees to start retirement planning early by including it in their suite of benefits. A recent survey found that only 54% of respondents have started making financial plans for retirement, and those who have often start planning in their 50s or later. Early retirement planning can help maximize compound interest and reduce reliance on simple savings, which can be insufficient for a greying population. Employers can provide free and unbiased courses, such as those offered by the Institute for Financial Literacy, to help employees develop a solid foundation for a comfortable retirement.

site_title: Singapore a choice site for data centres, but constraints on supply incur ‘opportunity cost’, NUS poll finds
summary: A poll by the National University of Singapore (NUS) found that Singapore's data centre market faces constraints on supply due to land scarcity, high land prices, and sustainability requirements. Only one-third of respondents rated the market positively, citing power supply and cooling energy constraints as key challenges. Despite this, data centres are seen as an attractive investment class, with respondents expecting a 2-4% premium in investment yield. The poll also highlighted the growing demand for cloud storage and the strategic location of Singapore as key drivers for the asset class.

site_title: Gamers get hold of Nintendo’s hotly awaited Switch 2
summary: Nintendo's highly anticipated Switch 2 console has been released, featuring a bigger screen and more processing power. The device is an upgrade to the original Switch, which has sold 152 million units worldwide since its 2017 release. Gamers in Japan and other countries have been eagerly awaiting the console, with many pre-ordering it online, resulting in 2.2 million pre-order applications in Japan. The Switch 2 costs US$449.99 and is expected to break sales records, with Nintendo forecasting 15 million consoles to be shipped in the current financial year.

site_title: Ship carrying EVs abandoned in Pacific after catching fire
summary: A ship carrying about 3,000 electric vehicles to Mexico caught fire in the Pacific Ocean, forcing the crew to abandon the vessel. The fire, which involved about 800 EVs, was difficult to extinguish due to limited ventilation on the ship. Responders were deployed to support salvage and firefighting operations, and all 22 crew members were safely evacuated. The incident highlights the growing risk of transporting electric vehicles at sea, particularly given the value of the vehicles on board.

site_title: South Korea Q1 GDP -0.2% q/q, unchanged from early estimate
summary: South Korea's GDP contracted 0.2% in the first quarter from a quarter earlier, unchanged from the previous estimate, according to the Bank of Korea. The contraction was steady from a year earlier, marginally revised from a 0.1% decline initially estimated in April. This marks the first quarter-on-quarter decline in South Korea's GDP since 2020. The news comes as the country's economy faces various challenges, including trade tensions and a slowing global economy.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield sinks to 2.05%
summary: Singapore's latest six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) cut-off yield dropped to 2.05%, the lowest level in the year to date. The median yield for the latest auction stood at 1.99%, lower than the 2.18% median yield in the previous round. Demand for the T-bill fell, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.35, compared to 2.41 in the previous auction. Analysts attribute the decline to increased demand for Singapore dollar fixed-income products, with expectations of the US Federal Reserve keeping interest rates steady in June and potentially cutting them later in the year.

site_title: Brookfield office tower in Los Angeles sells for 42% less than 2005 price
summary: A unit of Brookfield sold its 52-storey office tower in downtown Los Angeles for US$210 million, 42% less than its 2005 purchase price. The sale marks a continued exodus from downtown LA, with the building being 73% leased. The price-per-square foot of US$201 surpassed recent downtown office sales, with brokers optimistic that the worst is behind downtown LA's office market.

site_title: Former Biden spokeswoman quits US Democratic party
summary: Former White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre has quit the US Democratic Party after its "betrayal" of President Joe Biden, according to her publisher. Jean-Pierre, 50, will explain the decision in her upcoming book "Independent: A Look Inside a Broken White House, Outside the Party Lines." The book, set to be published on October 21, will detail the three weeks leading up to Biden's decision to drop his bid for a second term. Jean-Pierre, who was the first Black and gay presidential spokesperson, will also push back against misinformation and urge Americans to step beyond party lines.

site_title: A lingering Musk: The bromance is over. Will ex-aide Elon get up Trump’s nose?
summary: US President Donald Trump's sweeping domestic policy bill faces complications in passage due to opposition from tech billionaire Elon Musk, who has called the bill a "disgusting abomination" and urged Republicans to "kill the bill." The 1,100-page blueprint would add $2.4 trillion to US debt by 2034, according to the Congressional Budget Office. Musk's criticism has complicated negotiations, with the White House downplaying the significance of his comments. Analysts predict that the fragile alliance between Trump and Musk may be at risk, with potential conflict between the two egos.

site_title: GrabCab to launch in July with 40 new Toyota Prius taxis for a start
summary: GrabCab, Singapore's sixth taxi operator, will launch its services in July with 40 new Toyota Prius taxis, starting with a fleet size of 40 vehicles. The company plans to add more models, including an electric hybrid Hyundai Kona in August and a fully electric vehicle in 2025. GrabCab has received over 700 registration applications and selected 400-500 drivers with taxi driver's vocational licenses. The company aims to meet the minimum fleet size requirement of 800 taxis within three years.

site_title: US economic activity declines as tariffs pressure prices, Fed says
summary: The US economy experienced a slight decline in recent weeks, according to the Federal Reserve's Beige Book survey, citing tariffs and uncertainty as major factors. Prices rose at a moderate pace, with firms planning to pass along tariff-related costs to consumers within three months. The report noted widespread uncertainty, with 80 mentions of the word "uncertain" and 122 mentions of tariffs, indicating a cautious approach to business and household decisions. The outlook remains "slightly pessimistic and uncertain."

site_title: What to know about China’s rare earth export controls
summary: China, the world's largest producer of rare earths, has imposed export controls on seven of the 17 rare earth metals, affecting global manufacturers. The move, which includes curbs on exporting rare earth magnets, is seen as a response to US tariffs and a bid to maintain its dominance in the market. Global automakers have warned of production delays and shutdowns due to the export restrictions, while China has defended its actions as "non-discriminatory."

site_title: JPMorgan plans to offer clients financing against crypto ETFs
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to offer financing to clients against crypto exchange-traded funds (ETFs), starting with BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust. Wealth management clients will be able to use their crypto holdings as collateral for loans, with cryptocurrencies given similar treatment to stocks and art when calculating borrowing power. The move marks a significant step by the US bank to enter the crypto industry, following a more favorable regulatory environment.

site_title: Amazon’s delivery, logistics get an AI boost
summary: Amazon is forming a new group at its Lab126 device unit to create warehouse robots that can perform multiple tasks, a significant advancement over current robots. The robots will use agentic AI, allowing them to unload trailers and retrieve parts for repairs. The new technology also aims to minimize waste and cut carbon emissions. Additionally, Amazon is using generative AI to create more advanced maps for delivery drivers, making it easier for them to navigate and deliver packages. The company's goal is to speed up delivery times and improve efficiency.

site_title: US-China at trade impasse as Trump’s steel tariff hike strains ties
summary: US President Donald Trump has dampened hopes for a quick resolution with China over a trade impasse, citing China's "principles and stance" as consistent. Trump's doubling of metal tariffs on China has strained ties with trading partners, including Canada and Mexico, which have vowed countermeasures. The US and European Union are making progress in trade talks, but the US-EU agreement is contingent on a deal by July 9. Trump's tariffs have been criticized for reducing the US economy and fueling inflation, with the Congressional Budget Office predicting a negative impact.

site_title: Tesla’s China shipments extend slump, bucking broader sales boom
summary: Tesla's China shipments fell 15% in May, marking an eighth consecutive decline, amid a global sales slump. The automaker shipped 61,662 Model 3 and Model Y vehicles, down from the same period last year. This contrasts with a 38% rise in nationwide new-energy vehicle sales in China. The decline signals further challenges for Tesla's sales across major global markets, potentially bucking a broader sales boom. CEO Elon Musk is expected to refocus on the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Newly manufactured Tesla Model Y SUV vehicles are transported along a freeway near Carlsbad, California, U.S., September 9, 2024.    REUTERS/Mike Blake//File Photo

site_title: Oil settles 1% lower after US data shows large builds in fuel stocks
summary: Oil prices settled 1% lower on Wednesday after US data showed large builds in fuel stocks, swelling fuel supplies. Brent crude futures closed at $64.86 a barrel, down 77 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $62.85, down 56 cents. The large builds in refined products and plans by Opec+ producers to increase output by 411,000 barrels per day in July weighed on investors. Geopolitical tensions, including trade tensions and a potential supply glut, also impacted the energy demand outlook.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures rose US$1, or 1.5 per cent, to settle at US$65.63 a barrel while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose 89 cents, or 1.4 per cent, to close at US$63.41 on Tuesday.

site_title: Digital money and the art of the impossible
summary: India's United Payments Interface has surged ahead with a mobile-based payments platform accounting for half the world's real-time payments in 2023. Meanwhile, other major economies like China and Brazil have set aside trying to map distributed ledger technologies (DLT) onto national payments systems. However, DLT is expected to become a component of mainstream finance, with stablecoins and tokenised money market funds gaining traction. Central banks struggle with regulatory, liquidity, and interoperability challenges, with some opting for alternative solutions like Project Agora, a cross-border DLT network.

images.alt_text: The US Federal Reserve has conducted research on central bank digital currencies, but has made clear on multiple occasions that it currently has no plans to put one into circulation.
Blockchain in capital markets: revolution in waiting?

site_title: Witness testifies Sean Combs dangled her from balcony
summary: Sean "Diddy" Combs is on trial for sex trafficking and racketeering charges. A witness, Bryana Bongolan, testified that Combs dangled her over a 17th-story balcony and threw her onto furniture, leaving her traumatized and bruised. Bongolan, a friend of Combs's ex, Cassie Ventura, said she feared retaliation and did not report the incident. Combs faces life in prison if convicted. Other witnesses have testified about alleged abuse and coercion by Combs, including a hotel security guard who received $100,000 in exchange for surveillance footage of Ventura.

images.alt_text: Casandra Ventura, the singer widely known as “Cassie,” returned to the witness stand in the sex trafficking trial against her ex for another marathon day of questioning from prosecutors who accuse Sean "Diddy' Combs of heading a criminal sex ring.

US federal prosecutors allege that Sean Combs, 55, sexually abused women and coerced them into drug-fuelled sex parties using threats and violence.
He has pleaded not guilty to all charges.
Sean 'Diddy' Combs has been jailed at the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn since his arrest.

site_title: Singapore and the Philippines to expand collaboration in renewable energy, sustainability and healthcare
summary: Singapore and the Philippines have agreed to deepen their collaboration in renewable energy, sustainability, healthcare, and civil service development. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr announced the plans at a joint press conference in Manila. The two countries aim to accelerate efforts to achieve the Asean power grid, connect electricity networks, and facilitate cross-border power trading by 2045. They also plan to work together on cross-border carbon credit transfers, health cooperation, and a digital leadership program. The partnership is expected to spur economic opportunities, create jobs, and strengthen regional integration.

site_title: STMicro to cut 5,000 jobs in next 3 years, says CEO
summary: STMicroelectronics, a Franco-Italian chipmaker, plans to cut 5,000 jobs in the next three years, including 2,000 due to attrition, as part of its cost-cutting program to save hundreds of millions by 2027. CEO Jean-Marc Chery stated that discussions with stakeholders and authorities are on track, but hinted that Italy might delay the implementation of the plan. The company employs 50,000 people worldwide and owns a combined 27.5% share through a holding company in Italy and France.

images.alt_text: ESIA said chip policy under the incoming EU Commission should feature fewer export restrictions, focus on areas where European companies already had advantages, and that aid should be awarded more quickly.
China is both the largest producer and the world’s biggest market for EVs, yet the manufacturers mostly rely on foreign companies for the multiple chips that modern high-end cars require.
STMIcroelectronics' revenue for the second quarter came in at US$3.32 billion versus US$3.2 billion expected by analysts.
STMicroelectronics views being in the Chinese market for electric vehicles, digital power controls, and renewable energy as essential.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed on slower hiring, economic uncertainty
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipping 0.2% to 42,427.74 and the S&P 500 Index remaining flat at 5,970.81. Private sector hiring slowed in May, with 37,000 jobs added, below expectations. Despite this, markets were supported by hopes of lower interest rates and a potential response from the Federal Reserve to signs of a weakening economy. Analysts attributed the lack of a significant reaction to increased uncertainty surrounding US President Donald Trump's policies.

images.alt_text: “ADP number out. ‘Too Late’ Powell must now lower the rate. He is unbelievable. Europe has lowered nine times,” US President Donald Trump said in a Truth Social post.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 54.5 points, or 0.13 per cent, at the open to 42,574.13.

site_title: Even after explosive run, European defence stocks may still have firepower left
summary: European defence stocks have surged in recent months, driven by increased nationalist spending and a shift away from relying on American support. Companies like Germany's Rheinmetall, Italy's Leonardo, and Sweden's Saab have seen significant gains, with Rheinmetall up over 200% and Leonardo up over 103% in the year to date. This trend is expected to continue, with many of these companies well-positioned to scoop up new orders, particularly if the war grinds on or spreads beyond Ukraine. Valuations remain a concern, with some companies trading at high price-earnings ratios, but investors may see this as a sign of the industry's growth potential.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan proposed that Russian President Vladimir Putin (left), Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky (right) and US President Donald Trump (centre) come together for a third round later this month in either Istanbul or Ankara.
Europe’s rearmament hopes rests not only on Germany, as France, Italy, and Poland have comparative advantages in critical defence subsectors.

site_title: Singapore’s climate strategy stands firm amid global setbacks on emissions
summary: Singapore remains resolute in its climate ambitions, with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong reaffirming the government's commitment to decarbonisation despite global setbacks. The city-state aims to cut emissions to 45-50 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent by 2035 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Singapore's approach is seen as a model for other countries, with the government investing in clean power, electric vehicles, and green infrastructure. The country's climate strategy is also expected to create new job opportunities and drive economic growth, with the International Energy Agency projecting 10.3 million new jobs by 2030.

images.alt_text: UOB chief sustainability officer Eric Lim

site_title: Beyond polar bears: How nature-related financing can help companies be more resilient
summary: UOB's chief sustainability officer Eric Lim emphasizes the need to integrate nature into economic value chains beyond conservation and restoration perspectives. Companies are increasingly dependent on natural capital, such as water, air, and land, which are essential inputs to daily lives and business models. UOB has published its nature strategy to help clients start thinking about how their business models interact with natural ecosystem services. The bank aims to scale financing towards real-economy activities that reduce pressure on nature or are nature-positive, with a focus on sustainable trade and sustainability-linked loans.

site_title: OCBC partners Ant International to offer embedded finance to Indonesia SMEs
summary: OCBC has partnered Ant International to offer embedded finance services to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Indonesia. The partnership aims to boost financial inclusion for businesses in the country, leveraging OCBC's presence and knowledge of SMEs, and Ant's capabilities in alternative data modelling and automated credit decision. The collaboration is expected to benefit thousands of SMEs in Indonesia over the next few years.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh

site_title: Thai parliament to deliberate casino Bill next month
summary: Thai lawmakers will begin deliberating a draft law for casinos and entertainment complexes next month, aiming to attract US$3 billion in new investment and boost foreign tourist arrivals by up to 10%. The proposed law, modeled after Singapore, Japan, and the UAE, will impose strict regulations, including a 5,000 baht entry fee and minimum bank deposit requirements. The government hopes to create jobs and state revenue, with the current government aiming to finalize the bill within two years.

images.alt_text: Businesses were concerned about the uncertain status of trade negotiations with Washington, and the prospect that other nations could strike a better deal than Thailand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 4)
summary: CDL sold its 50.1% stake in South Beach to Malaysia's IOI for S$834 million, yielding S$465 million gain. The Norman Foster-designed complex is valued at S$2.75 billion. COE premiums for most categories decreased, except motorcycle segment. Chinese corporations are eyeing deals in Asean, with secondary listings on SGX. FedEx partnered with Singapore startup QuikBot to deploy robots for deliveries. Singapore ranked as the world's top port for 12th consecutive year.

images.alt_text: 新加坡金融管理局（Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS)）外观。金管局标志。

site_title: Thailand receives seven applicants for central bank governor post
summary: Thailand has received seven applicants for the role of its next central bank governor, a position that will require the new chief to steer the country's economy through the global trade war. The selection committee plans to shortlist at least two candidates by July 2, with the finance minister expected to make a final decision by the end of the month. The new governor must be modern and forward-thinking, able to work with the government and support its policies, following the five-year term of incumbent Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput.

images.alt_text: Thai corporations experienced a 40 per cent increase in aggregate net profit from the year before corresponding period
Bank lending dropped 1.3 per cent in the first quarter of 2025 from a year earlier, after an annual fall of 0.4 per cent in the previous quarter, says the Bank of Thailand.

On April 30, the Bank of Thailand’s monetary policy committee voted to cut the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 1.75 per cent, the lowest level in two years, and lowered its growth and inflation forecasts.
Governor Sethaput’s term ends on Sep 30. The 60-year-old former World Bank economist cannot seek a second term as he has reached retirement age.
The Bank of Thailand cuts its growth forecast for 2025 to 2 per cent.
The governor selection is being keenly watched by investors to see if PM Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s administration pushes its own nominee to tighten its grip over the central bank.

site_title: Europe: German stocks rise on tax relief package approval; Stoxx 600 touches one-week high
summary: European stocks rose 0.47% on Wednesday, with the Stoxx 600 touching a one-week high, driven by Germany's approval of a 46 billion euro corporate tax relief package aimed at boosting growth. The package follows recent surveys showing euro zone business activity barely expanded in May and Germany's services sector contracted. Other bourses, such as France and Spain, also saw gains, while Britain's slipped. The approval comes ahead of US-China trade talks and the European Central Bank's policy meeting on Thursday, where a rate cut is expected.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 0.2 per cent to 42,427.74 while the broad-based S&P 500 Index was flat at 5,970.81 on Wednesday.

site_title: SP Group launches initiatives to help seniors and young at inaugural Community Festival
summary: SP Group launched three initiatives, including SG60 Journeys from the Heart, a program offering customized day trips for 600 seniors, youth, and children, to explore Singapore's landmarks. The initiative aims to promote social mobility and well-being, particularly for lower-income households. Additionally, SP Group is enhancing its donation-matching initiative for the SP Heartware Fund, which supports vulnerable communities, and distributing care packs worth S$300,000 to 10,000 lower-income households under its SP Power Packs initiative.

images.alt_text: Part of the funding went towards upgrading SAAC’s three kitchen spaces, which have been refurbished to provide a more supportive and conducive learning environment for the trainees.

site_title: Overcoming challenges in sustainable finance
summary: Sustainable finance faces challenges, but experts believe it's a structural trend. Despite growing interest, investors are hesitant due to complexities, concerns over climate commitments, and data quality. However, Asian regulators are stepping up with policies and regulations that create an enabling environment for climate action. Key areas for investment include energy, mobility, agriculture, and nature-based solutions. Renewable energy sources, transmission infrastructure, battery storage, and green data centres are promising investment opportunities. As the business case for climate-aligned investing remains robust, investors are increasingly focusing on sectors that offer both climate impact and attractive returns.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Companies should look to include 30- and 80-year-olds in their top executive teams
summary: DBS' newly appointed CEO Tan Su Shan, 57, is the sixth most powerful woman in business according to Fortune's 2025 list. Her leadership team, however, is predominantly dominated by members in their 50s. Experts suggest that age-diverse corporate leadership teams can better serve stakeholders and meet the needs of customers spanning different age groups. A multi-generational team with members ranging from the 30s to 70s or older could provide a competitive edge in handling the challenges of disruption and change in the business world.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Women held 13 per cent of all board leadership roles in Singapore-listed companies last year, up from 11 per cent in 2023.
Tan Su Shan, DBS’ CEO

site_title: Ong Ye Kung dismayed by S$52,000 clinic rent bid; HDB to roll out new tender approach for GP clinics
summary: Minister for Health Ong Ye Kung expressed dismay over a record-breaking S$52,188 bid for a general practitioner clinic in Tampines, exceeding S$1,000 per square meter in monthly rental. The Housing and Development Board (HDB) awarded the bid to I-Health Medical Holdings, citing it as the highest per-square-foot rent for GP and dental clinics of this size. HDB plans to roll out a new tender approach, prioritizing quality of care over rental rates, to ensure more affordable healthcare.

images.alt_text: Jessie Lim
The Tampines clinic’s eye-popping rent recently caught public attention and ignited discussion about rising rentals and healthcare costs.

site_title: Who is behind Malaysia’s IOI Properties Group?
summary: IOI Properties Group (IOIPG), the property arm of Malaysian conglomerate IOI Corporation, is acquiring the remaining 50.1% stake in South Beach development in Singapore from joint venture partner City Developments Ltd (CDL) for S$834.2 million. The acquisition, set to complete by Q3 2025, will give IOIPG full ownership of South Beach's commercial components, including office units, a hotel, and restaurants. The deal expands IOIPG's Singapore investment property portfolio and solidifies its presence in the city-state's real estate market.

images.alt_text: The complex in Singapore’s central business district includes retail space, a 34-storey office tower, and a 45-storey building housing a JW Marriott Hotel.

site_title: OCBC stays the course on climate commitment
summary: OCBC remains committed to its decarbonization agenda despite global efforts to combat climate change facing headwinds. The bank's group chief sustainability officer Mike Ng says climate change is a "real issue based on science" and that OCBC's commitment to net-zero emissions by 2050 is a "strategic, long-term decision." OCBC supports businesses through strategic advisory, innovative financial solutions, and ecosystem partnerships to achieve their sustainability goals. The bank also offers unique products, such as its 1.5 degrees Celsius loan, and a sustainability hub for retail investors.

images.alt_text: South-east Asian banks must keep up decarbonisation efforts despite lower climate targets

site_title: Going green in a multi-polar world
summary: Institutional investors are a bright spot in the fight against climate change, with the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change finding that more institutions are integrating climate into their investment processes. A Morgan Stanley survey found that over half of individual investors plan to invest more in sustainable investments, citing increased confidence in market-rate returns. However, the global financing gap remains acute, with the annual amount of finance needed to fund climate efforts surging by 36% from 2015 to 2022. The region requires about $2.2 trillion for mitigation and $2.5 trillion for adaptation, but only a fraction of this amount is currently in climate finance flows.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

Sustainable investing is no passing fad
Ng says that OCBC’s net-zero commitment in its financed emissions is a “strategic, long-term decision”, aligned with the enduring nature of climate change.
The WMO says there is an 80 per cent chance that at least one year between 2025 and 2029 will be warmer than the warmest year on record, 2024.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, June 4, 2025
summary: Asian stocks rose following Wall Street's gains after jobs data, while South Korean stocks entered a bull market after Lee's presidential election win. However, bonds sank due to the election outcome. Meanwhile, iron ore markets are poised for a shake-up as the Singapore-linked Simandou project nears production.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Wellington, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta stocks all rose on Wednesday.

The Kospi Index ended 2.7 per cent higher on Wednesday (Jun 4), taking its gain from the April low to more than 20 per cent as investors piled into potential beneficiaries of Lee’s reform and growth agenda.
The expected influx of high-grade iron ore from Simandou might worsen an oversupply situation as China’s demand growth softens, which would put more pressure on iron ore producers.

site_title: CIMB set to appoint former Securities Commission chief Syed Zaid as chairman: sources
summary: CIMB Group Holdings, South-east Asia's fifth-largest lender by assets, is set to appoint former Securities Commission chief Syed Zaid Albar as chairman, pending regulatory approval. The appointment comes as incumbent chairman Mohd Nasir Ahmad prepares to step down after nearly a decade on the board and six years as chairman. CIMB posted a net profit of RM2 billion, a 1.9% increase from a year earlier, driven by stronger net interest income and non-interest income growth. The bank's leadership transition follows its steady financial performance and a more challenging macroeconomic environment across South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Tan Ai Leng
Maybank said results for the first quarter of FY2025 were “lacklustre” as the results of several banks came in below expectations. PHOTO: BT FILE
“Malaysia has all the parameters that tick the boxes for investors as they look at asset allocation and investments,” Novan Amirudin says.
South-east Asian banks must keep up decarbonisation efforts despite lower climate targets
CIMB has 592 retail branches across 10 countries, serving around 28 million customers.

site_title: Singapore stocks close Wednesday higher amid regional gains; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,903.88 on Wednesday, driven by regional gains and speculation of a potential Trump-Xi call to ease trade tensions. The broader market saw 311 gainers and 163 losers, with one billion securities worth S$1.2 billion changing hands. South Korea's Kospi led regional gains, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Japan's Nikkei 225 also rose. The STI's gains were tempered by concerns over trade uncertainty and a possible slowdown in Singapore's economy.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1 per cent or 3.79 points to 3,894.38.

site_title: Malaysia’s EPF weighs £1.4 billion sale of UK private hospitals
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) is selling a portfolio of 12 UK private hospitals valued at £1.4 billion, following a surge in interest for healthcare properties with long-term leases. The hospitals, operated by Spire Healthcare Group, were purchased by an EPF-led consortium in 2013 for £700 million. The sale, facilitated by Knight Frank, comes as investors seek alternative assets to diversify their portfolios. The UK's National Health Service (NHS) has increased its use of private hospitals to reduce waiting times, with £2.1 billion spent in private hospitals last year.

images.alt_text: Total investment assets stood at RM1.26 trillion as of end-March, with 38 per cent invested internationally, EPF said.
EPF, one of the world’s biggest pension funds, in common with other major investors is grappling with the uncertainty triggered by US President Donald Trump’s tariffs and policy orders.
Currently, the Employees Provident Fund has over 16 million members, of which nearly 8.8 million are active members

site_title: South Korea’s new leader to seek more time for US trade talks
summary: South Korea's new President Lee Jae-myung is seeking more time for US trade talks, citing the need to study Japan and China's negotiations for leverage. The deadline of July 8 is being reconsidered, with the administration aiming to buy time to formulate a strategy. The future of South Korea's export-oriented economy hinges on the outcome of the talks, with key sectors exposed to global trade. The US has set a deadline for countries to provide their best offer, but Seoul may use ongoing negotiations with other countries to gain time.

images.alt_text: (From left) Democratic Party presidential candidate Lee Jae Myung  and his wife Kim Hye Gyeong celebrate at the party's headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, June 4, 2025.

site_title: How to ace Father’s Day
summary: Father's Day is approaching, with just one week to go. To make it special, consider gifting unique items such as personalized items, unique clothing, or experiences like a nostalgia walk or massage. Alternatively, last-minute ideas include superimposing his face on a birthday cake or gift. The article also highlights various other topics, including travel, shopping, arts, and dining, but focuses on providing ideas for a perfect Father's Day celebration.

site_title: Trump signs travel ban for 12 countries including Myanmar
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a proclamation banning individuals from 12 countries, including Myanmar, from entering the US, reinstating a travel ban from his first term. The ban covers Afghanistan, Myanmar, and 10 other countries, with exemptions for those with visas, lawful permanent residents, or teams traveling for the World Cup or Olympics. The move comes after a recent terror attack in Boulder, Colorado, and Trump claims it's necessary to vet foreign nationals. The ban is likely to face legal challenges, following a similar ban from his first term, which was upheld by the US Supreme Court in 2018.

images.alt_text: Early on Wednesday, US President Donald Trump appeared to dampen hopes for a quick resolution with China.
Tesla scion Elon Musk has called US President Donald Trump's "big, beautiful bill"  a “disgusting abomination.”
“ADP number out. ‘Too Late’ Powell must now lower the rate. He is unbelievable. Europe has lowered nine times,” US President Donald Trump said in a Truth Social post.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens slightly higher after private payrolls data
summary: US stocks opened slightly higher on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 54.5 points, or 0.13%, to 42,574.13, amid concerns about the Trump administration's trade policies and their impact on the labour market. Weaker-than-expected private payrolls data deepened these concerns. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains, rising 0.14% and 0.19%, respectively.

site_title: Thai business group cuts 2025 GDP forecast as US tariffs threaten exports
summary: Thailand's business group has cut its 2025 GDP forecast due to US tariffs threatening exports. The economy is now expected to grow 1.5% to 2.0%, down from 2.0% to 2.2%, with exports likely to drop 0.5% to rise 0.3%. Uncertainty over trade negotiations with Washington and potential better deals from neighboring countries, such as Vietnam, have raised concerns. The US tariff of 36% on Thailand's exports and a 46% tariff on Vietnam's exports will also impact the economy.

images.alt_text: Thailand faces challenges including the tariff threat from the US, as well as structural issues such as ageing and high household debts, notes Euben Paracuelles of Nomura.

site_title: Madrid's ghost towns revived as Spain's housing crisis escalates
summary: Spain's housing crisis is escalating, with demand outpacing supply in ghost towns like Sesena, 40km south of Madrid. Construction has restarted, and there's a waiting list of 70 people for each property. Middle-class families are moving in, drawn by affordable prices, with some homes selling for 20% less than in the city centre. The crisis is exacerbated by a boom in holiday lets, record migration, and onerous planning laws. Authorities aim to provide affordable homes, with the government planning to build 110,000 new homes by 2028.

images.alt_text: Spain is trying to balance maintaining tourism as its economic engine while addressing popular concern over high housing costs as landlords opt for more lucrative tourist rentals.
To fight the housing shortage, the central and local administrations are also clamping down on holiday rentals, with Barcelona aiming to ban all short-term rentals by 2029.
Every quarter, Madrid puts 50 to 200 social housing flats up for grabs in a lottery that is open to people who meet income and residency criteria.

site_title: Most COE category premiums down; mainstream car category drops 5.4% to S$96,999
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums for the first round of June bidding showed a decline across categories, except for motorcycles, which rose 3.5%. The mainstream car category (Category A) decreased 5.4% to S$96,999, its second-largest drop this year. The commercial-vehicle category (Category C) fell 1.9%, while Category E (open category) dropped 3.5%. The decline in premiums is attributed to high prices in recent months, with dealers expecting a correction. The drop in premiums may lead to increased buying activity and showroom traffic.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
Sky-high prices are reflective of the fact that premiums have been steadily rising over the past two decades.
Aaron Tan, Co-founder and CEO, Carro
A passenger enters a Grab taxi private hire car outside Bishan Junction 8 December 11, 2020.
Neta dealer Evology Automobile has closed its showroom at One Commonwealth in Singapore as at April 12, 2025.

site_title: Sip, savour and explore: Unveiling Cocktail Months at MGallery hotels across the world
summary: MGallery hotels, a collection of 120 luxury boutique hotels under French hospitality group Accor, is celebrating World Cocktail Months through August 31. The celebration features three limited-edition cocktails created in collaboration with Citadelle Gin, available exclusively at MGallery hotels. The cocktails include the Crystal Diva, Timeless Negroni, and Honey 75, each crafted by guest mixologists at different hotels. The event also includes unique experiences, such as a traditional Japanese rickshaw ride in Sapporo, Japan, and a guided tour of artworks at Hotel Naru Seoul - MGallery Collection in South Korea.

images.alt_text: Sarah Poniatowski, founder, designer and chief executive officer of Maison Sarah Lavoine, with the three cocktail glasses she designed.
Consider alternative destinations such as Labuan Bajo, Indonesia, to crowded hot spots.

site_title: National Gallery Singapore’s ink show is ambitious – but unsatisfying
summary: National Gallery Singapore's "Where Ink Tides Meet" exhibition showcases over 50 never-before-seen ink works, including new acquisitions, tracing the history of ink art and highlighting creative exchange across cultures. However, the show is marred by significant gaps, particularly the lack of women artists and younger voices, with the majority featuring male artists from the 20th century. The exhibition highlights moments of beauty and insight, but its uneven quality and limited representation raise questions about whose stories are told and how ink can continue to feel relevant without emerging artists. The show runs from June 6 to November 16, 2025.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Valerie Koh, a mother of four, calls her Crybaby plushies "mood boosters".
National Gallery Singapore honours the late Spanish-Filipino abstractionist Fernando Zobel with his first Singapore retrospective.
Wilfredo Lam's print Apostroph’ Apocalypse Plate IX (1966) is one of over 60 prints on display at STPI.

site_title: China considers ordering hundreds of Airbus jets in major deal
summary: China is considering ordering hundreds of Airbus jets, potentially worth $100 billion, in a major deal that could surpass the largest ever order. The order, which could include 200-500 aircraft, would be a significant boost to Airbus and a blow to Boeing, which has not won a major order from China since 2017 due to trade tensions and self-inflicted issues. The deal could be finalized during a visit by European leaders to Beijing in July to celebrate 50 years of diplomatic relations between China and the European Union.

images.alt_text: Getting new planes is crucial for Air India, which has suffered from years of under-investment under government ownership and is now undertaking an ambitious modernisation plan to recapture market share lost to global rivals.
The cautious tone on deliveries was reinforced at a recent customer gathering in Toulouse.

site_title: Hedge fund manager Ray Dalio remains as adviser to Indonesia’s Danantara, quashes exit rumours
summary: Ray Dalio, founder of Bridgewater Associates, has reaffirmed his role as an informal, unpaid adviser to Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund Danantara and Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto, following speculation about his possible departure. Dalio stated his commitment to advising the fund remains unchanged, despite media reports suggesting he may have distanced himself amid restructuring in Indonesia's investment ecosystem. His advisory role is described as purely advisory and non-executive, with no formal contract or compensation.
