“Our priority remains ensuring that European consumers can have a safe, reliable, and enjoyable online shopping experience,” Shein said.
Sales have taken a beating for both Shein and Temu in the US following the e-commerce platforms’ price adjustments.
Given the ongoing instability of the situation, analysts say Shein has little choice but to reduce its reliance on China.
Uncertainties remain around trade negotiations – and e-commerce retailers such as Shein.

site_title: Japan’s richest ride yen gains; Uniqlo boss Tadashi Yanai leads 2025 pack with record US$48 billion fortune
summary: Japan's 50 richest individuals saw a 14% increase in total wealth to US$228 billion, driven by the yen's strength, despite the country slashing its economic growth estimate to 0.5%. Tadashi Yanai, CEO of Fast Retailing and Uniqlo, topped the list with a record US$48.2 billion fortune, followed by Masayoshi Son of SoftBank Group with US$28.2 billion. Other notable individuals include Nobutada Saji of Suntory and Yasumitsu Shigeta of Hikari Tsushin, who joined the top five wealthiest for the first time.

site_title: Australia central bank pondered outsized rate cut in May, decided to be predictable
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) considered a 50 basis point interest rate cut in May to address global trade risks, but ultimately decided to hold rates at 4.10% due to a resilient domestic economy and tight labour market. The board was influenced by US President Donald Trump's tariffs, which posed significant risks to global growth, but deemed it not yet time to move monetary policy to an expansionary stance. Markets imply a 70% chance of a rate cut at the next meeting on July 8, with analysts expecting rates to bottom around 2.85-3.1% by early next year.

The minimum rate will rise to A$24.94 (S$20.80) per hour for about a fifth of the Australian workforce, the Fair Work Commission said in its annual review.

site_title: Bank of Japan urged to keep or slow bond taper pace from fiscal 2026
summary: The Bank of Japan is reviewing its taper plan and may slow down the reduction of its bond purchases from fiscal year 2026. Financial institutions have urged the central bank to maintain or slightly slow the pace, citing concerns over declining market liquidity for super-long bonds. The BOJ will conduct a review at its next policy meeting on June 16-17, with some participants calling for reducing monthly purchases to around one trillion yen to two trillion yen by the end of the new taper program.

images.alt_text: The BOJ has usually kept a target of provision for losses on bond transactions around 50 per cent of gains or losses from the transactions.
People shop in a supermarket in Tokyo, Japan, May 23, 2025. Japan's core inflation rate accelerated in April to 3.5 percent as rice prices almost doubled year-on-year, official data showed.

Renewed rise in food prices, particularly a 90 per cent spike in the price of rice, is pushing up not just headline but underlying inflation, which is typically influenced mostly by improvements in the economy and a tight job market, Kazuo Ueda said.

The year-on-year increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which includes oil products but excludes fresh food prices, compared with a median market forecast for a 3.4 per cent gain and followed a 3.2 per cent gain in March.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 3)
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) proposed a framework for private-market investment funds, welcomed by the private capital community. Industry players emphasized the need for transparency and flexibility in valuation and fee structures. Meanwhile, South-east Asia's export boom may be fading due to the impending US tariff pause. City Developments placed a top bid for a site next to Lakeside MRT station, and SMRT was fined S$3 million for a major MRT disruption in 2024. Singapore stocks rose on the prospects of US-China trade talks.

site_title: US pushes countries for best offers by Wednesday as tariff deadline looms
summary: The US is urging countries, including the European Union, Japan, and India, to submit their best offers by June 4 as a deadline for trade negotiations looms. The US Trade Representative's office has requested countries to provide proposals on tariffs, quotas, and digital trade, with the goal of reaching a "landing zone" that could include reciprocal tariff rates. The deadline is part of the US's effort to complete deals ahead of a self-imposed deadline in July, despite ongoing litigation over the legality of some tariffs.

images.alt_text: As China keeps constraints on metals critical to America’s national security, Washington is ramping up its own tech restrictions.
More than 80 per cent of the aluminium used in the US is supplied via imports, while less than 20 per cent of the country’s steel is sourced from overseas, according to Morgan Stanley.
Beijing accused the US of unilaterally introducing new discriminatory restrictions.
Since returning to the presidency in January, US President Donald Trump has moved to reconfigure US trade ties with the world while using levies to force foreign governments to the negotiating table.

site_title: Trade war cuts global economic growth outlook: OECD
summary: The OECD slashed its global growth forecast to 2.9% for 2025 and 2026, citing US President Donald Trump's tariffs as a major contributor to the slowdown. The US economy is now expected to grow at 1.6% in 2025 and 1.5% in 2026, down from a previous forecast of 2.2%. US inflation is expected to accelerate to just under 4% by the end of the year, while the eurozone economy is expected to grow at 1%. The OECD warns that protectionism and trade policy uncertainty will increase further, fueling inflation and dampening global growth.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 30: Shipping containers sit stacked in the Port of Newark on September 30, 2024 seen from New York City. The OECD's Andrew Blazey says that the arrangements for fiscal discipline and fiscal management are very strong in Singapore.

Indonesia is among 140 countries which agreed on a landmark 2021 deal that allows governments to apply a top-up tax to the 15 per cent level on any corporate profits booked in a country with a lower rate.

Under new rules being shepherded by the OECD, a minimum 15 per cent tax will be charged on multinationals with an annual global turnover of more than 750 million euros (S$1.06 billion), regardless of their location.
The OECD says “increases in trade-restrictive measures could raise costs and prices, deter investment, weaken innovation and ultimately lower growth”.

site_title: Electric trucks are the latest threat to oil demand in China
summary: China is shifting towards electric trucks, threatening oil demand. Tax breaks on electric vehicle sales, including trucks, have boosted sales, with electric trucks accounting for 22% of light-duty commercial vehicle sales in April. Diesel demand is being threatened on two fronts, with liquefied natural gas gaining traction. The central government's incentives and local trade-in programs are driving the switch, with apparent demand for diesel falling 8.4% year-on-year in April. Electric trucks could jump to 50% of new sales in the next three years, according to forecasts.

images.alt_text: Tesla has long wanted to sell in India, but high tariffs, which its chief Elon Musk has said are among the steepest in the world, have been a deterrent.
As of end-May, Nio’s cumulative deliveries reached 760,789 vehicles. PHOTO: REUTERS
The company is also ramping up overseas sales, delivering more than 89,000 units in May, its highest on record.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise as traders eye possible Trump-Xi talks
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday as investors awaited possible talks between US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping amid the ongoing China-US trade war. Trump accused Beijing of violating a deal to slash tariffs, but expressed confidence in speaking with Xi, who has expressed uncertainty about a conversation. The US Treasury Secretary hinted at talks this week, and officials from both sides are set to meet at an OECD ministerial meeting in Paris. The rally was driven by hopes for a positive outcome, with gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, and other Asian markets.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 slipped 0.14 per cent to 547.92 on Monday, after recording about a 4 per cent gain in May.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 0.1 per cent at 42,305.48, while the broad-based S&P 500 finished 0.4 per cent higher at 5,935.94 on Monday.

site_title: Singapore hedge fund Arrowpoint capitalised on May market turmoil
summary: Singapore's Arrowpoint Investment Partners, backed by Blackstone, Canada Pension Plan, and Temasek's Seviora, has capitalized on market dislocations since mid-April, generating a 3% gain in May, its best month since launch last July. The $1.1 billion multi-strategy hedge fund exploited dislocations in equities, currencies, and bond curves, including non-deliverable forwards in Asia FX markets and Australian rate curve anomalies. The fund's chief investment officer, Jonathan Xiong, expects more arbitrage opportunities ahead as market volatility increases and investors seek diversification.

images.alt_text: The Temasek logo at the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.

Australia has a large, mature electricity market with relatively few players and plenty of space for new arrivals.

Suzuki’s India unit is the country’s biggest car company by sales and recently started production at its first new plant in eight years.

site_title: Singapore companies must go global despite ongoing trade turbulence: SBF returning chairman SS Teo
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) Chairman SS Teo urges businesses to expand globally due to ongoing trade turbulence, citing the need to "break out of their comfort zone" and pursue new opportunities in emerging markets like South-east Asia, Africa, and the Middle East. With over a third of businesses already feeling the impact of global tariffs, Teo plans to intensify SBF's efforts to organize trade missions, launch new Singapore Enterprise Centres, and provide advice on navigating tariffs and free trade agreements.

SBF chairman Lim Ming Yan was just re-elected for a third two-year term in June 2024., following the business chamber’s annual general meeting.

site_title: CDL places S$1,132 psf ppr top bid for plot next to Lakeside MRT station
summary: Singapore's City Developments (CDL) has secured the top bid for a 99-year private housing site next to Lakeside MRT station, paying S$1,132 psf ppr. The site can yield about 575 private homes, with a capped commercial component of 10,764 sq ft gross floor area. This bid was within the predicted range of S$900 to S$1,250 psf ppr, drawing six bids from developers for the site zoned for residential and commercial use.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
The three sites were launched under the confirmed list.
Media Circle (Parcel B), zoned residential with commercial at first storey, can yield about 500 private homes.
The 99-year leasehold privatre housing site in Bayshore Road can yield about 515 units.

site_title: China’s private factory gauge plunges to weakest since 2022
summary: China's manufacturing sector experienced its worst slump since September 2022, with the Caixin manufacturing purchasing managers' index falling to 48.3 in May. The private sector gauge is significantly lower than the official PMI reading, highlighting the disproportionate damage to small and medium-sized Chinese companies from the trade war. Higher tariffs took a toll on smaller exporters, despite a truce in the trade war with the US. The economy remains under pressure from sluggish domestic demand, and the prospects for manufacturing in the months ahead are uncertain due to an uncertain export outlook.

images.alt_text: As China keeps constraints on metals critical to America’s national security, Washington is ramping up its own tech restrictions.
Hong Kong’s audit regulator is still investigating PwC’s Hong Kong role in the Evergrande audit.
Beijing accused the US of unilaterally introducing new discriminatory restrictions.

site_title: Australia cracks down on crypto ATMs as scams, fraud uncovered
summary: Australia's financial crimes agency, Austrac, has cracked down on cryptocurrency ATMs amid rising scams and fraud. The agency has imposed a $5,000 limit on cash deposits and withdrawals, refused to renew the registration of one crypto ATM provider, and introduced enhanced customer due diligence and scam warnings. Austrac has also found that 72% of crypto ATM transactions were made by customers aged 50 and older, with those between 60 and 70 accounting for 29%. The agency warns consumers to be cautious when using these machines, especially if asked to send funds to someone.

site_title: Asean’s export rush wanes as tariff clock ticks down
summary: South-east Asia's export boom may be nearing its end as major exporters face a looming slowdown due to a US tariff pause ending on July 9. Despite a front-loaded rush to export goods, April trade data shows a month-on-month slowdown in Thailand, Vietnam, and the Philippines, with the rest of the region likely to follow in the second half of the year. This could lead to stronger export growth in the second quarter than initially projected.

images.alt_text: An archive photo of Port Klang. It is one of the key transshipment hubs in South-east Asia, handling over 14.6 million TEUs in 2024.
Overall, total trade rose 14.7% from the corresponding year-ago period in April.
Vietnam sees strong exports, FDI pledges in April despite tariff woes

site_title: Australia raises minimum wages by 3.5% as inflation eases
summary: Australia's Fair Work Commission raised the national minimum wage by 3.5% to A$24.94 per hour, effective July 1, resulting in a real wage increase for about 2.6 million workers on the minimum wage. This increase comes as inflation eases, with headline consumer price inflation holding at 2.4% in the first quarter, within the Reserve Bank of Australia's target band. The move aims to correct the wage stagnation experienced over the last four years and is seen as a positive outcome for employees on minimum wages.

images.alt_text: The largest capital markets of Sydney and Melbourne are among the softest, the data shows.
The port is Australia’s northernmost maritime facility, positioned close to South-east Asia.

site_title: Oil gains on supply concerns as wildfires disrupt Canada supply, Opec+ keeps output plans unchanged
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 3% on Monday as supply concerns grew due to wildfires in Canada's Alberta province, disrupting 7% of the country's crude oil output. Opec+ kept its output plans unchanged, despite mixed signals from Iran-US talks. A weaker US dollar and concerns over geopolitical risk also supported prices, with Brent crude futures settling at $64.63 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $62.52. Analysts expect Opec+ to implement further production increases, with Goldman Sachs predicting a total of 2.2 million barrels per day by October.

images.alt_text: Opec+ officials have said the quota boost reflected Saudi Arabia’s desire to punish over-producing members such as Kazakhstan and Iraq.

site_title: China’s rare earths grip gives Xi leverage in US trade duel
summary: The US and China are embroiled in a trade dispute over access to critical minerals, particularly rare earth metals, which are crucial for making fighter jets, nuclear reactor control rods, and other critical technology. China has tightened controls on exports of these metals, despite agreeing to lift export controls in a Geneva tariff agreement. The US is accusing China of violating the agreement, and President Trump is seeking a call with Chinese President Xi Jinping to resolve the issue. The dispute has the potential to endanger the fragile trade truce between the two countries, and China's leverage in the standoff is seen as more durable.

images.alt_text: More than 80 per cent of the aluminium used in the US is supplied via imports, while less than 20 per cent of the country’s steel is sourced from overseas, according to Morgan Stanley.

site_title: Indian billionaire Adani under new scrutiny from US prosecutors: WSJ
summary: The US Justice Department is investigating whether Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's companies imported Iranian liquefied petroleum gas into India through their Mundra port, potentially evading sanctions. An investigation by the Wall Street Journal found tankers traveling between Mundra and the Persian Gulf exhibited traits common for ships evading sanctions. Adani Group has denied any deliberate engagement in sanctions evasion or trade involving Iranian-origin LPG. This comes months after Adani and his nephew were indicted on bribery allegations.

images.alt_text: Billionaire Gautam Adani-owned conglomerate, with interests stretching from ports to green energy, is steadily regaining creditor confidence following a US Department of Justice indicted Adani over an alleged bribery plot in November.

In November, US authorities indicted Gautam Adani (pictured) and his nephew, Sagar Adani, alleging that they paid bribes to secure Indian power supply contracts, and misled US investors during fund raises there.
Vizhinjam is expected to facilitate the movement of transshipment traffic into India as well as on the major routes between the US, Europe, Africa and East Asia.
North Queensland Export Terminal is part of the Adani Group operating under the Bravus banner in Australia.
The latest win is the second boost for the Adani Group as it is in the process of redeveloping Mumbai’s Dharavi slum, which is also the largest in Asia.
Adani Enterprises will sell a 13 per cent stake in Adani Wilmar to comply with India’s minimum public shareholding requirements.
The founder of the port-to-power conglomerate is considered a close ally of the prime minister.
Indian billionaire Gautam Adani on Saturday blamed “a lot of the vested reporting” for spreading “negativity” about the nature of the US charges.

site_title: Disney lays off hundreds in film, TV as industry woes linger
summary: Walt Disney is laying off hundreds of employees across its film and TV businesses, marking the latest round of cost-cutting in the struggling entertainment industry. The layoffs, which began on Monday, affect employees in marketing, publicity, casting, and development, as well as corporate financial operations. The move comes as consumers shift to streaming services, crimping advertising and distribution revenue for traditional channels, and follows previous cuts by competitors such as Comcast and Warner Bros Discovery.

images.alt_text: The company will continue to offer its ESPN+ streaming service, which has programming different from the main channels.

ABC shows "20/20" and "Nightline" will be consolidating into one unit, the Wall Street Journal said, adding that ABC would also be eliminating the political and data-driven news site 538, which had about 15 employees.

site_title: Widjaja family’s Sinarmas Land offer closes with 98.65% resultant shareholding
summary: The Widjaja family's Sinarmas Land has completed a privatisation offer, resulting in a 98.65% resultant shareholding after 4.2 billion shares were accepted. The offeror, Lyon Investments, will now acquire remaining shares, triggering a compulsory acquisition and delisting from the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading. The offer price was S$0.375 per share, a 21% increase over the initial bid.

site_title: Bearish investors live in hope as markets rise
summary: Market bears are optimistic as the S&P 500 resumes an uptrend, potentially forcing them to cover shorts and redirect cash to bulls. Rising inflation in Japan, with high debt-to-GDP and interest rates, could drive the yen up and encourage Japanese investors to exit US investments, leading to a market collapse and profits for bears. The S&P 500 has approached old highs, testing a rounding-top pattern, and a breakout above 6,000 would confirm continued bullish pressure. Gold prices have also risen, contradicting the usual risk relationship, and a move below 5,700 would signal continuation of bearish pressure.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended 0.6 per cent lower at 42,098.70 on Wednesday.

The earnings yield of the S&p 500, which measures how much investors are willing to pay for each dollar of corporate profit, has dropped to 3.95 per cent, about half percentage point below 10-year bond yields.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.8 per cent higher at 42,343.65 on Tuesday.
The US dollar index fell 0.1 per cent after a sharp rise in the previous session, making greenback-priced gold more attractive for other currency holders.

site_title: Microsoft cuts hundreds more jobs after firing 6,000 last month
summary: Microsoft has cut hundreds more jobs, adding to its 6,000 layoffs last month, as the tech industry prioritizes AI-focused jobs and harnesses the technology to save costs. The company, which has about 228,000 full-time employees, did not specify the types of jobs affected. This move follows similar efforts by peers like Meta Platforms, which have touted the effectiveness of AI-assisted coding tools in speeding up software development. The AI boom is roiling the tech labor market, with companies seeking to trim costs while investing in AI.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is focused on driving adoption of Copilot AI and is closely tracking what share of customer workforces are using the tools, CEO Satya Nadella said during the event.
xAI’s Grok chatbot last week ignited controversy by answering multiple user prompts with right-wing propaganda about the purported oppression of white South Africans.
Microsoft is holding its Build conference in Seattle on May 19, where analysts expect the company to unveil its latest tools for developers building AI systems.

site_title: Google Deepmind CEO says global AI cooperation ‘difficult’
summary: Google DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis stated that global AI cooperation for regulation is needed but "difficult" due to geopolitical tensions. He emphasized the importance of international cooperation to address AI's impact on various industries and societal concerns. Hassabis advocated for "smart, adaptable regulation" to adapt to the evolving technology and problems. The call for cooperation comes after a 2025 AI summit in Paris, which saw 58 countries call for enhanced coordination on AI governance, while the US warned against excessive regulation.

images.alt_text: Meta plans to let advertisers personalise ads using AI, so that users see different versions of the same ad in real time, based on factors such as geolocation

site_title: Asia’s top-rated bonds lifted by pullback from US Treasuries
summary: Asia's top-rated bonds, particularly those in Australia and Singapore, have seen a lift due to a decline in US Treasuries and concerns over the US fiscal position. Regulators are considering easing rules on insurer asset reporting to mitigate the impact of the US dollar's decline. Taiwanese insurers are shifting away from US dollar assets, while Hong Kong pension funds prepare contingency plans. The Singapore dollar market is expected to gain more investors due to its AAA rating, with Goldman Sachs predicting a shift towards this market over time.

site_title: Toyota to take key supplier private in US$33 billion deal
summary: Toyota Motor will take forklift-maker Toyota Industries private in a $33 billion deal, allowing the company to take a longer-term business perspective. The deal, which includes a $26 billion tender offer, will be funded by the Toyota Group, with Akio Toyoda investing $1 billion and Toyota Fudosan investing $180 billion. The acquisition will simplify cross-shareholdings within the group and enable Toyota Motor to leverage potential autonomous logistics technology in the future.

images.alt_text: Toyota has mostly stayed its course, emphasising that it will respond flexibility but refrain from big changes until the future is less opaque.
The company is one of several companies focusing on eVTOL that plan to fly customers on short commuter journeys via battery-powered air taxis.
The latest RAV4 is not a complete redo: It uses the same chassis and underpinnings as the current version, and borrows the Camry’s hybrid powertrain.

site_title: South Koreans vote for president in hope of restoring stability after martial law crisis
summary: South Koreans voted for a new president on June 3, 2025, amidst six months of turmoil triggered by a martial law attempt by former leader Yoon Suk Yeol. The election is seen as a chance to restore stability after a chaotic period, with voters urging the next leader to ease discord and address economic challenges. Liberal frontrunner Lee Jae Myung and conservative rival Kim Moon Soo have pledged change, with Lee advocating for investment in innovation and technology, and Kim campaigning on giving businesses more freedom. Turnout is expected to be high, with Lee favored to win according to polls, leading Kim by 14 percentage points.

site_title: Gold hovers near four-week peak on weaker US dollar, trade concerns
summary: Gold prices rose to a near four-week high on Tuesday, driven by a weaker US dollar and rising uncertainty over the US-China trade deal. The US dollar index hit a one-month low, making gold cheaper for foreign buyers. Spot gold increased 0.1% to $3,381.13 an ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.3% to $3,406.10. The European Commission is set to make a strong case for US tariffs to be reduced or eliminated, amid tensions between the US and China.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered as a safe-haven asset during geopolitical and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Google to spend US$500 million revamping compliance in shareholder settlement
summary: Google agreed to spend $500 million over 10 years to overhaul its compliance structure, settling shareholder litigation accusing the company of antitrust violations. The changes include creating standalone committees to oversee risk and compliance, and reporting to CEO Sundar Pichai. Shareholders, led by Michigan pension funds, accused Google executives of breaching fiduciary duties, but will not receive payment. The settlement requires US district judge Rita Lin's approval and must remain in place for at least four years.

site_title: Elon Musk taps investors for billions days after Washington exit
summary: Elon Musk is selling $5 billion in debt for his AI startup xAI, with Morgan Stanley shopping the debt for a double-digit interest rate. The financing will help Musk continue to spend aggressively on AI infrastructure, including a massive data centre in Memphis. The debt sale, which has garnered demand of over $3.5 billion, comes after Musk stepped back from politics and returns to running his businesses. This is the latest in a series of fundraising efforts across his business empire, following recent raises for his neurotechnology company Neuralink and social networking platform X.

images.alt_text: Musk discovered that operating in the political sphere of Washington is very different from doing business in the free market, and he did end up spending too much time on politics.
As the world’s richest person bowed out of his role as Trump’s cost-cutter-in-chief, the Republican hailed Musk’s “incredible service” and handed him a golden key to the White House.

Tycoon Elon Musk on Wednesday thanked US President Donald Trump as his time as a special government employee as a part of the Department of Government Efficiency draws to an end, he said in a post on social media platform X.

Tech tycoon Elon Musk said President Donald Trump’s bill would increase the US deficit and undermine the work of Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency (Doge), which has fired tens of thousands of people.

site_title: US manufacturing remains subdued in May; delivery times lengthening
summary: US manufacturing contracted for a third straight month in May, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing PMI at a six-month low of 48.5, below the 50 threshold that indicates contraction. Despite this, the PMI remains above the 42.3 level that suggests an overall economic expansion. The survey also showed suppliers taking longer to deliver inputs amid tariffs, potentially leading to shortages of some goods. Economists attribute the slowdown to the ongoing trade tensions and uncertainty surrounding the implementation of tariffs.

images.alt_text: Inflation-adjusted personal spending rose 0.1 per cent after rising 0.7 per cent a month earlier.
Cranes at the Port of Los Angeles are empty of cargo ships in San Pedro, California, May 13, 2025.

The US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on Thursday has granted a temporary stay “until further notice” while the Trump administration’s appeals process plays out. This means the tariffs can remain in effect for now, while a longer-term outcome is yet to be determined.
Companies ranging from airlines, retailers to motor vehicle manufacturers have either withdrawn or refrained from giving financial guidance for 2025.
The economy’s primary growth engine – consumer spending – advanced 1.2 per cent, down from an initial estimate of 1.8 per cent and the weakest pace in almost two years.
The Fed‘s meeting on May 6 and 7 took place after US President Donald Trump had announced a 90-day pause on the most severe levies he had threatened against dozens of trading partners.

Given high uncertainty around the economic impact of US tariffs and trade policy, central banks should focus on avoiding taking steps where the “cost of getting it wrong far outweighs the benefits,” rather than aiming for the perfect solution to the problem, New York Federal Reserve President John Williams said.
Some consumers mentioned lower gas prices in write-in responses.

site_title: The world’s strongest currency is also super-competitive
summary: Switzerland's strong currency, the Swiss franc, has enabled the country to maintain a highly competitive economy despite a strong manufacturing base. The country's decentralized system encourages small enterprises, accounting for over 99% of Swiss companies, and its exports have risen to near historic highs. Switzerland's exports are valued for their high quality, earning a currency premium, and the country has a large share of globally competitive businesses. Its all-weather economy has allowed it to resist external shocks, with a net international investment surplus of over 100% of GDP.

images.alt_text: France’s BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank and US lenders Citi and Bank of America are among those increasing staffing and courting smaller companies that form the bedrock of the Swiss economy.
Swiss business doing well months after franc shock

site_title: Ads ruined social media; now they’re coming to AI
summary: Artificial intelligence chatbots are pivoting to the ad model, similar to social media, which fueled the internet's attention economy. As subscription revenue limits growth, companies like OpenAI and Google are exploring advertising to boost profits. However, this shift may lead to addiction, manipulation, and emotional attachments, potentially compromising users' well-being and autonomy. Regulating AI advertising is crucial to avoid repeating the mistakes of social media, where targeted manipulation and data exploitation led to significant consequences.

images.alt_text: The pact between Google and Facebook, the No 1 and No 2 players in the online advertising market, was approved at the highest levels of both companies.

site_title: Europe: Shares stumble on Trump’s new tariff threat
summary: European shares slipped 0.14% to 547.92 on Monday, amid US President Donald Trump's new tariff plans that threatened to reignite global trade tensions. Trump's plan to increase tariffs on imported steel and aluminum to 50% from 25% prompted a decline in the automobile sector, with Stellantis and Mercedes-Benz falling 5% and 2.7% respectively. Despite this, oil stocks rose 1.4% and mining and healthcare companies boosted shares. The European Central Bank is set to announce interest rates on Thursday, with traders pricing in a quarter-point cut.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 0.1 per cent at 42,305.48, while the broad-based S&P 500 finished 0.4 per cent higher at 5,935.94 on Monday.

site_title: US airlines oppose credit card fee crackdown they say could imperil free flight offers
summary: Major US airlines, including Delta, United, and American Airlines, oppose a proposed bill that could reduce fees charged by Visa and Mastercard on transactions, potentially forcing them to stop offering rewards credit cards. The airlines argue the reduction in swipe fees would harm air travel and tourism, citing their billions of dollars in annual fees for branded credit cards. They also reference a 2010 law that nearly eliminated rewards debit cards. The bill, sponsored by Senators Dick Durbin and Roger Marshall, could save merchants and consumers $15 billion annually in fees.

images.alt_text: A Japan Airlines jet at Haneda Airport. Photographer: Kentaro Takahashi/Bloomberg
The Dubai-based carrier will introduce one more upgrade to the aircraft’s first-class cabins before retiring the planes at the end of next decade.
Newark Liberty, one of the main airports serving New York City, is about 9 miles (14.5 km) from Manhattan.
The cautious tone on deliveries was reinforced at a recent customer gathering in Toulouse.

(From left) France's President Emmanuel Macron, Airbus executive vice-president Wouter van Wersch, Vietjet CEO Dinh Viet Phuong and Vietnam's President Luong Cuong pose after signing a trade agreement at the Presidential Palace, Hanoi, Vietnam, May 26, 2025.

site_title: Asean increasingly pulled in opposite directions
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) is facing increased pressure from the US and China, pulling it in opposite directions. The US is pushing Asean countries to clamp down on transshipments from China to circumvent US tariffs, while China is strengthening ties with the region through initiatives such as the Belt and Road Initiative and an economic community. This has created uncertainty for Asean countries, which are likely to pivot towards trade with China in the short term, despite the risks of US tariffs going back up.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (middle), accompanied by Malaysia's international trade and industry minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz (right) and Malaysia's foreign affairs minister Mohamad Hasan, at the media conference of the close of the 46th Asean Summit in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: EB Impact to launch initiatives to raise awareness of sustainability among seniors, youth
summary: Non-profit organization EB Impact will launch two initiatives later this year to engage youth and seniors with sustainability, raising awareness and promoting social change. The Seeds of Change programme targets seniors, offering urban farming, sewing, and craft projects, while also providing training and resources for them to facilitate their own programmes. The Sustainability Youth Festival will engage youth through booths, hands-on activities, and a pitch competition for sustainability solutions. Both initiatives aim to promote sustainability and address social issues, such as increasing senior participation in society.

images.alt_text:
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam and Jane Ittogi touring various
stations showcasing programmes funded under President’s Challenge 2025.

site_title: Should SingPost stop delivering letters?
summary: Singapore Post (SingPost) may consider exiting the local letter delivery business due to declining mail volumes and unprofitable post office network. With technology adoption high in Singapore and digital services consolidated, SingPost could face significant financial challenges. PostNord in Denmark has successfully phased out letter delivery and focused on parcels, with a 90% decline in letter volumes since the turn of the century. Tweaking the postal network and raising rates may be options, but SingPost's monopoly on basic mail services ended in 2007, raising questions about its future role.

images.alt_text: Joyce Hooi
Singpost postman packing his mail in the Singpost delivery truck in Toa Payoh on 27 Mar 2020.
SingPost’s operating profit in H2 for its Singapore postal and logistics segment falls 55.5% year on year to S$7.4 million, from S$16.6 million.

site_title: Vanguard files for new ex-China emerging markets ETF
summary: Vanguard Group plans to launch a new exchange-traded fund (ETF) targeting emerging markets while excluding China, joining a growing niche amid investor debate over China's role in global portfolios. The Vanguard Emerging Markets ex-China ETF will debut later this summer, offering investors a fee of 0.07% and swapping outsize positions in China for exposure to Taiwanese and Indian companies. The move is seen as a response to geopolitical risks and investor concerns about state intervention in private markets, despite recent gains in Chinese stocks.

site_title: South Korea presidential candidates rally in final campaign stretch
summary: South Korea's presidential election is set to take place on June 3, with liberal candidate Lee Jae-myung leading conservative candidate Kim Moon-soo by 14 percentage points in polls. Lee has framed the campaign as a fight for the nation's soul, while Kim has focused on issues such as economic growth and national security. Despite controversy surrounding Lee's endorsement by a Singapore-based investor, experts say Lee remains the strong favourite to win, taking office on a single five-year term with no transition period.

images.alt_text: The case has cast a shadow over Lee Jae-myung’s bid in the Jun 3 South Korea presidential election.
Overseas voting reached a record high, with nearly four-fifths of the 1.97 million eligible voters casting their ballots last week.
South Korea faces a Jul 8 deadline before the bulk of US tariffs are due to start after a 90-day pause.
Yoon is accused of tacitly encouraging the violence after warning that the country was “in danger”.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, June 2, 2025
summary: Asian stocks fell as US President Donald Trump fired a fresh volley in the ongoing trade war, impacting exports and production in the region. South Korea's ministry announced plans to minimize the impact of a 50% tariff on steel products. In contrast, Grand Venture Tech and Azeus Systems saw significant gains, with shares rising 10% and 16.6% respectively.

images.alt_text: Asian markets sank on Monday as investors brushed off data showing the Federal Reserve’s favoured inflation gauge cooled more than expected last month.

site_title: Japan raises foreign direct investment target to 150 trillion yen by mid-2030s
summary: Japan's government has set a new foreign direct investment target of 150 trillion yen by the mid-2030s, a 20% increase from the previous goal of 100 trillion yen by 2030. The plan aims to stimulate regional economies, create jobs, and attract foreign firms to key growth sectors like decarbonisation. To achieve this, the government is considering new grants and public-private collaboration frameworks to support foreign facility establishment in local areas.

site_title: Stablecoin issuer Circle targets US$7.2 billion valuation in upsized US IPO
summary: Circle Internet, a US-based stablecoin issuer, is targeting a valuation of up to $7.2 billion in its upsized initial public offering (IPO) in the US. The company plans to raise up to $896 million from 32 million shares priced between $27 and $28 each. The IPO comes amid growing momentum in the stablecoin market, with Circle's USDC stablecoin expected to benefit from the impending stablecoin bill, which could catalyze institutional adoption. Circle's reserve income from interest on Treasuries backing its USDC coin rose 55.1% in the quarter ended March 31.

images.alt_text: New York-based Circle and some existing investors are looking to raise up to US$624 million by offering 24 million shares priced between US$24 and US$26 apiece.
Stablecoins have become crucial to the functioning of crypto markets, with about US$243 billion of them in circulation in May 2025.
Bankers have lobbied – mostly unsuccessfully so far – to bar commercial firms such as big tech companies or retailers from issuing their own tokens.
Stablecoins, a type of cryptocurrency designed to maintain a constant value, usually a 1:1 US dollar peg, are commonly used by crypto traders to move funds between tokens.

site_title: BlackRock plans private-market hires to win over rich Europeans
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, plans to expand its private-market offerings to individual investors in Europe, the Middle East, and Africa (Emea). The firm aims to boost access to its private-markets products through a hiring drive and tie-ups with digital investment platforms. BlackRock has committed $28 billion to acquiring private-asset firms to enter the space, driven by CEO Larry Fink's bet on shifting investment portfolios. The company plans to increase individual investors' access to private markets, with a goal of reaching at least 20% of portfolios in non-listed assets.

images.alt_text: The ports sale is structured to give the Italian billionaire Gianluigi Aponte family’s Geneva-based Terminal Investment ownership of all but the two Panama ports, whose control would go to BlackRock.
BlackRock’s Fink sees trillions of dollars idle as volatility persists
Larry Fink, CEO of BlackRock says: “The market downturn impacts millions of ordinary people’s retirement savings.”
BlackRock said investors added US$107 billion to exchange-traded funds and US$38 billion to fixed income in the first quarter.
The additional pay perks reflect BlackRock’s commitment to private markets, as does a trio of recent acquisitions.
Celia Yan will remain at the firm till the middle of June, ensuring an orderly transition of her responsibilities.

site_title: Earnings showing ‘uncertainty’ – that’s the only sure thing for investors
summary: Investors are feeling uncertain about the impact of President Donald Trump's global tariffs, with corporate executives citing a lack of clarity and macroeconomic uncertainty as a major concern. The courts have challenged Trump's tariffs, with a federal judge ruling some tariffs unlawful and a three-judge panel declaring the Trump administration's invocation of a 1977 law was wrong. As a result, investors are hesitant to make big decisions, and a measure of chief executives' confidence has plummeted to the lowest level since 2022, with over 80% expecting a recession within the next year and a half.

images.alt_text: Since returning to the presidency in January, US President Donald Trump has moved to reconfigure US trade ties with the world while using levies to force foreign governments to the negotiating table.

The US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on Thursday has granted a temporary stay “until further notice” while the Trump administration’s appeals process plays out. This means the tariffs can remain in effect for now, while a longer-term outcome is yet to be determined.

The implication of the “revenge” measure, as it’s quickly becoming known, is clear to analysts: If signed into law, it would further drive away foreign investors at a time when their once ironclad confidence in Treasury bonds and other US assets has already been shaken by Trump’s erratic trade policies and the nation’s deteriorating fiscal accounts.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher as traders shake off trade tensions
summary: US stocks ended higher on Monday, shaking off trade tensions fueled by President Donald Trump's recent tariff threats. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.1%, the S&P 500 climbed 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 0.7%. Despite Trump's threat to double steel tariffs, traders adopted a more buoyant mood, citing positive earnings from Nvidia and the potential impact of AI on profits. Auto makers were hit hard, with Ford and General Motors finishing the day down 3.9%.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 70.1 points, or 0.17 per cent, at Monday's open to 42199.94

site_title: Sanofi to buy US biopharma group Blueprint for up to US$9.5 billion
summary: Sanofi has agreed to buy US-based biopharma group Blueprint Medicines Corporation for up to $9.5 billion, bolstering its rare and immunology portfolios. The deal includes Blueprint's rare immunology disease drug Ayvakit and a promising pipeline, and is expected to close in the third quarter. Sanofi CEO Paul Hudson said the acquisition represents a strategic step forward in the company's transformation into a leading immunology company.

images.alt_text: The drugmaker will pivot away from consumer health to focus on fast-growing drugs such as its RSV shot.
The site, which will be in the Beijing Economic and Technological Development Zone, will be Sanofi’s fourth production and supply base in China.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after Trump’s steel tariff threat
summary: US stocks fell on Monday after President Donald Trump threatened to double tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, adding to uncertainty around US trade policies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 70.1 points, or 0.17%, to 42,199.94, while the S&P 500 fell 15 points, or 0.25%, to 5,896.68. The move sparked concerns about the impact on global trade and economic growth.

site_title: CK Hutchison announces completion of Vodafone and Three’s merger in UK
summary: Vodafone and CK Hutchison have completed the merger of their UK operations, creating VodafoneThree. The new company will invest £11 billion over the next 10 years in building a 5G network, surpassing BT's EE and O2 to become the market leader. VodafoneThree will also retain the Vodafone and Three brands, as well as Voxi and Smarty offers, and will create a new force in UK mobile, transforming the country's digital infrastructure.

images.alt_text: epa11702608 A pedestrian passes by a Vodafone mobile store in London, Britain, 05 November 2024. According to the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA), a merger between Vodafone and Three could go ahead if both companies make price promises to consumers and commit to a 5G rollout across the UK. Vodafone and Three announced plans to merge their UK-based operations in June 2023. If a merger goes ahead, their combined network would have some twenty-seven million customers.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
Vodafone's net profit totalled nearly 1.1 billion euros (S$1.6 billion) in the six months to the end of September.

site_title: US aluminium and steel prices surge as Trump doubles tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump doubles tariffs on aluminium and steel, causing prices to surge. Aluminium futures jumped 54% on the Comex exchange, while steel futures rose over 8%. The increased levies aim to protect domestic mills and spur investment in new production capacity, but construction companies warn that levies will increase the cost of critical building materials. Analysts predict prices will rise, citing a lack of domestic capacity and a tax on consumers.

images.alt_text: Beijing accused the US of unilaterally introducing new discriminatory restrictions.
Since returning to the presidency in January, US President Donald Trump has moved to reconfigure US trade ties with the world while using levies to force foreign governments to the negotiating table.

site_title: Haidilao founder Sean Shi, Ray Dalio, Forrest Li’s wife among ultra-rich splurging on 8-figure Singapore properties
summary: Ultra-rich individuals, including tech billionaires and family office heads, are splurging on 8-figure properties in Singapore amid a tanking US dollar and global market uncertainty. Notable buyers include Ray Dalio, Jack Ma's wife, and Sean Shi, co-founder of Haidilao International. The Good Class Bungalow (GCB) market, a rarefied segment of Singapore's real estate, is particularly coveted, with prices reaching up to S$2,740 per square foot. The Republic's push to become a wealth hub is attracting more ultra-rich buyers, including those from the crypto sector.

images.alt_text: Residential skyscraper buildings in the Dubai Marina district of Dubai. Photographer: Natalie Naccache/Bloomberg
Singapore GCB market sees interest picking up amid global uncertainty

site_title: DBS mobile app customers face intermittent access on Monday; bank says issue resolved
summary: DBS mobile app customers experienced intermittent access issues on Monday, with over 1,000 reports made on outage tracking site Downdetector. The issues were mostly related to mobile login and mobile banking problems. However, the bank stated that the problem has been resolved, with access restored to normal at 4:08 pm.

DBS’ PayLah, internet banking, credit and debit card services may however still be used to make payment transactions.

site_title: UK economic team looks beyond Europe
summary: The UK is shifting its focus to non-EU nations for trade agreements, with a potential new deal with the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) being finalized. The GCC bloc has a total GDP of around $2 trillion and offers access to investment from Gulf sovereign wealth funds. A UK-GCC deal is forecast to add £1.6 billion to existing bilateral trade in the short term, with potential for £8.6 billion by 2035. This move underlines the UK's emphasis on consolidating ties with key non-European Union nations post-Brexit, as the country seeks to reinvent its world role in trade relations.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer says the new trade agreements with India, the US and the EU show that the UK  is back on the world stage.

site_title: Digital banking startup Chime targets US$11.2 billion valuation in US IPO
summary: Chime, a digital banking startup founded in 2012, is targeting a valuation of up to $11.2 billion in its US IPO. The company is offering 32 million shares at a price range of $24 to $26 each, with 25.9 million shares being sold by Chime and 6.1 million by existing shareholders. The IPO is seen as a positive sign for the US market, following recent successful listings, and could pave the way for other fintech companies to go public.

site_title: Trump ‘open’ to meeting leaders of Ukraine, Russia to push ceasefire
summary: US President Donald Trump is open to meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky in Turkey to push for a ceasefire in the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war. The proposal, made by Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, comes after failed talks in Istanbul, where Ukraine agreed to a prisoner exchange and Russia proposed a limited pause in fighting. Zelensky has urged Trump to take strong steps, including tougher sanctions on Russia, to push for a full ceasefire, while Putin has refused to attend a summit. A third round of talks is proposed for later this month.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian firefighters and rescuers work at the site of a damaged storage facility of a private factory following an overnight attack in Vasyshcheve, near Kharkiv, Ukraine, May 26, 2025.

site_title: Singapore PMI marks slower contraction in May as trade tensions thaw but uncertainty remains
summary: Singapore's overall factory activity remained in contraction in May, with the Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) posting a reading of 49.7, up 0.1 point from April. This marks the second successive month of contraction, after a 19-month expansion streak. While global trade tensions have eased, uncertainty remains, with the US and China's trade truce expected to be temporary. The electronics sector PMI also contracted, despite a slight uptick, due to lingering front-loading momentum.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
In Vietnam, companies say an improvement in production and a more optimistic outlook was aided by tariff stability.

site_title: Nio’s May deliveries up 13.1% as Firefly rolls out, but stock hovers near 52-week low
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker, delivered 23,231 vehicles in May, a 13.1% increase from the previous year, with cumulative deliveries reaching 760,789 vehicles as of end-May. The company launched its Firefly brand in April, which delivered 231 vehicles in the same month. Despite the growth, Nio's shares have fallen 31.6% over the past year, hovering near its 52-week low of $3.21.

images.alt_text: Low Youjin
In January, the company said it delivered a record 72,689 vehicles in Q4, with full-year delivery at 221,970.

site_title: Enhancing portfolios with private-market assets
summary: Yale University's chief investment officer, David Swensen, developed the "Yale model" or "endowment model" of asset allocation and investing, which emphasizes a heavy equity bias and investing in private markets, such as private equity and venture capital, to generate higher returns and lower volatility. This approach has been successful, with the Yale Endowment growing from $1 billion to over $40 billion in assets. Investing in private markets can provide diversification, lower volatility, and improved systemic returns, making it a valuable strategy for individual and institutional investors.

images.alt_text: Private market assets are not without risks. They are more complex, less transparent and more costly. Access to the best managers is also not assured.

site_title: Indonesia trade surplus shrinks as global tariff fears boost imports from China
summary: Indonesia posted its smallest trade surplus in over five years, narrowing to $159 million in April, as imports from China, Japan, and Singapore jumped 22% and 54% year-over-year, respectively, amid rising global tariff fears. Exports rose 5.8% to $20.76 billion, driven by higher shipments of coffee and basic metals, but mining exports dropped 21% due to weaker coal shipments. The smaller surplus may weigh on Indonesia's current account, but economists believe it will be manageable due to low oil prices and steady services.

site_title: Share buybacks on SGX surge 84% in first five months to 5-year high of S$930 million
summary: Singapore's primary-listed companies spent a record S$930 million on share buybacks in the first five months of 2025, an 84% jump from S$505 million in the same period last year. April saw the highest monthly buyback of S$425 million, driven by market volatility. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC led the charge, accounting for 77% of the total buybacks. The surge in buybacks is seen as a growth strategy to return surplus capital and boost return on equity.

images.alt_text: In the first week of November, seven companies listed on the Singapore Exchange conducted buybacks over five trading sessions.

site_title: Azeus Systems shares surge 16.6% as earnings, dividends double
summary: Azeus Systems shares surged 16.6% after the company reported a 91% increase in net profit to HK$118.1 million for the second half-year, driven by 56% revenue growth to HK$305.5 million. The company's full-year net profit rose 96% to HK$166.9 million, and revenue increased 44% to HK$474.8 million. A final dividend of HK$3.90 per share is proposed for the second half of the financial year, bringing the total dividend for FY2025 to HK$5.50 per share.

images.alt_text: Azeus executive chairman and director Lee Wan Lik said sales of its Azeus products segment has increased globally.

site_title: BT Club brews up a storm at coffee masterclass
summary: The Business Times hosted an exclusive pour-over coffee masterclass at the Cheerful Goat Cafe in Singapore, where 12 coffee lovers gathered to learn the art of the technique. Led by the cafe's expert baristas, attendees mastered the pour-over method, focusing on precision and patience, and discovered how subtle changes in water temperature and extraction time can dramatically alter the flavor profile. The event concluded with a Q&A session and takeaway goodie bags, and is part of BT Club's ongoing commitment to enriching the reader experience through curated lifestyle and networking events.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Embrace the ritualistic nature of pour-over brewing at BT Club's upcoming coffee masterclass.

site_title: Dutch high-tech equipment maker VDL ETG opens new facility in Singapore
summary: VDL ETG, a Dutch high-tech equipment manufacturer, has opened a new 20,000 square-metre facility in Singapore, expected to create over 400 jobs. The new facility, named SQ1, houses an office block, warehousing and logistics space, and cleanroom manufacturing space. The company plans to invest S$100 million over the next five years and aims to grow its revenue from S$400 million to S$1 billion. The facility's opening reflects the close relationship between Singapore and the Netherlands, with the country's Economic Development Board (EDB) and JTC Corporation (JTC) providing support.

images.alt_text: JTC will introduce a scheme to allow companies to extend their leases in shorter periods, for incremental business investments.

site_title: PwC troubles in China deepen with exit of Hong Kong partners
summary: PwC is facing further turmoil in Hong Kong as at least 10 partners are set to leave the city over the coming month, adding to the 20 that have already exited the firm. This comes as the firm grapples with the consequences of its audits of China Evergrande Group, including a 441 million yuan fine and suspension of its China arm. The exits underscore the firm's struggles in Hong Kong due to its China woes, with 77 partners leaving the Chinese mainland since December.

site_title: South Africa’s amapiano has the world dancing
summary: South Africa's amapiano music genre is gaining global popularity, with over 855 million streams recorded in 2024. Characterized by its unique blend of soulful jazz, deep house, and kwaito, amapiano has become a powerful tool for career dancers and a unifying force across cultures. The genre's energy and inclusiveness have taken social media by storm, with dance challenges and tutorials spreading across the globe. As a result, amapiano has become a global language, connecting people of all ages, backgrounds, and cultures through its infectious beat and authentic South African roots.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 2)
summary: Asia-Pacific will lead the world in aviation sector growth in 2025, with airline revenues projected to hit a near US$1 trillion record. In Singapore, share buybacks surged 84% to a 5-year high of S$930 million, while the Singapore stock market fell 0.1% after US President Trump vowed to double steel tariffs. Thailand is set to issue three virtual banking licenses, aiming to inject competition into the financial sector, and Singapore remains the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: From public to private - Reit delistings in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Reit sector is undergoing a transformation, with companies like Paragon Reit and Frasers Hospitality Trust announcing plans to delist. The decision is driven by macroeconomic trends, including higher interest rates, increased debt costs, and a strong Singapore dollar. Despite the sector's popularity for delivering consistent cash distributions, investors need to consider the need for significant property reinvestment and asset enhancement initiatives. The trend of delisting may continue, but a resurgence of new, more resilient Reits entering the market is also possible, according to host Ben Paul.

site_title: Meta aims to fully automate advertising with AI by 2026: WSJ
summary: Meta aims to fully automate advertising with AI by 2026, allowing brands to provide product images and budgets, and the platform will generate ads, including images, videos, and text, and target users based on geolocation. This move is part of the company's efforts to deliver "measurable results at scale" and build an AI one-stop shop for businesses. Meta's AI tools already help create personalized ad variations, image backgrounds, and automated adjustments to video ads, making it lucrative for advertisers.
