Meta engineers are struggling to significantly improve the capabilities of its Behemoth large-language model.
TikTok’s largest market by users is the US, but five of its 10 biggest globally are in South-east or South Asia, according to Kepios data.

Apple will try to mitigate tariffs by shifting production of US-bound iPhones to India, but it is likely to keep price increases to a minimum to avoid losing market share and would have to stomach any elevated costs.
While Meta’s stock has performed strongly, the company faces both regulatory challenges and emerging competition.
Meta executives see their chatbot as providing a different experience with its voice and personalisation capabilities, and because Meta AI draws data from the company’s social media platforms.

site_title: HSBC to inject US$4 billion into its private credit funds
summary: HSBC is investing US$4 billion into its private credit funds, aiming to build a US$50 billion credit fund within five years. The move is part of CEO Georges Elhedery's strategy to drive up revenue in higher-returning areas such as private credit, following declining profits from traditional lending. This investment is part of a broader trend by banks, including Citi and UBS, to enter the booming US$2 trillion global private credit market, dominated by private equity giants.

images.alt_text: The latest revamp comes as chief executive officer Georges Elhedery continues to streamline the lender to increase efficiency.
HSBC is among lenders seeking to step up offerings in private credit, a US$1.6 trillion global asset class that is luring more and more players.
FILE PHOTO: A view of the logo of HSBC bank on a wall outside a branch in Mexico City, Mexico June 14, 2024. REUTERS/Henry Romero/File Photo

site_title: Federal Reserve still open to cutting interest rates later this year, says governor
summary: US Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller expressed openness to cutting interest rates later this year if economic conditions allow it, despite the Trump administration's tariffs potentially pushing up price pressures. Waller noted that the economy has seen little impact from tariffs so far, and that a rise in inflation pressures tied to the tariffs is unlikely to be persistent. He also emphasized the importance of watching market views and professional forecasts, which expect price pressures to remain contained.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump said “he believes the Fed chair is making a mistake by not lowering interest rates, which is putting us at an economic disadvantage to China and other countries,” White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt told reporters in Washington.
The Fed‘s meeting on May 6 and 7 took place after US President Donald Trump had announced a 90-day pause on the most severe levies he had threatened against dozens of trading partners.

Given high uncertainty around the economic impact of US tariffs and trade policy, central banks should focus on avoiding taking steps where the “cost of getting it wrong far outweighs the benefits,” rather than aiming for the perfect solution to the problem, New York Federal Reserve President John Williams said.

site_title: Gold prices climb on softer US dollar, Trump’s fresh tariff threat
summary: Gold prices rose 0.6% to $3,309.89 an ounce amid US President Donald Trump's threat to double tariffs on steel and aluminum, while a weaker US dollar also supported the asset. Investors now expect a 50-basis-point rate cut by the US Federal Reserve in October, citing economic uncertainty. Spot silver rose 0.2% to $33.04 an ounce, while platinum fell 0.2% to $1,054.28.

images.alt_text: Gold’s strong performance this year is the result of a confluence of factors, including global uncertainty from trade wars, the US dollar weakness and concerns over the US fiscal outlook.

site_title: Eurozone factory downturn eases in May: survey
summary: The eurozone manufacturing sector showed signs of stabilization in May, with output increasing for the third consecutive month and supported by a near-stabilization in demand. The HCOB Eurozone Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 49.4, a 33-month high and just below the 50 threshold separating growth from contraction. New orders approached stabilization, while export orders reached a 38-month high, with Germany's manufacturing sector recording one of the softest deteriorations in three years. The European Central Bank is expected to cut its deposit rate again on Thursday, with a majority of economists predicting at least one more cut after June.

images.alt_text: A giant Euro sculpture is pictured at the headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) prior to a press conference on the Eurozone's monetary policy in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on January 30, 2025. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)
Manufacturers managed to increase their profit margins as input costs declined for the first time since November while output prices rose at their fastest rate in two years.

A giant Euro sculpture is pictured at the headquarters of the European Central Bank (ECB) prior to a press conference on the Eurozone's monetary policy in Frankfurt am Main, western Germany, on January 30, 2025. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)
Customers shop at a supermarket in Budapest, Hungary, March 17, 2025. REUTERS/Bernadett Szabo

European Central Bank board member Isabel Schnabel said that real income grew in over half of all households in the euro area last year but that an ECB survey of consumers showed that only 11 per cent perceived that increase.
Compared with a year earlier, Eurozone economy expanded by 0.9 per cent, the same as in the previous quarter but a modest expansion from earlier quarters.

site_title: China accuses US of violating trade deal, vows firm response
summary: China has accused the US of violating their trade deal, with the Chinese Ministry of Commerce stating that the US has unilaterally introduced new discriminatory restrictions, including export controls and curbs on chip design software sales. China vows to take measures to defend its interests, amid growing tensions between the two nations. The US has planned to revoke visas for Chinese students and restrict chip design software sales, further straining economic ties.

images.alt_text: Electronic design automation software makers, which include Cadence, Synopsys and Siemens EDA, were told via letters from the Commerce Department to stop supplying their tech to Chinese groups, FT said.
Upcoming sectoral tariffs are unlikely to be as low as 10%, and for pharmaceuticals, the rate will likely be 25%, says Citigroup global chief economist Nathan Sheets.
Given current trade dynamics, one in two Singapore-based firms plan to increase trade with South Asia, including Asean and India, as well as mainland China, according to HSBC's survey.

site_title: Bank of Japan sets aside maximum provision of losses for bond transactions
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) has set aside the maximum provision for losses on bond transactions, a 100% provision for fiscal 2024, amid mounting pressure to keep hiking borrowing costs. This move follows the central bank's steady short-term interest rates in its May meeting. The decision comes as the BOJ faces requests from financial institutions to maintain or slow the pace of tapering its bond purchases from fiscal year 2026 onwards.

images.alt_text: Renewed rise in food prices, particularly a 90 per cent spike in the price of rice, is pushing up not just headline but underlying inflation, which is typically influenced mostly by improvements in the economy and a tight job market, Kazuo Ueda said.
Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda declined to comment on short-term developments but said the central bank would closely monitor the bond market.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall as Trump fires fresh volley in trade war
summary: Asian stocks fell on Monday as investors dismissed data showing the Federal Reserve's inflation gauge cooled more than expected, while US President Donald Trump's fresh trade threats against China, including doubling tariffs on steel and aluminum, sparked market concerns. The US president's comments and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick's claim that China was "slow-rolling" the deal reignited worries about the trade war, leading to a decline in markets across the region, including Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Shanghai.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Tokyo stocks were off more than one per cent each, while Shanghai, Sydney and Seoul also sank into the red on Friday.

site_title: S$50 million property buy, adult learning push among Teo Ser Luck’s final-year agenda at Isca
summary: Singapore's national accounting body, Isca, is in talks to acquire a property in the Central Business District (CBD) for about S$50 million as part of a long-term investment strategy. Isca president Teo Ser Luck says the acquisition will create a "more balanced portfolio" and is exploring its options to conclude a deal by the end of the year. This move is part of Isca's broader efforts to ensure long-term financial sustainability.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Boosting entry-level wages and creating more diverse qualification pathways are said to have helped reverse the talent decline in the Republic's accountancy industry.
Acra chief executive Chia-Tern Huey Min at the playbook's launch on Tuesday (May 27).
Preliminary results of the survey are expected in the second half of this year, says IFAC chief executive officer Lee White.
NP students Lim Hui Zhen (left) and Aaron Hemmings intend to tap the PPP after graduation.
The SCAQ is the only pathway to attaining the Chartered Accountant (Singapore) qualification.
Generic photos for stories related to manpower, the future of work after COVID-19 and the complex impact of COVID-19 on work-life balance.
The Accountancy Workforce Review Committee’s report lays out strategies to make the industry more appealing to graduates and mid-career professionals.
Annual new enrolments have exceeded 1,000 for the first time, says Isca president Teo Ser Luck.
The new task force will tackle industry concerns about whether enough young Singaporeans are joining architecture and engineering.
Minister in the Prime Minister’s Office Indranee Rajah said in her keynote address that as Singapore's accountancy sector develops, it has to look internationally in an interconnected global economy.

site_title: AI demand drives chip equipment sales forecast to new highs but tariff jitters cloud outlook
summary: Singapore-listed companies like Frencken and Grand Venture Technology are poised to benefit from the growing demand for artificial intelligence (AI) driven semiconductor growth. Global equipment sales are forecast to reach a record $121 billion in 2025, driven by AI-related technologies and investments in data centers, edge computing, and generative AI. However, smaller firms are vulnerable to supply chain shocks and policy shifts, such as US tariffs. Industry experts expect moderate growth in demand by mid-2025, but caution that market sentiments may slow down growth.

images.alt_text: Tom Hunsinger, MacDermid Alpha’s vice-president of semiconductor assembly (left) and Jack van Mook, vice-president of Asia commercial.

site_title: Samsung nears wide-ranging deal with Perplexity for AI features
summary: Samsung is nears a wide-ranging deal to invest in Perplexity AI, a US$500 million funding round at a US$14 billion valuation. The partnership could preload Perplexity's app and assistant on Samsung devices, integrate its search features into the Samsung web browser, and weave its technology into Samsung's Bixby virtual assistant. This deal may help Samsung reduce its reliance on Alphabet's Google and pave the way for a mix of AI developers, similar to Apple's strategy.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics' acquisition of FlaktGroup is its biggest since 2016 when it announced an US$8 billion deal to buy car electronics maker Harman International Industries.

Samsung Electronics reported 6.7 trillion won (S$6.1 billion) in operating profit for the quarter ended in March, up 1.2 per cent from a year earlier and in line with its earlier estimate of 6.6 trillion won.
A Samsung logo is displayed in a supermarket in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, October 29, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic

site_title: Musk bids farewell to Washington – or has he?
summary: Elon Musk is exiting his role as a special government employee, having spent 130 days working with the Department of Government Efficiency (Doge) to reduce wasteful spending in the federal government. Despite saving an estimated $175 billion, Musk's efforts were hindered by non-discretionary spending programs and his attacks on government personnel. Musk has returned to his private companies, citing that he "probably spent a bit too much time on politics" and has reduced his government involvement. His companies, including Tesla, have suffered as a result of his controversial role in the Trump administration, and Musk has expressed criticism of the administration's plans to cancel clean energy tax credits.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, chief executive officer of Tesla Inc., during a news conference in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, May 30, 2025. The event gives an opportunity for the president and his largest campaign benefactor to dispel any notion of an acrimonious divorce. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippines eyes India, Thailand rice to cut Vietnam reliance
summary: The Philippines plans to diversify its rice imports from Vietnam, aiming to reduce reliance on the country due to potential supply shocks. Agriculture Secretary Francisco Tiu Laurel is in talks with private importers to purchase rice from India, Thailand, and other countries. The move is part of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.'s agenda to secure affordable prices for the staple grain. The Philippines' rice imports are expected to be lower than forecast this year, with the country on track to produce a record 20.46 million tonnes of rough rice.

images.alt_text: On a seasonally adjusted basis, Philippines' economy grew 1.2 per cent quarter-on-quarter, below the median forecast of 1.6 per cent in a Reuters poll of economists.
The latest number would help the central bank to continue cutting its key interest rate for the rest of the year.
Philippines' consumer price index rose 1.8 per cent in March, below the previous month’s 2.1 per cent rate and the 2.0 per cent median forecast in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Grab makes move to enter motor insurance market in Singapore
summary: Grab is set to enter Singapore's motor insurance market through its insurance arm, GrabInsure, which has begun hiring staff for a motor insurance team. The company has obtained a general insurance license from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and is seeking experienced professionals to develop its motor insurance products. Industry experts believe Grab's entry will give it a strategic advantage due to its data, cost advantages, and captive base of private-hire drivers. The move could potentially disrupt the dominance of existing players like Income Insurance.

images.alt_text: Chief Technology Officer of Grab, Suthen Paradatheth; CEO of Grab, Anthony Tan; DPM Gan Kim Yong; Chief Operating Officer of Grab, Alex Hungate, at Grab Headquarters  during the launch of Grab's AI COE.
GoTo will be selling off its international unit in Singapore to Grab.

Osorio is set to be involved the company’s “next phase of growth in Singapore”, by scaling the new GrabCab taxi business to improve transport accessibility and convenience, integrating dining platform Chope’s capabilities for a unified food experience, and leveraging GrabFin and GXS Bank to develop innovative financial products for Grab’s users and partners.

site_title: Hong Kong property firm New World’s securities tumble after coupon payments deferred
summary: Hong Kong property firm New World Development's securities plummeted after the company announced it would defer coupon payments worth US$77.2 million on four perpetual bonds scheduled for June, citing liquidity concerns. This move follows a similar decision by Road King Infrastructure, and raises concerns about the sector's financial woes. New World's shares slid 7.5% and its 4.8% perpetual bond was bid at 19.090 US cents on the dollar, down from 25.4 cents before the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the headquarters of New World Development at New World Tower, in Hong Kong, China September 27, 2024. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo
New World is controlled by the family of Henry Cheng, an avid player of a Chinese poker game called Big Two, whose fortune is estimated at US$22.9 billion.
New World is separately seeking to raise an additional loan of as much as HK$15.6 billion using Victoria Dockside as a first-ranking mortgage.
The developer has sweetened terms of two loans it is seeking, using one of its most valuable assets which it already pledged as collateral for another facility.

site_title: How the US market fell from 4th to 41st for returns – and what it means for stocks in 2025
summary: US stocks have fallen from 4th to 41st in terms of returns since 2020, with non-US stocks outperforming, gaining 8.8% by May 22. This is attributed to President Trump's trade policies, which have led to uncertainty and funds fleeing the US market. In contrast, European and Chinese stocks have risen 13.7% and 10% respectively, while Mexican stocks have seen a 20.7% gain. The article suggests that investors can profit from the current market trends, which are seeing through the "smoke and mirrors" of Trump's trade policies.

images.alt_text: Even in a Europe-led year, investors should diversify their portfolios with stocks from outside Europe, the writer says.
Virtually every global financial hub vies to be crypto’s capital. But the writer asks: can you stomach the volatility?
What might US President Donald Trump do next? No one knows – maybe not even Trump himself, the writer says.

site_title: Tesla not keen on local production in India, minister says
summary: India has finalized its electric vehicle policy, offering significant cuts in import taxes for foreign automakers that invest in domestic EV production lines. The country aims to increase EV sales to 30% of total car sales by 2030. Despite this, Tesla, which has long wanted to sell in India, does not plan to produce cars locally due to high tariffs. Instead, the company will import cars into the country. Other foreign automakers like Mercedes-Benz, Volkswagen, Hyundai, and Kia have shown interest in India's EV manufacturing policy.

images.alt_text: The city of Austin does not regulate self-driving vehicles, but has set up a task force that coordinates with Tesla and other autonomy companies.
Tesla’s sales fell for a fourth month in a row, down 49 per cent year-on-year, and its share of the total market nearly halved to 0.7 per cent from 1.3 per cent a year ago.
BYD outsold Tesla by an even wider margin when including the carmaker’s plug-in hybrid electric vehicles.
BYD saw a surge in revenue last year,  surpassing the $100 billion mark and beating rival Tesla.
Tesla sales have fallen worldwide with rising competition and as Musk faces a backlash for his right-wing political views and his work for US President Donald Trump.
“In terms of political spending, I’m gonna do a lot less in the future. I think I’ve done enough,” Musk said.
The compensation agreement, approved by shareholders in 2018, was initially worth US$2.6 billion.
Tesla has been seeking approvals from state governments for a robotaxi service using a fleet of Cybercabs with no steering wheel or control pedals

site_title: Don’t blame high rents for F&B business closures
summary: Singapore's food and beverage scene is experiencing a high failure rate, with 3,047 closures last year, a 20-year high. The number of monthly closures in the first quarter of this year is above 300. High rents, not high rents, are the main cause of F&B business closures, according to the article. Greedy mall owners prioritize high occupancy rates and successful tenants, leaving little room for struggling businesses to survive.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
The Cat Cafe at The Rail Mall is bowing out after facing a 50 per cent rental increase
Popular Chinese hotpot chain Haidilao shuttered three restaurants earlier this year in Bedok (above), Pasir Ris and Punggol, after a period of rapid expansion.
Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.

site_title: China home sales slump drags on as deflation eats into incomes
summary: China's residential property sales declined 8.6% in May from a year earlier, with new-home sales from the 100 largest property companies reaching 294.6 billion yuan. The slump is attributed to deflation eroding corporate profits and employee incomes, leading to suppressed demand. Despite a truce on US tariffs, China's top officials acknowledge the sector hasn't yet reached a bottom, and a recovery will depend on a broad rise in income and wealth. Existing real estate programs remain in place, but authorities are taking a patient approach to issue more support.

site_title: Gold seen maintaining upward momentum
summary: Gold has seen a 26% year-to-date gain, driven by global uncertainty from trade wars, US dollar weakness, and concerns over the US fiscal outlook. US President Donald Trump's unpredictable strategy has contributed to escalating trade disputes, while the US dollar's 9% decline has made gold more attractive to international investors. Moody's downgrade of the US sovereign credit rating has also fueled gold's appeal as a safe-haven asset, with the metal expected to maintain its upward momentum if it breaks above the US$3,365 level.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index fell 0.1 per cent after a sharp rise in the previous session, making greenback-priced gold more attractive for other currency holders.

site_title: Amro cuts Hong Kong’s 2025 growth outlook on trade uncertainty
summary: Hong Kong's growth outlook for 2025 has been cut to 1.9% by the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (Amro) due to growing trade uncertainty. The forecast is a step down from 2.4% last month, with the city's expansion driven by a front-loading of exports and tourism, but facing uncertain trade conditions for the rest of the year. Amro analysts urged the city to diversify its economy and trading partners to counter protectionism, and to deepen partnerships with other nations, including China.

site_title: ECB expected to cut rates again as Trump trade war rumbles on
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to deliver its seventh-straight interest rate cut, likely a quarter-point reduction, as US President Donald Trump's trade policies continue to impact the eurozone. The cuts aim to protect the eurozone from the trade war while keeping inflation stable. The ECB faces a challenging task, as Trump's tariffs have added to downward pressure on eurozone inflation, with analysts predicting a further reduction in growth estimates. The June cut may be the final one in the current streak, with the ECB likely to pause at its next meeting in July.

images.alt_text: The ECB is widely expected to lower borrowing costs on Jun 5 as inflation retreats and the economy faces headwinds from US tariffs.

The euro’s appreciation, tighter financing conditions due to increased fiscal expenditures and a drop in energy prices are also set to weigh on prices, strengthening the case for an eighth quarter-point rate cut in June.
The ECB has been easing borrowing costs rapidly as undue price pressures are disappearing, and recent turmoil on global markets is likely to bolster the bank’s conviction.

site_title: Thailand’s virtual bank race heats up – but real disruption may take time
summary: Thailand's central bank is set to issue three virtual banking licenses by mid-June, injecting competition into the country's lucrative but tightly held financial sector. Five consortiums have submitted bids, including Thai corporate heavyweights and foreign partners such as South Korea's Kakao and China's WeBank. The new virtual banks will aim to serve underserved segments, including personal loans and SME loans, and will operate with up to 60% lower costs than traditional banks. Meanwhile, the Bank of Thailand is working on legislation to introduce "open data" to the financial system, expected to expand credit access and benefit fintechs and startups.

images.alt_text: Chin Sophonpanich founded Bangkok Bank in 1944, when he branched out from selling construction materials and canned goods.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Grand Venture, Tung Lok, DFI, Olam, Stamford Land, Boustead, Wee Hur, OKP
summary: Several companies announced significant developments on June 2, 2025. Agribusiness giant Olam secured a $1.85 billion loan for general corporate purposes. Semiconductor company Grand Venture Technology paused its proposed secondary listing due to confidential talks about a possible transaction. Tung Lok Restaurants reported a 52.1% decline in second-half net profit due to economic headwinds. DFI divested 22.2% of its stake in Robinsons Retail for an undisclosed sum. Meanwhile, Boustead Projects won a tender to develop an industrial facility, Wee Hur established a $500 million medium-term note programme, and OKP won a contract worth $258.3 million for cycling path construction.

images.alt_text: Scott Price, DFI Retail’s group chief executive, said the transaction representing a “significant step” in DFI’s evolution as an operating company.

Boustead Singapore’s office. A unit of the group's subsidiary Boustead Projects clinched the tender with its joint venture partner.

Wee Hur’s purpose-built student accommodation at 124 Waymouth Street in Adelaide. It said Wee Hur, which sold GIC a 49.9 per cent stake in 2022, is expected to retain a stake as GIC transfers ownership of its holding to Greystar.
The scope of the contract includes converting existing footpaths to cycling paths and creating new pedestrian footpaths through “careful space planning” with stakeholders and landowners, said OKP.

site_title: Airline revenues to hit near US$1 trillion record in 2025 even as trade tensions bite: Iata
summary: Airline revenues are expected to reach a record $1 trillion in 2025, with a stable net profit of $36 billion, according to the International Air Transport Association (Iata). Despite US tariffs and industry supply chain issues, Asia-Pacific is expected to lead the world in aviation sector growth at 9% year on year. North America will be the slowest-growing market, expanding just 0.4% due to uncertainty from tariffs and migration policies. The industry's net profit margins are expected to improve to 3.7% from 3.4% in 2024.

images.alt_text: Derryn Wong
An artist’s impression of Changi Airport Terminal 5.
Asia-Pacific is expected to lead the world in air travel growth at 5.1 per cent per year, with South-east Asia and India heading that expansion.
Passengers at the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 1
Generic photograph of Crowne Plaza Changi Airport hotel, Jewel Changi Airport, Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplanes, Changi Airport control tower on Nov 28 2024.
(From Left) Anand Stanley, president & head of region, Airbus Asia-Pacific and Minister for Transport Chee Hong Tat touring the Airbus Asia Training Centre on May 7, 2025.

The airline aims to maintain its strong performance in passenger numbers by expanding and optimising routes said its CEO, Leslie Thng.

site_title: South Korea to minimise impact of 50% tariff on steel products, ministry says
summary: South Korea's Industry Ministry plans to minimize the impact of a 50% US tariff on steel products by responding to trade discussions with Washington. The country, the fourth-largest steel exporter to the US, has called for exemptions on steel, autos, and other items. The ministry held an emergency meeting with major steelmakers, including Posco and Hyundai Steel, amid shares of the companies falling 3-6.3% on Monday. South Korea aims to craft a trade package by the end of the 90-day US tariff pause in July.

images.alt_text: Bank of Korea Governor Chang Yong-rhee says: “During the global financial crisis, the probability of negative growth was estimated at around 5 per cent. Now, that likelihood has risen to nearly 14 per cent on average.”
South Korea faces a Jul 8 deadline before the bulk of US tariffs are due to start after a 90-day pause.
The South Korean economy’s dependence on exports makes it especially vulnerable to Trump’s trade policies.

site_title: Singapore shares fall after Trump vows to double steel tariffs; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% on Monday, June 2, after US President Donald Trump vowed to double steel tariffs to 50% to "even further secure" the US steel industry. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 3,890.59 points. The top loser was Seatrium, while Hongkong Land was the top gainer. Regional bourses also declined, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index falling 1.3% and 0.6%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Navene Elangovan
Asian markets sank on Monday as investors brushed off data showing the Federal Reserve’s favoured inflation gauge cooled more than expected last month.
Beijing accused the US of unilaterally introducing new discriminatory restrictions.
Stocks are seeing through the smoke and mirrors, the writer argues.
Trump has repeatedly postponed or pulled back tariffs he has announced since his inauguration, causing the market to quickly rebound after big sell-offs.

site_title: BYD faces growing backlash over EV price war as May sales jump
summary: BYD's electric vehicle sales surged to 382,476 units in May, its highest on record, but shares plummeted 5% in Hong Kong amid criticism from the Chinese government over the industry's price war. The price cuts, which have reached as high as 34%, have raised concerns about supply-chain security and product quality, with the People's Daily warning that low-priced and low-quality products could damage China's international reputation. BYD's overseas sales also reached a record high, with over 89,000 units delivered in May.

images.alt_text: The steep price cuts have taken some of the gloss off what has so far been a stellar year for BYD.
BYD offered discounts on 22 of its electric and plug-in hybrid models that it sells in China until the end of June, fanning the flames of a renewed sector-wide price war.
BYD outsold Tesla by an even wider margin when including the carmaker’s plug-in hybrid electric vehicles.

site_title: Tung Lok Restaurants H2 profit falls 52.1% to S$853,000 amid F&B industry woes
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants reported a 52.1% decline in second-half net profit to S$853,000, driven by lower contributions from its catering business and existing outlets. The group's full-year net loss was S$1.8 million, with revenue dropping 8.7% to S$82.1 million. The company expects the F&B industry to remain challenging in the coming year, citing rising operating costs and consumer price sensitivity. Despite this, Tung Lok is confident in its ability to navigate obstacles and is streamlining operations to enhance efficiency.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
While Singaporeans love to dine out, wobbles in the F&B sector could spell trouble for suburban malls.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees dollar falling 9% on slowing US growth bets
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts the US dollar will fall 9% from current levels by mid-2026, driven by interest rate cuts and slowing US growth, exacerbating its recent decline. The report adds to bearish views on the US currency, with JPMorgan Chase also recommending bets on the euro and yen. The US dollar index has dropped nearly 10% from its February peak due to President Trump's trade policies. The euro, yen, and Swiss franc are expected to rise as the US dollar weakens, with the euro potentially reaching 1.25 and the yen strengthening to 130.

images.alt_text: The greenback still accounts for around 60% of global foreign exchange reserves and is involved in nearly 90% of forex trading.

site_title: Bank of Korea’s Rhee says US-China trade talks important for Asia
summary: Bank of Korea Governor Rhee Chang-yong emphasized the importance of US-China trade talks for Asia's economies, citing the interconnectedness of supply chains and the significant impact of US tariffs on South Korea through China. Rhee highlighted the need for Asian economies to factor in the US-China element when assessing the hit from US levies. He also noted that sectoral tariffs and post-July 9 developments are key issues for South Korea, which relies heavily on exports of semiconductors, steel, aluminum, and cars.

images.alt_text: In Vietnam, companies say an improvement in production and a more optimistic outlook was aided by tariff stability.
Beijing accused the US of unilaterally introducing new discriminatory restrictions.

site_title: ‘Let’s bank’: How MariBank plans to win over Singapore’s retail and SME segments
summary: MariBank, a digital bank backed by Sea, aims to expand its retail and SME segments with new products and services. Since its launch in 2023, the bank has seen steady growth in net interest income, with a 126% increase in FY2024. CEO Natalia Goh plans to keep the bank true to its mission of making banking accessible and simple, with a focus on underserved segments. In the next 12 months, MariBank plans to introduce more products, including a cross-border remittance service, and expand its operations in the SME space, with a growing share of customers coming from outside the Shopee ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
MariBank in Singapore and SeaBank in Indonesia and the Philippines will also be part of the Monee segment of Sea.
BT

site_title: Grand Venture Tech shares up 11.9% on paused Malaysian listing amid potential share offer
summary: Grand Venture Technology (GVT) shares rose 11.9% on Monday after the company paused its proposed secondary listing in Malaysia amid potential discussions of a transaction that could lead to an offer for its shares. The pause was announced on Sunday, with no certainty of a transaction or progress in the discussions. GVT shares were trading at S$0.94 at 9 am, up from S$0.84 on Friday, with 550,300 shares changing hands.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Smaller companies like Grand Venture Technology (GVT) and Frencken Group are well-positioned to benefit from this wave, said Ang Wee Seng, executive director of SSIA.

site_title: Thailand’s stalled cash handout scheme sours voters on ruling party
summary: Thailand's ruling Pheu Thai Party faces a major political risk due to the delayed implementation of its flagship cash handout scheme, which was meant to stimulate the economy. The scheme, intended to provide 10,000 baht to 16 million registered households, has been put on ice due to US tariffs and budget issues. The delay has damaged the party's credibility, with many voters expressing disappointment and anger. Analysts warn that the delay could lead to a loss of trust in the government, potentially affecting the party's chances in the next elections.

images.alt_text: The Thai economy will probably post growth of 2.4 per cent in the second quarter from a year earlier, down from the previous forecast of a 2.8 per cent expansion.
Thailand Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks during a parliament session on the budget for 2026 fiscal year in Bangkok on 28 May.
Thai corporations experienced a 40 per cent increase in aggregate net profit from the year before corresponding period

site_title: More seeking accountancy qualification in Singapore, even as global talent shortage continues
summary: Singapore's accountancy industry is experiencing a talent boom, reversing a years-long decline. Higher entry-level wages and diverse qualification pathways have attracted more students to the field. According to the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants, the number of candidates entering the training pipeline has increased, providing relief from manpower shortages. This growth is a positive trend for the industry, which had struggled to attract fresh talent globally.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
A real estate asset would create a “more balanced portfolio”, says Isca president Teo Ser Luck.

site_title: Trade war hits Asia factories as exports, production slide
summary: Manufacturing activity in several Asian nations weakened in May due to US tariffs and trade uncertainty, with new export orders contracting for a seventh straight month in Vietnam. Taiwan, Indonesia, South Korea, Vietnam, Japan, and the Philippines all recorded contractions in overall activity, with the Purchasing Managers Index remaining below the 50-no change mark. The ongoing uncertainty amid US President Trump's tariff campaign and the start-stop nature of US trade policies are expected to dampen demand in the region, with manufacturers citing lower demand and increased client hesitancy to commit to new work amid US tariffs.

images.alt_text: DPM Gan was speaking at the two-day 30th Nikkei International Forum on the Future of Asia, themed “Asia’s Challenge in a Turbulent World”.
Asian nations would be among the hardest hit in the trade war, as many economies, such as Vietnam, rely heavily on exports to the US.
“This is a time for Asia to boost domestic demand, pursue sound economic policies and diversify industries and trade partners,” Masato Kanda says.

site_title: Record labels in talks to license music to AI firms Udio, Suno
summary: Major record labels Universal Music Group, Warner Music Group, and Sony Music Entertainment are in talks to license their music to AI startups Udio and Suno, potentially establishing a framework for compensating recording artists for AI-generated music. The negotiations follow lawsuits over copyright infringement, with the labels seeking up to $150,000 per work infringed. The talks aim to settle the dispute and pave the way for a deal, with the labels seeking greater control over the use of their work and Udio and Suno seeking flexibility and reasonable pricing.

images.alt_text: Paid subscription services accounted for 79 per cent of streaming revenues, and almost two-thirds of total revenues.
The self-titled, 26-minute film was shot this past September and will be available as a demo in Apple Store locations worldwide on Mar 14.
Major music companies are pushing streaming services to charge more for different features as growth in major markets such as the US slows.

site_title: Big Tech is back in S&P 500 driver’s seat as profit engines hum
summary: The S&P 500 is trading at 21 times earnings projected over the next 12 months, driven by strong performances from technology giants like Nvidia, Microsoft, and Tesla. Despite tariffs and other Trump policies remaining a market overhang, investors are optimistic about the sector's potential to lift the broader market. The Magnificent Seven stocks, which account for a third of the S&P 500, have outperformed the index over the past eight weeks, but shares of Apple and Amazon, which face greater risks from tariffs, are weighing down the cohort.

images.alt_text: Trump has repeatedly postponed or pulled back tariffs he has announced since his inauguration, causing the market to quickly rebound after big sell-offs.

site_title: Disney’s ‘Lilo & Stitch’ wins North America box office for second week
summary: Disney's live-action remake "Lilo & Stitch" wins the North American box office for a second week, earning US$63 million and bringing its worldwide total to US$610 million. It takes second place with "Mission: Impossible - The Final Reckoning", which made US$27.3 million in the US and Canada. The top 10 films include "Karate Kid: Legends", "Final Destination: Bloodlines", and "Bring Her Back".

images.alt_text: The film, starring Florence Pugh, Sebastian Stan and Julia Louis-Dreyfus, raked in an additional US$33 million for the three-day period.
The first original film from Ryan Coogler has Michael B Jordan playing twins who encounter a sinister force as they return home to Jim Crow-era Mississippi.

site_title: Chinese economy stays challenged but some consumer stocks offer potential: BOA
summary: The Chinese economy remains challenged, with low consumer confidence and deflationary pressures, but some consumer stocks offer potential for growth. Bank of America analysts identified five themes that could benefit from Chinese consumer spending: health and wellness, affordable luxury, pragmatic goods and services, personal experiences, and intellectual property. These "new consumption" stocks outperformed peers in earnings growth and share prices, driven by factors such as post-pandemic health and wellness focus, affordable luxury, and increasing demand for pragmatic items.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Deflation is eating into corporate profits and worker incomes, which can lead to a negative loop and result in even lower prices.

site_title: Obscure tax item in Trump’s Bill alarms Wall Street
summary: A tax provision in President Donald Trump's bill, Section 899, is raising concerns among Wall Street analysts, who fear it could further deter foreign investors at a time when their confidence in US assets is already shaken. The measure would increase tax rates on passive income earned by investors from countries deemed "discriminatory," potentially boosting the federal income tax rate on US assets held by foreign investors. This could weaken the dollar and European stocks with US exposure, according to analysts, and create a "capital war" between the US and other countries.

images.alt_text: Feedback on Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS)' proposed framework for retail private market investment funds was due on May 26.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Is now the time for ETFs?
summary: ETFs have gained popularity due to market volatility, offering precise exposure and various strategies to balance income and performance. Senior vice president of Franklin Templeton, Dina Ting, suggests ETFs could provide easier liquidity, especially in fixed income investments, during stressed markets. Despite risks, ETFs have shown reliable performance and are competitively priced, making them an attractive option for investors seeking diversification, particularly with tariff uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
Are Reits a better bet than bank stocks now?
Defensive sectors such as consumer staples, healthcare, and utilities tend to perform well during volatile times.
What are the things to consider when planning a home renovation?

site_title: Japan’s firms raised capital spending ahead of US tariffs
summary: Japanese businesses increased capital investment by 1.8% in the first quarter, beating expectations, ahead of US tariffs that are expected to dent exporters' competitiveness and reduce their willingness to invest in facilities and raise wages. The tariffs, which kicked off in March, are expected to hit Japan's biggest carmakers, including Toyota, with a potential loss of over $19 billion. Despite the tariffs, the value of sales and capital investment reached record levels, with food and steel companies increasing outlays to boost production capacity.

images.alt_text: People shop in a supermarket in Tokyo, Japan, May 23, 2025. Japan's core inflation rate accelerated in April to 3.5 percent as rice prices almost doubled year-on-year, official data showed.

When combined with contributions such as enhanced access to loan programmes from the Japan Finance Corporation and insurance support, the overall scale of the programme is expected to reach around 2.2 trillion yen, according to Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshimasa Hayashi.

Renewed rise in food prices, particularly a 90 per cent spike in the price of rice, is pushing up not just headline but underlying inflation, which is typically influenced mostly by improvements in the economy and a tight job market, Kazuo Ueda said.
Looking ahead, the trajectory of outbound investment may hinge on whether Japanese firms continue to expand their overseas spending, especially in the US.

site_title: Oil advances as Opec+ supply boost vies with geopolitical risk
summary: Oil prices rose as Opec+ agreed to add 411,000 barrels a day of supply in July, defying reports of a potential larger increase. The decision, made by Saudi Arabia, aims to punish over-producing members such as Kazakhstan and Iraq. Meanwhile, geopolitical risks in Ukraine and Iran, including a record uranium enrichment by Iran, supported prices. Brent crude rose 2.1% to $64.09 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate was below $62. The Opec+ group will meet on July 6 to discuss output levels for August.

images.alt_text: It was the first time since September 2023 that the number of rigs declined for five straight weeks.

site_title: Emirates will keep A380 jumbo flying until end of next decade
summary: Emirates plans to keep its A380 fleet operational until the end of the next decade, with a planned upgrade to first-class cabins before retirement. The airline is investing billions in refreshing the aircraft to extend its lifespan, as it lacks an obvious replacement. The A380's high fuel costs and operational complexity have made it challenging for other airlines, but Emirates sees its size and luxurious layout as a selling point. The move is seen as a strategic decision to maintain its global dominance.

images.alt_text: Newark Liberty, one of the main airports serving New York City, is about 9 miles (14.5 km) from Manhattan.

site_title: China and US must keep talking to better understand each other: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Defence Minister Chan Chun Sing of Singapore emphasized the importance of direct dialogue between the US and China to better understand each other's perspectives, despite their differences. He noted that even if they don't agree, it's crucial for them to hear each other's views and understand why they hold certain positions. Chan highlighted the value of the Shangri-La Dialogue in facilitating small-group discussions and direct communication, which he believes is essential for achieving deeper understanding in defence diplomacy.

images.alt_text: Defence Minister Chan Chun Sing speaking at the sixth and final plenary session of the Shangri-La Dialogue on June 1.ST PHOTO: JASON QUAH

site_title: Citigroup names Bank of America veteran Zhang as new China country head
summary: Citigroup has appointed Zhang Wenjie, a veteran banker from Bank of America, as its new country officer and banking head for China, effective July. Zhang, with 30 years of experience, will lead the team and foster strong regulatory relationships and risk controls. The appointment is subject to regulatory approvals. Zhang will be based in Shanghai and report to Marc Luet, Citi's head of Japan, Asia North and Australia and Banking.

images.alt_text: The four traders have filed their lawsuit right before a statutory deadline that requires labour dispute claims to be lodged within six years of an event such as job termination.
FILE PHOTO: The Citigroup Inc (Citi) logo is seen at the SIBOS banking and financial conference in Toronto, Ontario, Canada October 19, 2017. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo
Citigroup will use a platform operated by SDX, a subsidiary of SIX, to offer shares in late-stage, pre-IPO companies to investors.

site_title: South-east Asia joins Europe’s calls to defend subsea cables
summary: Defence officials from Europe and South-east Asia called for stronger collaboration to protect the global network of subsea cables, which carry nearly all of the world's data. The issue was highlighted at the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue security forum in Singapore, where countries such as Singapore, Malaysia, and the Philippines expressed concerns over threats to the network. European officials shared lessons from recent cable damage in the Baltic Sea, while NATO countries have increased patrols in key areas to ensure the safety of undersea infrastructure.

images.alt_text: France's President Emmanuel Macron (left) and Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong shake hands after a press briefing in Singapore on May 30, 2025.

site_title: Newark airport runway to reopen Monday after construction
summary: US Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy announced that Newark Liberty Airport's runway will reopen ahead of schedule, nearly two weeks before the original June 15 target. The runway closure was due to equipment outages, construction, and air traffic control staffing shortages, causing flight cancellations and delays. Operations have improved significantly, and the FAA has ordered reduced flight rates until October 25. The airport's normal capacity of 77 total flights per hour will resume after the construction is completed.

images.alt_text: Air traffic at Newark International Airport has been hit by a series of outages including a serious incident on April 28 that led to dozens of flight diversions.

site_title: Dubai expects to shine in times of volatility due to stability, talent attraction
summary: Dubai's stability and ability to attract talent are expected to drive growth despite global uncertainty. In 2024, the Dubai International Financial Centre saw a 25% increase in active companies to 6,920, with a record 1,823 new firm registrations. Executives attribute this growth to Dubai's "safer platform" for businesses, making it an attractive alternative to other locations.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
A view of the Dubai skyline, on May 12, 2025. (Photo by FADEL SENNA / AFP)
Residential skyscraper buildings in the Dubai Marina district of Dubai. Photographer: Natalie Naccache/Bloomberg
UBS, which is known for its wealth management offerings globally, already operates offices elsewhere in the Gulf, including in Dubai, Riyadh, Qatar, and Bahrain.
The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.

site_title: Brunei ruler discharged from hospital, resting in Malaysia
summary: Brunei's 78-year-old Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah has been discharged from a Malaysian hospital and will rest at the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Malaysia before returning to Brunei. The sultan, who was admitted for fatigue, will not disclose the exact return date. He holds multiple roles in the small South-east Asian nation, including prime minister, armed forces commander, and finance minister. The queen and other members of the royal family were by his side during his hospital stay.

site_title: Thai household debt drops to five-year low as new loans shrink
summary: Thai household debt has dropped to a five-year low, reaching 87.4% of GDP in the first quarter, down from 88.4% at the end of last year. The decrease is attributed to lenders tightening new loan approvals and government measures providing relief to millions of borrowers. The economy expanded 3.1% in the January-March quarter, also contributing to the decline. This marks a significant step towards reducing Thailand's high household debt ratio, which is the highest in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: The Thai baht has surged about 5 per cent this year, prompting some ministers and business groups to call for the central bank to weaken the currency to boost exports and tourism – the nation’s biggest drivers of growth.
The Bank of Thailand logo is pictured in Bangkok, Thailand, January 30, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

site_title: Carbon tax-paying firms can carry over unused offsets to 2025 due to limited carbon credit supply
summary: Singapore's National Environment Agency has allowed carbon tax-liable companies to carry over unused carbon offset limits from 2024 to 2025 due to a limited supply of international carbon credits. The offset limit, previously capped at 5% of emissions, will be rolled over to 10% for companies that did not use any offsets in 2024. The move aims to incentivize companies to switch to cleaner energy and improve efficiency, while also addressing the constrained supply of international carbon credits.

site_title: Trump’s tariffs, ‘big beautiful Bill’ may do more for the Singapore market than the MAS review group
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs have sparked uncertainty in the global market, but Singapore may benefit more from the situation. A federal court struck down most of Trump's tariffs, but the US government plans to appeal the ruling. This uncertainty may lead to paralysing spending and investing decisions, potentially causing more harm to companies than the tariffs themselves. In contrast, Singapore's stock market has shown resilience, with the Straits Times Index up 2.8% this year, driven by solid financial numbers and efforts to deliver shareholder value.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

The US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on Thursday has granted a temporary stay “until further notice” while the Trump administration’s appeals process plays out. This means the tariffs can remain in effect for now, while a longer-term outcome is yet to be determined.

The implication of the “revenge” measure, as it’s quickly becoming known, is clear to analysts: If signed into law, it would further drive away foreign investors at a time when their once ironclad confidence in Treasury bonds and other US assets has already been shaken by Trump’s erratic trade policies and the nation’s deteriorating fiscal accounts.

site_title: Creative Technology CEO Freddy Sim to step down for health reasons; Tan Jok Tin will serve as interim CEO
summary: Creative Technology CEO Freddy Sim, 67, will step down on Jul 11 due to health reasons, with Tan Jok Tin serving as interim CEO during the transition. Sim, who took on the top job in May, will remain as a non-executive director. The board will search for a new CEO, following the company's announcement on Jun 30.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo

site_title: Stoneweg European Reit outperforms global peers in sustainability rankings: report
summary: Stoneweg European Reit has secured a four-star rating and an overall score 9% above the global average in the GRESB Real Estate Assessment, a widely recognized ESG benchmarking framework. The trust retained its rating despite scoring poorly in waste, water, and energy, with full marks in performance, data monitoring, and stakeholder engagement. Its manager aims to achieve net zero operational carbon emissions by 2040, and the trust has made progress in reducing waste, greenhouse gas emissions, and energy intensity.

images.alt_text: Goh Ruoxue
A 20-year lease renewal for Haagse Poort has been signed with tenant NN Group.
The Green Office in Krakow, which has housed Motorola since 2011, was acquired by Sert in July 2019.

site_title: S-Reits with Singapore office assets post resilient Q1 2025 amid positive rent reversions and high occupancy
summary: Six Singapore-listed office real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) reported positive rental reversions in the first quarter of 2025, with some achieving double-digit growth. Keppel Reit and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit posted the highest rental reversions of 10.6% and 13%, respectively. Occupancy rates remained healthy, with Suntec Reit's office portfolio maintaining a committed occupancy of 98.7%. Reit managers expect performance to remain stable, citing limited supply of new office space and a flight-to-quality trend in the sector.

images.alt_text: Sabana Industrial Reit’s manager says it remains focused on optimising portfolio occupancy.

site_title: Highways baking at 70 deg C signal a red-hot summer from China to the US
summary: Extreme heat is expected to hit North America, Europe, and Asia, with temperatures soaring to record highs and increasing energy demand. The scorching conditions threaten to wilt crops, send energy prices soaring, and elevate the risk of wildfires. According to climatologists, the heat is a symptom of climate change, with the Earth warming by more than 2°C since the 1950s. The extreme heat is expected to inflict about $200 billion in annual losses in the US alone by 2030, with the risk of derechos, intense thunderstorms, and hurricanes also on the rise.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians protect themselves from sunlight during a heatwave in Bangkok, Thailand, April 28, 2025.
Many Chinese consumers remain concerned about the safety of GM food crops.

site_title: Asia: Most stocks rise as investors eye US trade talks
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, following a record-breaking day on Wall Street, as investors await US trade talks with countries like Japan and India. The dollar weakened, and interest rate cut expectations grew, while US President Donald Trump's tax-cutting bill faces a Senate vote. Officials from Japan and India extended their US stays to continue talks, raising hopes for agreements with two of the world's biggest economies.

images.alt_text: Xie’s strategy lies firmly in targeting the Gen Z consumption trend, where purchase decisions are driven by emotional triggers and hobby interest.
Hong Kong Stock Exchange, under new CEO Bonnie Chan, aims to boost its global profile by attracting secondary listings from Southeast Asia.

Pedestrians walk past an electronic board showing the numbers of the Nikkei Stock Average on the Tokyo Stock Exchange along a street in Tokyo on April 8, 2025. Tokyo's Nikkei index jumped nearly six percent in early trade on April 8 after plunging an eye-watering 7.8 percent the previous day, as US tariffs fuel market volatility. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Air India in talks for major new narrow-body jet order
summary: Air India is in talks with Airbus and Boeing for a major new narrow-body jet order, potentially involving hundreds of planes across various sizes. The order comes as the airline pursues a multi-billion revamp to recapture market share lost to global rivals. This follows a record 2023 order for 470 planes and 100 Airbus jets last year. The new order is crucial for Air India, which has suffered from under-investment under government ownership and faces supply chain issues and a looming jet shortage. Details of the exact number of planes under the new order are not immediately clear.

images.alt_text: Air India’s growth is also set to slow because of a retrofit programme that will temporarily remove some jets from its fleet, and a plan to phase out some Airbus models.

site_title: Going alone is not the answer to security questions: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Defence Minister Chan Chun Sing emphasized that going alone in security matters can lead to greater insecurity and a vicious spiral. He cited the 1930s as an example of beggar-thy-neighbour policies contributing to World War II. Chan advocated for guardrails and communication channels to reduce the risk of miscalculation, highlighting Singapore and Malaysia's successful resolution of a reclamation works dispute through international tribunal. He also stressed the importance of international laws and norms, and encouraged small countries to take a principled approach, rather than taking sides, to promote a more integrated global economic and security order.

images.alt_text: “We need to work together to defend the entire network,” Singapore Defence Minister Chan Chun Sing said at the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue security forum on Sunday.

site_title: China blasts Hegseth as defence minister avoids Singapore forum
summary: China has blasted US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth after he warned of an imminent conflict over Taiwan, calling the US "the true hegemonic country in the world" and telling it "must never play with fire" regarding Taiwan. China's absence from the Shangri-La Dialogue, a major Asian security summit, has also sparked frustration, with Beijing choosing not to send its top military diplomat, Defense Minister Dong Jun. The move has been described as a missed opportunity for China to engage with other countries and showcase its vision for regional security.

images.alt_text: China’s defence minister Dong Jun will not attend the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore.

site_title: Asia’s coal-reliant steel giants stall green transition: panellists
summary: Asia's steel giants, particularly China and India, are slowing the global green transition due to high costs and weak market demand. China relies on coal-dependent blast furnaces and prefers low-grade iron ore, while India's steel producers are also delaying decarbonisation efforts due to cost-cutting. The industry's carbon-cutting efforts are being "significantly delayed" due to market preferences for cheap iron ore and high capital expenditure required to overhaul production methods. The lack of a carbon market in China and the reluctance of steelmakers to invest in cleaner production methods are also hindering progress.

images.alt_text: Mia Pei
Red-hot steel is seen at a steel factory in Yantai, in eastern China's Shandong province on April 24, 2025. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

Benchmark iron ore futures in China plunged more than 6 per cent on Wednesday (Feb 9), snapping a five-session rally, after authorities pledged to strengthen supervision of the market and crack down on any irregularities.

site_title: Canada rescinds tax hitting US tech firms: government
summary: Canada has rescinded its Digital Services Tax (DST) on US tech firms, which had prompted US President Donald Trump to call off trade talks. The tax was set to bring in C$5.9 billion over five years. Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney have agreed to resume negotiations by July 21, 2025. The move comes after Trump had imposed steep levies on imports of steel, aluminum, and autos, and Canada had been spared some of the sweeping duties.

images.alt_text: Nearly 140 countries struck a deal in 2021 to tax multinational companies, an agreement negotiated under the auspices of the OECD.
The S&P 500 surged 3.4 per cent this week and closed at a record high.

Canada is the largest supplier of foreign steel and aluminum to the United States, and PM Mark Carney (pictured) earlier this month had denounced the doubling of US tariffs on Canadian imports of steel and aluminum, calling them “unjustified” and “illegal.”

site_title: From palm oil to platforms and parcels, Malaysian tycoons chase Indonesia’s digital gold rush
summary: Malaysian tycoons are investing heavily in Indonesia's digital space, with nearly US$1 billion poured into the country so far, peaking at US$229 million in 2023. Prominent investors, including Wilmar's Robert Kuok and Genting Group's Lim Kok Thay, are backing digital ventures and logistics firms, driven by Indonesia's growing middle class, urbanization, and digital connectivity. The investments reflect a strategic move to tap into South-east Asia's largest economy, where clicks are increasingly important over commodities. Despite challenges, experts see long-term growth potential in Indonesia's digital storefront sector and logistics industry.
